title: Dearborn

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I first spied Ghassan Zeineddine’s debut collection of short stories when I read a great NPR  of them upon their release last fall.I’ll admit, II first spied Ghassan Zeineddine’s debut collection of short stories when I read a great NPR  of them upon their release last fall.I’ll admit, I was drawn in at first glance by the book’s cover (those colors! that eye-catching font!), and so I mentally filed away the title as one I wanted to pick up whenever I experienced my next itch for some short stories (something I’m more picky about than the novels I choose to read). Fast forward to February, and suddenly I’m suggesting the collection to my partner in crime (and by crime, I mean lover of books), Laura, as our next selection for the online book club we’ve created, Great Midwest Book Group.Laura and I are devoted to showcasing authors whose books celebrate the Midwest, and I loved the idea that, instead of the stereotypical corn-fed, white farmers and factory workers readers may think of when they think of that word, this author sought to educate readers about the rich diversity of Dearborn, Michigan, aka the Arab-American capital of the USA.After finishing the first story, I *knew* in my gut this was going to be our next pick (Ghassan’s writing is just that good!) and when Laura texted me to share her own enthusiastic endorsement of the selection, I might have done a little jig in my office chair.I did another one when Ghassan confirmed that he would be willing to join us for our Zoom discussion with him on Thursday, April 25, so I’ll inform anybody reading this  before that date that you are MORE than welcome to join us (message me if you’re interested in the details).Already I cannot wait to talk to Ghassan about his American experience (he grew up in Saudi Arabia); his role as a professor of creative writing at various Midwestern universities (U of M-Dearborn and Oberlin, among them); and his inspiration for the remarkable characters who populate this award-winning collection of short stories that, as I've taken to describing them, are filled with heart, humor, and history in equal measure. (Among my favorites: “Speedoman,” “Money Chickens,” “Marseille”, “I Have Reasons to Believe My Neighbor is a Terrorist” and “Yusra”.) After reading this debut, one thing's for certain: I will be pre-ordering whatever Ghassan Zeineddine writes next....more

title: Expiration Dates
author: Serle, Rebecca*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Expiration Dates is Rebecca Serle’s newest novel and, without question, my favorite title of hers to date. The focus of the story (or so you’re lead tExpiration Dates is Rebecca Serle’s newest novel and, without question, my favorite title of hers to date. The focus of the story (or so you’re lead to believe) is how, with each new love interest she meets, Daphne Bell receives a slip of paper informing her how much time they’re destined to spend together.It’s an interesting concept and one that made me want to read Serle’s work again (after some of her previous titles ended up only 3-star selections for me). In the end, it wasn’t the promise of romance that kept me turning the pages of this buzzy new release so much as the direction the story took in focusing on Daphne’s growth—a personal journey that played out in a contemplative way against the backdrop of her hometown of Los Angeles (a city I happen to love). A quarter of the way through this one, I thought I saw the ending coming (by that I mean, who Daphne ultimately ends up with), but the plot twists that followed proved to be the book’s real (and rather unexpected) reveals. Those twists are what made reading Expiration Dates an overall engrossing experience, and so I wholeheartedly recommend this title, especially for anyone seeking out stories about self-love and the importance of living in the moment. Excited now to hear the Bad on Paper gals discuss it for their upcoming April Book Club podcast episode! ...more

title: The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn
author: Twain, Mark
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ernest Hemingway once said, "All modern American literature comes from one book by Mark Twain called Huckleberry Finn. … It’s the best book we’ve had.Ernest Hemingway once said, "All modern American literature comes from one book by Mark Twain called Huckleberry Finn. … It’s the best book we’ve had. All American writing comes from that. There was nothing before. There has been nothing as good since.”Shame on me for having never read this classic before! I can't for the life of me understand why not, other than the fact it was probably caught up in one of its many book bannings while I was in high school and passed over by the conservative school system that chose which novels I read for the mandatory curriculum I studied as a teenager. Oh well, I suppose it's better to come to a classic late than never at all, and this one I was all too happy to read ahead of diving into Percival Everett's new release, James. So glad I did, too, as I now have a richer appreciation not just for Twain's take on his clever characters' many escapades, but for how catching a ride on a raft down the mighty Mississippi represented a pathway to freedom for both a young boy named Huck and a runaway slave named Jim. [On a related note, I had about a dozen different versions of this book to choose from when it came to checking out a copy from Libby. To save time, I chose to listen to an abridged one narrated by the late Jack Lemmon, and I gotta say, he did a pretty solid job with all the dialects in this book—the first to really introduce the concept of dialect to American readers.]...more

author: Park, Barbara
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It can feel like cheating to add children's books toward your GoodReads book count and yet, I *DID* read this book with my six-year-old daughter this It can feel like cheating to add children's books toward your GoodReads book count and yet, I *DID* read this book with my six-year-old daughter this past month and I *DO* want to remember that fact, especially since it's the first chapter book series she's sunk her teeth into and I LOVE THIS FOR HER.What to make of the pint-sized Ms. Jones? Well, I found her to be a bit of a brat, I'm not going to lie. But she's also very funny and the mistakes she makes (from mispronounced words to physical pratfalls) are very age appropriate. Sometimes I think writing a character like this is purposeful, as my daughter would occasionally love pointing out to me, "Hey, that wasn't very nice of Junie, was it?" (Love seeing her flex that emotional intelligence muscle as she listens to a story during bedtime.)I'll end this  by saying how much I absolutely adore reading books with my kids (and how fun it is to explore a popular series that my son didn't care to give the time of day when he was his sister's age). Audrey and I have now read about six or seven of the books in this series and I'll keep on reading them to her (there are so many!) for as long as she keeps on plucking them off the shelves of our local library!...more

author: Frankel, Laurie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I wanted to love the newest release from Frankel as much as I loved her This is How It Always Is, but there was too much that didn't grab me the same.I wanted to love the newest release from Frankel as much as I loved her This is How It Always Is, but there was too much that didn't grab me the same. Or just made me scratch my head instead? For starters, the dialogue was too clever too much of the time. (I kept thinking, especially with the kids, 'Who talks this way in real life?') Then there was my bone to pick with the fact that, in wanting to write a novel that examined adoption through a flattering lens, Frankel had this to say on the topic: “There’s no shortage of books, TV, and movies about adopted families and orphans, and they’re all couched in this ‘oh, poor you, this is a tragedy’ language. I hate it!”I absolutely support what Frankel says here—and her decision to write about it—but what I hate is there are also no shortage of books, TV, and movies that portray Christians as homophobic, intolerant, or hateful. So, I guess I was just disappointed that this was the same language Frankel adopted here (to be so on the nose) when it came to providing a backstory of one of the tertiary characters in this book. A small thing to get stuck in my craw, but for a book that asks readers to be more open minded and accepting of other people, it's a message I felt the author ended up being pretty selective about herself. ...more

title: No Crying in Baseball: The Inside Story of A League of Their Own: Big Stars, Dugout Drama, and a Home Run for Hollywood
author: Carlson, Erin
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A vivid memory from childhood is seeing "A League of Their Own" in the theater with classmates, all of us piling into the minivan driven by the motherA vivid memory from childhood is seeing "A League of Their Own" in the theater with classmates, all of us piling into the minivan driven by the mother of my best friend, Tracy, whose birthday that November afternoon*** we were celebrating. Before the credits rolled, I knew "League" had cemented itself onto my heart as one of my favorite films (the imprint of which remains to this day). I share this story to explain why my great love of "League"—the most record-breaking movie about baseball of all time—makes it impossible for me to give this book anything less than a five-star .But even for readers who aren't super stans, there's still plenty within its pages to enjoy. The chapters are chock full of tidbits about the shoot (more on that in a moment), sprinkled into a narrative that offers a fascinating deep dive both into the biography of its director, Penny Marshall, and a history of the All-American Girls Professional Baseball League.Here were a few anecdotes that, combined with all the on-set tea spilled by cast members, made this a home run read for me:• I had no idea until reading this that the beloved character of Betty Spaghetti was portrayed by Penny's daughter, Tracy Reiner (the story of how she gets involved in casting was delightful)! • A who's who list of actresses and actors were in the running for the major roles of this film before Penny finally settled on the familiar names who were cast. Can you imagine Debra Winger as Dottie Hinson? Jim Belushi as Jimmy Dugan? We came thisclose to their names being on the movie poster! • Much of the movie was filmed in Indiana, with locals around Evansville (where the majority was shot) cast for supporting roles. Among them was local softball player DeLisa Chinn-Tyler, who portrayed the Black bystander who threw the ball in the iconic scene where words were unnecessary to convey the injustice that was Black women being shut out of the league. The fact her story is included in this book (when her name was left out of the credits) was a small sliver of justice served. • Penny shot so much film for this movie—about TWO MILLION feet—that Kodak threw her and the cast a party, complete with plenty of bottles of champagne to go 'round.***Given when I saw this film as a kid, I always assumed it came out in the second half of 1992. I was SHOCKED to learn while reading this that it actually debuted on July 1, 1992....which means it was still playing on the big screen five months later, when I saw it. It was probably at the $1 movie theater by then (remember those?!) but still, how incredible that this film—a commercial success that ended up earning $130+ million against a budget of $40 million—spent roughly a half-year in theaters!...more

title: Hits, Flops, and Other Illusions: My Fortysomething Years in Hollywood
author: Zwick, Ed
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Until this year, I had no idea writer-producer-director Ed Zwick was responsible for some of the greatest TV series and films that have defined my entUntil this year, I had no idea writer-producer-director Ed Zwick was responsible for some of the greatest TV series and films that have defined my entire life, basically.Take, for example, his role as co-creator (with writing partner, Marshall Herskovitz**) of thirtysomething***, the poignant TV drama that captivated my mother (and thereby my)’s attention when it aired in the late ‘80s and early ‘90s. The influence of that one series cannot be overstated when you consider what Zwick has to say about the actors, writers, and producers he and Herskovitz hired to work on the series with them: “Their work has had an undeniable influence on the best television has had to offer,” he wrote in his new memoir. “Alias, My So-Called Life, Friday Night Lights, Brothers & Sisters, Grey’s Anatomy, Parenthood, New Amsterdam, Breaking Bad, Without a Trace, Nashville, Once and Again, Damages, Jane the Virgin, In Treatment, and This is Us, to name a few.”Ummmmmmm…. best television has had to offer INDEED!While it may have been my understanding of Zwick’s work on thirtysomething that initially drew me into this read, I was pulled along by discovering how many other projects he’s worked on that I love, most notably his role in producing and directing Legends of the Fall (aka, the film that took my teenage obsession of Brad Pitt to an 11).As Zwick says in his introduction, “I’ll be dropping a few names,” and indeed he does throughout his life story—from recounting his experience casting Matthew Broderick and Denzel Washington in Glory, to discovering Claire Danes during the casting process for My So Called Life to courting Julia Roberts for the lead in Shakespeare in Love (a project for which Harvey Weinstein swooped in and stole from him like the colossal bully he was). It truly is CRAZY how many legends this man has worked with over the years!I loved the unexpected discovery of this memoir landing onto my 2024 reading list as much as I loved all the behind-the-scenes anecdotes Zwick shared within its pages. This is a title that’ll stick with me for years to come and is a must-read for anyone who loves pop culture, the film industry, and/or creative professions as much as I do. **Multiple times while reading this book, I thought of Zwick and Herskvotiz as TV’s answer to the famed theater partnership of Rodgers and Hammerstein … I also LOVED learning Ed and Marshall’s production company is named Bedford Falls Productions after the fictional town in It’s a Wonderful Life, a film that resides on the “forever favorites” shelf in my heart. ***Since reading this book, I’ve started re-watching thirtysomething and it’s SUCH a nostalgic, Baby Boomer blast from the past—one that feels like the pop culture equivalent of being wrapped up in your grandma’s coziest afghan. I can’t get enough of the series and I’m already looking forward to rediscovering My So-Called Life next! ...more

review: What Sally Rooney is to Irish novels about sad Millennials, Madeline Gray is to Australian novels about sad Millennials.I know lots of folks will loveWhat Sally Rooney is to Irish novels about sad Millennials, Madeline Gray is to Australian novels about sad Millennials.I know lots of folks will love this one for all its self-aware snark, but this Elder Millennial had a hard time rooting for main character Hera, whose ambition to have an affair supersedes her ambition to do anything else, like, I don't know, be good at her job, for starters? (See also: be a good daughter or good friend.)Maybe my favorite thing about this buzzy new read is the fact its title comes from the eponymous green dot that's always popping up on the screen of Hera's phone or computer as she waits for her co-worker, Arthur, to message her back. (God, Arthur...WHAT A LYING, CHEATING ASSHOLE.) It's a tie-in as clever as much of Gray's writing, even if I should have known better than to think all the positive press about this one could make me overlook my misgivings about any book centering on adultery. ...more

review: This is a really sweet book about a flighty (aren’t 90 percent of them?) female protagonist, Eve, who finds herself unexpectedly pregnant with a guy, This is a really sweet book about a flighty (aren’t 90 percent of them?) female protagonist, Eve, who finds herself unexpectedly pregnant with a guy, Ethan, who owns a dog-friendly (say what?) bar in Brooklyn. Ethan is a good guy, so this story doesn’t set out to paint this baby’s daddy in a negative light. Matter of fact, the author chooses instead to double down with her good guys by introducing Shep (the brother of Eve’s best friend), who quickly becomes the third point of this book’s literary love triangle.Shep may be the most perfect man to exist on paper — like, in a world of romantic tropes, his Golden Retriever energy is less single dog and more litter of adorable puppies. He’s cute. Eve’s cute. Ethan’s cute. And together the story that plays out between these three makes for a funny, feel-good read where nothing nefarious happens and a scenario you *think* could never work out does, resulting in a HEA so sweet you’d find it unbelievable if you didn’t love it so much.  For another take on this read, I loved what Lauren had to say about it: “Cute, charming, bubbly, perfectly displays the difference between gender and sex, characters not bound by toxic masculinity, A+ pronoun inclusion, and a wonderful depiction of motherly love, slow-burning romance, and co-parenting. Please give this book the chance it deserves!” ...more

Specifically, the relationship the book’s main characters (a Black RA, Millie Cousins, central among them) have to it and all its trappings.While this title may have started slow for me, once I let myself get immersed in the story (much of which takes place inside a single residence hall on the campus of the University of Arkansas) I.was.sucked.in! Mostly because Reid writes female characters so well. She knows these women and, thanks to her own stint as an RA for a year, has been a version of these women. I loved the nuances of their voices on the page, how well Reid nailed their insecure stutters and upspeak. In that sense, this book felt as true as if I were the the one who was eavesdropping outside of Millie’s dorm room, not Agatha Paul....more

review: I don’t remember the Bookstagrammer who wrote the  of this book that caught my attention mid-scroll, causing me to put this one on hold on LibbyI don’t remember the Bookstagrammer who wrote the  of this book that caught my attention mid-scroll, causing me to put this one on hold on Libby immediately. I wish I did so I could thank her because this is SUCH A GOOD BOOK.It’s a slip of a novel really, a quiet story about forbidden love, set in a time and place—1950s Appalachia—that feels forgotten against the greater backdrop of American history. But it’s precisely because of its setting and the major events covered in its chapters—the Korean War and polio epidemic—that I felt so compelled to read it. The narrator of the audiobook, James Patrick Cronin, does a tremendous job with all the characters' accents. The entire time I listened, I felt like I was right there alongside them, whether it was with Jacob fighting off a North Korean soldier or with Naomi and Blackburn in North Carolina, awaiting his return. Rash takes this story places I didn’t expect it to go, and I found myself holding my breath until the final minutes, unsure how it would end. As a fellow er wrote of the book: “Here we have good, old fashioned storytelling with no flourishes, no tricks, no meta puzzles.” I couldn’t agree more, and it’s why I look forward to reading more of Rash’s work in the years to come. ...more

title: Sure, I'll Join Your Cult: A Memoir of Mental Illness and the Quest to Belong Anywhere
author: Bamford, Maria
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This new memoir from stand-up comedian Maria Bamford was my book club’s January pick and .... it received a mostly lukewarm reception when we met to tThis new memoir from stand-up comedian Maria Bamford was my book club’s January pick and .... it received a mostly lukewarm reception when we met to talk about it last week. Among our critiques? Maria never joins any actual cults (such faulty advertising!) She does, however, partake in a number of support groups (Debtors Anonymous, Sex Addicts Anonymous, Overeaters Anonymous … the list goes on). And in writing this book, she shares lessons learned from each of those experiences along with chronicling her rise in LA as she endured multiple mental health crises. (Crises that warranted time spent at inpatient psychiatric units, so we’re not talking about your garden-variety depression here). The publisher describes Maria’s memoir as “brutally honest” and “hilariously frenetic.” While I personally felt it (ahem) light on hilarity, I did think it offered an enlightening look into the brain of someone forced to battle significant demons while fighting for her definition of career success. And truly, my heart goes out to anyone and everyone battling mental illness—what a cruel motherfucker it can be. ...more

title: This Summer Will Be Different
author: Fortune, Carley*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: How absolutely fitting to be greeted by a Lucy Maude Montgomery quote the first time I pulled up Goodreads on my phone after finishing an ARC of CarleHow absolutely fitting to be greeted by a Lucy Maude Montgomery quote the first time I pulled up Goodreads on my phone after finishing an ARC of Carley Fortune’s newest book, This Summer Will Be Different. And this summertime read IS different …. from Carley’s 2023 title, Meet Me at the Lake, that is.It’s sexier, for starters (whew….Felix ‘Wolf’ Clark*** may just be my favorite male love interest to date—like, of any romance I’ve read). But also, this book is just more self-assured in its storytelling, with a plot that focuses on a forbidden love affair between Toronto florist Lucy Ashby and the brother (Felix) of her best friend, Bridget. Carley Fortune has been open about how the runaway success of her 2022 debut, Every Summer After, prompted crippling anxiety when it came time to write her second book, one that required a number of rewrites that made her doubt her abilities as an author. How wonderful, then, to realize within the opening chapter of This Summer that the sophomore slump is a fear of the past and that Carley is at the top of her game with this new title, which, IMO, is her best yet. Finally, talk about a love letter to a “happy place” (there’s a cute nod to Emily Henry’s books in this novel, just as there’s a cute nod to Carley’s books in Henry’s new Funny Story—these two share a literary agent and, clearly, a fair amount of appreciation for one another): After finishing This Summer, I’m now ready to read all the Anne of Green Gable novels and then book a flight for Prince Edward Island where I will happily consume my weight in Malpeque oysters. The tourism board of PEI seriously needs to send Carley a massive bouquet of flowers when this book hits shelves on May 7, because WOW is that place about to experience an uptick in visitors, mark my words! ***This is a very low stakes, spoiler-y mention about Felix I feel compelled to share that is my one gripe that isn't REALLY a gripe about this book: (view spoiler)[But I think Carley has crafted maybe TOO perfect of a man with this guy ...Like, can I believe this twenty-something guy shucks oysters with as much confidence and skill as he constructs cottages (and…ahem…performs cunnilingus)? Definitely. But do I think this same guy would actually have a fetish for classic novels published before the 20th century? [ Cue my favorite meme in response]. I guess that’s the beauty of fiction though, right? We get to fantasize about a sexy love interest who knows how to build a dock as well as he can quote Dickens.  (hide spoiler)]...more

title: Anita de Monte Laughs Last
author: Gonzalez, Xochitl*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Unpopular opinion time: I did not like this book! Primarily because it's an obvious (if you know the backstory) roman a clef about Cuban artist Ana MeUnpopular opinion time: I did not like this book! Primarily because it's an obvious (if you know the backstory) roman a clef about Cuban artist Ana Mendieta who, after a fight with her husband, famed sculptor Carl Andre, "went out the window" of their 34th floor NYC apartment in the 1980s—an incident that overshadowed Andre's career up to his own death in January 2024. Case in point, here's the headline and subhead from his recent obituary in the New York Times: Carl Andre, 88, Austerely Minimalist Sculptor, Is DeadHe worked with elemental metals, granite, wood and brick in sculpture “free of human association.” His career was marred by accusations that he had a role in his wife’s fatal plunge.I first learned of Mendieta's story last fall, while reading Claire Dederer's Monsters, which is why this novel's plot—about Cuban artist Anita De Monte winding up dead after a fall that followed a nasty fight with her husband, famed sculptor Jack Martin—was so familiar to me. González references Mendieta by first name only in her dedication of Anita: "In memory of Ana/And all the women who endured solitude/never knowing the rest of us were out there." I happened to overlook said mention when I started reading this book. So when I came to the Acknowledgments, I expected at least a few sentences about how González wrote this novel—one so heavily inspired she basically passed off exact artworks of Mendieta's as ones created by Anita—to shine light on the life and artistry of Mendieta, much in the way González's other main character, Raquel Toro, writes a thesis that brings renewed attention to the late Anita de Monte.Instead, I was BEYOND disappointed to find no such mention of Mendieta by her full name. This failure to give her proper credit as source material? To explain more about who she was and to point readers to other resources about her (like this podcast, for example)? It felt like one more way Ana Mendieta continues to hide in plain sight from those who don't know her story. Talk about a missed opportunity! Finally, in relation to what happens to Anita's ghost, I agree with what author Jean Hanff Korelitz had to say about the strange metaphysical transformations that happen late in this book: "It asks a good deal of a reader to shape-shift with Anita, and while many will gladly make that jump with the author, I found I wasn’t among them. In the end, it was simply a leap (or, more likely, a push) too far."...more

title: Birdie & Harlow: Life, Loss, and Loving My Dog So Much I Didn't Want Kids
author: Wolfe, Taylor
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I can still remember the moment in Summer 2023 when Taylor Wolfe (@thedailytay) first popped up in my Instagram feed with her hilarious "55 Ways to GiI can still remember the moment in Summer 2023 when Taylor Wolfe (@thedailytay) first popped up in my Instagram feed with her hilarious "55 Ways to Give Your Child an Old Fashioned Summer!" post. Oh man, did I laugh SO hard watching it— then immediately sent it to six fellow Elder Millennial girlfriends after hitting the "Follow" button to keep more of Taylor's content coming.When I learned she was releasing her debut memoir a few months later, I put myself on the list to check it out from the library. Then, over the past weekend, I finished listening to it as tears rolled down my cheeks while wrapping Xmas gifts for my kids' teachers. Taylor's comedic chops are on full display with this book (which she does a bang up job reading on audio, I might add). Her humorous takes on growing up in the Midwest, flailing in jobs in her 20s, and becoming a mother made me LOL multiple times. But what surprised me most was how, depending on the context of the chapter, her writing could be as tender** as it was tongue in cheek.My favorite dynamic of the book was her great love for her dog, Harlow—the Vizsla she adopted with her husband that is definitely the star of this story. Her conversations with Har (or Carl, the nickname she gave him when he was being an asshole - ha!) were so touching I was won over ten-fold by their buddy comedy routine. I honestly can't remember the last time I cried over a dog's story—I think it was Where the Red Fern Grows? But Taylor's writing—specifically the last few chapters—really got to me. To say more would ruin the journey she takes you on with Har, and what a sweet, affirming journey it is. Now, because of the feelings stirred up by this book, I feel like it may finally be time for my own family to welcome a dog into our house again. Let's see if that happens in 2024! **TW // pregnancy, miscarriage, pregnancy loss ...more

title: One in a Millennial: On Friendship, Feelings, Fangirls, and Fitting In
author: Kennedy, Kate
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Millennials are defined as people born between 1981 to 1996 — so here I am, a 1982 baby, just squeaking past that Gen X generational divide.Given I haMillennials are defined as people born between 1981 to 1996 — so here I am, a 1982 baby, just squeaking past that Gen X generational divide.Given I have three (much) older siblings, I’ve always felt, in many ways, that I’m more Gen X than a product of my true generation. (I’ve also felt, even more so, that I belong to that distinct micro generation that refers to itself as Xennials/the Oregon Trail Generation/Elder Millennials … take your pick.) I mention this age gap because it made itself all-caps KNOWN while I was listening to Kate Kennedy’s One in a Millennial.For every reference Kate made to, say, Beverly Hills 90210 or Saved By the Bell, she made a dozen more to, say, her love of Mary Kate and Ashley Olsen movies. (Considering I would have been a high school senior when those were popular, no way in hell would I have been caught watching them!)Many times throughout this read, I was reminded of just how much older I am than her. (Case in point: While she was a 10 year old using AOL Instant Messenger, I was a college freshman doing the same.)But despite us having some major clashing cultural touchpoints, there were plenty that we shared, including zeitgeisty references to listening to the Spice Girls, wearing a “going out” top, and shopping at Limited Too (though my preppy version of that store circa 1992 was MUCH different than the glittery version Kate shopped at years later!) Overall, I think Kate did a great job critiquing the culture that shaped our generation as women. (I especially loved her examination of the character Jessie Spano from Saved by the Bell.) And while she could often be humorous on the page, she was strikingly serious when, for example, connecting the dots on how purity culture of the 80s/90s/00s shaped the sexuality of many millennial women.No regrets about reading this and I’ll go out on this note: My favorite “nod my head in agreement” moment of the book was when Kate spoke about her “daybed days” of girlhood. Having spent MANY nights growing up sleeping alongside my BFF in her daybed, I could relate to this nostalgia—and to Kate’s assessment that sleepovers (intimate overnights spent with 2-3 of your best friends) were WAY better than slumber parties (which were bigger, louder, and involved more classmates, which, for an introvert like me, often meant less fun)....more

review: When my bestie Jill told me this book involved two rival journalists falling for each other through a magical connection, I was like, “Sold!” And I ceWhen my bestie Jill told me this book involved two rival journalists falling for each other through a magical connection, I was like, “Sold!” And I certainly enjoyed meeting Iris Winnow and Roman Kitt in this war-torn romantasy (a genre that most definitely had a moment in 2023, did it not?) Overall, this book is otherwise hard to pigeonhole: the characters are in their late teens but it doesn’t read like YA; there’s an epic battle happening between gods but the fighting takes place entirely on the ground in realistic battle scenes; and the time period is impossible to determine (if you picture World War I era vibes, you’re basically there). Yet somehow Ross manages to make all these disparate elements work together in service of one heck of a page turner (with one HELL of a cliffhanger ending!)...more

review: Becca Freeman (co-creator of my favorite Bad on Paper podcast) has written a charming holiday rom-com about a group of friends who become one another’Becca Freeman (co-creator of my favorite Bad on Paper podcast) has written a charming holiday rom-com about a group of friends who become one another’s “found” families—a bond cemented by their decision to spend Christmas together every year.There are a *lot* of 2000s pop culture references and a healthy dose of humor (including one Ben Affleck-Dunkin’ joke that made me LOL) woven into this book, which is as much a love letter to the holidays as it is to friendship and life as a 20-something in NYC.If I had any complaints, it’s that the narrative jumps around (and not at all chronologically). Read this if you want a mistletoe-esque mash-up of your favorite FRIENDS episodes meets the grand romantic gesturing of Richard Curtis’s Notting Hill. review: Within the world of romance, there are popular tropes—plots, themes, devices that get used so often they become a convention of the genre. And boy oh Within the world of romance, there are popular tropes—plots, themes, devices that get used so often they become a convention of the genre. And boy oh boy does Jessica Joyce go ALL in with the enemies-to-lovers trope with this debut of hers! Said trope is actually my personal least favorite in romance, yet I was able to move past my misgivings here. Mostly because the couple in Jessica’s story—Noelle and Theo—are caught up in a great love story that isn’t even their own! Together, they embark on a long road trip to learn more about the romance that once flamed bright between Kathleen, Noelle’s recently deceased grandmother, and Paul, Theo’s adorable grandfather.You, With a View made me miss my own beloved grandmother something fierce. For that reason, coupled with the high-quality heat score between Noelle and Theo along with the story’s major focus on photography (a preferred pastime), I found this a rather satisfying read....more

review: This book falls into that "part history/part travelogue/part memoir" genre that I like to read on occasion, and this one grabbed my attention in partiThis book falls into that "part history/part travelogue/part memoir" genre that I like to read on occasion, and this one grabbed my attention in particular since I'm an Elder Millennial who can vividly remember the first wave of American Girl fandom that took hold in the early '90s.I was never fortunate enough to own one of these dolls (though several of my friends did), but I did read (and re-read!) the books that chronicled the young lives of those first historic dolls: Kirsten, Samantha, Molly (my favorite!) and Felicity.Dolls of Our Lives is the brainchild of historians Allison Horrocks and Mary Mahoney, who were shocked by the popularity of the titular podcast they launched several years ago dedicated to all things AG. They parlayed the success of the pod into this book, which dives into everything from the evolution of the company to the way in which these dolls provided limited views of history that catered to their white (and wealthy) audience. I appreciated the authors' balanced approach to covering this cultural juggernaut, and I enjoyed their insights into an iconic brand that shaped a generation to which I belong. ...more

title: Talking at Night
author: Daverley, Claire*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Second Review, December 2023This book shot to the top of my favorites list of 2023—hands down my most recommended book of the year. I knew I wanted toSecond Review, December 2023This book shot to the top of my favorites list of 2023—hands down my most recommended book of the year. I knew I wanted to own a copy, but my love for this one ran so deep that I specifically *had* to purchase a UK edition from British bookseller Blackwell's Bookshop. Mostly because its bright orange cover features gorgeous foil-embossed spoons in empty cereal bowls—a graphic nod to an important scene central to the opening chapters of the novel. So what did I make of a second reading, this time with a physical copy in hand? I loved it every bit as much, if not more, as my first time discovering this beautiful story. I remain blown away that this book is author Claire Daverley's debut -- her ability to invoke setting and emotion and sensory imagery with just a handful of words per sentence is astonishing. And I was swept up anew in the love story of Rosie and Will, who by this point feel as real to me as cousins or coworkers. Wherever they are now in the literary ecosystem, I wish them well in their journey through life together. Original Review, October 2023I’ve been calling this book a “magic unicorn” read to all my friends, in large part because it is SO rare (in my experience, at least) to discover a novel that reads both like literary fiction AND a truly compelling romance. This story is about Will and Rosie and how they fall for each other as young teens in England (first over a bonfire and then late night bowls of cereal and then dreamy meet-ups next to the sea). But it’s also about how first love can be torn asunder by tragedy.And….sigh. Will and Rosie? They face a LOT of tragedy in their young lives. To say more would give too much away, as I feel this read is best experienced knowing next to little about the story overall. If you HAVE read it and you want to know a few specific scenes that made this a Top 3 read of 2023 for me, have a gander at my list below:(view spoiler)[* When Rosie and Will make off with a tray of desserts and talk outside during her family’s Xmas party…that was such a fabulous depiction of a stolen moment every young person wishes for alongside the crush of their dreams. (See also: eating bowls of cereal in the middle of the night together.)* When Rosie’s twin brother, Josh, confides in Rosie that he is gay and has a crush of his own on Will …. oh Josh, you sweet tormented soul, you! * Will’s relationship with his sweet grandmother.* Will’s relationship with his wise little sister, Amber.* Will refurbishing a piano for Rosie …..SWOONNNNNNNNNNN!!!* Will and Rosie finally getting stolen time together—time during which there is consolatory mac and cheese devoured and passionate love made (the carpet burns!)* Will helping Rosie care for Simon while he has cancer (a plot pivot I didn’t see coming!)* Those final chapters when Rosie and Will (both having found what they needed personally and grown as people) reunite and finally (FINALLY!) get to be a couple. (hide spoiler)]...more

review: I am a sucker for any form of media (book, film, TV series or otherwise) that wants to play with the trope of wish fulfillment in life. Which explainsI am a sucker for any form of media (book, film, TV series or otherwise) that wants to play with the trope of wish fulfillment in life. Which explains why I L-O-V-E-D Sophie Cousens’ The Good Part. As the author herself shares in her acknowledgments, this book is her homage to some of her favorite films: Big, The Family Man, 13 Going on 30, and Freaky Friday.Many times while reading this, I found connection points to each of those classics. My least favorite part of the book may have been how worried 26 year old Lucy Young was to wake up suddenly 42 (especially given the fact, next week, I turn that same age…it’s okay, Lucy, really!)And my favorite part of the book was realizing, despite all the shocking twists and turns Lucy encounters in her sudden jump into her older life, she has a one-in-a-million kind of love with her husband, Sam. Their relationship was a breath of fresh air in this endearing read, and I loved getting to feel like a fly on the proverbial wall as I witnessed them fall in love with each other a second time around. (More stories with people who are in solid marriages in their 40s, please and thanks!) ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A bright spot of my 2023 has been co-creating an online book club—the Great Midwest Book Group—with my friend Laura, a talented middle grade author anA bright spot of my 2023 has been co-creating an online book club—the Great Midwest Book Group—with my friend Laura, a talented middle grade author and fellow bookworm from Wisconsin.Laura and I are committed to encouraging other readers to join us in discovering authors who share our mutual love for the Midwest. Carol Dunbar is one such author, and her debut, The Net Beneath Us is our January pick for our book group. Let me stop here and encourage you to join us on January 30 for our Zoom conversation with Carol about her work. (I can DM you details if interested! Also, friend our account on Instagram too, please!) Having finished this book on a recent road trip, and without giving anything away, here are a few thoughts I’m holding on to in anticipation of our upcoming Q&A with the author:• This book is set in the woods of rural Wisconsin, and I loved how I felt like I was right there with the main character, Elsa. I appreciated how this read was both a story about how people choose to live off the grid and a narrative about a woman who—having lived a rather bougie East Coast existence before meeting her husband, Silas—finds solace in the quiet life they establish as newylweds in the Midwest. • I *really* enjoyed this book on audio—the narrative performances were so nuanced and added tension to a story chock full of drama.• One of the throughlines of this story is about Elsa being a woman unaccustomed to accepting help from others—something she desperately needs in the wake of a family tragedy—and how she has to find it within herself to accept that help from the type of humble, hardworking people (Ethan and Luvera) who define the Midwestern lifestyle. • Dunbar herself lives off the grid (she writes from a solar-powered office on the second floor of a water tower) so I cannot wait to ask her about how this type of lifestyle has changed her, given she was once, like Elsa, a “city girl.”• This is a book I may never have gotten around to reading were it not for this book group. For that reason alone, I am grateful for the time that Laura and I are investing in cultivating this group for ourselves and for like-minded readers who want to see more fiction written about the Midwest as a place where people want to live versus leave....more

title: The Woman in Me
author: Spears, Britney
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Britney Jean Spears is two months older than me. Which means I can remember every aspect of her meteoric rise, because I watched her strut down the haBritney Jean Spears is two months older than me. Which means I can remember every aspect of her meteoric rise, because I watched her strut down the halls of high school in 1999 in that “…Baby One More Time” video while neck deep in my own high school experience. [Said performance would later air ad nauseam on TRL, MTV’s after-school video countdown, a defining cultural touchpoint for most of us millennials.] What followed after her debut was watching her dance with a snake during the VMAs in 2001, a pop culture moment everybody talked about at the time (including me and my college besties). Then (and this is something I am NOT proud of…something I thought about a lot while listening to Michelle Williams’ tremendous audio narration of this memoir) came the “Is she crazy?” questioning of her behavior in the aughts—the deriding of her shaved head and “mishandling” of her babies and panning of her 2007 VMAs performance (which, watching in 2023 is not nearly as bad as media made it out to be then). So yeah, all of what I wrote above I wrote to acknowledge that this memoir of Britney’s? It’s about HER finally having a say about the shitstorm that’s been her life. But it’s also about US acknowledging our complicity in the power of the mean-spirited narrative that defined her twenties (whether it was watching Diane Sawyer roast her in that infamous interview or clicking on PerezHilton.com or scanning US Weekly headlines at the grocery store ... sadly, I am guilty of all three and for that, I am truly sorry, Britney.)Like so many others, I am here for the cultural reckoning happening in relation to this poor woman—everything from examining how media grilled her incessantly (seriously, why were they OBSESSED with asking about her virginity?) to addressing her mental health (by making her the butt of countless jokes and casual cruelty). Of all the confessions to come from this book, it is how Britney confronts these issues on her own terms that made for the most powerful revelation to me. A few parting thoughts:— I’d like to take back the money I spent on the Justin Timberlake concert I attended in 2013. That asshat deserves ALL the ridicule he’s facing in response to this book. (Fo shizz, fo shizz #iykyk )— Despite all her family put her through, Britney remains SUCH an empathetic person. This character trait comes through loud and clear throughout this short read and it endears me to her all the more.— Given how Britney explains her Instagram videos, I support her freedom to portray herself how she wants online (even if I can admit I mute them because it's just too much skin for me). But Brit, you do you. FINALLY.— When Britney writes about the “Free Britney” movement and her chance to escape her conservatorship, this was the line that made me tear up: “If you stood up for me when I couldn’t stand up for myself, from the bottom of my heart, thank you.”— Jamie Spears should be in jail for life. (And while there, he should be force fed nothing but plain chicken breast and canned vegetables. #iykyk ) — Michelle Williams should (and likely will) win a Grammy for Best Audio Book recording of this memoir. EGOT status, here she comes! ...more

But mission accomplished, Ms. Michallon …. you had me hooked wanting to find out what would happen to the poor “woman in the shed” (aka, the sole surviving target of serial killer Aidan Thomas). This book was elevated on audio by the stellar voice work of the narrators. (After I finished, I learned the author is a member of the cast, “becoming” one of the nameless women whose short vignettes give readers clues into their final moments with Aidan before they die at his hands.)In many ways, this book made me think of the great work Jamie Dornan did playing a doting father with serial killer tendencies in the TV series, The Fall. title: Monsters: A Fan's Dilemma
author: Dederer, Claire
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My husband and I listened to much of this book together on a recent road trip, and only a chapter or two in I was hit anew by the realization that criMy husband and I listened to much of this book together on a recent road trip, and only a chapter or two in I was hit anew by the realization that criticism truly is an art form.I suppose this inkling hit me as hard as it did because author Claire Dederer is a PARTICULARLY EXCELLENT CRITIC.In this latest work of hers, Dederer sets out to reconcile her “appreciation of great art with the real-life misdeeds of its creators.” (source) And so I found this book—which reads two-thirds like essays one might find in The New Yorker and one-third like a personal memoir—to be a fascinating peek into a topic that I, too, have been thinking about as I get older, especially in the wake of so much public reckoning that has happened for fallen rogues (men, mostly) whose misdeeds were all we could read about for a time. (I’m looking at you, 2017 and 2018….)What MOST fascinated me about this read, however, wasn’t what Dederer had to say about Woody Allen or Roman Polanski or Pablo Picasso (monsters, all) but rather what female monstrousness looks like—and that is abandoning one’s child for one’s art.Those chapters really got this brain of mine working in overdrive, convincing me this read would be an excellent pick for a book club. (I want to ask other readers—women especially!—what they think of it. And if, like me, they disagree with her notion 'pregnancy is the end of narrative.' Pfftt…that doesn’t have to be true! )One final observation: My husband and I’s tandem read of this book happened over the course of a getaway during which we toured Frank Lloyd Wright’s incredible Wisconsin home, Taliesin. The irony was not lost on us that, hitting pause on this read, we left behind one work of criticism about certain monsters to join a tour in which we learned a great deal about another. Say what you will about FLW (and it’s no exaggeration to call him a genius) but damn the man and his philandering ways! Upon leaving the grounds of his home, I felt, in the words of Dederer, “a little urpy.” Like the fan who now (unfortunately) knew too much. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Words I’ve come across that have been used to describe the debut novel of Emily Habeck:“Beguiling.” “Delightfully unusual.” “High concept.”Yes, for meWords I’ve come across that have been used to describe the debut novel of Emily Habeck:“Beguiling.” “Delightfully unusual.” “High concept.”Yes, for me, this weird little wonder of a book was all of those things. And I’m glad I went into it with the open mind that I did, curiosity piqued by friends who spoke highly of it. Because yes, this is a book about a man who turns into a shark. But in Habeck’s world, transforming into an animal is a life-altering diagnosis that can befall any person, same as cancer or Parkinson’s or Alzheimer’s.  There’s something refreshing about processing the grief and trauma of an illness or terminal diagnosis like that through the lens of the paranormal. At least, I found this to be true as I read along—immersed in a story that was unique in both concept and in construct. (Some chapters are only a few sentences long).But what really stole my heart with this title was its closing scenes, which are a beautiful rumination on loss and love and parenthood. They were the reason I turned the final page with big old crocodile** tears in my eyes. **Not to worry, I’m not ACTUALLY turning into a crocodile … a lame joke I feel compelled to make given the book in question. (Ba dum tss!) Parting thought: If you were a fan of Shelby Van Pelt’s Remarkably Bright Creatures, I can all but guarantee you will fall equally hard for this new read. Give it a shot and prepare to be dazzled....more

title: The Love Prescription: Seven Days to More Intimacy, Connection, and Joy
author: Gottman, John M.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Before picking up this little book, I’d heard of the Gottmans thanks to their various guests appearances in the podcast world (take your pick, from BrBefore picking up this little book, I’d heard of the Gottmans thanks to their various guests appearances in the podcast world (take your pick, from Brené Brown to Goop). Yet, I could not say my knowledge of them was more than surface level.Now that I’ve plowed through The Love Prescription—their latest guide that “distills their life’s work into a bite-size, seven-day action plan”—I can tell you I’ve become huge fans of their work. (Huge!) In part because I am fascinated by the science behind their decades of research. (Case in point: In a study of couples he conducted in the ‘90s, John Gotten was able to predict divorce in couples with 94% accuracy. Ninety-four percent!)Because of their expertise, I put stock in absolutely everything John and Julie have to say about the building blocks of what makes a relationship last for the long haul. If I had to summarize their major takeaway from this read it would be that partners need to build habits of *turning towards each other* in simple everyday moments—moments that, over time, build the bridges of trust and affection that help a couple survive even the toughest of times.I would recommend ANYONE in a relationship—be it days or decades old—pick up this book. There is so much knowledge and actionable suggestions to take away from it. I feel fortunate that my experience of reading it (aloud, I might add!) happened alongside my husband as we took a road trip to celebrate our 17th wedding anniversary … a fitting occasion to remind ourselves of the positive practices we can incorporate into our relationship to make it even stronger than it currently is. ...more

I picked this one up after spying it on a list I scrolled past on Instagram, then returned to so I could thumb through the selections Oprah’s Book Club deemed “5 Immersive Audiobooks That Take Storytelling to New Heights.”And look, if you ARE going to have a go at this “brilliantly original” novel (so sayeth the publisher), then ABSOLUTELY audio is the way to do it. Because it really does hit the mark when it comes to being a stellar immersive experience, in large part because of the talented multi-person cast responsible for voicing the various characters, from Greta (the transcriptionist) to Om (the sex coach whose therapy sessions Greta transcribes) to the titular Big Swiss (the stoic Swiss client of Om’s whom Greta becomes infatuated with over the course of the book).I joked with a friend who loves to talk inside baseball about publishing that this book is to fall 2023 and the Hudson Valley what Emma Cline’s The Guest was to summer 2023 and the Hamptons. author: Ward, Jesmyn*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Only a few chapters into this book and I knew I needed a break, both because the material is SO heavy but also to seek out a few interviews with the aOnly a few chapters into this book and I knew I needed a break, both because the material is SO heavy but also to seek out a few interviews with the author, since this is one of those novels where context seemed key. What I found certainly deepened my appreciation for both Ward and for this read:• Ward spent years writing and researching this book. Her work on it was stalled when she lost her partner in December 2019 (right as COVID was hitting in the US). For six months after his death, she feared she’d never write again. • Ward wondered if the world needed another slave narrative and if she should be the one to write it. It was a conversation with writer Ta-Nehisi Coates that gave her the boost to do it. “One of the things he said was, if you think about it, there were millions of people who were enslaved. So there are millions of lives to write about and their experiences were all different. The common element was the fact they were enslaved, but they all had different wants and desires and dreams and longings and griefs. That’s a very simple declaration, but I needed to hear it.” (Source)• Ward was inspired to write the book while driving from her home in Mississippi to New Orleans, where she teaches at Tulane. Listening to NPR, she heard a series they were doing about the history of New Orleans, where a portion of the book is set. “I was shocked that I knew none of the history that they were covering in the radio show,” she says. “And that I think really drove home for me the fact that that history had been erased; so erased from the landscape that I had spent years of my life in that place and couldn’t see that history at all. I just remember being appalled in that moment and wondering, What if I wrote about it? Would that help to bring that reality back into the public consciousness, back into [the] public awareness?” (Source)At this point in my life, I’ve read many a slave narrative and what I appreciated most about this one was the incorporation of spirits into the story—how they guided Annis in her decision-making and on her path to freedom.I also appreciated the title, which comes from a scene early in the book when Annis overhears the tutor of her master’s daughters (her half-sisters) learning about Dante’s Inferno. In that moment, Annis (and the reader) is introduced to the poem’s opening lines: Let us descend and enter this blind world.Such an apt description for the specific hell that was chattel slavery in this country....more

title: The Vaster Wilds
author: Groff, Lauren*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Before you read this remarkable new novel from Lauren Groff (without question one of our greatest living writers), do yourself a favor and have at thiBefore you read this remarkable new novel from Lauren Groff (without question one of our greatest living writers), do yourself a favor and have at this NYT profile that details *how* she writes her books. If you’re not up for that, then here’s the TLDR version: She works on several manuscripts at once, writes all first drafts long hand, then locks them in a bank box and starts over FROM MEMORY.Oh, and just to get into the “rhythm” of the language of the time period in which The Vaster Wilds takes place, she wrote a version of this novel in iambic pentameter FOR FUN.With those mind-blowing facts out of the way, I will say I DEVOURED Vaster Wilds—an engrossing adventure story about a young woman who escapes the fledgling colony of Jamestown to forge her own path in the North American wilderness.I was maybe a few dozen chapters in when I realized, “Huh…this book has no dialogue in it.” In lesser hands, this would have been a deterrent. And yet, with Groff at the helm, I could not get enough of her beautiful, propulsive prose.This is one of those books I will keep returning to in my mind, turning over the fate of the characters, the hellish realities of the 17th century time period, and the atrocities committed on the natives who were here in this country first. It’s a trip to early colonial America I didn’t know I needed, and I’m grateful to Groff for gifting it to us.A few passages I don’t want to forget:“And yet you do not know the scale of this place? the voice said, and it was now scornful. And the girl said, No, but surely it must be smaller than my own far greater country across the waters, where each field is so thick with legend and myth and ancient battles that one step is not merely in space, unlike in this new world, but also through layers of time. Here there is nothing, only land, all the earth and mountains and trees remain innocent of story. This place is itself a sheet of parchment yet to be written upon.”“For what woman has not, walking in the dark of the street or along a path deep in the countryside, sensed the brutal imaginings of a man watching her from his hidden place, and felt the same chills chasing over her skin, and quickened her steps to get away.”“All the trees wore coats of ice so thick that they seemed glazed over with glass, and the stars shone so bright upon the world that the world shone back at the stars in stupid dazzlement.”“It is a moral failure to miss the profound beauty of the world, said the voice in her mind. Yes, she said along, for now she did see the sin in full.”...more

review: Years ago, my friend Stefanie turned me on to The High Low, a weekly pop culture and news podcast created by the posh double-act that was Pandora SykeYears ago, my friend Stefanie turned me on to The High Low, a weekly pop culture and news podcast created by the posh double-act that was Pandora Sykes and Dolly Alderton.For years I looked forward to their “high low” take on cultural happenings in the states and abroad and was heartbroken while listening to their final episode in December 2020, seeing as how I’d fallen in love with them. The women ended their pod with good reason though—to branch out into other personal projects—and they have been busy ever since, penning multiple books, podcast series, and TV shows.Yet it’s Dolly’s second novel, Good Material, that I am confident will now make her a household name here in the states. Good Material is the story of a fledgling comedian (Andy) recently dumped by his career-driven girlfriend (Jen), and it reads like you tossed a Nora Ephron script and a Nick Hornby novel into a blender and hit the “ON” button. There’s a great twist to its ending (that I think fans of Taffy Brodesser-Akner will especially appreciate), and because Dolly is as well connected as she is, I like to imagine she’s meeting with Richard Curtis to plan out who he’ll cast in an extremely watchable adaptation of her millennial love story, one with two very different (but equally compelling) endings. ...more

review: This book gets my vote for one of the Best of 2023 for:✔️its midwestern setting (Chicago in the '90s and current day) ✔️ strong POV characters ✔️ uniqThis book gets my vote for one of the Best of 2023 for:✔️its midwestern setting (Chicago in the '90s and current day) ✔️ strong POV characters ✔️ unique voice (Hill takes you down rabbit holes you didn't know you wanted to go down--like, suddenly I, too, became SO FASCINATED by the placebo effect!) ✔️ on-point themes (it's basically The Great American Novel for the Gen X/Elder Millennial set)   ✔️ and that brilliant middle-of-the-book passage that's essentially a dissertation on how Facebook brainwashed the Boomer generation into believing the Internet's most outlandish conspiracy theories.Clocking in at 600+ pages, Wellness requires commitment, but from its opening pages, this book sucked me in similar to how I felt buckling up for my favorite "big" read of last year (Tomorrow and Tomorrow and Tomorrow). So if you liked THAT read—or you're curious about Wellness b/c of any of what I wrote above—then go on and tackle this one. It’s a genius-level work of literary fiction written by an author with the most inquisitive mind** I’ve encountered on the page. (**Anthony Doerr gives Nathan a run for his money though!)...more

title: Games and Rituals
author: Heiny, Katherine
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Within the first few minutes of listening to Katherine Heiny’s new collection of short stories I was smitten. There is just an “it” factor to KatherinWithin the first few minutes of listening to Katherine Heiny’s new collection of short stories I was smitten. There is just an “it” factor to Katherine’s writing—something I couldn’t quite put my finger on until I read a Guardian  of Games and Rituals, which points out Heiny’s ability to deliver “deadpan delivery, the bittersweet wisdom, the sublime farce.”See also how author Jennifer Close so perfectly describes the experience of reading Katherine’s work: “The opportunity to read a new short story by Katherine Heiny always fills me with delight. I know I’m going to laugh; I know I’m going to be slightly shocked by a deliciously inappropriate joke or line of dialogue; I know I’m going to laugh some more; and I know I’ll probably have my heart broken just a little bit."I’m always quick to say how much I don’t enjoy short stories, but when it’s an author who straight up excels at them? Forget those words ever came out of my mouth! If Katherine Heiny wants to write nothing BUT short stories going forward, I will always be game (ba dum dum tss!) to read her work. Speaking of games (and a few rituals), here were my favorite stories from this collection:* Chicken-Flavored and Lemon Scented—a story that follows the shenanigans of a bunch of DMV workers with a surprising twist at the end* Turn Back Turn Back—a story about what happens when a bedtime story unravels a struggling marriage (side note: Katherine really likes to center her stories around the topic of infidelity)* CobRa—a story that details an “off” season of marriage between a wife relying on the Marie Kondo method to help cope with empty nest syndrome and a husband whose metabolism has turned on him “the way the tabloids turned on Meghan Markle” (when I came across that description I straight up laughed out loud)* 561—a story about a woman forced to help her ex-husband’s wife move out of the family’s home (with a brilliant backstory of how they met working at a suicide prevention hotline)Games and Rituals is easily going to end up in my list of Top 10 Books of 2023, you watch....more

review: I was SUCH a fan of the TV series Friday Night Lights (#cleareyesfullheartscantlose), and so, when a friend of mine raved to me about Minka's new memoI was SUCH a fan of the TV series Friday Night Lights (#cleareyesfullheartscantlose), and so, when a friend of mine raved to me about Minka's new memoir, I knew I had to check it out.I was ... not prepared for the whiplash of what I perceived this stunningly beautiful young woman's life to be and the reality of what it really was.From the opening pages (when Minka pulls us DIRECTLY into her view from the peep show window she's working at a seedy club in Albuquerque), I felt like I was every GIF that exists of a slack-jawed cartoon character.The trauma Minka endured throughout her young life was gutting, and juxtaposed against the portrayal of herself as a sweet, innocent, mature-beyond-her-years child? Well, let's just say it hurt my mama heart DEEPLY to read about. It's clear Minka has done a LOT of work on herself in therapy to overcome the demons of her youth, but this memoir is a powerful example of how ghosts from a person's past can and will haunt every waking hour of one's life, well into adulthood. Kudos to her for finally telling her story. I am confident it's one that will help many, many other people with similar childhood hurts. ...more

review: Picture Hollis Shaw, a domestic goddess the likes of Joanna Gaines, gathering four friends from different stages of her past for a sun-drenched weekenPicture Hollis Shaw, a domestic goddess the likes of Joanna Gaines, gathering four friends from different stages of her past for a sun-drenched weekend on Nantucket to help patch over the wounds of grief gouged by the sudden death of her husband. That's the premise of Elin Hilderbrand's 2023 release. But what takes this book's "exploits of privileged women" plot up a notch is the surprising connection one of these "five-star" guests has to someone important in Hollis's life. (Cue the suspenseful music!)This is only my second Hilderbrand title, but I continue to be impressed by how well she serves aces in the genre of summer beach reads. I especially love that she's been at this game long enough—and is popular enough—she can break all the rules: Head hop between two dozen characters, one being a dog? Sure, why not! Throw in a Greek chorus of townspeople while you're at it? Abso-freaking-lutely!In lesser hands, such narrative scheming might prove disastrous on the page, but Hilderbrand manages to make her style of storytelling equal parts zeitgeist-y and compelling. No complaints from this fan! ...more

review: Like debut author Meg Shaffer, I adored Roald Dahl’s Charlie and the Chocolate Factory as a kid. Unlike Shaffer, I did not think to use this classic cLike debut author Meg Shaffer, I adored Roald Dahl’s Charlie and the Chocolate Factory as a kid. Unlike Shaffer, I did not think to use this classic children’s tale as a springboard to create my own whimsical debut novel, the likes of which made me feel a certain way (that way being a mix of charmed and delighted).Several times, I shook my head in admiration at the creative plot Shaffer cooked up for her readers—a plot in which she manages to accomplish the following:• Create a believable story about a teacher’s aide named Lucy who wants to adopt a young boy named Christopher but, because she is short on funds, chooses to enter into a unique game hatched by her favorite children’s author, Jack Masterson. The prize of said game is the unsold manuscript of the latest book in Masterson’s successful Clock Island series, the sale of which will provide Lucy the money she needs to adopt Christopher and to embark on a fresh start.• Create excerpts from the Clock Island series that are sprinkled throughout the main story—excerpts good enough they could be be bestsellers of their own if the series actually existed. • Create riddles and games for Lucy and the other contestants to solve that stumped this reader time and time again. • Create a heartwarming backstory for Hugo, the handsome illustrator of Jack’s books, who becomes Lucy’s love interest and whose works are described so vividly I would pay good money to see them in a touring exhibition (again, if said works actually existed). I guess what I’m trying to tell y’all is that this book has as many layers—and is every bit as good—as my favorite dip. So pick it up already … especially if you are in need of a book that makes you smile and a story that's brave enough to break out of any genre that tries to contain it....more

You guys have enough baggage between you to fill a goddamn carousel at JFK, but isn't that kind of the point of love, that you help each other carry the bags?"I ended up smitten with this second-chance romance that is as much about two hurt and bruised 30-somethings finding love again as it is a love letter to big families, New York City (specifically Little Italy) and the ability of food to bring us together (specifically vanilla gelato). December was a great time of year to read this, as I just finished my annual rewatch of "While You Were Sleeping." (Main character Iris is as emotionally in tune with Bullock's Lucy Moderatz as she is physically a match for Jess from "New Girl"). If you love the idea of a tender read featuring a male protagonist who whispers sweet nicknames in Italian into the ear of his lover, then this book is for you. It's also for you if you can appreciate a healthy dose of '80s pop culture sprinkled throughout a story as well. title: Honey, Baby, Mine: A Mother and Daughter Talk Life, Death, Love
author: Dern, Laura
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Start to finish, what a brilliant read! There are no shortage of celebrities who put memoirs into the world, but I was smitten with the construct of tStart to finish, what a brilliant read! There are no shortage of celebrities who put memoirs into the world, but I was smitten with the construct of this one: Faced with a life-threatening illness, actress Diane Ladd receives a prescription from her doctor to walk to strengthen her lungs. Her daughter, the brilliant Laura Dern, recognizes the only way she's going to get her mother to exercise is by turning it into a creative exercise. And so begins the conversations that form the basis of Honey, Baby, Mine, a book that takes its title from the Crawdad Song that Ladd's father used to sing to her when she was little.These two cover all the bases in their discussions: from surviving Hollywood, to their favorite things, to raising kids and the guilt (and opportunities) that accompany the role of being a working parent. I loved every one of their "walk and talk"s, even as SEVERAL made me cringe. (OMG…do not get Laura started on the time Diane gave her grandson, Ellery, a gender-defining hair cut!)Because these two are the acting powerhouses they are, they elevate the audio version of the book to performance art. I finished this one wanting to call my own mother as well as dig into a backlist of both actresses’ films, starting with the Oscar nominated “Rambling Rose.”...more

title: In Memoriam
author: Winn, Alice
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "If Ellwood were a girl, he might have held his hand, kissed his temple. He might have bought a ring and tied their lives together. But Ellwood was El"If Ellwood were a girl, he might have held his hand, kissed his temple. He might have bought a ring and tied their lives together. But Ellwood was Ellwood, and Gaunt had to be satisfied with the weight of his head on his shoulder." Oh Sidney Ellwood! Oh Henry Gaunt! HOW YOU STOLE MY HEART!It is impossible for me to believe this is a debut novel from author Alice Winn (who reportedly began writing it at 26, inspired as she was by the stories contained in the digitized newspapers of the English boarding school she attended—papers that informed the fictional paper, The Preshutian, that makes up the backbone of In Memoriam). As Alice said, “You get to know them ... you feel like you’re watching this tiny little society just be completely destroyed and dismantled.”It is this experience—learning about the lives of these young men and then watching as war viciously snatches them away—that Winn captures so brilliantly for readers of this remarkable book that for sure counts among my Top 5 reads of 2023. It's been a long time since I've read a book with a scene that made me gasp out loud and that happened with the brilliant twist Winn writes into this story. (Another reason I loved it!) But as sad and horrifying as its gruesome battle scenes were, In Memoriam still contains plenty of heart and humor. (There is a running joke about George Elliot's Adam Bede I found particularly funny.) I saw a  of this book that compared it to "Heartstopper on the Western Front" and ...that's a pretty accurate summary, if you ask me. Throughout its 400 pages, you can't help but think about how different the lives of Ellwood and Gaunt would have been had they been born 100 years later—to live full lives and to love who they wanted to love without fear or penalty. My life feels a little richer now for having gotten to know them. A final note worth mentioning is that I very much enjoyed reading in Winn's acknowledgments about how many of her characters were inspired by real soldiers of the Great War. One in particular I came to love immensely, and whose fate I cared about as much as Ellwood and Gaunt's, was Gideon Devi (inspired by Indian RFC pilot Erroll Chunder Sen). There was another soldier I loved for his willingness to help Ellwood and Gaunt in a pivotal way and that was Captain Cyril Roseveare, whose bravery and loyalty was captured beautifully in the final entry Winn gives us from The Preshutian. What an ending and just ... wow .... What. A. Book....more

title: The Covenant of Water
author: Verghese, Abraham*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This beautiful behemoth of a book stole my heart this month and, to be quite honest, I STILL haven’t recovered from it.Years ago, I read Verghese’s CuThis beautiful behemoth of a book stole my heart this month and, to be quite honest, I STILL haven’t recovered from it.Years ago, I read Verghese’s Cutting for Stone and fell hard for his eloquent writing, which is why I purchased Convenant the minute it came out last May. Then, I sat on it for MONTHS, intimidated by its brick-like size. What a dum-dum move that was, because really, what’s better? Reading two mediocre 350-page novels back to back—something I definitely did in the time between purchasing this book and finally picking it up—or reading one epic 700-page saga that reads like a modern-day masterpiece? From its opening page, Covenant sweeps you away to the lush landscape of South India’s Malabar Coast, beginning at the turn of the 20th century. And it’s here that Verghese introduces a remarkable cast of characters—Big Ammachi, Baby Mol, Philipose, Elsie, Mariamma, and Digby among them—who burrow into your heart and forever change you.Like the author, I loved these women and men deeply, all the more so because of the epic highs and lows he put them through. (Truly, there are some next-level shocks and reveals in this story that will make your jaw drop right up until its final pages!)Oprah made Covenant her 101st book club pick last year and, in doing so, created a six-part companion podcast series for which she interviewed Verghese at length. It was this series that leveled up my appreciation for this book from “I loved it!” to “I AM OBSESSED WITH THIS BOOK.” If you choose to read it based on anything I’ve written above, then know that I consider listening to these interviews a must!...more

A quick peek at other s of the book here on GoodReads tells me you either love her style or you (very much) do not. Lucky for me, I fall into the former camp, and I was taken by how this fellow Midwesterner managed to write her way through such a seismic shift in her life. review: A few thoughts on this title, aka my FAVORITE read of 2023:1) Meryl Streep performs this audiobook like it is a play onto itself. I was captivated by A few thoughts on this title, aka my FAVORITE read of 2023:1) Meryl Streep performs this audiobook like it is a play onto itself. I was captivated by her performance and admire all the voices she adopted for the various characters, Maisie being a personal favorite as well as Lara's grandmother (whose voice sounded SO much like my own deceased grandmother's that a certain late-in-the-story scene involving the character made me break down in tears). 2) I am SO glad I read Thorton Wilder's "Our Town" before reading this. Just ...SO GLAD. (To Ann's point: "The beauty and the suffering are equally true. Our Town taught me that.")3) There are maybe 5 or 6 writers working today who I would consider at the absolute pinnacle of their game, creatively speaking. Ann Patchett is at the top of that list. 4) I loved the quiet perfection of this story, one where nothing major happens and yet, through small chapter-by-chapter reveals, you are left surprised by the particulars of Lara's story and how she chooses to reveal them (or not!) to her daughters. Of course, the surprise that got to me the most—the one that made for the *second* spot I cried in this book (which NEVER happens to me!) came with the (view spoiler)[discovery of Duke wanting to be buried on the farm under the daisies....what a tie-in to that glorious cover and an ending to a book that stole my heart so!
