my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Years ago, I remember watching Jennifer Finley Boylan being interviewed on Oprah and my mind was blown at the time because it was the first instance IYears ago, I remember watching Jennifer Finley Boylan being interviewed on Oprah and my mind was blown at the time because it was the first instance I could recall of watching an honest, open conversation on television with a transgender woman. That memory came back to mind as I picked up this new book—co-written by Boylan and Jodi Picoult—which my book club selected for our summer read.Now that I’m finished with it, I can say I would not have wanted to read a book about a transgendered person in the Year of Our Lord 2023 that WASN’T co-written by someone who was also transgender. In this respect, Boylan succeeded in continuing my education of the trans experience and my understanding of the trans community. This was one of those reads that was propulsive, narratively speaking, but … I did struggle with it at times. I’m not much for narratives where domestic abuse is a focus (not because of personal experience just, ugh…such stories are hard to read, you know?) Also, I felt like this book needed a bit more editing (not a ton, but had it been cut by at least 30 pages or so, it would have been even more of a stellar read …I might recommend 3-4 fewer instances where beekeeping metaphors were employed, for starters). I do, however, have one major gripe about the plot (and it’s something I look forward to talking about with members of my book club when we meet to see if they felt the same): (view spoiler)[The constant mentioning of Asher’s jerky friend Dirk made the reader believe he was going to have something to do with Lily’s death. It was enough to learn in the trial that Lily ACTUALLY died because of a medical condition related to her transition … I don’t think the story was served well by the bait-and-switch of making Maya (Asher’s jealous BFF) the person responsible for her death instead. And if Dirk WASN'T going to be involved (and this WASN'T going to be a crime of trans hate), then yeah, fewer references to him would have helped move the story along a little quicker, too. (hide spoiler)]...more

I agree wholeheartedly with Debbie's take that Demon's is the "Best voice ever!" As I told a girlfriend while reading this, I could almost believe that Demon came to the author fully formed as a character—she was just the conduit for his voice. THAT is how real he feels to the reader.If I were teaching a college-level American studies course, I would require my students to read Patrick Radden Keefe's Empire of Pain for a detailed factual account of how the 21st century opioid epidemic in this country came to be. And then, after my students finished that, I'd require them to read Demon Copperhead so that they could empathize with the poor victims of the crisis. This one is SO well-deserving of that Pulitzer Prize win, that's for dang sure!...more

title: Bright Young Women
author: Knoll, Jessica*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I absolutely loved how author Jessica Knoll flipped the script with this book—taking the spotlight off our collective fixation on serial killers and sI absolutely loved how author Jessica Knoll flipped the script with this book—taking the spotlight off our collective fixation on serial killers and shining it instead on their victims. In Bright Young Women, we get a fictional retelling of the victims of serial killer Ted Bundy—specifically his victims from 1974 to 1978, which included an attack on the Florida State University Chi Omega sorority house, where he killed two women and beat two more, before attacking another woman blocks away.Knoll purposefully never refers to her serial killer by name, only as “The Defendant,” establishing a pattern of belittling his intellect (going so far as to point out that he picked his nose while in the courtroom).There were moments throughout Bright Young Women*** where I occasionally felt out of “syntactical alignment” with the writing (and apparently wasn’t the only one). Yet overall, when I think back on my reading experience of it, this book was such a stand-out story that I know I won’t be letting go of my memories of it anytime soon—a good thing, considering I chose it for the next pick for my book club! ***Knoll named her novel in reaction to watching courtroom footage of an overly complimentary judge say of Bundy: “You’re a bright young man. You could have done all these things with your life, and you went another way.” Gross, right? No wonder Knoll felt compelled to reveal all the ways our nation “got the story wrong” with this famed psychopath.Also, if you finished this book wanting to know more—about Knoll, about her inspiration for the book, about her research for the dual-narrative timeline she used—this interview is a great companion read and so is this one, too....more

author: Levy, Shawn*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: For anyone interested in the history of Hollywood, this meticulously researched narrative about the famed Chateau Marmont is required reading. It’s anFor anyone interested in the history of Hollywood, this meticulously researched narrative about the famed Chateau Marmont is required reading. It’s an origin story of the hotel itself, but it's also a dishy collection of tales about its most famous guests (from the 1930s to now, so it's quite a 'Who's Who' list we're talking about!), as well as a history of the Chateau's mythic reputation as an anchor institution along the Sunset Strip. I found most fascinating the stories of how the hotel served as the backdrop to the birth of “Rebel Without a Cause," as well as the scene of the untimely death of actor John Bellushi. I've always been a bit starstruck by Hollywood and I've loved every visit I've made to L.A. Whenever I get the chance to head there again, I'll have to go out of my way to visit the Chateau, because now that I know so much about its past, I see drinks on its patio in my future.Merged :For anyone interested in the history of Hollywood, this meticulously researched narrative about the famed Chateau Marmont is required reading. review: This book (which appropriately enough, I read during Disability Awareness Month) is an excellent primer on all things disabilities, and I learned so mThis book (which appropriately enough, I read during Disability Awareness Month) is an excellent primer on all things disabilities, and I learned so much about how to think/talk/ask about disabilities as well as how to be a better ally. (Also, it really is MINDBLOWING how ableist our world is.) What made this read all the more memorable is that, earlier this month, the book’s author, Emily Ladau, was a guest lecturer at Ball State University (my alma mater and employer). It was a privilege to attend and to hear Emily speak both about her process of writing the book (something she romanticized doing from a coffeeshop and instead found herself completing while holed up at home during the pandemic) and about her role as a disability rights activist.Perhaps the most sobering moment of the evening was hearing Emily talk about the hell she has to endure any time she flies. Airlines are notorious for taking the WORST care of wheelchairs, and Emily’s chair remains broken from a recent flight (and she has yet to be reimbursed for the damages). Emily’s experiences flying have been chronicled by VICE News in this powerful feature about the indignities wheelchair users undergo every time they travel by air. I especially loved the Jordans of this friend set, whose coupledom centers the narrative. There were a few plot lines to the storyline that felt a tad underbaked, but in Rowley's capable hands, I easily looked past them so as to honor the love, loss, and friendship forged between this particular literary fivesome.In checking out a few s, I liked this line from the NYT  of this read: "With its minimalist plot, “The Celebrants” has the vibe of a late-career Garry Marshall movie, but with a better-than-usual script."And speaking of likes, I snorted with laughter when Rowley introduced the "Courtney Scale" and found myself grinning every time he invoked it after first mention. It's those little bits of pop culture savvy in his work that endure me to Rowley and make his books "auto" buys for me....more

title: We Could Be So Good
author: Sebastian, Cat*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When describing this book to one of my bookish besties, I said it was like “if ‘Mad Men’ and ‘Newsies’ had a gay book baby.”AND I MEAN THAT IN THE BESWhen describing this book to one of my bookish besties, I said it was like “if ‘Mad Men’ and ‘Newsies’ had a gay book baby.”AND I MEAN THAT IN THE BEST WAY because …. OHHHHH how I loved this read (clearly, seeing as how I gave it 5 stars)! It checks so many boxes on the list of things I love:✅ 1950s setting✅ INCREDIBLY well researched history of NYC during said time period✅ NEWSPAPERS (as a former journalist, I will always be a sucker for any book set in a newsroom)✅ a handsome reporter with dark hair and features named Nick (I married one of those, only my Nick is straight—OBVIOUSLY)✅ adorable glimpses into domestic life (homemade meals! watching TV together! the caring of a stray cat!)✅ multiple references to Cornelia Street (I’m a Swiftie…what can I say?! Ha!) Sometimes you read a book that’s been hyped and you feel let down when you realize you don’t share the same love for it as all your friends do. And then sometimes, you pick up a book having lesser expectations (maybe because you’ve just never read the author before or the book hasn’t been a darling of the publishing world with the marketing budget to show for it) and you end up being blown away by it and seriously, ISN’T THAT THE BEST FEELING?That’s me in 2023 with We Could Be So Good.Finally, a description I wanted to remember from this mid-century romdram because it took me *immediately* back to my own days as a journalist (which I was for much of the aughts): “At eight thirty in the morning the newsroom is always like a coiled spring, still lacking the movement and energy of later in the day, but with plenty of latent force if you know where to look.” ...more

title: Barracoon: The Story of the Last "Black Cargo"
author: Hurston, Zora Neale
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: At the same time my late grandmother was a 10-year-old, growing up in her small Ohio hometown, down under the hot Alabama sun, Zora Neale Hurston was At the same time my late grandmother was a 10-year-old, growing up in her small Ohio hometown, down under the hot Alabama sun, Zora Neale Hurston was interviewing 86-year-old Cudjo Lewis (born Oluale Kossola), the last living slave to endure the Middle Passage from Africa.It’s mindblowing … to think how close our country remains under the shadow of slavery. I couldn’t stop thinking about this fact as I listened to the audiobook of Barracoon. This is the work of Hurston’s that languished for YEARS because her publisher wanted her to change the language of the text to standard English as opposed to Lewis’s native dialect.Because Hurston stood her ground, in 2018 we were (finally!) rewarded with one of the most immersive first-hand slave accounts on record. Consider this passage and then imagine it stripped of Lewis’s language, which Hurston knew was key to understanding this poor man (who endures SO much in his lifetime … TOO much!):“Dey takee de chain off us and placee us in de boats. Cudjo doan know how many boats take us out on de water to de ship. I in de last boat go out. Dey almost leaves me on de shore. But when I see my friend Keebie in de boat I want to go wid him. So I holler and day turn round and takee me.”Robin Miles does a TREMENDOUS job narrating Cudjo’s words. I was in tears at several points in his story, and I can't think of a better book to read in observance of Black History Month.I followed up listening to Barracoon with a viewing of the Netflix documentary, “Descendant,” which I also HIGHLY recommend. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was SUCH a phenomenal book—a graphic novel that should be required reading for all young adults (ages 8-12) everywhere. What I loved most about NThis was SUCH a phenomenal book—a graphic novel that should be required reading for all young adults (ages 8-12) everywhere. What I loved most about New Kid was how deftly Jerry Craft examines issues that his Black protagonist, Jordan, experiences at his fancy (new to him) private school. From having to code switch between his wealthy peers and friends in his neighborhood, to handling school bullies, to dealing with micro aggressions from his classmates and teachers alike, Jordan is a character for the moment and New Kid is a book that makes these topics both timeless and relevant. While reading this together, my son and I had some great conversations about the above topics. He also appreciated that, while he’s not of the same race or socioeconomic background as Jordan, he IS a kid who has been picked on for being small … so to read about how Jordan successfully navigated the halls of middle school as the “shrimp" of his group was yet another reason for him to root for this character’s success at Riverdale. A 5-star book I highly recommend, especially as a joint read between parents and their children....more

review: If this book taught me anything, it’s not that I shouldn’t leave my bag unattended. It’s that I don’t much care for reading novels where the main charIf this book taught me anything, it’s not that I shouldn’t leave my bag unattended. It’s that I don’t much care for reading novels where the main characters are the literary equivalent of milquetoast. Also? It’s really hard to read about a character who’s the spouse of someone battling depression when you yourself have lived that experience. (Oof … I may not have picked this one up if I knew I would be getting into that narrative arc.)Overall, I was pretty “meh” about this book … it’s bloated (Moyes writes great narrative descriptions, just too many for my taste). And I really hated the fact that Nisha was originally poor white trash from …where else? (Oh, the Midwest …go figure!) Despite those squabbles, I did keep reading to the end. Namely because at some point every couple of pages, Moyes would land an observational gem that shone as much as the diamonds that … well, I’ll let you read the book to figure out how gemstones factor into its zany plot. Below is one example of what I mean:“There is a shorthand to women this age, Sam realizes. There is none of the sharp elbows of their twenties and thirties, not an ounce of competitiveness. By their late forties and fifties, they’re all survivors, of death, divorce, disease, trauma, of something.” ...more

title: Spare

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I’m trying to think about what to say about this buzzy new memoir that hasn’t already been said by so many other readers. Rather than rehash a versionI’m trying to think about what to say about this buzzy new memoir that hasn’t already been said by so many other readers. Rather than rehash a version of, say, Rae’s spot-on  (which I agree with every word of), I’ll write instead about some of the more bonkers things we learn about Harry using the old party game “Two Truths and a Lie”: • Harry delivers a toast at Will and Kate’s wedding reception at which he presents a furry thong made out of ermine to the blushing bride.• Harry goes on an expedition to the North Pole, where he develops frostbite on various parts of his body, including his “todger”.• Harry loves the sitcom F•R•I•E•N•D•S and hooks up with one of the cast members while on a trip to America.Okay, that last one is DEFINITELY a lie. But Harry really is obsessed with the series (which he watched on repeat while suffering from depression post-combat duty). And he DOES meet his favorite Friend, Courtney Cox, while staying at her place in LA. (It’s during said trip that Harry trips on mushrooms and has a very Seth Rogen-esque moment with a bathroom trash can—another weird truth that legitimately made me laugh out loud!)A final bonkers revelation touches on Spare’s popularity. As I write this (the same month it came out), the memoir has sold more than 3.2 million copies worldwide. (source) It’s been reported Penguin Random House needed to sell “in the vicinity” of 1.5 million copies to break even with the $20 million they paid Harry upfront to write the book (with help from his incredible ghostwriter, JR Moehringer). I’d say the Penguin folks got their money’s worth publishing what is on track to becoming the bestselling memoir of all time, wouldn’t you? ...more

review: I picked up Olga Dies Dreaming on the advice of several friends (including one who’s a photographer working the same high-end NYC wedding scene chroniI picked up Olga Dies Dreaming on the advice of several friends (including one who’s a photographer working the same high-end NYC wedding scene chronicled in the book). I loved it as much as they did, but here’s what I wasn’t expecting from this buzzy debut that hit a number of “Best of” lists as one of 2022’s breakout novels: — That wrapped up in the story of a jaded wedding planner (Olga Acevedo) and her rising Democratic star of a brother (Prieto), I'd discover a comprehensive history of the island of Puerto Rico.— That I'd be so caught up in this (highly autobiographical) narrative, I'd Google “Panuelos Negros” to find out if they were an ACTUAL revolutionary group in Puerto Rico. (Spoiler: They are not.)— That I would find myself caring about how, for many Nuyoricans, gentrification is destroying their cultural ties to the city. See also: my new-found understanding of neo-colonizing in Puerto Rico. — That I would be inspired by the author’s life story of giving up her own successful wedding planning business at 40 to become a writer accepted to Iowa Writer’s, where she wrote her first draft of Olga.— That upon learning a Hulu adaptation of Olga was in the works, I would excitedly check who’s been cast as the heroine (picturing a post-Hustlers J.Lo as my version of the curvaceous Latina) only to be…surprised(?!) to learn Aubrey Plaza nabbed the role. Um, what?! Look, I am SO glad they cast someone of Puerto Rican descent (which Plaza is), but wow, that was a left-field casting call for me! I am a tad skeptical and yet very excited to see what she does with the role, as well as Jesse Williams as Matteo (Olga’s eccentric but extremely likable love interest). Since the author is writing the screenplay, I’ll keep my fingers crossed this is one of those rare adaptations that lives up to the amazingness of the book![For a  that offers a MUCH different take on this book from mine, and one I would encourage others to read, as it's written by someone with ties to PR, check out what Melanie had to say. This L.A. Times profile of Gonzalez is also an interesting companion read.]...more

review: This was up there on my shortlist of non-fiction books I was most excited to read in 2023. I mean, Benjamin McKenzie wrote a book about crypto!? THE BThis was up there on my shortlist of non-fiction books I was most excited to read in 2023. I mean, Benjamin McKenzie wrote a book about crypto!? THE Benjamin McKenzie, aka Ryan Atwood from The O.C.?SIGN. ME. UP.I’d seen Benjamin commenting enough on this topic in the news to know he did his homework, and having paid little attention to all things crypto in the past few years, I was ready to be schooled.The problem? Turns out I actually do NOT want to be schooled about crypto. Not even by someone as awesome as teen idol-turned-armchair economist Benjamin McKenzie.What it came down to is whenever I started reading sentences about, say, blockchains (WHAT?), followed by a rehashing of economic principles from the likes of John Maynard Keynes, my brain just started shutting down. And so, despite multiple efforts to reboot it with each new chapter, this one ended up being a DNF halfway through for me.No disrespect to Ben or Jacob Silverman (the journalist who helped research and co-write this book). I just got lost a lot … and maybe a glossary of terms at the beginning would have helped. Even then, I just couldn’t care to keep reading and solidifying my existing belief that uh, yeah, crypto is a scam. ...more

review: It can be hard to explain to your child the magnitude of the Holocaust — but how important that explanation is, especially in light of the reality a sIt can be hard to explain to your child the magnitude of the Holocaust — but how important that explanation is, especially in light of the reality a shrinking number of young adults understand the true toll of this terrible tragedy.I will not let my children grow up to be included in this majority. When I started this Newbery winner with Dean, I wasn’t sure to what extent death would center in the story (and therefore read each chapter to him with bated breath, wondering what would happen to little Annemarie, her family, and the Jewish friends, the Rosens, they help during World War II). It was a relief to know the Rosens survived, as did almost all of the Danish Jews who were helped by Resistance fighters in that country. I learned so much about Denmark’s role in the war from this book, one that gives children a brief glimpse into how frightening this time was while (thankfully) dwelling on a more positive story of bravery and hope. review: I have fond memories of one of my favorite elementary school teachers, Mrs. Stapleton, reading this book to us in the third grade. Oh how I loved PeteI have fond memories of one of my favorite elementary school teachers, Mrs. Stapleton, reading this book to us in the third grade. Oh how I loved Peter and Fudge then! Thirty plus years later, and that love is still there: for these characters, of course, but foremost for the brilliant, warm, and humorous mind that created them. (I’ll love you forever, Judy Blume!)I will say reading Tales of a Fourth Grade Nothing now made me cringe at plot points that wouldn’t fly in publishing today: the fat jokes, the casual misogyny of a ‘70s workplace, the ineptitude demonstrated by Peter and Fudge’s father while (gasp!) his wife hems and haws before deciding to leave her family for a weekend to visit her sister and her new baby. I’m grateful we’ve come a long way in the span of a generation—enough so that, in between scenes that made me and my son laugh out loud as he read this to me, we could have a few frank discussions about why plot points like the ones described above feel progressively out of place in 2023....more

review: I spent the past few months listening to my son read this book to me as part of his daily reading log for school. We came to the final pages last nighI spent the past few months listening to my son read this book to me as part of his daily reading log for school. We came to the final pages last night in tears (poor T.J.!), both of us grateful for the experience of having been introduced to the Logan family.I count this novel among the classics of children's literature I never got around to reading myself. And since Dean and I are dedicated to working our way through Newbery Medal winners of the past, this one was on our short list. At times, it wasn't an easy read. (It also required navigating around the "n" word, prompting us to skip over the word multiple times in the pages that followed its first usage!) But Roll of Thunder was, however, an enlightening glimpse into what life was like for Black families of the South in the 1930s. We came away from it admiring the strength, perseverance, and independence of Cassie, her siblings, and her parents. ...more

title: Before I Let Go        (Skyland, #1)
author: Ryan, Kennedy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: One of my favorite shows of the past 10 years is Issa Rae’s “Insecure.” The popular HBO miniseries ran for five seasons and, in the words of actress YOne of my favorite shows of the past 10 years is Issa Rae’s “Insecure.” The popular HBO miniseries ran for five seasons and, in the words of actress Yvonne Orji (who played Issa’s BFF, Molly) did “a really good job of showing Black people just in their element.”I thought so often of “Insecure” as I was reading Kennedy Ryan’s newest release, Before I Let Go. Because Ryan, too, does a really good job of showing her Black characters in their element.And just who are those characters? There is Yasmen, a businesswoman and mother starting to come out of the hole of depression that resulted in the wake of the untimely stillbirth of her third child. There is her ex husband, Josiah, who still carries a torch for her (and vice versa). And then there are the couple’s two children, along with the employees who work for them at the popular restaurant they co-own, as well as the friends who help them navigate the circus of their everyday complicated lives. Can I mention that said friendships in this book ALSO made me think of “Insecure”? A show that, to this day, is one of the greatest love letters to female friendship I’ve ever seen on the small screen?And that, the entire time I was reading Ryan's descriptions of just how hot Josiah was, all I could do was picture the insanely handsome Jay Ellis (Lawrence from ‘Insecure’) playing him in an adaptation? So yeah, this is me telling you if you miss “Insecure” as much as I do, then you should consider picking up this book. And if you’ve never watched “Insecure,” well, you should get on that, too! No matter the order, you will be submerging yourself in content created by talented Black women who center contemporary Black lives in the best, most normalizing of ways....more

title: Quietly Hostile: Essays
author: Irby, Samantha*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are moments in every collection of Samantha Irby essays that make me cackle, in large part because she finds the words to skewer modern-day cultThere are moments in every collection of Samantha Irby essays that make me cackle, in large part because she finds the words to skewer modern-day culture in a way that has me saying out loud, "YESSSSS." Consider these few sentences by way of example:"You know how everybody now drinks old man cocktails that taste like rancid cough syrup? Or they order whatever's on the bar menu that has mezcal in it and therefore tastes like burning newspaper? When did we start doing that?"HAHAHAHA. This woman is FUNNY, even if I can admit that this latest book is not my favorite of hers. There were a few too many essays here that didn't hold my attention (see: "Two Old Nuns Having Amzing [Sic] Lesbian Sex" ... and if you're like, whoa to that title, you've clearly never been introduced to this author's work!) My favorite might have been "I Like It!"—a brilliant take down (and come back) for every person that "puts you on the defensive, that sends you down an internal spiral thinking, Why do I like the dumb shit I like?" I've jokingly used that line a few dozen times already. I also fell down a rabbit hole listening to Dave Matthew Band songs after reading Samantha's essay on her love of the band. AND knowing she loves Aidan as much as I do ("he was cuter than Big, nicer than Big, more thoughtful than Big...") I might have watched a "Best of Aidan" SATC montage on YouTube after I read her (did it really have to be that long?) essay about her experiences as a writer on "And Just Like That." Overall, it's a great day when a new Irby collection hits the shelves. Even when its contents are list-heavy and a bit niche-y, there's still much to learn "from an essay writer who creates literacy currency out of commiseration and coping."...more

title: A Fever in the Heartland: The Ku Klux Klan's Plot to Take Over America, and the Woman Who Stopped Them
author: Egan, Timothy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I was growing up in Fort Wayne, Indiana, I took a school field trip (in maybe the third grade?) to the Fort Wayne Historical Society. The buildinWhen I was growing up in Fort Wayne, Indiana, I took a school field trip (in maybe the third grade?) to the Fort Wayne Historical Society. The building itself made the trip memorable, but what seared that field trip into my brain is the recollection of turning the corner on one of the floors and discovering a glass display with a dummy inside (which, dude, scary already) WEARING A FULL KU KLUX KLAN COSTUME***.I thought a lot about that trip (which gave me nightmares for months after) as I read Tim Egan’s new book A Fever in the Heartland—a work of nonfiction that hits *too* close to home given its examination of that dark period in American history when WAYYYYYYY more Americans were members of the KKK than our history books led us to believe. (In Indiana, the heart of Klan activity at the time, ONE IN THREE Hoosiers were members of the Klan in 1923. ONE. IN. THREE.) It’s easy 100 years on to romanticize the ‘20s as that roaring era of flappers and jazz and the Charleston, but peel back the Gatsby-colored curtain and pick up a book like this (or watch Ken Burns’ “The US and the Holocaust”) and you can realize this was also the same terrifying decade when xenophobia reigned supreme, the KKK was hosting parades like they were going out of style (not just in the Midwest …. apparently the organization was so deep in the pockets of Anaheim, the city was dubbed ‘Klanaheim’), and eugenics was a global movement. To say this book—which details the rise and fall of the terrible DC Stephenson, grand dragon of the Indiana KKK—was eye-opening is like saying water is wet. I learned SO much from this read—about my home state, about tolerance, and (sadly) about how we are doomed to repeat history if we do not take the time to learn from it. (To say DC would be friends with Donald Trump today is like saying …. well, you know where I’m going with that analogy).What made this book a 5-star read for me was that *very* rare experience where the topic being covered becomes personal in an unexpected way. Throughout Fever, Stephenson chronicles the pervasiveness of the KKK in the lives of everyday citizens (you could shop at Klan-approved stores! enroll your children in the Ku Klux Kiddies!) but he *also* shares the stories of the individuals who put up a fight against the terrorist organization. One of those individuals was George R. Dale, a rabble-rousing newspaper editor from Muncie (the city I’ve called home for the past 20 years).Dale has been described as “Indiana’s Jazz Age version of a Stephen Colbert or Jon Stewart,” and I absolutely RELISHED every moment he was on the page of this book, raising hell against the Klan.You want to know why?Because my husband and I bought our home 17 years ago from George's great-grandson, Andrew Dale, who lives in Muncie and, like his family members before him, is involved in community building and local politics. So yeah, forget Kevin Bacon, with this book it was ALL about “Six Degrees of George Dale” for me. ***Sadly, seeing that Klansman as a kid feels like the most I recall learning about the KKK in grade school history. We as a society are WAY overdue both for how we talk about slavery and racism in our texts as well as white nationalism, which, as we ALL know, is on the rise again in this country....more

title: In Love: A Memoir of Love and Loss
author: Bloom, Amy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was so achingly beautiful—one of those hard but heartfelt memoirs detailing the good, the bad, the ugly of everyday life interrupted by disease. This was so achingly beautiful—one of those hard but heartfelt memoirs detailing the good, the bad, the ugly of everyday life interrupted by disease. If you read (and appreciated) Paul Kalanithi's When Breath Becomes Air or Nina Riggs' The Bright Hour, then I promise you will be just as moved by this love letter Amy Bloom wrote as a tribute to her husband that works double time as a testament to his final days living with Alzheimer's. This book is also a fascinating behind-the-curtains look at what it takes to end one's life in an assisted manner (a decision that is VERY difficult to carry out in the states, hence the reason Amy and her husband, Brian, jump through all the hoops—and SO MUCH PAPERWORK—to travel to Switzerland, where Brian chose to end his life with the help of the Swiss non-profit Dignitas). Finally, Amy's description here of what Alzheimer's does to the brain was so powerful and succinct (and poetic, really) that I wanted to record it in this  so I would remember it:"Those neurons, the brain's soldiers, march for years, from the time we're born, through the byways of the brain, setting actions into motion, rolling away boulders of all kinds, and then, with Alzheimer's, they're blocked by trees down at one end of the road, dangling wires at another. Over the years, the brain's soldiers—this well-trained and reliable army, which has done so much, on so many different terrains, gone high and low, swum, climbed, strolled, and marched to all the different destinations of the mind—begin to falter, long before outsiders can see the troubles. Eventually (five years on for some, three for others, ten for some), the obstacles cannot be overcome. Messages cannot be received. The soldiers cannot break through to new ground. Retreat is the only possible path and you'd be a fool to try to lure someone out, amid the heavy artillery. Alzheimer's for me is 1914, and a good day with Brian now is that famous Christmas truce, which was quite short and quite beautiful (German boys caroling to the English, calling out, "Merry Christmas, Englishmen" as they climbed out of the trenches; tobacco shared, souvenirs exchanged, rations shared, and prisoners swapped) and never repeated. Retreat makes sense, and it is agony for me and, I think, not much of anything now for Brian."...more

review: This book is a classic for a reason. I remember a copy of it sitting on my shelf as a kid (this exact one, specifically) and just the sight of it takeThis book is a classic for a reason. I remember a copy of it sitting on my shelf as a kid (this exact one, specifically) and just the sight of it takes me back to Christmases of my childhood.Naturally, I had to check it out from the library and read it to my son. Within the first chapter, we were chuckling as I reintroduced myself (and him for the first time) to the Herdman clan. This is one of those children's books that, when you read it in 2022, you can't help but cringe a bit at some of the dialogue (it was the '70s...kids fat shaming one another was par for the course) but overall, the message here is on point and the book is just as funny to read today as it was back then.When we got to the final pages—with the Wise Men presenting the ham and Imogen weeping over "Silent Night"—I couldn't help but feel a little choked up myself....more

title: The Light We Carry: Overcoming in Uncertain Times
author: Obama, Michelle*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: How much do we love the relatability of this phenomenal FLOTUS? (Answer: So much!)It’s this aspect of Michelle Obama—along with her ability to inspireHow much do we love the relatability of this phenomenal FLOTUS? (Answer: So much!)It’s this aspect of Michelle Obama—along with her ability to inspire and motivate—that brings fans (myself included) coming back for more of her storytelling. And stories are what she shares in this book, which reads like a self-help manual, Commencement speech, and diary, rolled into one. My favorite chapters were the ones she devoted to her marriage, her mother, and her dearest friends. A few anecdotes I want to remember: On coming of age Our hurts become our fears, our fears become our limits.On friendshipWhat mattered is that we just kept showing up: in closeness, in commitment, in compromise, and even, in fatigue. The best way to BE a friend …is to revel in their uniqueness. To appreciate each person for what they bring, receiving them simply as themselves.Life has shown me that strong friendships are most often the result of strong intentions. Your table needs to be deliberately built, deliberately populated, and deliberately attended to.On marriageIf you choose to try to make a life with another person, you will live by that choice. You will find yourself having to choose again and again to remain, rather than run. It helps if you enter into a committed relationship prepared to work, ready to be humbled, and willing to accept—and even enjoy—living in that in-between space, bouncing between the poles of beautiful and horrible, sometimes in the span of a single conversation, sometimes over the course of years. And inside of that choice, and those years, you’ll almost certainly come to see there is no such thing as a 50-50 balance. Instead, it’ll be like beads on an abacus, sliding back and forth, the math rarely tidy, the equation never quite solved. When it [marriage] does work? It can feel like an actual honest to god miracle. Which is what love is after all. That’s the whole point. Any long-term partnership, really, is an act of stubborn faith.Finally, I had to laugh when I realized that the last celebrity-penned book I’d listened to prior to Michelle’s had been Prince Harry’s. My mind IMMEDIATELY traveled back to the last time I was proverbially “sandwiched” between these two, courtesy of a designer friend with a talent for Photoshop!...more

review: Kate's poetry is just *so* moving. The way she can capture a mood, a feeling, the meaning of woman/motherhood in just a handful of lines ...that is a Kate's poetry is just *so* moving. The way she can capture a mood, a feeling, the meaning of woman/motherhood in just a handful of lines ...that is a true talent. I will admit I appreciated these poems a smidge (and I mean a millimeter of an inch) less than her first collection. I think it's because there was more of a mystery to some—and to solve that mystery would require understanding the source of the melancholy Kate brings to the page. Overall, I just found that fewer of the poems from And Yet left me feeling warm/fuzzy/uplifted/understood and more left me curious as to what she wasn't telling her readers.My brain is like a sieve with poetry (I can never remember poems I love!) but here's one from this collection I don't want to forget because it rings so true to where I'm at this particular stage of my own life:Still MarriedThe children are getting older andI don't know how we ever managed with the dark nights and heavy car-seats and babies nursing at my bleedingbreast. Nothing is easier and yethere we are making pancakeswith the radio on....more

author: Center, Katherine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Maybe because I’ve been reading some SUPER heavy reads this month, but I chugged this delightful rom-com down like I was desperate for the literary eqMaybe because I’ve been reading some SUPER heavy reads this month, but I chugged this delightful rom-com down like I was desperate for the literary equivalent of a tall glass of sugary sweet tea on a hot summer's day. I LOVED the subtle ways Katherine Center broke the fourth wall in telling Hannah’s story (a technique that felt like a nod to “Fleabag” and maybe even Elizabeth Strout’s Lucy Barton). I LOVED that, in picturing Jack, Drew, and Hank Stapleton, I EASILY envisioned Liam, Chris, and Luke Hemsworth as this trio of mighty fine fictional brothers. (A fact I did not mind … not one bit!)Most of all I LOVED that, in a sea of literary rom-coms that insist on making the protagonist some form of manic pixie dream girl, Katherine Center gave Hannah JUST the right amount of quirk, balancing out her character by placing a strong head on her shoulders (which she uses ever so effectively to flip Jack in my favorite scene of the book! Oh wait…I take that back, my favorite scene is DEFINITELY the nightgown scene!)My Libby app informs me I read this book in 7 hours, most of which were consecutive because I was THAT sucked in to this fun (and funny!) story. I now want the film adaptation ASAP, PLEASE. Also, if this book were in fact the ‘90s rom-com that it reads like, then Sandra Bullock would ABSOLUTELY play Hannah. No questions asked....more

title: Surrender: 40 Songs, One Story
author: Bono
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I think of my most played albums in my CD collection (still enshrined in a couple of good ‘ol CaseLogic binders!), I think of my “Best Of” U2 albWhen I think of my most played albums in my CD collection (still enshrined in a couple of good ‘ol CaseLogic binders!), I think of my “Best Of” U2 albums. In tribute to those albums, here’s a “Best of” list of what I enjoyed most about Surrender:Bono’s Backstory: The way he writes about the death of his mother, Iris, at 14 and his complicated love for his father, Bob. Broke my heart multiple times. U2’s Origin Story: I’ve been a casual U2 fan for years, but I never knew the band formed in Larry Mullen’s kitchen when the foursome were young teens. What a fateful meeting that was!Bono’s Love for Ali Hewson: Good GRIEF does this man love his wife! They met at 12, married at 21, and have been together 40 years. Surrender is his love letter to her and it’s a hell of a good one.Art Meeting Life Experience: I loved learning about the trips Bono took in his 20s that shaped his songwriting for The Joshua Tree (ie, his trip to El Salvador in ’86 and the resulting “Bullet the Blue Sky” and Ethiopia inspiring “Where The Streets Have No Name”)Live Aid Memories: Bono writing about his bad haircut for this famed concert and how much (but how little) help it provided Africa.Bono Getting In The Way of the Band: Bono takes the fault for the many ways his ego and quest to “break the mold” of U2’s sound led to some less than stellar results (Pop being one example). Bono as a Parent: I adored Bono’s writing about his kids, even as he acknowledged his guilt of not being as present in their lives as he should have been. “Your children take you back to being children” is a line to remember …. as is “We begin by looking out for our children and, in time, if we are so blessed, we find they are looking out for us.” Bono and Michael Hutchence: Bono writes about the halcyon years (“a 90s carnival”) when he and Ali spent so much time with Michael Hutchence (of INXS) and his girlfriend, Helena Christensen. To have been a fly on the wall for one of their vacations! I was saddened to read about Bono’s frustrations at Hutchence’s drug use and his grief over his death. I had no idea how close those two were. Bono and Debt Relief: It was enlightening to read about Bono’s work—especially with US officials—to persuade the world to erase the debts of poor countries, particularly in Africa. I was too busy being a self-absorbed high school senior to remember Jubilee 2000, so this was an informative behind-the-scenes look into his humanitarian efforts. Bono on Mortality: Being 40 myself, and worrying about my aging parents, this scene hit me like a truck. In his words: “I was crossing the 40th birthday threshold, the halfway mark of a good life, and for the first time noticing my mortality and those of the people I loved, like Michael Hutchence, like my dad.” Bono put his feelings into a song, “Kite” (from my favorite U2 album, All That You Can’t Leave Behind). Knowing what I do now, I’ll never listen to it the same again. The Apple Partnership: A fascinating peek behind the curtains into Bono’s close relationship with Steve Jobs, the development of the black U2 iPod, and Bono’s regret over pressing Tim Cook to put Songs of Innocence on the iPhone 6. An experimental mistake he owns.Bono’s Voice: Bono’s dad loved to tell him “You’re a baritone who wants to be a tenor.” After his dad (a singer himself) passed in 2001, Bono writes about his voice changing. “I feel like he gave this gift to me in passing … I’m a tenor now.” Bono on Religion: Bono writes often about his Christian faith but divulges he’s never found a church he could call a home. “It’s more likely that church is not a place but a practice, and the practice becomes a place.” I relate to this sentiment.U2 as Family: I got teary-eyed at Bono’s parting thoughts about his bandmates—the “beloved brothers” he’s worked beside for more than 40(!) years. “These fellow travelers, who had no idea when we first met what kind of road we’d be taking…thank you for giving me a great life, thank you for letting me be in your band…”Bonus Content:— This audiobook has the best sound design of any I’ve read. My admiration went beyond the song snippets Bono performs to all the immersive sound elements in between. A treat to listen to, start to finish.— Bono is a musician who writes like a musician. But just as often he writes like an artist, poet, spiritualist, humanitarian, and punny wordsmith, rolled into one. Hard to describe what I mean until you listen to his musings in Surrender. A unique soul, this one. — Bono’s real name is Paul David Hewson. “Bono” was bestowed upon him by his childhood BFF, Guggi. It comes from the Latin word, Bonavox, or “good voice”. — Bono does impressions in the book…not all of them great. (Bono, please, no more Bill Clinton!) I love the guy, so whenever he’d break into one, it felt like my corny dad embarrassing me as I listened. Ha!...more

review: (Landed between 3.5 and 4 stars on this one)This is one of those works of women's fiction that's catnip for ladies of a certain age—primarily those wh(Landed between 3.5 and 4 stars on this one)This is one of those works of women's fiction that's catnip for ladies of a certain age—primarily those who, like the characters of this book, spent a chunk of the '90s roaming the halls of their high school. I loved how steeped this book was in nostalgia from that era. (I'd forgotten Hard Candy nail polish until I came across it in these pages!) Something I cared less for? How this story leaned too hard on hitching its characters' fates to their senior superlatives.If you're looking for a book that plays up high school reunions as a plot device while also exploring a host of women's issues (from the myth of 'having it all' to aging to divorce to parenting and second chance romance), then you might want to pick this one up, too. [Minor quibbles: Assuming this book gets another printing, I would ask the publisher to (1)  some of the dates of items included in the 1997 time capsule ("Armageddon" didn't come out until 1998 and the Da Vinci Code wasn't published until 2003!) Also, maybe think of another hideaway location for this quartet to hang out that isn't owned by (ewwww) Elon Musk.]...more

review: This unusual rom-com was cute. Maybe a little too cute for me. (Case in point: The mayor of the protagonist’s hometown is a dog and she refers to her This unusual rom-com was cute. Maybe a little too cute for me. (Case in point: The mayor of the protagonist’s hometown is a dog and she refers to her coffee as “zoom zoom juice”.) Rather than serving as a reflection of Ashley Poston’s writing (because plenty of GoodReads ers loved this book, as did Good Morning America, which made it their July ’22 book club pick), I’ll just say I’m noticing as of late when I'm about 10 years too old for a rom-com plot. Said plot typically involves a manic pixie female wanting to climb her love interest “like a tree.” (Multiple times this tree-climbing business is mentioned in this book. MULTIPLE TIMES.)So yeah, to quote Roger Murtaugh, maybe my opinion of this book has more to do with how I feel like “I’m getting too old for this shit.”For this reason, and because of a totally unbelievable plot element (and I’m not talking about the ghosts here…the ghosts I was on board with, but a man being obsessed with romance novels? title: Have I Told You This Already?: Stories I Don’t Want to Forget to Remember
author: Graham, Lauren
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My hold for this audiobook came in as I was listening to my purchased copy of Bono’s memoir—a memoir you HAVE to listen to at 1.0x speed, or else BonoMy hold for this audiobook came in as I was listening to my purchased copy of Bono’s memoir—a memoir you HAVE to listen to at 1.0x speed, or else Bono’s voice does NOT sound like Bono.Why do I share this detail? Because it’s hilarious that, after YEARS spent watching “Gilmore Girls,” Lauren Graham’s voice does not sound “normal” to me unless it’s at Lorelai Gilmore speed, which, if you are curious, is 1.5x speed on audio—not even kidding!At that pace, I plowed through this relatively short collection of new essays from Ms. Graham in record time. Let it be known I enjoyed every one, a few more than most (my least favorite being the one where she describes all the “health” camps she’s gone to over the years…namely because they all sound pretty calorie-restrictive and miserable—like, she’s binge eating Burger King before sneaking in!)What I loved most about Graham's writing here is she's reached a point in her career where she’s okay spilling Hollywood insider secrets (like how every actress wears a hair piece when filming for the sake of continuity) but also okay admitting she STILL doesn’t understand her industry and probably never will. (Case in point: She once, at the height of Gilmore Girls fame, found herself on Louis Vutton’s MVP list..a list she had no clue existed and then was promptly relegated from a year later for reasons unknown). It’s Graham's dissection of these strange pecking orders of the famous—coupled with her warmth when talking about her relationships, including her friendship with the actress Mae Whitman—that make these stories go down like …well, a cup of coffee from Luke’s Diner? I'll just say her vibe is energetic, entertaining, and quick-witted and leave it at that! ...more

review: Having read (and felt rather meh about) Kevin Wilson’s first two titles (Family Fang and Nothing to See Here), I’m like Goldilocks and the Three BooksHaving read (and felt rather meh about) Kevin Wilson’s first two titles (Family Fang and Nothing to See Here), I’m like Goldilocks and the Three Books in declaring that I found Now Is Not the Time to Panic to be just right. I loved the nostalgia Now invokes for the ‘90s. I loved how the characters’ family dynamics made me wish Cameron Crowe would direct a big screen adaptation (because if ever there was a book that reads like a movie Crowe would write and direct, it’s this one). And I loved that I could picture any one of the kids from “Stranger Things” playing Frankie and Zeke if a big screen adaptation does indeed happen.My paperback of Now was an advanced reader copy, and for that I’m grateful. Because its opening pages included an essay from the author not included in the published version. Said essay details the origin story of the defining phrase of the book: “The edge is a shantytown filled with gold seekers. We are fugitives, and the law is skinny with hunger for us.” Turns out this phrase haunted Wilson much the way it haunts Frankie. The words were made up by a friend of his whose life was cut short in 2020, and Wilson dedicates the book to him. If you enjoyed Now as much as I did, I recommend reading this NPR interview about their relationship and why the two sentences have, for 25 years now, been “rattling around” in Wilson’s head....more

title: Dickens and Prince: A Particular Kind of Genius
author: Hornby, Nick
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I love that the Guardian describes this newest release from Nick Hornby as a “heartfelt exercise in hero worship,” because that’s EXACTLY what I foundI love that the Guardian describes this newest release from Nick Hornby as a “heartfelt exercise in hero worship,” because that’s EXACTLY what I found it to be as well—an in-depth look at a famed Victorian novelist and a famed modern-day musician who, on the surface, have nothing in common … until you dig deeper, as Hornby has done in this short little tome.The reality is that while it may be a stretch to make connections between this pair, it is a hell of a good time (if you are into literature, history, and musicology) to spend a few hours learning more about the lives of both these men—how (again, quoting the Guardian here) their “deprived childhoods fuelled their ambition, their precocious fame … their shrewd management of later setbacks in their careers.”I also was grateful to learn that, in all his exhaustive research, Hornby found that, with the exception of Sinead O’Connor’s account of a hellish night she spent with him, Prince was overall an ally to women. Evidence of this (of which there is plenty) made me feel better about still being a Prince fan, because shew…it’s a dwindling list of artists we can still admire full-stop, is it not?I normally wouldn’t give away a book’s ending, but this one resonated with me so much as a creative, that I’m going to include it here so I can come back to it myself every now and then:“What matters to me is that Prince and Dickens tell me every day, ‘Not good enough, not quick enough, not enough … more, more, more…think quicker, be more ambitious, be more imaginative.’ And whatever you do for a living, that’s something you need to hear every now and again. “Were they happy? Probably not. Were they crazy? Probably. That, too, is beyond the scope of this book. This book is about work, and nobody worked harder than these two, or at a higher standard, while connecting to so many people for so long. That’s why I have photos of them both on my office wall. They will stay there for as long as I need them, which will be for the rest of my life.”...more

review: Earlier this year, I read (and loved) Emily Giffin's latest, Meant to Be, a roman à clef of John F. Kennedy and Carolyn Bessette's relationship. AfterEarlier this year, I read (and loved) Emily Giffin's latest, Meant to Be, a roman à clef of John F. Kennedy and Carolyn Bessette's relationship. After I finished it, a friend of mine suggested I read Fairytale Interrupted, a memoir written by JFK Jr.'s longtime assistant, RoseMarie Terenzio.I guess 2022 is the year I re-up my fixation on this particular Kennedy because Terenzio's book did NOT disappoint. I appreciated her insights into working for John—stories about his kindness, his commitment to the magazine he co-founded (George, for anybody not alive in the '90s to remember it), even her stories about the times his behavior was less than perfect (with her and others) and how he worked to make things right when that happened. To read this book—or any book about John and Carolyn—is to long for a time when the world seemed less daunting ... when 9/11 hadn't happened, the Internet was nascent, and social media had yet to fracture our political landscape. I think so often (and not in a creepy QAnon way) about the promise of John—what office he might have aspired to and held eventually—were it not for his tragic death. But in reading Fairytale, it's clear no one "what if"s this idea more than RoseMarie, or "Rosie" as John always referred to her. In writing this book, she has given readers a very poignant and all-too humanizing glimpse into the final years of his beautiful life. How so many of us miss him still, quirky hats and all.[Technical critique: The only reason I didn't give this 5 stars is because the quality of the audiobook is not great. I kept reading, despite this criticism, but the publisher should think about re-recording it—still with RoseMarie reading—and this time in a better studio without so many glitchy cuts (and occasional car honks!) included.] ...more

review: In college, I majored in journalism, with a dual focus on news editorial writing and graphics. See, back when we had these things called newspapers, tIn college, I majored in journalism, with a dual focus on news editorial writing and graphics. See, back when we had these things called newspapers, there was an almost daily need to fill them with locator maps included with many news stories (ie, whenever there was an accident or robbery or something.) The reason I share this story is because I had to take a cartography class as part of the requirements for my major. And I thought this class was going to be cool (because I was a nerd who went into EVERY class she took in college thinking—hoping—it was going to be cool). Friends, it was not cool. And it made it so that any time I had to create a locator map for the college paper, I dreaded it. I thought of that class often as I read this book—a book I probably wouldn't have gotten around to were it not the November pick of my beloved book club. It's not that this book isn't well written. (It is). It just bored me (which is probably why I had to check it out twice to finish it). There's a lot of maps, a timeline-hopping mystery and a fair amount of magic involved to this story. And while I do appreciate there's an actual town of Agloe that inspired the author, this knowledge couldn't save me from feeling this book stole too many moments of my October that I could have spent reading something I loved more....more

review: I went into this audiobook hoping for an appropriately seasonal classic that would give me a good spook. That did not happen—not even a little bit! InI went into this audiobook hoping for an appropriately seasonal classic that would give me a good spook. That did not happen—not even a little bit! Instead I got to "meet" a cast of four main characters (Dr. Montague, Luke, Theodora, and Eleanor) who become proverbial boiling frogs inside the walls of a house that does (based on the strength of Jackson's writing in this respect) come across as well and truly cursed.The audio narration of this title was both good (in the sense that the narrator chose distinct voices to differentiate between the characters) and bad (in the sense that her choice for Eleanor's voice—breathy, child-like, verging on hysteria—eventually drove *me* insane, so much so I had to speed things up at the halfway point, listening to it on 1.5x until the end.) And about that ending. For those who've read it, was it not equal parts anti-climatic and abrupt?Consider me far from the camp of readers and ers who view this a perfect work. Despite my issues with it, I can admit that I (1) loved the idea of Eleanor's "cup of stars" (2) appreciated the repetitive tie-in of her "Journeys end in lovers meeting" and (3) think that the opening and closing lines of this book are in a class of their own (on par with the opening lines of Daphne du Maurier's Rebecca):“Hill House, not sane, stood by itself against its hills, holding darkness within; it had stood so for eighty years and might stand for eighty more.”...more

review: One of my best friends (hi Andy!) and I decided to tandem read something we’d never tackled from GoodRead’s list of 100 Years of Popular Books. Lo andOne of my best friends (hi Andy!) and I decided to tandem read something we’d never tackled from GoodRead’s list of 100 Years of Popular Books. Lo and behold, our first choice was Tennessee Williams’ Glass Menagerie. Given how much I enjoy the theater, I don’t know how I’ve made it 40 years having never seen OR read any of Williams’ work, but that changed as of last month, when I finished this title—the play that first made him famous—in just two sittings. I enjoyed it immensely, and soon after spent a good hour reading up on Williams’ life, everything from how he based the character of Laura on his sister to his ill-fated romance with Frank Merlo (a love affair that inspired this work of fiction I now want to read) to how fame became an albatross he wore around his neck. I’m grateful Andy and I decided to venture into this fun little reading challenge, and I already look forward to whatever we choose to read next from the list above. It’s an exercise that’s made for a nice reminder of how beneficial it can be to step out of our reading “comfort zones” every now and then. ...more

title: The Last Days of John Lennon
author: Patterson, James*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I picked this book up at the airport on a whim, having finished the read I brought along with me on my girls' trip to Arizona last month. Having neverI picked this book up at the airport on a whim, having finished the read I brought along with me on my girls' trip to Arizona last month. Having never read James Patterson, I sort of chuckled to myself, "Okay James, you titan of publishing, let's see what you have to teach me about John Lennon."Ummmm....turns out a lot? As big of a Beatles fan as I am, there was so much about John I should have/could have known but, in reading this book, realized I didn't. Case in point:— John wrote and recorded "Instant Karma! We All Shine On" in a matter of HOURS. He was a fast writer/producer of music, and his impatience in the studio for those who weren't was well known. — John and Elton John became good friends and collaborators in the '70s. Elton played piano/sang backup on the jangly "Whatever Gets You Through the Night" (the only solo No. 1 hit John ever had--which I've been listening to nonstop since finishing this book)— John was a huge influence (and friend of) David Bowie. Without John, there would be no "Fame" — For as rock-solid as I perceived John and Yoko's relationship, I had no idea that, for a short time in the '70s, Yoko sent him off to LA, where (with her blessing), she allowed him to enter into a relationship with her personal assistant, May Pang So yeah, a lot of learning going on for me about John's life post-Beatles. And while *of course* I knew about his assassination at the hands of Mark David Chapman, I didn't know the specific details surrounding that December night in 1980. Like the fact that, at the time of his death, John was the happiest he'd ever been. His and Yoko's Double Fantasy had just been released (the first new music he'd written in 5 years), and he was feeling good about his role as primary caregiver for Sean, the son he shared with Yoko (who was born on his birthday in 1975). As a 40 year old woman with a (soon to be) 5 year old daughter, it hit different knowing that, on the night he was gunned down, 40 year old John was taking a break from recording music because he wanted to return home to give goodnight kisses and hugs to his 5 year old son. I came to the final pages of this read more emotional than I anticipated, and more saddened than ever to think of all that living—and loving—John had stolen from him at the hands of an enormous creep who, just last month, was denied parole again for the TWELFTH time. ...more

title: I Have Some Questions For You
author: Makkai, Rebecca*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: To read this book is to pick up on all the headlines Rebecca Makkai ingested in the past 8 years, spinning them into a work of fiction that, at its beTo read this book is to pick up on all the headlines Rebecca Makkai ingested in the past 8 years, spinning them into a work of fiction that, at its best is a real page-turner and, at its worst, a labor of character study.The obvious “ripped from the headlines” storyline being the one that involves a podcaster reexamining whether a man serving prison time for the murder of a young woman was wrongfully convicted.Nine years ago, Americans held their breath as they listened to Sarah Koenig reveal the fraught story of Hae Min Lee and Adnan Syed in the cultural phenomenon of a podcast that was Serial. In Makkai’s version, the podcaster in question is Bodie Kane, the scene of the crime the New Hampshire boarding school she attended in her youth, the victim her former roommate, Thalia Keith, and the alleged perpetrator of Thalia’s murder the school’s Black athletic trainer, Omar Evans. I was easily caught up in the storyline above, despite moments when I thought Makkai’s various subplots and techniques didn’t always play well with the larger narrative at hand. (See: the recurring lists of unnamed women wronged by men; the #metoo storyline involving Bodie’s husband, Jerome; the second person POV that took some getting used to … it was all a LOT.) Even when Makkai lost herself to paragraph after paragraph of character backstory, I still kept reading. Because I’m a sucker for ‘90s nostalgia and her writing is that good, especially in the final act (which had that same propulsive feeling of reckoning I remember from binge listening Serial). Now that I’m finished, I’m still not sure how I feel about the book’s ending … and maybe that’s the point? It’s rare to want a follow-up to a work of literary fiction, but I’m curious where all these characters—Bodie, Fran, Geoff, Omar (even that asshole Denny Block!)—end up in the next five years. Aren’t you? I Have Some Questions for the Author• Was Bodie’s career inspired by Karina Longworth's? Readers who might be curious about what an episode of Bodie’s podcast would sound like should ABSOLUTELY check out Karina’s incredible podcast series, You Must Remember This. • Could you not have given us more scenes with a grown-up Bodie and Geoff? Even though it’s only February, that hotel room scene (specifically the moment Geoff recites lines from his  of “Pulp Fiction”) will go down as one of the best things I read in 2023.• Did you really have to make Bodie from Indiana? (Sorry, I’m just tired of reading works of fiction that shit on my home state.)• I’m guessing you gave Bodie her name in PART so you could work that clever Tom Petty riff into your book (still singing that in my head, thankyouvermuch!). review: I was fortunate to receive a gifted copy of this book from the author, a fellow Midwesterner who I've befriended on Instagram and whose s of booI was fortunate to receive a gifted copy of this book from the author, a fellow Midwesterner who I've befriended on Instagram and whose s of books I enjoy online. Laura Anne has done a tremendous job of penning a book that explores what it means to be young and to grapple with the grief that accompanies losing someone you love. What I also appreciated is how this book is a love letter to the Midwest, specifically Wisconsin in high summer. I want to encourage my children to read widely, and I believe that diversity in books should include geography as well as race, gender, ethnicity, and religion. Given the Midwest isn't represented in fiction as much as I'd like, my son was excited to discover the book's main character, Clare Burch, hails from outside of Chicago and loves to fish as much as him.For youngsters, this book offers up great age-appropriate themes—family strife, the comings and goings of friends, and how to make nice with bullies among them. Bonus: There's a cute dog in the mix! I recommend this read to children ages 8-12. As a parent, I especially enjoyed reading it aloud to my son (which I can't always say about the pacing of every book we read together!) ...more

review: I loved EVERYTHING about this new suspense story from Deanna Raybourn but my favorite part may have been the last three sentences of her “AcknowledgmeI loved EVERYTHING about this new suspense story from Deanna Raybourn but my favorite part may have been the last three sentences of her “Acknowledgments," in which she dedicates her newest novel to:“Every person who identifies female and has rage. I feel you sister. This one’s for you.”With that tone established, let me share that this read is perfect for anyone—especially any woman—who wishes more books featured older female protagonists like Helen, Mary Alice, Natalie, and Billie. This quartet of agents-gone-rogue are out to discover who’s trying to kill them on the eve of their retirement as badass female assassins. The escapades that result from their reconnaissance work take readers from the streets of New Orleans to the catacombs of Paris to the British countryside (with flashback chapters about their early days working for the “Museum” in between). Half the fun of Killers was determining which actresses I wanted to star as the book’s protagonists. Because this book HAS to be a movie. IT HASSSSSS TOOOOOO! I dare anyone to read this and not think it would be the perfect vehicle for any number of amazing actresses who, at present, have been relegated to secondary parts because Hollywood has deemed them “past their prime”!Here’s who I could see in each starring role:Billie— Holly Hunter (64)'s pint-sized toughness is perfect for this character, who has to get the most physical in her work (and with whom we spend the most time inside the head of, narratively speaking).Helen—Patricia Clarkson, 62, has the right combination of intellect and grace to pull off this character, someone nursing a big loss who is the most stoic member of the group after Billie. (I could also see Madeline Stowe, 64, given the character being written as a “Jackie Kennedy” type.)Mary Alice—While the author makes a point of noting all these characters are white (at least, from my reading of the text!) I could see 65-year-old Sheryl Lee Ralph (where my fellow Abbott Elementary fans at?!) playing her. I could also see Jamie Lee Curtis (63) in the role, with Michelle Yeoh, 60, playing her wife (which is really my way of wanting these two to team up again after their amazingness in Everything Everywhere All At Once). Natalie—Maybe it’s because I just read her memoir and listened to her podcast episode with Rob Lowe, but Jennifer Grey, 62, deserves a comeback role like this. Natalie is the tiniest, flirtiest, FUNNIEST gal of the whole bunch, and I had fun imagining what the pint-sized Jennifer would do with the character if given the chance. “The Shepherdess” Constance Halliday: Helen Mirren. Period. THERE IS NO ONE ELSE....more

title: Butts: A Backstory

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I sent screenshots from this book a half-dozen times to a few of my favorite girlfriends … each time with a note that read something to the effect of:I sent screenshots from this book a half-dozen times to a few of my favorite girlfriends … each time with a note that read something to the effect of: “Have you ever heard of Sara Baartman*?” or “I am now Googling Gordon Conway**—my new feminine crush of the past!” or “Did you know there's a woman*** whose ass is THE model for like, EVERY jean company?” Butts is one of THOSE types of books—the type that's one part cultural history, one part pop culture, one part how-is-this-not-a-6-part-podcast-series already? AND I LOVED IT.In covering everything from the giant bustles of the Victorian era to the rise of the Brazilian butt lift to the earworm-inducing popularity of Sir Mix-a-Lot’s “Baby Got Back”, author Heather Radke explores the many reasons that butts (women’s in particular) have been (in the words of the NYT) “described, displayed, and fetishized—and what that says about gender, race and more.”The cover of this one is great, but the content inside even better.* Sara Baartman was one of the first Black women to be subjected to human trafficking (taken from her home in South Africa in the late 1700s and brought to London where she was displayed as a “freak show” attraction on account of her extremely large butt)… I cannot believe I never knew about her before reading this, which is why I found the chapter devoted to her fascinating (and really effing sad)**Gordon Conway was an artist during the height of the Roaring 20s—she made more than 5,000 illustrations for major magazines (helping to popularize the flapper style of the era) and went on to design costumes for stage and film. I could watch a biopic about her and still want to know more!***said woman is Natasha Wagner and her story is so fascinating!...more

It’s rare for a book to portray death with such heart—even more rare for a hospice setting (oh Shapely!) to take center stage. But in sharing with readers the story of Ash and Edi, Newman brilliantly examines how (in the words of The Guardian) “even the deepest of losses can be accompanied by a joyous affirmation of life.” A pleasure to read, cover to cover—even when it made me cry. ***As if I didn’t laugh enough throughout this book, I came to the “About the Author” section and cackled upon reading these final three sentences: “This is [Catherine’s] first adult novel. review: Allow me to share a transcript of my inner monologue as I listened to Jennifer Grey’s FANTASTIC new memoir:Prologue: Dammmnnnnn her MOM is the one whoAllow me to share a transcript of my inner monologue as I listened to Jennifer Grey’s FANTASTIC new memoir:Prologue: Dammmnnnnn her MOM is the one who wanted her to get a nose job? That’s…so harsh!Chapter One: Wait…Jennifer is the daughter of JOEL GREY? The Broadway veteran (who I saw perform with Sutton Foster in Anything Goes?) HOW DID I NOT KNOW THIS?!) [Probably because I am an ‘80s baby and MUCH of ‘70s pop culture—including Joel’s performance in Cabaret—is lost to me…I still have never seen that iconic film!]Chapter 13: Oh yes, gimme ALLLLL the behind-the-scenes gossip about how Dirty Dancing came to be, Jennifer….this is what I came for ... [pauses audiobook to watch Dirty Dancing screentest ]Chapter 16: Holy HELL Jennifer was in a traumatic car crash with Matthew Broderick?! And it happened RIGHT before the Dirty Dancing premiere? HOW did I not know about this?! [Probably because I was 5 and it happened about 2 years before I started tuning into Entertainment Tonight, THE “show about the stars” you watched if you were obsessed with them—and I was—throughout much of the ‘80s and ‘90s]Chapter 18: Wait, wait, WAITTTTTT…Jennifer Grey was ENGAGED to Johnny Depp?!! HOLD THE PHONE. Chapter 21: [pauses audiobook to watch a montage of video clips of Jennifer with Derek Hough on Dancing with the Stars]Epilogue: Well how much did I LOVE this read? Is that…a tear in my eye? [sniff, sniff]On a parting note, I loved how Jennifer walked the fine line of holding the feet of past lovers (ahem, Matthew Broderick) to the fire in terms of the emotional ringer they put her through while at the same time owning up to her own role in the decisions she made that had a major impact on her life and her career. Below, I’m transcribing what she said in the final lines of the book, as she talked about how meaningful the experience of writing her memoir was and how she thinks memoir writing should be taught in schools, if only because it’s such a powerful exercise of reflection:“How might your retelling of your life change the way you see yourself [in your memoir]…what if the worst things ended up being some of the most transformative things? The things necessary to launch you into your next rendering? Until then, I offer you these scenes from my life … maybe your own memories rise up to meet them and your own life come back to you. Enjoy, it goes by so fast.”...more

review: You know that GIF that's popular of a blinking, speechless Carrie Bradshaw? That was basically me when I finished this brilliant—and all too believeabYou know that GIF that's popular of a blinking, speechless Carrie Bradshaw? That was basically me when I finished this brilliant—and all too believeable—book.Bruce Holsinger created an adrenaline-fueled narrative that kept me on the edge of my seat, a climate disaster scenario where the world's first Category 6 hurricane destroys Miami and Houston, forcing thousands (millions?) of IDPs (internally displaced persons) to flee.There are shady characters aplenty paired with dramatic plotlines that feel lifted from the headlines. And I couldn't help but reach its suspenseful conclusion wildly impressed by the talent it took for Holsinger to pull this story off—a story that required no small amount of research and felt like he had a crystal ball in his office and could look into our (bleak) future as he wrote it.Kirkus predicts this new release is "destined to be a blockbuster" while the NYT describes it as a "hypnotic," "upsetting" story that is a "thorough translation to fiction of what it can feel like to live right now."I believe both things to be true, just as I believe I'll still be thinking about this book with every climate change headline I read in the future. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you liked Demi Moore's memoir (which I did...very much!) then there's a good chance you'll enjoy Selma Blair's as well. I loved listening to Selma If you liked Demi Moore's memoir (which I did...very much!) then there's a good chance you'll enjoy Selma Blair's as well. I loved listening to Selma tell her life story to me—a story that begins with her unconventional upbringing in Michigan (an alcoholic for much of her life, Selma shares how her road to addiction started with stolen sips of Manischewitz wine at the family's seder at 7) and ends with her at home in Los Angeles, making peace with her MS diagnosis (one that followed years of debilitating symptoms that first began when she was a young girl). Like Demi, Selma had a crazy complicated relationship with her mother, and every nook and cranny of that relationship is explored in this memoir—as are many of her friendships with Hollywood A-listers. (I loved learning that her and Carrie Fisher were tight IRL!) My own sister has MS and I was reluctant to read this in fear of it triggering my anxiety about her condition. Instead, I was grateful for the way Blair describes what her days are often like—it made me realize that for people suffering from this incurable disease, sometimes just getting out of bed is the biggest victory of the day (which in turn makes me that much more empathetic toward my sis). A stellar celebrity memoir if you like your version of the genre served with a main course of "tortured artist" and a side order of A+ celebrity namedropping. Making it even better is the realization you'll have while reading that Selma really had her hand in writing this (unlike some celebs who you can tell rely heavily on their ghost writers). ...more

Ha!)I did NOT expect this story to take me on a dramatic thrill ride of following along (horrified!) as Allison makes a series of bad decisions that endanger her life and and then force her into a state of trauma-induced limbo until the book's final climatic scenes. But being in her head for the few hours it took me to read this short novel made for a "wholly unusual place to be".
