title: Growing Up Getty: The Story of America's Most Unconventional Dynasty
author: Reginato, James
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Back in July, I visited the Getty Villa in Malibu, California. It’s hard to describe how incredible the property is until you’ve taken your own (free)Back in July, I visited the Getty Villa in Malibu, California. It’s hard to describe how incredible the property is until you’ve taken your own (free) tour of it. But to summarize, billionaire John Paul Getty built the villa—a recreation of a Roman seaside home—to house the antiquities he’d acquired over his lifetime. (The kicker being he died before he could visit it, though he was later buried there.)While at the villa, I tapped my way through an interactive display about Getty’s life, but I was left wanting to learn more. I almost bought a biography from the gift shop, but the next morning, sipping coffee and paging through the July issue of Vanity Fair, I learned about this book instead.Weeks later, I can share I’m glad I listened to it, as it offers an in-depth look into a dynastic family known for many things—from fame and fortune (through oil) to various scandals and tragedies (not the least of which was the harrowing kidnapping of John Paul Getty III in 1973).The book’s author, James Reginato, is not out to vilify the family (as has been the case with so many articles and biographies, including the 2017 Ridley Scott film, “All the Money in the World” and the 2018 FX drama “Trust.) Instead, he paints a rather sympathetic portrait of Getty and his descendants, which include his five children and many grandchildren and great grandchildren. I had to stop the audiobook multiple times to learn more about each branch of the family tree. I then went on even more deep dives to learn about Getty's grandchildren and great-grandchildren, because I was so fascinated by so many of them. Among the more memorable members:— son John Paul Getty Jr. and his second wife, Talitha Pol, who was STUNNING. In the late ‘60s, their party pad in Marrakesh was THE place to be for London pop culture elite, including the Rolling Stones.— grandson Mark Getty, co-founder of Getty Images.— granddaughter Aileen Getty, once married to Christoper Wilding, son of Elizabeth Taylor, who's done much for AIDS research (as a sufferer of HIV herself) and climate change (she’s been arrested with good friend Jane Fonda as part of Jane’s recurring Fire Drill Friday movement). — great grandchild Nats Getty and wife Gigi Gorgeous, a fascinating couple for the Instagram/YouTube era if ever there was one!— great grandson Balathazar Getty (son of J. Paul Getty III), an actor who starred in one of my favorite mid-2000s dramas, ABC’s Brothers and Sisters.— Gordon and Ann Getty, who (for years) were as close to royalty as it comes on the San Francisco social scene and whose sons were tight with the Newsom clan (as in California Governor Gavin) as well as Kamala Harris and the Pelosis. — great granddaughter Ivy, whose lavish wedding last fall made a splash in the pages of Vogue (her mirrored dress was …just wow. WOW). Ivy's photographer, Jose Villa, is someone I've followed for years (as a former wedding photographer myself) and I was so happy for him that he landed a wedding as incredible as this one! I could go on about the reasons why I enjoyed this book, but I suspect I belong to a niche audience—one that regularly peruses society pages in publications like Vanity Fair and Vogue and who is always down for stories about famous American families (the first gift my hubby ever gave me was a biography of the Kennedys!) I’ll end this (long-winded)  by noting how impressed I am by the range of interests the Getty descendants have involved themselves in—from environmental causes to wineries to fashion to LGBTQ causes to feminist art…the list goes on. No family is perfect, but as Reginato points out, compared to some of their Forbes list counterparts, the Gettys are doing what they can to make good with the fame and fortune they’ve inherited thanks to their pioneering patriarch. How fascinating to watch their reach from afar ......more

review: This may be the most “quiet” book I’ve ever read. By that I mean, it’s 320 pages of reading about Laurie, a soon-to-be 40-year-old (40 being the magic age in publishing this year, no?) going through ALLLL the things left behind in her Great Aunt Dot’s estate and stumbling upon….a mysterious wooden duck?Yes, a wooden duck.If this plot sounds boring, it might be to some people. But these people would not be stans of Linda Holmes. And as a Linda Holmes stan myself, I can tell you I was sucked into this book from beginning to end. That’s because Linda writes characters who feel true, banter so good it deserves delivery on the big screen (seriously, get this woman a scriptwriting deal already!), and story laden with tons of delightful pop culture references (a nod to her work as a critic and writer in this realm for NPR). review: This book worked for me on so many levels, not the least of which is that, from the opening pages, I pictured Phoebe Bridgers as my version of the rocThis book worked for me on so many levels, not the least of which is that, from the opening pages, I pictured Phoebe Bridgers as my version of the rock star protagonist, Greta James.Once I did that, it was easy to get on board (literally!) with the storyline, one that finds Greta taking a week-long Alaskan cruise with her father as the pair come to terms with their grief over the sudden death of Greta’s mother.Throughout the journey there are arguments between Greta and her dad, cute moments of banter between Greta and her parents’ BFFs (also on board), and Greta’s burgeoning romance with fellow passenger, Ben. Given the fact Ben is written as a hunky bearded outdoorsman who happens to be both an author and doting father (attributes that also describe my own husband), I think it’s an easy guess as to why I fell pretty hard for Ben myself!So yeah, I loved this book. And as someone who's read several of Smith’s earlier novels, all set within the young adult world, it was lovely to see her make a seamless transition into the land of adult fiction. title: My Policeman
author: Roberts, Bethan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this novel for two reasons: (1) because I knew a film adaptation was in the works (one I cannot wait to watch, based on this trailer alone … anI read this novel for two reasons: (1) because I knew a film adaptation was in the works (one I cannot wait to watch, based on this trailer alone … and one for which I am especially excited to see how Harry Styles, aka My Summer 2022 Crush, portrays the titular character of Tom) and (2) because it’s PRIDE month—a month during which I make at least a few of my book selections based on a desire to flex my empathy muscles on behalf of the LGBTQ+ community. On that note, this novel is heartbreaking in that it relays the story of Marion (a timid school teacher), Tom (the hunk of a policeman she marries), and Patrick (the closeted museum curator who is Tom’s true love). It’s a love triangle set against the backdrop of 1950s Brighton (though it could have been any country at the time), and sadly, it’s a story that rings familiar for other works of fiction or non-fiction focused on this era in history (two that come to mind that I've read in recent years include John Boyne's The Heart’s Invisible Furies and Elon Green's Last Call). As much as I was sucked in by the lush prose of this novel, I was also transfixed by the WAY in which Roberts allowed the narrative to play out, alternating in time between Marion’s POV in the modern day and journal entries from Patrick from the ‘50s. There comes a twist late in the story that brought tears to my eyes—a twist that reminded me of how draconian the laws were at one time for anyone not cisgender or straight. And while I finished this book on vacation in early June, I typed this  on the same day I learned Roe v. Wade was struck down in the U.S.—a ruling for which Clarence Thomas wrote an opinion targeting other Supreme Court rulings that protect same-sex relationships and same-sex marriage in America. Where we go from here, I don’t know, but I’m legitimately frightened by the future intentions of this current court. It’s because of this fear that I worry about the fate of today’s Toms and Patricks who may soon lose their rights to love and marry who they legally want. PS —I did not know, until I did a small amount of research writing this , that My Policeman is Roberts’ reimagining of the real-life relationship between E.M. Forster, policeman Bob Buckingham, and his wife. I’m fascinated by this fact—and the way in which Forster keeps turning up in  recent reads of mine! ...more

title: Beautiful Country
author: Wang, Qian Julie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I started this book last month to coincide with AAPI Heritage Month, but it took me a little longer to finish it as my reading bled into June. To recaI started this book last month to coincide with AAPI Heritage Month, but it took me a little longer to finish it as my reading bled into June. To recap, this memoir belongs in that genre of books I like to call Beautiful but Hard Reads™. In it, Qian Julie Wang recounts her years living as an impoverished, undocumented child in New York City—years that weren’t all that long ago (Qian is only 34), thus making her narrative all the more jarring to read. Listening to Beautiful Country (which Qian narrates), I was reminded of how I felt listening to Trevor Noah’s Born a Crime. As in, it’s hard to reconcile the idea that while this little Chinese-born girl was sitting somewhere in Brooklyn, reading her Babysitter’s Club books** with an empty stomach and a single change of dingy clothes, I was living only a couple states away, reading my own copies of those same books from the comfort of my middle class, two-story home.Overall, what I appreciated most about Beautiful Country was how insightful Wang’s memories were of her childhood. In that sense, I feel like if you are a fan of Ashley Ford’s brilliant Somebody’s Daughter, you’ll be moved in a similar way by the clarity and charm of Wang’s powerful coming-of-age story.**On a happier note, I started following Qian on Instagram after finishing her book, and this post—in which Ann M. Martin sends her a curated box of BSC books and a hand-written note—made my heart beat fast, because is there a greater gift to give a girl who grew up in the ‘80s/‘90s worshipping this stellar YA series?! I think not! ... What a beautiful full-circle moment that must have been for Qian....more

To the unfamiliar, Meant to Be is a roman à clef of John F. Kennedy and Carolyn Bessette's relationship—an attempt by the author to humanize this beautiful couple many of us stanned throughout the '90s. And because I expected Joe and Cate's story to play out the same way as their real-life counterparts, I found myself unprepared for my emotional reaction to the book's climatic ending. (view spoiler)[Giffin's choice to have Joe and Cate survive the plane crash, to give them a HEA in which the couple look to Joe's run for office with their children at their side, left me teary-eyed because isn't that what we all wished would have happened IRL? (hide spoiler)]I'm glad Giffin included an "Author's Note" with Meant to Be (one that establishes her personal feelings about JFK Jr and Carolyn, what she was doing in her life when their plane crash in 1999 stunned the world, and why she felt so compelled to write this story). And now, as is true to my running theme of 2022, I'm off to wrap myself up in the comforts of '90s nostalgia as I continue to look up photos of this gorgeous pair and wonder again (like Giffin) "What if?"...more

review: The first half of this novel had me in solid 3-star territory. It wasn't that the writing wasn't good. (Celeste Ng's writing is always good). I just sThe first half of this novel had me in solid 3-star territory. It wasn't that the writing wasn't good. (Celeste Ng's writing is always good). I just struggled to connect with the character and there was a LOT of telling to the story. (So many sentences of description about various things! Enough with the descriptions of all the things!)Then, the second half took off, approaching 5-star territory, especially with the conclusion.So yeah, a 4-star read it is for me. If you decide to pick this one up, be mindful that the book is essentially the author's attempt to:• grapple/process with a shocking rise in AAPI hate in recent years. • grapple/process with a world-defining crisis (but swap out the COVID-19 pandemic for a brutal economic collapse that happens around the same time...at least, I think?).• and, most importantly, grapple/process with our nation's ongoing (appalling) ability to take children from families. STILL! (To that point, I thought of #ourmissinghearts just yesterday as I read about the Supreme Court hearing oral arguments in a case centering on the Indian Child Welfare Act.) Maybe I've just hit my fill on dystopian/fascistic fiction for the year, but the above points are all reasons why this buzzy fall release ended up being my least favorite of Ng's books. ...more

title: I'll Show Myself Out: Essays on Midlife and Motherhood
author: Klein, Jessi
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I started listening to I’ll Show Myself Out from comedian Jessi Klein on Mother’s Day, which made for the perfect day to dive into this bold collectioI started listening to I’ll Show Myself Out from comedian Jessi Klein on Mother’s Day, which made for the perfect day to dive into this bold collection of essays that tackles the topic of parenthood with “brutal honesty, candid emotion, and humor” (Publishers Weekly).I was only a few essays in before I was ready to press this book into the hands of every woman I know who, like me, is between the ages of 30 and 40 and the parent of young children. “Read this so you don’t feel so alone or misunderstood," I want to say to them. "Also, so you can laugh a lot. Because you need a dose of that right now.”Any mother who's being honest and secure enough with herself can admit this role is TOUGH (despite social media influencers who want to convince us otherwise). So I appreciate someone who, with essays like “The Car Seat” and “Bread and Cheese” (about the tendencies of children who are picky eaters) validates the modern-day frustrations of a job that is simultaneously the most challenging and most rewarding that most of us will ever take on. In PW’s starred- of this read, mention is given to how, in between moments of hilarity, Klein drops in unexpected glimpses of joy—her reminder that “being a parent is a lot like having a dream … Most of it, even when it’s ugly, is beautiful.”It might take being a parent to unpack those words, but I whole-heartedly endorse the sentiment.Also, if you do wind up reading this one, audio is 100 percent the way to go. Klein does an excellent job with the narration. I was sad to reach the end, having taken an odd degree of comfort in the dry delivery and dark humor of her words. Related: One of my favorite essays in the book is “An Open Love Letter to Nate Berkus and Jeremiah Brent". It’s a lovely little read, but even MORE lovely was seeing how the power couple surprised her during her May 19, 2022 appearance on the TODAY Show.An excellent Vanity Fair interview with Klein, who, by now, has become a comedic author crush of mine. Jessi, will you be my Nate Berkus and Jeremiah Brent?!...more

review: Pardon the crass (and gendered) term, but it takes real cahones to write a novel about a sport one does not play. And yet, despite being "really out oPardon the crass (and gendered) term, but it takes real cahones to write a novel about a sport one does not play. And yet, despite being "really out of her zone" with the subject material presented in her latest novel, TJR delivers a narrative about a No. 1 female tennis player so utterly convincing, I felt like I had a front row (players’ box) seat to her entire fictional career. Even when I struggled with this story (and struggle I did…at least in the first 50-60 pages, with the Spanish dialogue cropping up in a way I initially found distracting), I still admired what TJR was doing with Carrie and the cast of secondary characters who surround her, most notably her Argentinian born father, Javier.By the time I reached the final third of the book, a series of compelling events (view spoiler)[starting with Javier’s death, followed by Bowe’s demonstrative love for Carrie, on to the final exhilarating match between her and her marvelously rendered rival, Nicki Chan (hide spoiler)] had me turning the pages so quickly, tears pricking my eyes, that I hated to come to its end. That bittersweet feeling is no different from how I’ve felt finishing every novel TJR has written. The exception here being, with Carrie Soto, I think TJR’s gutsy talent has finally met her unapologetic ambition at a level few other contemporary authors dare aspire to. title: Mrs. Frisby and the Rats of Nimh
author: O'Brien, Robert C.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I was a kid, I read voraciously (a truth that likely applies to many of us on GoodReads). And one of the books that stands out in my memory as anWhen I was a kid, I read voraciously (a truth that likely applies to many of us on GoodReads). And one of the books that stands out in my memory as an early favorite is Mrs. Frisby and the Rats of NIMH. The copy I owned was a hand-me-down from a relative, and I can still picture its white cover and purple text on the shelf of my childhood bookcase. What I can also still picture is the VHS cassette cartridge we kept next to our (new!) VCR that contained our family’s copy of the Don Bluth animated film, The Secret of NIMH (released in 1982, the same year I was born).Let me pause and say that you know you’re an ‘80s baby if you recall the best animated films of your childhood—American Tail, All Dogs Go to Heaven, Land Before Time—as Don Bluth films. (I mean, Disney is great and all, butttttt their studio flicks of that era had nothing on Don’s work. Just thinking of Littlefoot with his dying mother STILL brings tears to my eyes. Shew!)Where was I? Oh, right …..talking rats. I knew at some point I would introduce my kids to Mrs. Frisby. And that glorious moment with my 9-year-old son happened this spring, as I read him this timeless classic about a tiny widowed mouse and her relationship to a mischief of extraordinarily intelligent rats. The best part? He loved the story every bit as much as I did. And this weekend, we’re tracking down the animated film so we can watch it together. That, in a nutshell (or a rat’s nest), is what we call the “good stuff” of parenting, if I do say so myself....more

review: Oh man, how I love Katie Cotugno. I discovered her work years ago when I read one of her novels and fell hard for how well she wrote a certain sub-genOh man, how I love Katie Cotugno. I discovered her work years ago when I read one of her novels and fell hard for how well she wrote a certain sub-genre of young adult fiction—the kind dedicated to fast-paced plots, troubled boys, multi-facetd girls, and pop culture nods galore.It was a delight to discover that, with the release of her adult debut, “Birds of California,” she has carried that talent and voice through a seamless transition into the Land of Grown-Up Fiction.In “Birds,” the focus of the story is Fiona St. James, a young actress whose life has gone off the rails since starring in a (believably pitched) WB-style family drama called Birds of California. I read Fiona as Jessica Biel wanting out of 7th Heaven and finding her exit ramp via a series of troubling acts that draw the attention of the paparazzi (a la Britney Spears at the height of her public meltdown). Fiona has gone back to as normal a life a possible in the wake of that era of her life—until the day she’s paid a visit by the actor, Sam Fox, who played her older brother on the series. Sam is a himbo of sorts (picture a young Justin Hartley if This is Us had never taken off) struggling to find his next steady acting gig and therefore needing the money promised with the pitch of a sequel to Birds. What happens when he tries to convince Fiona to join in on the reboot is what makes the sparks—and banter—between these two fly. This one is a perfect read for your upcoming summer vacation. And bonus: Thanks to that eye-catching cover, it’ll look great next to the cocktail you order poolside and then photograph for that “Out of Office” post you plan on sharing with all your Instagram followers. ...more

review: The elements that worked for me in Black Cake worked REALLY well. By that I mean, I appreciate Charmaine Wilkerson using her fiction to shine a spotliThe elements that worked for me in Black Cake worked REALLY well. By that I mean, I appreciate Charmaine Wilkerson using her fiction to shine a spotlight on so much ethnocultural history missing from our textbooks.A few examples are the way she weaves into her story accounts of the Chinese immigrant experience in the Caribbean; the complicated origin story of black cake; the mass immigration of Afro-Caribbeans to the UK; and, most tragically, the forced adoptions in that country that went on for decades. Had Wilkerson winnowed down the length of this book, cut a few points of view (did we really need that one-off chapter from Marble’s mother?) and nixed a few of the “‘issues’ and ‘soapbox moments’ that aren’t seamlessly woven into the narrative” (as er Melissa so aptly describes), then this would have been a 5-star read for me.As it was, I found Black Cake a bit disjointed and longggg for my taste. Despite these narrative hang-ups, I have no regrets in reading this imaginative novel, and I respect why, for many, it was among their favorite debuts of last year....more

title: Dolly Parton, Songteller: My Life in Lyrics
author: Parton, Dolly
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: God bless Dolly Parton, am I right? I listened to this on audio because I wanted her voice (that iconically sweet Tennessee accent of hers!) to be froGod bless Dolly Parton, am I right? I listened to this on audio because I wanted her voice (that iconically sweet Tennessee accent of hers!) to be front and center as I was reading these stories. And I'm glad I did. But at multiple points, I found myself (more than any other audiobook I've read) wishing I had the physical copy alongside me for reference. Mostly because the audio here was recorded in such an anecdotal way I came to believe what I was actually listening to were the interview clips Dolly's co-writer (Robert Oermann) used to help him write the book. This wasn't a bad thing (I cannot tell you how much I giggled hearing Dolly—in her own words—acknowledge "I just love horny songs!" or "They'll do anything for a titty joke!") but I was left wishing I felt more grounded in the timeline of her life (with, say, photos from each era of her career). The chronological references seemed to jump around (confusing me a bit), and the interludes from the male narrator were stiff compared to the warmth and goodness that exuded from Dolly herself.Overall, I'm so glad I listened to this, as I learned quite a bit about Dolly's upbringing and how stifled she felt by the early influence of her creative partner, Porter Wagner. I loved hearing how open Dolly was to collaborating with other artists, especially those (like Whitney Houston) who took her work and made it their own. And while I wish I could have listened to snippets from each of the 175 songs she wrote about (handpicked from the more than 3,000 (!!!) songs she has written over the course of her career), I know it might have taken me until 2023 to read this book had that been the case! A wonderful showcase of Dolly's charm and wit, with her commitment to her roots and her care for her community evident throughout the text. May she live on wearing the crown of "Ageless American Sweetheart" that Betty White (#RIP) has passed down to her. ...more

title: Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow
author: Zevin, Gabrielle*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are books that, within the first 20 to 30 page, you know are going to be special. Maybe not to everyone, but to you in particular.Within the firThere are books that, within the first 20 to 30 page, you know are going to be special. Maybe not to everyone, but to you in particular.Within the first half-hour of meeting Sam Masur and Sadie Green, game loving strangers-turned-best friends, I knew that’s how I was going to feel about Gabrielle Zevin’s Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow.I don’t know how much of my obsession with this knockout novel is because I, like Sadie, LOVED Oregon Trail growing up (the book’s running “SADI MIRANDA GREEN. YOU HAVE DIED OF DYSENTERY!” joke is its most endearing) OR if it’s because I serendipitously read this novel while on vacation in Los Angeles (where much of the book is set), but I DO know I will spend the rest of 2022 trying to convince everyone I know to read it.And while I’m not much of a gamer (that season of my life ended with beating Super Mario Brothers at 12), I would happily while away an afternoon playing any one of Sadie and/or Sam’s brilliant games … oh, what’s that? I CAN play Emily Blaster? For REAL?!! BRAVO, KNOPF! +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++On a personal note, while on said vacation to L.A., I had this sixth sense thought of ‘You were meant to live in this city.' It’s something I was struggling to come to terms with (like, did I live here in another life? in another…multiverse?) until I came across this moving paragraph in Tomorrow that reminded me I wasn’t alone in sitting with this feeling:“On the night Sam went missing, it occurred to Sadie nothing in life was as solid-state as it appeared. A childish game might be deadly. A friend might disappear. And as much as a person might try to shield herself from it, the possibility for the other outcome was always there. We are all living, at most, half of a life, she thought. There was the life that you lived, which consisted of the choices you made. And then, there was the other life, the one that was the things you hadn’t chosen. And sometimes, this other life felt as palpable as the one you were living. Sometimes, it felt as if you might be walking down Brattle Street, and without warning, you could slip into this other life, like Alice falling down the rabbit hole that led to Wonderland. You would end up a different version of yourself, in some other town. But it wouldn’t be strange like Wonderland, not at all. Because you would have expected all along that it could have turned out that way. You would feel relief, because you had always wondered what that other life would have looked like. And there you were.”Just … chills.And to end this (rambling)  on a silly note, while there are literally 1,000 reasons for me to love this novel, the fact Gabrielle Zevin models the character of Marx (OOOHHHHH MARX, HOW I LOVE YOU SO!) on Keanu Reeves is definitely my superficial favorite!...more

author: Espach, Alison
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Every now and then I stumble upon a book that surprises me in a way that makes me sit up and pay attention. That’s how I felt with Notes On Your SuddeEvery now and then I stumble upon a book that surprises me in a way that makes me sit up and pay attention. That’s how I felt with Notes On Your Sudden Disappearance, a 2022 release I bought during an e-book sale for $2 last year after spying it pop up on a number of friends’ reading lists. Having finally gotten around to it myself, I feel like it’s one that’ll stick with me for a while. In part because it’s rare that I enjoy a book written in second person (there’s always a whiff of too much ‘try’ involved with that POV), but here? I thought it worked brilliantly. And as a ‘90s baby myself (I would have been about the same age as Kathy*** circa 1998), so much of this novel resonated with me, culturally speaking. At various points, I even found myself nostalgic for my own dog days of summer, staying up until 2 am with my best friend watching re-runs of trash talk TV. (I loved all the mentions of Jillian Williams in this book, a stand-in for Jerry Springer-Ricky Lake-Jenny Jones if ever there was one). Given the book’s plot centers around a car accident involving a teenager, this, too, made me think of my high school years. Namely because a classmate of mine lost a sister in a similar accident when I was a freshman. And really, don’t we all have an experience like this from our formative years? One in which we are forced to learn too soon that death can, indeed, come for the young? Alison Espach captures this particular tragedy in an extremely evocative and poignant way. ***My one petty gripe with this book is the fact that Sally (our protagonist)'s sister is named Kathy. Given her birth year (early '80s?), that is … not a popular name from that era. Jessica? Yes. Heather? Yes. Jennifer? ABSOLUTELY. So yeah, even though it felt like we hardly got to know her, I really wanted Kathy to have a more timely name. But hey, this is coming from a Gail born in 1982, so maybe Kathy was named after her great grandmother, too! ...more

review: A common refrain about this book in various s here on GoodReads is that it's a title where the cover is deceiving and ... I can agree with that.A common refrain about this book in various s here on GoodReads is that it's a title where the cover is deceiving and ... I can agree with that. Of course, within the rom-com genre, it fits right in to the trend of illustrated covers. But the writing in this book is so good—and the plot so layered—that I agree with Lily's take that there was a missed opportunity to catch a wider audience with a cover look more like that of Tia Williams' Seven Days in June.Never mind this minor pet peeve, let's talk about what happens between the pages of How to Fake It, shall we? This is a book that, chapter by chapter, reveals a steamy love story that pairs an up-and-coming starlet (Grey) with an A-list superstar (Ethan) in a fake romantic relationship that is believable as hell.So much so that, when I read up about its author, I was shocked to learn she lives in Oklahoma and has no attachment to the industry or to LA aside from a lifelong fascination with celebrities (kindred spirits on this front, we are--ha!) I loved picturing the stars I could see serving as Wilder's inspiration for Grey (Blake Lively) and Ethan (Ben Affleck), and I also admired how tenderly Wilder treated Ethan's relationship to his ex-wife, Nora, as well as the friendship that eventually blossoms between Nora and Grey.A fabulous first-time effort from this author—one that has me excited to read whatever she writes next! ...more

review: I listened to Phoebe's first collection of essays on audio and really enjoyed them, which is the reason I thought I'd feel the same upon checking thisI listened to Phoebe's first collection of essays on audio and really enjoyed them, which is the reason I thought I'd feel the same upon checking this newest collection of hers out from the library. But (and I hate to admit this because I like her so much) this newest book of Phoebe's was sort of a mixed bag reading experience for me. The first few essays were mostly Phoebe (sort of shouting?) her laments about how 2020 wasn't the year she thought it was going to be (helloooo pandemic) and how she DOESN'T WANT KIDS SO LEAVE HER ALONE ABOUT IT ALREADY. The experience of listening to those essays was just shy of off-putting enough for me to consider returning the book early.BUT ....I'm glad I didn't. Because as the book continued, I found myself enjoying more of her later essays that (topically speaking) allowed her talent for on-point cultural criticism to shine. I especially enjoyed "Black Girl, Will Travel" (about her eye-opening experiences traveling while Black) and her essay "Please Don't Sit on My Bed in Your Outside Clothes" (even if I found her commitment to refusing to allow 'outside' clothes to touch her bed to be a bit OTT ... like, is that how Howard Hughes' germ phobia started?)I also really loved Phoebe's essay on being a boss, which provided inspiration and insights into the"mini empire" she has built for herself in recent years as a writer/comedian/podcaster and master mind behind the new publishing imprint, Tiny Reparations. One of the titles from said imprint (Portrait of a Thief) is on my short stack of 2022 Must Reads ... to which I say, kudos Phoebe for being such a baller that I'm tired just thinking of what your definition of work-life balance must look like. ...more

review: A scene from my marriage that played out while reading Julia May Jonas’ debut:Husband: “You might want to think twice about being seen reading that boA scene from my marriage that played out while reading Julia May Jonas’ debut:Husband: “You might want to think twice about being seen reading that book right now.”Me: “Why? Because of the scandalous [said in my best mocking tone] cover?”Husband: “Nope. Because of the title. Just thinking of a certain Vladimir in the news right now.”Oof. The timing! My husband’s jests aside, I am so glad I read this book because I LOVED IT. Here are the types of people I think would love it along with me:1) Anyone working in academia: The author nails the current climate of higher ed, in particular the way sexual politics have changed post-#MeToo movement. 2) Anyone (and this is related to 1) above) who enjoyed the Netflix series, “The Chair”: It’s interesting, isn’t it, how so many novels and films with Ivory Tower settings happen to involve professors from English departments?3) Anyone who loves unlikeable female narrators: The unnamed narrator of this novel got under my skin in a good way—a way that made me want to add her to my list of favorite female literary “baddies” (said list also includes Olive from “Olive Kitteridge” and Amy Dunne from “Gone Girl”)4) Anyone who appreciates living in the head of a woman who thinks in descriptive passages like this:“[Vladimir] wore a knit tie with an engraved tie bar over a checked shirt with rolled-up sleeves, well-cut pants, and good-quality leather boots with thick white soles. Clearly a transplant from the city–no heterosexual man who’d spent much time here would look like that. Even my husband, a vain man with a taste for expensive Irish knit sweaters, had forgotten the specificity and light irony of urban style. My husband wore what he wore because he believed in it—he had lost the sense of costuming and presentation that well-dressed city dwellers naturally possessed. That perambulating sense of always being on display.”Overall, this novel was dark, insightful, and revealing in an extremely honest way that I very much appreciated. My only qualm with it might be with the ending (did not see the last act coming! would love to discuss it with others!). Still, I'm giving it 5 stars, because I think, by year’s end, it’ll wind up being one of my favorite novels of 2022—a novel that, for certain, I won’t soon forget!...more

review: I really enjoyed this book, which, on the surface, is the story of two Taiwanese American best friends whose lives (both together and apart) reveal thI really enjoyed this book, which, on the surface, is the story of two Taiwanese American best friends whose lives (both together and apart) reveal themselves in chapters that function as a series of linked stories. What I especially loved, as I got a little deeper into the narrative, is how the major theme of the book is this relatable rumination on how even the closest of friendships go through periods best defined as droughts. Because of my age, I also appreciated how Fiona and Jane experienced teenhood in the 1990s. This fact led to more than a few scenes that made me smile with recognition, from their cruising in Fiona's hoopty Shamu, listening to Salt-N-Pepa, to their navigating the halls of high school surrounded by boys "drenched in Cool Water cologne". Capturing a few passages here that so vividly capture what it can be like to have a best friend from childhood that has carried over into adulthood:"She'd introduced her to Willy as 'my best friend,' though in truth they'd hardly kept in touch. A distance between them Fiona felt acutely, marked by unspoken things, added up. She knew the contours of Jane's life, not its interior. If Fiona moved back to LA, what would their friendship be like—no longer held aloft by the nostalgia for their high school years, the romance of their present distance?""I still thought of her as my best friend, though more and more she was becoming a story to me, one whose plot I couldn't make sense of because either I was missing information or maybe I'd forgotten something from before—something important—and it was too late to ask about it now, because it would mean admitting I hadn't been paying attention. review: Midway through listening to John Green read his first work of nonfiction to me, I realized he would make for one hell of an addition to a trivia team.Midway through listening to John Green read his first work of nonfiction to me, I realized he would make for one hell of an addition to a trivia team. Because really, what doesn't the man know? I can't comprehend how his brilliant mind can hold so much! Obviously he does his research, but his capacity—no matter the topic—to toss in the perfect quote from a famous author or poet or artist elevates the material he presents in these pages in a way I couldn't get enough of ... no really, had this book been 20 hours long, I would have kept listening! The timing of this one is perfect for those of us still raw from the emotional (and in some cases, physical) wounds of the pandemic. Namely because John wrote large swaths of it in the middle of 2020 (and writes candidly—and cathartically—about the experience). In one  of the book I came across, the reader notes Anthropocene is "an odd book to define but very easy to recommend." I couldn't agree more. And in homage to the final line of each chapter, I type (while hearing John's voice in my ear) "I give The Anthropocene Reviewed 5 stars."PS — My favorite essay was the one on "Auld Lang Syne." review: Gotta say, I did not have “You will be bowled over by Molly Shannon’s memoir” on my 2022 bingo card. And yet, here I am, telling you how much I FIVE-SGotta say, I did not have “You will be bowled over by Molly Shannon’s memoir” on my 2022 bingo card. And yet, here I am, telling you how much I FIVE-STAR loved this read.If you have even an ounce of interest in picking this title up, but your familiarity with Molly centers mostly on your knowledge of her impressive run on Saturday Night Live**, then do NOT read any more s or press she’s done for this book. Seriously, don’t even Google her!I say this because I want you (like me) to have the experience of being fully stunned by the first 10 minutes of this book (.... or however many pages that turns out to be; I don’t know, because I listened to this on audio, which is absolutely how I recommend you experience this one.)Molly’s life is a rollercoaster of highs and lows, and she’s such a first-class storyteller that she had me hooked from the get go. Having read this, I can now say how much I admire her resiliency (as an actor, but, more importantly, as a person). I also very much loved her stories from her time at SNL as well as the tender way she talked about the dysfunctional yet dear relationship she had with her dad.For those of you who have read this, I wish I could talk with you in person about some of my favorite stories from the book. (For me, the highlights reel includes: her dad cleaning the house on speed! that time she snuck onto a flight to NYC as a child! her Gary Coleman encounter! the David Mamet scheme! and the origin story of Mary Katherine Gallagher!) If you’re in the mood for a book that will make you laugh, make you feel more grateful to be alive, and might even leave you with tears streaming down your face in its final few minutes, this memoir (with its bag of dramatic twists!) is the book for you. **Molly Shannon’s years on SNL—1995 to 2001—coincided with my years in junior high/high school. When I say I was obsessed with SNL at this age, I mean I.WAS.OBSESSED. (My best friend and I had the “Superstar” tees we bought from Spencer’s to prove it. Ha!) From Molly to Will Ferrell to Cheri Oteri to Ana Gasteyer, every cast member from that era was beloved. So, it was a nice gift of nostalgia to read this book, to remember how much Molly’s fearless comedy added to the show, and to reflect back on allll those happy Saturday nights I spent glued to the TV with my best friends by my side....more

review: Watching Viola Davis shout out “I just EGOT!!!” from the Grammy stage last month was all the reminder I needed to finally listen to this powerful memoWatching Viola Davis shout out “I just EGOT!!!” from the Grammy stage last month was all the reminder I needed to finally listen to this powerful memoir of hers.Davis’ (literal) rags-to-riches story is so raw, so real, and, in so many ways, so unbelievable, that at times I was like, “Not even an author would put a fictional character through such horrific conditions.” Truly, the poverty, the abuse, and the rats (LITERAL RATS! shudder) that Davis endured on her way to becoming one of Hollywood’s most talented actors is next level. I was already a huge fan, but I have a whole new respect for her after learning about her traumatic past and how her decades-long dedication to her craft finally paid off as an artist. She is a remarkable storyteller, and her narration of Finding Me is impeccable—truly the best way to experience this bestseller is on audio. PS — I especially loved: the tea Viola spills about getting paid in Hollywood and the lack of opportunities for Black actors, especially those as dark as she is (she’s so transparent about an industry cloaked in mystery); the affirmation of how amazing George Clooney is as a person (as is, apparently, his villa in Italy!); and how Viola’s faith journey led her directly to her husband (as a Christian, that story in particular gave me goosebumps!) ...more

review: There came a point about mid-way through Brendan Slocumb’s debut, “The Violin Conspiracy,” where I thought,  Wow, this author is really putting his maThere came a point about mid-way through Brendan Slocumb’s debut, “The Violin Conspiracy,” where I thought,  Wow, this author is really putting his main character, Rayquan McMillian, through the ringer of racism and bigotry. And for a moment, I wondered if he could have held back on that front, given how tough those scenes were, both for Ray and for the reader.Then I read Brendan’s “Author’s Note,” wherein he revealed many of the racially motivated incidents that Ray encounters as a violinist also happened to him in his own musical career and even though I should know better by now, I was still pretty floored.White people can really suck sometimes, huh?Putting those polarizing thoughts aside, I was completely taken with this book. Reading about what it takes to be a classical musician—the preparation, the thrill of performing, the competitiveness of it all—was such an engrossing experience. Add to it that Rayquan (Ray for short) is a minority performer in his genre (IRL, less than 2 percent of the world’s classical musicians are Black) and there was an element of raised stakes for him to be twice as good as his peers.With that set up in mind comes the novel’s compelling “whodunnit” plot: When Ray discovers that the fiddle he owns—an heirloom passed down from his grandmother—is a rare Stradivarius worth $10 million, he finds himself on the fast track to becoming one of the country’s most celebrated artists. But as he prepares for a major international competition, his beloved Strad is stolen. He then spends the rest of the story piecing together who nabbed it. Was it the descendants of the man who enslaved his great-great grandfather? Or one of his greedy family members? The answer kept me turning the pages, in awe both of Ray’s resilience and Brendan’s ability to write such a wonderfully suspenseful novel that revealed an ending I did not see coming. Bravo! Related read: This NPR book , ‘Thriller ’The Violin Conspiracy’ addresses racism in classical music’...more

title: Best. Movie. Year. Ever.: How 1999 Blew Up the Big Screen
author: Raftery, Brian
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I’ve decided 2022 is the year I lean into my “fetishistic fondness” (as writer Kurt Andersen describes it) for the ‘90s. Given the uncertain era we’reI’ve decided 2022 is the year I lean into my “fetishistic fondness” (as writer Kurt Andersen describes it) for the ‘90s. Given the uncertain era we’re living through, it feels like a warm hug to “transport” back in time to a decade when our country was prospering on so many levels, particularly the pop culture front.For proof, a person need look no further than entertainment writer Brian Raftery’s “Best.Movie.Year.Ever: How 1999 Blew Up the Big Screen.”This book was SUCH a delight for a pop culture nerd like me. What I especially loved is how Brian contextualizes the moment a true bumper crop of amazing films—from “Being John Malkvoch” to “Election” to “The Sixth Sense”—hit the big screen. Was it the hyperbolic BEST year for films? Maybe not, but it sure comes close and Raftery makes a convincing argument as to why. Personally, I was a junior/senior in high school in 1999 and I LIVED at the cinema. Every weekend, the theater was a destination for me and my boyfriend (usually) or my cluster of best friends. To tell you how amazing 1999 was in film, Raftery doesn’t even include the year’s mega-hit sequels to franchises like Toy Story and Austin Powers. Nor does he pay attention to the great grown-up rom-coms of 1999, from “Never Been Kissed” to (my personal fave) “Notting Hill.” While that’s a miss on his end, this book can only be so long, and I appreciate that he chose instead to veer into the rise of teen rom-coms that took off that year with the likes of “She’s All That” and “Ten Things I Hate About You.” Setting aside this minor quibble, overall I agreed with the smorgasbord of films Raftery included in “Best,” with my favorite chapters focusing on “Office Space,” “The Matrix,” “Blair Witch,” and “Boys Don’t Cry.” I also enjoyed the deep dive he did on a few others, including “Fight Club” and “Magnolia,” as his commentary contextualized those films in a way my young 17-year-old brain was too immature to understand at the time. Lastly, I appreciate that Raftery ends his book with an epilogue that points to why we (sadly) are past an era when another cinematic 1999 feels possible. (See: ‘we don’t go to movies to be challenged anymore,’ the Marvel-ification of Hollywood, and the rise of the ‘golden era’ of TV). Overall, this was a great recap of why 1999 was, as Raftery describes, “a near miraculous year of movies, full of original stories from exciting new voices.” Thanks, Brian, for taking me back for a few hours to relive it....more

Sarah Winman's writing is like no one else’s—her words are equal parts clever, sophisticated, and big-hearted. And with her newest novel, “Still Life,” she has accomplished the rare feat of making me laugh AND cry. When a writer can pull off that kind of emotional pendulum? Well, they earn a spot on my list of all-time favorite authors!I went into “Still Life” knowing only how much I loved Sarah’s last novel (“Tin Man”), and I thought (based on the jacket copy) this newest work of hers would center around World War II. The war does make an appearance, but only briefly as the plot moves readers to Florence, enveloping them in a story that centers on people brought together by love, war, art, flood, and the ghost of E.M. Forster.This is such a GORGEOUS novel—one that reminded me of “the goodness of people” (Sarah’s purpose in writing it, as she told Publishers Weekly) and one that has taught me about chapters of history I knew nothing about. I loved it from cover to cover and was both sad to end my “vacation” to Italy and to have to say goodbye to this lovely cast of characters (Ulysses, Evelyn, Col, Cressy, Peggy, Pete, Alys and a wise-cracking parrot named Claude) who, by the end, felt like they’d become *my* friends.Feeling grateful to have such a lovely book hangover to end this year on. title: Let's Get Physical: How Women Discovered Exercise and Reshaped the World
author: Friedman, Danielle*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I can’t say I’ve ever thought of a book as a perfect Women’s History Month read, and yet with this one, I absolutely did. I was glad my listening to iI can’t say I’ve ever thought of a book as a perfect Women’s History Month read, and yet with this one, I absolutely did. I was glad my listening to it coincided with the month we recognize the contributions of women to American history—because what a line-up of them featured in this read! Beginning with the first chapter, author Danielle Friedman expands on a topic (barre exercise) she wrote about as an article in 2018 for The Cut. Each subsequent chapter centers on the history of other forms of popular women’s exercise, from running to aerobics to weightlifting (Buns of Steel!) to yoga.Each chapter also provides an exploration of the lives of the women who were pioneers of physical activity. Their accomplishments seem easy to take for granted today, but when you put them in the historical light Friedman does—reminding readers women were discouraged to exercise right up through the ‘60s because society feared their uteruses might fall out (not even kidding!)—you understand how badass they were for wanting to break a sweat back in the day. This book is also catnip for readers who love random tidbits of trivia. For example, I can now tell you the history of the invention of the sports bra (it’s honestly pretty fascinating). See also: how Vidal Sassoon’s wash-and-wear hair cuts of the ‘60s freed women from highly sprayed bouffants that were a major reason they never pursued workouts in the first place.If I had one critique, it’s how little diversity gets represented in these pages. In fairness to Friedman, so much of the history of women's fitness is focused on white women because, for too long, they were the demographic with the means and capacity to work out. But I do appreciate that she spends her final chapter paying so much attention to rising fitness icons like queer “fat femme” yogi Jessamyn Stanley as well as Sadie Kurzban, the Cuban Jewish founder of a fitness chain (305 Fitness) dedicated to celebrating the bodies of all women, no matter size, race or religion.I’d certainly recommend this read, and I thought Friedman did a nice job with the narration. Because I don’t want to forget any of these women, here were a few of the trailblazers I learned about:— Bonnie Prudden, physical fitness pioneer who shocked the country by appearing in a fitness unitard (one of the first!) on the cover of Sports Illustrated in 1957— Lotte Berk, founder of barre whose free-love life story is crazy (she fled Nazis, for starters)— Kathrine Switzer, first woman to run the Boston Marathon as a registered competitor in 1967. (She went on to campaign for women to run the marathon in the Olympics…a goal she never experienced herself as the sport wasn’t an option for them until the ’84 Games.)— Indra Devi, the woman who brought yoga from India to the US in the 1950s (as much as I love and practice yoga, I cannot believe how little I knew of Indra’s contributions to its popularity….see also Lilias Folan, whose PBS series, “Lilias, Yoga and You,” was a gateway to the practice for women in the 1970s)— Jane Fonda, the woman who caused such seismic change in the fitness industry it’s seen as “Before Jane” and “After Jane”. This book taught me SO much about this icon, and the chapter on her fitness reign was my favorite. (Said chapter ALSO provided a truly fascinating history of the rise of the VHS workout as well as the story of how Reebok came to be THE workout shoe of the era…those are more trivia tidbits worth discovering yourselves, among many other gems in this insightful read!)...more

review: Updated Review for December 2023: I gifted this book to my boss this year, as its timely holiday message is one that I think holds up much the same waUpdated Review for December 2023: I gifted this book to my boss this year, as its timely holiday message is one that I think holds up much the same way as other classic Christmas stories. In doing so, I was due myself for a re-read and thus was not disappointed to revisit the story of Bill Furlong and the noble choice he makes to end this powerful story. Quiet heroism, indeed. Original Review for December 2021Every few years when the holidays roll around, I like to read O. Henry's short story, "The Gift of the Magi." It's a wonderful reminder that the most beautiful gift we can give another is our love. Now that I've read Claire Keegan's "Small Things Like These," I have a feeling this slim little novel will be another hopeful work of fiction I enjoy revisiting in future Decembers to come. "Small Things" is the story of Bill Furlong, a hardworking coal merchant doing his best in '80s Ireland to get by caring for his wife, Eileen, and their five daughters. This read tugs on your heart strings, invoking shades of other Christmas classics (think George Bailey meets Charles Dickens). It's also a read that reminds you of the atrocities of the Magdalen laundries, which I'm ashamed to say I knew nothing about before picking up this book. I have Keegan to thank for that gut punch of a history lesson, but—more importantly—for allowing me to dip into a seasonal story that offers up a timely lesson in the virtues of courage, kindness, and responsibility....more

review: I have my bookselling bestie, Jamie, to thank for introducing me to this stellar middle grade read, which was the book I ordered this fall for my son I have my bookselling bestie, Jamie, to thank for introducing me to this stellar middle grade read, which was the book I ordered this fall for my son to fulfill his daily 20-minute reading log challenge for school.He read this aloud to me, and we were both sucked into this narrative about a group of kids and their teacher who, in assigning a social issues project, gets them—and herself—into some hot water. What happens when the students rally to right their wrongs is what makes this such a heartwarming story.My son loved this book so much he finished it outside of his required reading time. (He's a great reader, but a reluctant one without being prompted, so that is quite the testament to the story!) The book is written through journal entries of a handful of student characters, each with a distinct style, from verse to screenplay format to letters to a grandparent to graphic novel illustrations. I especially appreciated the diversity of the characters and how this book fostered a great discussion with my son about consequences, personal responsibility, and how parents can (ahem) sometimes be troublemakers too! HIGHLY recommend this one for kids ages 8-12. ...more

review: Things about this book I loved:• a stunning cover (seriously, this baby grabbed me MONTHS ago when I first came across it online)• an engrossing look Things about this book I loved:• a stunning cover (seriously, this baby grabbed me MONTHS ago when I first came across it online)• an engrossing look into the true story of Chinese art disappearing from Western museums• a peek inside the believable minds of characters struggling with their Chinese American identitiesThings about this book I suspended my disbelief to get on board with:• the idea of a Chinese firm of mysterious origins plucking 5 no-name college students with zero experience in this line of work to pull off one of the greatest series (SERIES...this ain't no one-off job!) of heists on record. (But hey, if I can buy into literally any book offering me lovers who time travel to be together, I can roll with said plot. Now, whether others can as well remains the question...)Things about this book that drove me crazy:• the way so many of the characters seemed to address the same inner monologue time and again. (I'd come to a new chapter, read a scene and think, wait...didn't I read almost these exact same lines from [FILL IN THE BLANK]'s POV?) This book could have been a much tighter read had this element been addressed by the author and her editor.• and speaking of, I wish someone would have talked to the author about her overreliance on a certain narrative device—the "was all" construct in her descriptive language (ie, 'a penthouse that "was all light and burning gold," a voice that "was all confidence," a garage that "was all concrete and industrial noise," a studio that "was all clean lines and open spaces," a hall that "was all muted colors")— just a lottttttt of that going on (like, maybe every third page?) coupled with repetitive descriptions of certain elements (from cheekbones to moonlight) that took me out of the narrative so many times I almost gave up on the book. title: The Candy House
author: Egan, Jennifer*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Years ago, I remember leaving the theater after watching Christopher Nolan’s “Inception” and being like, “HOW does someone come up with a movie this uYears ago, I remember leaving the theater after watching Christopher Nolan’s “Inception” and being like, “HOW does someone come up with a movie this unique and brilliant?!”I had a similar experience when I came to the final pages of Jennifer Egan’s Candy House.For the unfamiliar, Candy House picks up with much of the same cast of major and minor characters featured in Egan’s Pulitzer Prize-winning Visit from a Goon Squad. (And for that reason, I am SO glad I re-read that novel this spring in preparation for this one!) But whereas Bix Bouton, creator of the company Mandala (a stand-in for Facebook if ever there was one), is a minor character in Goon Squad, his story—and more importantly, his invention “Own Your Unconscious”—is the beating heart of Candy House.This is a book that feels impossible to describe to someone who hasn’t read it (again with the “Inception” comparison). But for those who have, wouldn’t you agree it invites thought-provoking conversations about how we use technology for connection, be it with family or people from our pasts?And just as Egan did in Goon Squad, she employs in Candy House an array of narrative styles—first person plural, omniscient narrator, epistolary, a chapter of Tweets—to relay the stories of these characters whose lives intertwine in ways big and small. To summarize, I’m a HUGE fan of her work, and it was a small relief to finish this one holding on to that sentiment, already curious what new genius awaits inside the pages of her next book....more

review: I'm lucky enough to have a super cool friend who's a decade and some change older than me—which, I've got to admit, is an awesome kind of female frienI'm lucky enough to have a super cool friend who's a decade and some change older than me—which, I've got to admit, is an awesome kind of female friendship to have. Because in so many respects, this person schools me on arts and culture in ways that excite me, chiefly because she's forever introducing me to the coolest creative subjects, people, and ideas previously unknown.Over the summer, we got to talking about...well, I don't remember what exactly, but Sara Berman's name came up. She ran to her bookshelf and pressed this book into my hands, encouraging me to discover this immigrant woman whose life story was so simplistically understated, yet so inspiring, that the Museum of Modern Art created an exhibit from her closet in 2017.As a graphic memoir, complete with photographs and illustrations by Sara's daughter, Maria Kalman, I loved it cover to cover. review: What a fabulous collection of essays this was! I benefited from listening to them on audio and since I love Ann’s voice, it made for all the more of aWhat a fabulous collection of essays this was! I benefited from listening to them on audio and since I love Ann’s voice, it made for all the more of a treat. These essays covered a range of topics—from home and family, to friendship and the art of writing—and I felt like I could have listened to a dozen more, so powerful is the allure of Patchett's prose. Standout chapters for me were the essay about her three fathers; the essay about her love of Snoopy (this one particularly delighted me, as I love the Peanuts crew so!); the essay about how enchanted she became with Kate DiCamillo’s writing (a gushfest that prompted me to purchase several of Kate’s books on the spot!) and, of course, THE essay—the titular “These Precious Days”—about the unexpected friendship she fostered with Tom Hanks’ personal assistant, Sooki Raphael. If you can get through that beautiful piece without shedding a tear, you are a stronger person than me! ...more

title: Funny You Should Ask
author: Sussman, Elissa
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are so many reasons for this book to appeal directly to me, starting with my long-held preoccupation with celebrity/artist/musician profiles. (IThere are so many reasons for this book to appeal directly to me, starting with my long-held preoccupation with celebrity/artist/musician profiles. (In high school, I had a job as an assistant to a real estate agent whose office was next to the library ... when I had time to kill, I'd high tail it over there so I could read through the bound back copies of Rolling Stone and Vanity Fair ... all I wanted to do when I grew up was write long-form articles for any one of those popular magazines.)Follow this up with my love for any plot in which a "normal" has some kind of romantic encounter with a celebrity. (See my appreciation for: Notting Hill, Win a Date with Tad Hamilton, Beyond the Lights, or—my latest obsession—Starstruck on HBO.) Basically, what I'm saying is if you put a book in my hands about a young writer (Chani Horowitz) who falls head over heels for the hunky movie star (Gabe Parker) she's been assigned to write a profile about, well then yes, OF COURSE I am going to love it and give it 5 stars! The best part about Funny is the fact that Sussman writes with the kind of confidence that, like Taylor Jenkins Reid and Katie Cotugno, allows her to make up an alternate world where readers convincingly believe that actors named Gabe Parker and Oliver Matthias exist. That's no small feat in and of itself, and the highest compliment I can pay an author who attempts such a pop culture high wire act is to acknowledge that, after reading this book, I'd REALLY like to watch Ollie and Gabe act together in Tommy Jacks or their remake of A Philadelphia Story. So, thanks for that, Ms. Sussman. Related note: There exists a 2011 GQ profile of Chris Evans that reads like inspiration for this novel. I have to share the article because it's the reason I could perfectly picture Chris in the role of Gabe....which is funny because there's another book I loved about an ordinary woman falling for a celebrity—Ali Hughes Has Sex Sometimes —for which I ALSO pictured Chris Evans in the role. I guess maybe I just really want Chris Evans to marry someone he meets on the streets of his hometown of Boston, okay? Ha! ...more

title: The Maid        (Molly the Maid, #1)
author: Prose, Nita*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really wanted to like this book, given its buzz factor (and the fact the author seems like a lovely person who is a talented writer). But I have to I really wanted to like this book, given its buzz factor (and the fact the author seems like a lovely person who is a talented writer). But I have to admit, I never really settled into the storyline of her debut—not when it felt like the main character, Molly Gray, was someone who didn't know as much about herself as the reader did.By that I mean it's pretty clear Molly is on the spectrum. The characteristics Prose gives her all fit the bill. And they become a major reason why Molly (a maid in a fancy hotel) finds herself implicated as the main suspect in the murder of a man whose room she has been tasked with cleaning. What I found myself wondering multiple times throughout this novel was why couldn't we (the reader) have known from the get-go (aka, book jacket) that Molly is on the spectrum? Why couldn't Molly *herself* have been in the know? Is it because the plot couldn't stand on its proverbial two feet without her (and us) being kept in the dark? (And if so, what does that say about the story overall?) By leaving Molly's diagnosis up to ambiguity, Prose creates scene after scene where characters talk about how different she is—which makes for the perfect breeding ground for them to make fun of her and/or pity her and BLECH. I did NOT like feeling this way about her and yet, because of the way the book was written, it felt inevitable. I'll be curious if any other readers are as bothered as I was by this unspoken approach to Molly's developmental disability. For an example of an author who (IMO) pays more respect to a main character on the spectrum, check out Helen Hoang's "The Kiss Quotient." ...more

But as its chapters played out, I had a hard time connecting with the main character, Lucky. Sure, she was dealt a bad hand in being raised by a dad who was the ultimate con artist, but she herself carried on with his misdeeds, including bilking tons of people in a Ponzi scheme. Blech! Add to it the fact she allowed herself to be a pawn for so many others (from her boyfriend, Cary, to the woman she thought was her mom, Gloria), and I felt very little sympathy for her as a grown woman. review: “I’m quite obsessed with making drawing that encourage people not to give up.”That’s the artistic purpose of Charlie Mackesy (which he shares in this “I’m quite obsessed with making drawing that encourage people not to give up.”That’s the artistic purpose of Charlie Mackesy (which he shares in this wonderful CBS Sunday Morning feature). Said profile is what inspired my sister-in-law to buy a copy of Mackesy’s “The Boy, The Mole, The Fox and The Horse” as a Christmas present last year for my son. It took us until the following December to get around to reading it, and of course I now have to ask myself: What took us so long?From the minute we cracked open this beautiful graphic novel, my son and I were smitten with the quiet but powerful themes contained in its swirly words and the whimsical drawings that adorn each page. The conversations between the four wise and witty (in the case of our favorite, cake-loving mole) characters are at once simple yet profound. As quick of a read as this is, you immediately want to start over again because it’s a book where each message can hit differently, depending on the day and the mood. Overall, I’m so happy we finally got around to this moving little read, one that has clearly made an impact on millions of readers the world over. ...more

Yes (though I suspect I’m on the right track if the first thing that came to mind upon finishing was the Taylor Swift lyric “She had a marvelous time, ruining everything.”)Do I want to talk about this book (is it a domestic thriller? is it horror?) with others who read it? Absolutely.If you’re as curious as I was, then it’s best you go into this one knowing little to nothing about the plot. title: From the Mixed-Up Files of Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler
author: Konigsburg, E.L.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This might be my favorite book I've ever read aloud to my son (who just turned 9). It's a 1960s era adventure story about two very bright, very BRAVE This might be my favorite book I've ever read aloud to my son (who just turned 9). It's a 1960s era adventure story about two very bright, very BRAVE siblings, Claudia and Jamie Kincaid, who decide to take an extended field trip of sorts, running away from their childhood home in Connecticut to spend a week living undetected inside NYC's Metropolitan Museum of Art.The titular character, Mrs. Frankweiler, acts as one part narrator, two parts sage and it's a delightful journey to unravel her connection to the children. I don't know how this book missed me in my childhood, but one beautiful aspect of having children of my own is getting the chance to discover classics like this anew. Highly recommend for young readers (ideally 7-12 years old). This book sparked a lot of great discussion between me and my son, everything from whether we'd be brave enough to embark on a journey like the Kincaids, to where we'd hide in a museum, to how much things used to cost versus now, to what beautiful works of art were created at the hands of Michelangelo (who plays a part in this story as well). As a writer, I also enjoyed the "bonus" content included, such as Konigsburg's speech for winning the 1967 Newbery Medal for the book. Not knowing much about Konigsburg, I read up on her and when I came to this line about her work in an article written when she died (in 2013), I nodded my head in respect and agreement. We will certainly be reading more of her work in our household after this:"Konigsburg’s career was marked by a willingness to take young readers seriously, as people who could decipher more complicated literature than simple, straightforward tales. Her novels often include intricate structures, puzzles, and characters who aren’t immediately likable. Both of the novels for which she won the Newbery—From The Mixed Up Files Of Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler and The View From Saturday—are marked by their structural playfulness, which extends beyond their sometimes complicated subject matter."...more

title: Sea of Tranquility
author: Mandel, Emily St. John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Back in 2015, I fell hard for Emily St. John Mandel’s Station Eleven. If you’ve read it, you know how inventive it is—a high-concept pandemic novel wrBack in 2015, I fell hard for Emily St. John Mandel’s Station Eleven. If you’ve read it, you know how inventive it is—a high-concept pandemic novel written long before any of us knew COVID-19 existed.Then, in 2017, on my birthday (lucky me!) I attended a reading with Emily at Butler University. What struck me then was how … uncomfortable she seemed on stage? Not that she didn’t do a wonderful job, just that, as a self-described introvert, she gave off vibes of someone for whom this extroverted aspect of the job was a challenge. (When I made small talk with her during the signing, I recall her wearing a 'deer-in-the-headlights' look, but maybe that metaphor stuck because of her beautiful, doe-like brown eyes.)ANYWAY, the reason I’m sharing this story is because, upon meeting the character Olive Llewellyn in Emily’s newest novel, Sea of Tranquility, I was transported back to my evening with Emily. Olive is an author in Sea who resides in one of the moon colonies. She’s returned to Earth for her latest book tour in the year 2203. In her chapters, readers are given an intimate glimpse at what a slog such a tour can be (from staying in a string of look-alike hotel rooms to answering the same—often patronizing—questions from people to grappling with how to feel when something you write catapults you to a level of fame you never anticipated). So yeah, in a lot of ways, Olive could be Emily. Or Emily could be Olive. (You get my point.) And I loved the autobiographical leanings of this character as much as I loved the rest of the cast in this “time-traveling triumph” (The Guardian) of a book—one that leapfrogs over a few pandemics, embraces a future that entails space travel, and makes readers question if there’s a glitch in the matrix after all.To say more about Sea would be an error on my part, because this is a read where discovery is so much a part of the experience—you don't know how the characters are all connected until the end. Also, after a string of so-so reads, it was wonderful to be back in the hands of a storyteller as masterful at her craft as Emily St. John Mandel. Cast of characters so I don’t forget them:— Edwin St. John St. Andrew (British traveler who witnesses something remarkable in a British Columbian forest)— Olive Llewellyn (author of Marienbad)— Gaspery-Jacques Roberts (a hotel worker who becomes a journalist/detective)— Mirella and Vincent (supporting characters from Glass Hotel)Key passage to remember: “…my point is, there’s always something. I think, as a species, we have a desire to believe that we’re living at the climax of the story. It’s a kind of narcissism. We want to believe that we’re uniquely important, that we’re living at the end of history, that now, after all these millennia of false alarms, now is finally the worst that it’s ever been, that finally we have reached the end of the world … But all of this raises an interesting question,” Olive said. “What if it always is the end of the world?” She paused for effect. Before her, the holographic audience was almost perfectly still. “Because we might reasonably think of the end of the world,” Olive said, “as a continuous and never-ending process.” "A life lived in a simulation is still a life."Finally, two facts (if you made it this far): (1) Emily grew up in British Columbia (where part of her book is set) and (2) her grandfather was British and his name was Newell St. Andrew St. John (so that’s a fun flip of his name for Edwin’s character!)...more

title: The Storyteller: Tales of Life and Music
author: Grohl, Dave
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I came into this book knowing far more about Nirvana’s front man than I did the band’s drummer, but I finished “Storyteller” sad to reach its end, as I came into this book knowing far more about Nirvana’s front man than I did the band’s drummer, but I finished “Storyteller” sad to reach its end, as this book helped me develop the utmost admiration for Dave Grohl. Even more than earning my respect, Dave straight-up CHARMED me. In all ways, he came across as an affable older brother—a goofy dude raised by modest means with an aw-shucks niceness who put in a LOT of hard work honing his talent, all so he could be ready to fulfill his rock-and-roll destiny. In his appropriately titled memoir, Dave details all that his creative destiny has encompassed, starting with his early years of learning how to play drums on his pillows before dropping out of high school at 17 to tour nationally with his favorite punk band, Scream.The chapters that chronicle his career with Nirvana were riveting (longtime fan that I am of the band), as was his account of what came next for him after Kurt’s death—from trying to escape his grief in rural Ireland (and failing spectacularly), to being asked to play with Tom Petty on SNL, to turning down the chance to become a Heartbreaker to pursue the side project he was more passionate about—creating a band he called the Foo Fighters after learning the name from a book about UFOs. All these fascinating stories are there for the taking (and when narrated by Dave, come fully alive in his laid-back tenor and delivery of a well-timed “fuck”). So, too, are the frequent and fond mentions of his relationship with his mother, Virginia. As the mother of a boy myself, I never tired of hearing him talk about her influence (case in point: we have her to thank for Dave joining Nirvana), and I can only dream of having the kind of “best friend” relationship with my son that these two still share.“Storyteller” has proven to be my favorite surprise read of 2021: I went into it with zero expectations and came out appreciating the opportunity to get to know more about a guy who seems to be one of the nicest in the biz—grounded, humble, and grateful to still be making music after all these years, despite all the sadness, drama, and bullshit he’s endured along the way to get here. Rock on Dave, rock on....more

review: This book charmed my socks off and has become my favorite new romance in recent years. TBH, I’m not sure I would have picked it up were it not for RegThis book charmed my socks off and has become my favorite new romance in recent years. TBH, I’m not sure I would have picked it up were it not for Regina’s 5-star  landing it on my radar late last year. Reviews like hers are glowing examples of how this community generates well-deserved buzz for the books we read. Now I’ll do my part to keep that 5-star love going by telling you that if you want a summer read that will tug at your heart strings, remind you of the power of love, and make you laugh in equal measure, you REALLY need to do yourself a favor and discover how big-city ER doctor Alexis Montgomery falls for small-town do-gooder (and new favorite fictional boyfriend) Daniel Grant. This book gets bonus points for: (1) having actual high stakes for its main characters (2) centering a love story around a younger man falling for an older woman and (3) convincingly relaying the friendliness and welcoming spirit of a small-town community. I’ll be recommending Part of Your World for the rest of 2022 and beyond....more
