title: Hooked: How Crafting Saved My Life
author: Foster, Sutton
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What a delight it was, as someone who is a graduate and employee of Ball State University (a mid-major public research university in the Midwestern ciWhat a delight it was, as someone who is a graduate and employee of Ball State University (a mid-major public research university in the Midwestern city of Muncie, Indiana) to hear Sutton name-drop her association with my alma mater minutes into listening to the audio version of this poignant memoir. Sutton has lent her musical and acting talents to Ball State for years now, coming to teach as a guest instructor and to help produce our students’ musicals. (I’ve even had the privilege of getting to interview her a few times while she was on our campus … a real treat!)I share this anecdote because it’s the reason for my biased, 5-star  of this book. The Sutton I’ve come to “know” through stories from our faculty and students is the same affable, charming, and down to earth personality who shows up in the pages of “Hooked.” Also? She’s a bit of a nerd. And she’d be the first to admit it! But when you center your memoir on your love of crafting, maybe you can deduce as much? Overall, I loved getting to learn more about her backstory, even if it was hard to hear about the emotional abuse she and her brother, Hunter, suffered under the watch of their agoraphobic mother. Sutton’s fraught relationship with her mom casts a long shadow over much of her memoir, but there is a lot more to her life that she explores in these pages, including the meteoric rise of her musical theater career. (I especially loved hearing about how she gave up a starring role in Broadway’s “Les Mis” to take a chance on a then-unknown musical, “Thoroughly Modern Millie,” a show that went on to help her land her first Tony Award.) She also writes about the loves in her life (while I knew of her first marriage to Christian Borle, I did *not* know she had a steamy relationship with Bobby Cannavale before her second marriage!) And she shares about her entry into TV with “Bunheads” followed by “Younger” (a show I loved through all seven soap-y seasons), as well as her emotional journey of becoming a mother via adoption. Sprinkled throughout the book are also fun anecdotes that are the mark of any great celebrity memoir, from her fan-girl feelings for Patti LuPone to her stories about how Peter Hermann (her hunky “Younger” co-star) is the world’s best gift giver. If you like Sutton going into this book, you’ll love her after you finish. I am grateful for her willingness to share her talents with our students and I appreciate that she has stayed true to herself, using her love of crafting to keep her grounded throughout her exciting, successful career....more

title: Taste: My Life Through Food
author: Tucci, Stanley
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you’re lucky in life, you have friend, a colleague, or a family member who delights in being a consummate host. They are:	• the person who knows thIf you’re lucky in life, you have friend, a colleague, or a family member who delights in being a consummate host. They are:	• the person who knows the perfect wine to pair with the entrees they’ve ordered for the table. 	• the person who, minutes after greeting you in their home, makes you your favorite cocktail.  • the person whose love for food gets you to try new things, be it borscht, ceviche, or escargot.After listening to “Taste: My Life Through Food,” I can confirm Stanley Tucci is DEFINITELY one of these people. Is there a culinary lottery that exists where the prize is having this man make me a meal? I’d go broke buying tickets if there was. Of course, if I won, I’d have to decide which of the wonderful recipes he shares in “Taste” I’d want him to make for me. Would it be ragu and Bolognese? Spaghetti alla Nerano? Bouillabaisse? I’d suppose I’d settle for a Totino’s pizza if the consolation prize was having him make me one of his famous stirred martinis. (I can hear Stanley say “Kill me now.”)If you can’t tell, I found “Taste” to be a DELIGHTFUL read—a book that took my modest crush on this actor-turned Internet boyfriend-turned NYT best-selling author and dialed it up to an 11. All the things I love most about Tucci are on full display here, from his comedic timing and droll delivery to his erudite commentary on life, love, traveling, and the volatile nature of the entertainment industry. If you read this book, you get all those observations, plus the occasional recipe, on the page. But if you LISTEN to the book, you get that extra narrative “spice” (sticking with food metaphors here) that flavors Tucci’s storytelling, whether he’s name dropping famous friends like Ryan Reynolds or describing the best bowl of spaghetti carbonara he’s ever had. (The way he delivers an emphatic “Fuckkkkkkkk!” when describing this particular dish still makes me chuckle to think about.)Tucci covers a lot of personal highs and lows in “Taste,” from the death of his first wife to cancer to finding love again with Felicity Blunt (yes, Emily’s sister), to his recent battle with tongue cancer. There's one particular paragraph I want to remember here, because it made me unexpectedly tear up. To set the scene, Stanley is talking late in the book about how much he loves to cook for people, and how this love is inspired by his Italian parents and his appreciation for their recipes, which have been passed down for generations. He writes: “Watching my guests enjoy the meal I’ve made filled me with great familial pride. In those moments, it was clear to me that someday, when my parents are no longer alive, I will always be able to put their teachings, and all the love they gave me, into a bowl and present it to someone who sadly will never have had the good fortune of knowing them. But by eating that food, they will come to know them, if just a little.”Swap out his mother’s timpano for my mother’s potato salad, and it’s a beautiful reminder that, to many of us, food truly is family. ...more

title: Breath: The New Science of a Lost Art
author: Nestor, James
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: An online friend with excellent book taste spent the past year touting this book on her social media—enough times that one of her boasts coincided witAn online friend with excellent book taste spent the past year touting this book on her social media—enough times that one of her boasts coincided with the window of opportunity of my latest audiobook credit becoming available. I hit purchase but felt a bit skeptical—was I really going to spend the next 7 hours and 18 minutes entertained by some dude talking about the act of …. breathing? Turns out, yes, absolutely, I was. With each chapter of “Breath”, author James Nestor approaches the topic of health, breath, and the idea of how and why we breathe, from angles I never saw coming. His decade-long quest to investigate the history of breathing took him to places as far-flung as the the streets of Sao Paulo to the secret catacombs of Paris, where he examines the skulls of a whole lotta dead people to explore how the food we eat today (softer, mushier) has changed the shapes of our faces and made breathing more difficult than it was for our ancestors. Nestor’s curiosity also leads him to learn more about the women and men who were pioneers in studying the art of breathing. One of those individuals was Katharina Schroth, a German woman who straightened her severely scoliotic spine by repeatedly inhaling into one lung. Another “pulmonaut” (Nestor’s term for people who explore the bounds of human lung capacity) was Carl Stough, a New Jersey choral conductor who, in the 1950s, developed a deep form of breathing that helped singers improve the resonance of their voices and members of the US men’s track team break a bunch of records at the Mexico City Olympics in 1968. As a yogi, I was also fascinated to learn about the Indus Valley Civilization, a Bronze Age civilization in what today would be Afghanistan/Pakistan/India that is believed to be the first to practice yoga and yogic breathing.Along with the history of breathing, Nestor examines the topic from a wellness perspective, too. Perhaps the biggest takeaway? Breathing through your mouth is bad for you. Like, so bad for you it takes years off your life!Overall, I found this book to be the perfect combination of non-fiction that reads somewhat like a novel—engaging and informative in a way that reminds me of the work of the brilliant Mary Roach (so if you like her books, you’d love this).My final kudos (for the audiobook, at least) is that Nestor invites renowned Swedish breathing expert Anders Olson (a pulmonaut who joins him for an intense, weeks-long study to compare mouth vs nose breathing that he writes about in detail in the book) to lead listeners through a series of breathing exercises. I made notes for each of the styles of breathing, and fully intend to make future use of them!...more

title: The Comfort Book
author: Haig, Matt*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This little slip of a book contains the insightful musings of an author whose ability to overcome his personal struggles with depression and anxiety hThis little slip of a book contains the insightful musings of an author whose ability to overcome his personal struggles with depression and anxiety have given his readers inspiration to carry on themselves.Had I not read this during a summer in which someone very close to me struggled with a severe episode of depression, it might not have resonated with me the way that it did. As it was, I found myself screenshotting page after page of the e-copy I borrowed from the library, knowing I needed to buy a physical copy for said person as a gift. If you, too, have someone in your life struggling with their mental health (and, really, in 2021, who the hell doesn't?), then you could be a bright spot in their day by gifting them their own copy of "The Comfort Book."It's the kind of read wherein so many of its notes and lists feel like they should be taped up to the mirror of the person who's in need of a daily reminder to keep going. To illustrate what I mean by that, here's a favorite example that Haig shared in the book:Change is realWe turn keys all the time. Or rather: time turns keys all the time. Because time means change.And change is the nature of life. The reason to hope.Neuroplasticity is the way our brains change their structure according to the things we experience. None of us are the same people we were ten years ago. When we feel or experience terrible things, it is useful to remember that nothing lasts. Perspective shifts. We become different versions of ourselves. The hardest question I have ever been asked is: "How do I stay alive for other people if I have no one?" The answer is that you stay alive for other versions of you. For the people you will meet, yes, sure, but also the people you will be....more

title: The Nineties
author: Klosterman, Chuck
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Oof. Did it really take me three weeks to read this book? It did. You want to know why? Because this book is the Triscuits of books covering the '90s.Oof. Did it really take me three weeks to read this book? It did. You want to know why? Because this book is the Triscuits of books covering the '90s. And, I guess I wanted it to be more like the Wheat Thins of books covering the '90s? I was not expecting Klosterman to write in such a drrrryyyyy way about ....well, basically everything there was to love about the '90s. Does he cover "it" all ("it" being almost every major pop culture and newsworthy touchpoint of the decade, from Zima and Crystal Pepsi to Ross Perot and the Oklahoma City bombing)? Yes, yes he does.But in a way that is so borderline academic in tone I found myself bored at how laborious the book felt (these feelings were especially present when he broke down the Gen X generation for his readers).Also, there were multiple times where I didn't grasp the logic of his approach to various topics. Typically this didn't bother me, but it did make for occasional head-scratching moments. (One example: In the span of a chapter, he goes from covering the Biosphere project to the cloning of Dolly the Sheep, to Radiohead's popularity to....Pauly Shore's ascendance as an actor?)I will say my favorite element of his pop culture analysis is how he stressed the idea that the things we considered normal to us in the '90s would now seem batshit insane. (The popularity of Pauly Shore in the '90s standing in as a pretty great example of this—as in, we all just went along with the fact Pauly Shore could be the "face" of a movie in the '90s, when now we'd be like, "The hell?!") You will find far more five-star s of this book on GoodReads than three-stars, and that goes to show that Klosterman has a built-in fan base after so many years of writing about American pop culture. (I wouldn't know, as this is my first time reading him.)But I definitely come down on the side of GoodReads er Tracy on this one: "I loved the idea of this book, but The Nineties turned out to be far more dull than the ‘90s ever were."This '90s teen who wanted a "warm, fuzzy romp" through one of her favorite decades agrees....more

title: Billy Summers
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm not what you'd describe as a loyal King fan, but once every decade or so, I feel the desire to dip into his work. In high school and college, it wI'm not what you'd describe as a loyal King fan, but once every decade or so, I feel the desire to dip into his work. In high school and college, it was some of his classic horror ("The Shining,” “Carrie,” and “Misery,” among them). More recently, it's been his stellar book on craft, "On Writing" and "11/22/63." Several bookish friends spoke praisingly of his newest release, "Billy Summers," and I read this great Esquire profile of King from over the summer that helped me decide to give it a go.Boy am I glad I did. "Billy" is well-done crime fiction. Really well done crime fiction, in my opinion. The first half reads compelling enough, mainly because King is a master at what he does, so it's easy to be swept up in the story of Billy, a Marine sniper-turned-murderer for hire (think Dexter without the need to dispose of all the bodies) moonlighting as a novelist waiting to finish out his “one last job.” (“If noir is a genre,” King writes cheekily as Billy, “then ‘one last job’ is a subgenre.” )Where “Billy” picks up serious steam is exactly midway through—with the introduction of a secondary character whose depressing life circumstances eclipse Billy’s own. I don’t want to say anything more about who this person is because I want readers to be as shocked as I was by the outlaw-ish twists and turns that reveal themselves in the second half of this book. I came to the closing pages sad to let “Billy” go while also in complete agreement with Adrienne Westenfeld, writer of the Esquire article I mentioned above:“To see the undisputed master of horror shift seamlessly into the realm of noir thrillers is proof that King can still surprise and astound us, all these decades later."...more

title: In the Wild Light
author: Zentner, Jeff*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I can't  a book written by Jeff Zentner without disclosing my bias for his work: I have followed him online since discovering "Serpent King" yeaI can't  a book written by Jeff Zentner without disclosing my bias for his work: I have followed him online since discovering "Serpent King" years ago, and, over the years, have struck up a friendship with him. This is why I knew, months ahead of its August release, that Jeff had a new book coming out—it's also why, fan that I am, I couldn't wait to dive in to it. For sure, I was not disappointed. "In the Wild Light" serves up all the familiar delights of Jeff's previous novels—prose that borders on poetry, scenes that make you laugh one moment and tear up on the next page, an abundance of sensory details, scenic descriptions of Tennessee, and teenage characters whose greatest attributes are their heart and their humility. In Jeff's hands, these elements come together this time around to tell the story of Cash*** and Delaney, high school friends whose bond is formed by tragedy and then transformed when, together, they leave behind their hometown for the educational opportunity of a lifetime: the chance to attend an elite East Coast boarding school on full scholarship. I always lose count of how many pages I dog-ear in Jeff's books, but enough that the book grows bigger by the time I (unwillingly) turn to the last page. That was true here, of course. But what I especially loved about this title, and maybe it has to do with my own children getting older and so my "parent hat" is more firmly in place, is my appreciation for the many scenes in which Jeff was telling his readers that it's okay to:  — feel like an outsider — seek help for your mental health, especially if you are a guy — find solace in religion, especially prayer — be proud of your family, no matter your socioeconomic background — express emotions in front of your friends — stick up for someone who needs help, especially when that someone is a young woman in duressThose are important lessons that everyone needs to hear, but especially the young adults who make up Jeff's core audience.A beautiful book and my favorite of Jeff's novels since his debut, which will forever hold a spot on my shelf of all-time favorite reads. ***Bonus points to Jeff for working in the reference to Cash's physical resemblance to River Phoenix. Long live my crush on that beautiful, young man who died way too soon. ...more

review: If I could have a conversation with Jean Hanff Korelitz, I'd ask her one question and pay her one compliment:(1) Did you WANT your readers to figure oIf I could have a conversation with Jean Hanff Korelitz, I'd ask her one question and pay her one compliment:(1) Did you WANT your readers to figure out who the psychopath was wayyy before you chose to reveal said person's identity to Jake, AKA your main character? I'm usually the last person to figure out plot twists that are right in front of me. So if *I* sussed it out, then surely 98 percent of other readers did too...also, I think this is true because this book is WAY too smart overall for me to believe otherwise. (2) I really like where you left things with Jake at the end.It feels like there's a shortage of authors being published today who are willing to reach the final page with the flourish of a truly gutsy finale. JHK delivered one that made my eyebrows raise with "Okay, yeah, wow ... she really went there" delight. Related read: I love what Elisabeth Egan had to say  about this book for the NYT: "It keeps you guessing and wondering, and also keeps you thinking: about ambition, fame and the nature of intellectual property (the analog kind). Are there a finite number of stories? Is there a statute of limitations on ownership of unused ideas? These weighty questions mingle with a love story, a mystery and a striver’s journey — three of the most satisfying flavors of fiction out there."...more

review: I knew little about John Paul Brammer before I checked this audiobook out from the library, just that a good friend of mine (who happens to be gay) reI knew little about John Paul Brammer before I checked this audiobook out from the library, just that a good friend of mine (who happens to be gay) recommended it. I also thought it would make for a timely read, given the ongoing observance of National Hispanic Heritage Month.Imagine my surprise when, minutes into the first chapter, I learned that Brammer’s memoir was essentially a “best of” compilation of his advice columns for Grindr! It took me approximately 2 minutes (give or take) to process this new knowledge and then keep reading, taken as I was by Brammer’s terrific writing and the format of the book.This collection reminded me a bit of Cheryl Strayed’s Tiny Beautiful Things (itself a compilation of advice columns that I dearly loved), and by the time I reached its final pages, I felt like Brammer had become a friend. title: Yearbook
author: Rogen, Seth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "Yearbook" was as absurdly funny as I hoped it would be. Seth is a born storyteller, and to hear him narrate these essays (with that distinctive voice"Yearbook" was as absurdly funny as I hoped it would be. Seth is a born storyteller, and to hear him narrate these essays (with that distinctive voice and weirdly charming laugh of his) elevated this material to laugh-out-loud levels of humor.After years of experiencing Seth as an actor, what it is clear of him both when he is wearing that hat and in his real life is how his ability to be surprised by life becomes the je ne sais quoi that I believe sets him apart from his Hollywood peers. Like, every story he shares in "Yearbook," you think to yourself, "That's crazy!" And whether he's telling his readers about that time he was doped up on 'shrooms in Amsterdam or that time he was in the recording studio with Snoop Dogg (and his "hoes") or the absolute bizarre 2012 encounter he had with George Lucas in Steven Spielberg's board room, you feel as shocked by the absurdities of his life as he is. What ALSO made this audio book top-notch is how many guest stars Seth asked to participate in the recording of it. More than EIGHTY voices (from Seth's mom and dad to Nick Kroll, Jay Pharoah, Jason Segel, Dan Aykroyd, Ike Barinholtz, Simon Helberg, Tommy Chong, Billy Idol...and on and on) round out the cast, which demonstrates both how beloved a person Seth must be among his friends and how, in the right hands, a multiple-voice audiobook is a magical feat. ...more

review: I can't remember the last book I read that gave me such narrative whiplash. MCH seemed to delight in dropping bombshell surprises into her story in a I can't remember the last book I read that gave me such narrative whiplash. MCH seemed to delight in dropping bombshell surprises into her story in a way where, in one instance you're reading about a character making toast and the next you're reading about her mother as a child being forced to fellate her stepfather. If that sentence feels shocking to read in a , imagine how it was to stumble across in the book?! And yet, that's only a small reveal compared to the biggest family secret contained in this page turner—a secret so monumental it ends up upending the life of the book's main character, Elle, and that of her childhood best friend, Jonas. Ultimately, even when this story made me bristle, I couldn't stop reading it, which is a testament to MCH's skills on the page. Two related points to make about "The Paper Palace": (1) I was glad to discover, after a little sleuthing, that I wasn't the only one confused by that Jonas vs. Peter ending.(2) The entire time I was reading this, I had a ready-made cast for the characters in my head: Blythe Danner as Elle's mother; Gwyneth Paltrow as Elle (natch); Paul Rudd as Jonas and Dominic West as Peter. Have I mentioned how much I love to mentally cast the books I read? It really is one of my favorite pasttimes! Ha! ...more

title: Cloud Cuckoo Land
author: Doerr, Anthony*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I can say with certainty this book won’t be for everyone, but boy oh boy was it a book for ME. To give you an idea of how much this book overwhelmed mI can say with certainty this book won’t be for everyone, but boy oh boy was it a book for ME. To give you an idea of how much this book overwhelmed me (and I mean that in the best way possible), I stayed up WAY past my bedtime one night recently to finish it. (Anything that gets me to see the other side of midnight has to be astonishingly good.) Then I laid there staring at the ceiling for a solid 20 minutes, full of wonder at what a genius Anthony Doerr is for all that he was able to accomplish with this latest novel of his.Because somehow he manages to brilliantly weave together the narratives of five women and men who start off having nothing in common and whose lives span the course of eight centuries. These women and men include Anna and Omeir, teens who survive the 15th century fall of Constantinople; Idahoans Seymour and Zeno, a radicalized young man and aging Korean vet, respectively; and Konstance, a 14-year-old passenger on a 22nd-century spaceship fleeing an Earth ravaged by climate change.Over the course of "Cloud"'s 600-plus pages, Doerr employs fast pacing and short chapters (a signature approach to writing he’s admitted to adopting because of the relatable restrictions of parenthood), to reveal just how the stories of these five characters interconnect—and the end result is truly a genre-bending work of wonder. I could wax on for a long, LONG time about all the reasons why I love this book and all the lessons it has taught me, most notably to dig deeper into a topic (lost manuscripts) I’d never given much thought to previously.Instead I want to end my  by borrowing this spot-on line from author Marcel Theroux's  of "Cloud" for the New York Times: “It’s a wildly inventive novel that teems with life, straddles an enormous range of experience and learning, and embodies the storytelling gifts that it celebrates. It also pulls off a resolution that feels both surprising and inevitable, and that compels you back to the opening of the book with a head-shake of admiration at the Swiss-watchery of its construction.”A Swiss watch is not the analogy I would have grabbed myself to describe “Cloud Cuckoo Land.” And yet it is the perfect word to describe a book this wildly innovative, creative, and appealing. A true masterpiece that deserves to win this month’s National Book Award, no question....more

title: The Paris Bookseller
author: Maher, Kerri*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are no shortage of books in print nowadays that pay homage to kick-ass women who've been forgotten by history. And because there are precisely sThere are no shortage of books in print nowadays that pay homage to kick-ass women who've been forgotten by history. And because there are precisely so many of said books on bookstore and library shelves, much of what is being published in this micro-genre tends to pass me by (not unlike many of the quality TV series I can't keep up with across all the streaming services I pay for monthly!)But thanks to a trusted bookseller who recently sang the praises of Kerri Maher's "The Paris Bookseller," this read rose above the rest, especially once I realized it was set in that sliver of history—between the world wars in Paris—that fascinates me so. Add to it that it's the story of Sylvia Beach, the original American owner of the famous Shakespeare & Co. Bookstore, and I was all the more sold.I definitely lost myself down a few rabbit holes while reading this—everything from photographs of the real Beach (looking like the cool as hell, queer patron saint of indie bookstores that she was) to her friendship with James Joyce (good GRIEF the shit she put up with in dealing with him as, together, they gave birth to the modern classic that is Ulysses). Another detour I took in my historical wandering? Learning about how Joyce's horrible vision problems (which feature prominently in this book) were likely the result of his having syphilis. (Seriously, not a fan of the man, literary giant though he may be.) If you are down for discovering more about another fascinating member of the Lost Generation (one who propped up nearly every great writer of the era) then this book may be a must-read for you, too. ...more

review: The author of this book is one of my favorite writer friends—someone for whom I was happy to be an early reader for both the first and second novels iThe author of this book is one of my favorite writer friends—someone for whom I was happy to be an early reader for both the first and second novels in her Blackwood Cellars collection. And with "Blue Hawaiian," Carla has created a page-turning romance complete with a compelling enemies-to-lovers storyline that's set against the backdrop of a destination wedding on the alluring island of Maui.I really enjoyed the tension and the heat that she creates between her main characters, Jess and Connor, but I also really loved how much I fell for several of the secondary characters, including Brody, Connor's cousin, who, heartbroken over a recent breakup, ends up making a fool of himself in a pretty big way while at the wedding of Gabi (Jess's sister) and Marc (Connor's brother). Overall, this book made me love "love" all the more (and what more could you want from a romance)? Oh wait, I know .... a book that also makes you want to add Hawaii to your bucketlist (as if it wasn't already on it), attend a luau while you're there and then catch the sunrise from the top of a volcano.A perfect book for your next poolside afternoon or trip out of town! As the token of Poppy (the main character’s) friendship and (later) affection, Alex is my favorite Midwestern love interest since Rainbow Rowell introduced me so many years ago to the one and only Levi Stewart (#fangirlfan4life). Alex’s love for Poppy is so sweet and sincere, and when the two of them travel together, the sparks fly as bright and fast as their quick-witted banter. This is a perfect summer read from start to finish, with an ending that made my insides turn to goo. title: Holes        (Holes, #1)
author: Sachar, Louis*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is one of those kids’ classics I really looked forward to cracking open with my son, but the more of it we read, the more time I spent wondering,This is one of those kids’ classics I really looked forward to cracking open with my son, but the more of it we read, the more time I spent wondering, “What in the heck are we reading, anyway?”It’s just…such a bizarre story, from start to finish—one that involves kids who have to dig holes at what is essentially a corrections-style forced labor camp. But wait, don’t forget a historic backstory that centers on a doomed interracial romance! And the star of the novel….ONIONS! (Never did I envision that this book would be what prompted me to have a Very Serious Conversation™ with my son about how interracial relationships were outlawed for centuries in our country, and how Black men, like Sam the Onion Man, had to live in fear that they would be hanged. Yeah, *that* conversation happened over the course of reading this book. Didn't see that coming!)In summary, “Holes” is not the caper-driven action story I thought it was going to be (and I still can’t even tell you the difference between some of the characters, like Mr. Sir and Dr. Pedanski). While I suppose I’m glad I scratched my FOMO itch with this one when it comes to the canon of kid lit, I can’t say I care to recommend it to any parents or other young readers any time soon. ...more

title: How the Word Is Passed: A Reckoning with the History of Slavery Across America
author: Smith, Clint*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm glad I slipped this informative, insightful work of nonfiction into my 2021 reads. It's an essential book for anyone committed to racial justice aI'm glad I slipped this informative, insightful work of nonfiction into my 2021 reads. It's an essential book for anyone committed to racial justice as well as an incredibly timely one for those of us paying attention to the fight over critical race theory that's been playing out across America in 2021. In "How the Word Is Passed," journalist Clint Smith heads to places where the *true* stories of our country are hidden in plain sight. Among the locations he visits:1) Jefferson's Monticello Plantation2) The Whitney Plantation (the only plantation in the country where the perspective of slaves is central to the tours given)3) Angola Prison (Louisiana's state prison, which is HUGE..and, as I learned from this book, has a GIFT SHOP...the HORROR!)4) Blandford Cemetery (the largest Confederate cemetery in the country)5) Galveston Island (where the proclamation freeing slaves was read on June 19, 1865, which led to the national holiday of Juneteeth)6) New York City (this was my favorite chapter; I learned so much about slavery in the north from it)7) Gorée Island (the island off Africa that was the center of the slave trade for centuries)Within each chapter, Clint shares experiences from his visits, interviewing the people who work there or are affiliated with each location as researchers or tourists. I found his interviews with all his subjects to be fair, demonstrating a commitment to journalistic integrity that this former reporter greatly admired. I'm also glad I listened to this one too, as Clint does a great job narrating his work. A few points he made that I wanted to capture so I didn't forget them:• “I think that history is the story of the past, using all the available facts, and that nostalgia is a fantasy about the past using no facts, and somewhere in between is memory, which is kind of this blend of history and a little bit of emotion…I mean, history is kind of about what you need to know…but nostalgia is what you want to hear.”• “...I'm left wondering if we are all just patchworks of the stories we've been told. What would it take - what does it take - for you to confront a false history even if it means shattering the stories you have been told throughout your life? Even if it means having to fundamentally reexamine who you are and who your family has been? Just because something is difficult to accept doesn't mean you should refuse to accept it. review: There was a lot to like about this novel, especially how grounded it was by its setting (the tiny town of Olympus, Texas, pop. 2,000ish) and how, by iThere was a lot to like about this novel, especially how grounded it was by its setting (the tiny town of Olympus, Texas, pop. 2,000ish) and how, by its end, the characters who inhabited Olympus (most notably the members of the Briscoe clan) felt as familiar to me as the women and men of Dillon, Texas. (I had to work that Friday Night Lights reference in there somewhere!)Where I faltered with this book was 1) in questioning why its author felt the need to focus the story under a mythological lens (a lens that, in the words of a New York Times er I agree with felt “inoffensive but unnecessary; most of the time it made me wonder why more characters weren’t aware of the allusions.”) The other element of the book I struggled with was (again, in the words of Edan Lepucki for the NYT) its “violent, surprising turning point.”For that er, and the friend who recommended this book to me, this mega plot twist worked for them. For me, I couldn’t get past how ludicrous the actions of the individuals involved were related to the incident in question. (And apologies for being so opaque about what I’m referring to, but I keep my s spoiler-free, and this one deserves the shock it delivers to the reader once it’s introduced.)Overall, those two factors might have pulled me out of the book a bit, but I still enjoyed the time I spent in the heads of these complicated characters. Without question, Swann is a talented writer. I look forward to hearing more about whatever she may be working on next....more

review: When I first started Andy Weir’s buzzy new book, “Project Hail Mary,” a part of me balked because it felt like the humor and voice of its protagonist,When I first started Andy Weir’s buzzy new book, “Project Hail Mary,” a part of me balked because it felt like the humor and voice of its protagonist, Ryland Grace, was too much like Mark Watney from “The Martian.” But I kept reading because Andy hooked me with another one of his kickass plots.Then I hit a pivotal point in the book where the introduction of a major secondary character both surprised AND intrigued me—enough so that I couldn’t stop tearing through the pages of a book that essentially becomes a buddy road trip wrapped in a sci-fi survival tale through space. There are parts of “Project Hail Mary” where the science is *too* next-level, but for every scene that lost me, three more filled the gap with the humor and heart I've come to love in this author’s books. Maybe because I’m disheartened this summer by relentless news of our escalating climate crisis and the way billionaires are buying their way into space, but reading this book was an uplifting escape—one that made me root not only for the faint-hearted science teacher who becomes Project Hail Mary’s reluctant front man—but for the human race he’s trying to save along the way. review: It's fascinating to me how children can come from the same two people and be so radically different. My son follows the prototypical first-born traitsIt's fascinating to me how children can come from the same two people and be so radically different. My son follows the prototypical first-born traits: people-pleasing, takes directions well, more cautious in his approach to life. Then came my daughter, the ball buster, and suddenly I realized I needed a new bag of tricks to parent her (because the "time out" chair that proved so effective with my son was no match for her strong-willed temperament!)I've dipped in and out of this book throughout much of 2021—the same year my daughter has been three, which is an age that, with my son, was no problem, but with my daughter, I suddenly understand other parent's laments about. I highlighted so many pages, and found it so helpful, and kept meaning, in this , to capture down a lot of those notes here so I wouldn't forget.Then I randomly stumbled across this mom blogger's essay about "Dealing With a Strong Willed Child" and decided she basically did the core of that work for me.In summary, this book is a great reminder that all kids are different and that how you approach them—in tone and temperament—can make a huge difference in their behavior. title: Kitchen Confidential: Adventures in the Culinary Underbelly
author: Bourdain, Anthony
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Strange for me to give this audiobook a listen now when a) I’ve never watched a single episode of “Parts Unknown” and b) I failed to fully appreciate Strange for me to give this audiobook a listen now when a) I’ve never watched a single episode of “Parts Unknown” and b) I failed to fully appreciate Anthony Bourdain when he was still earthside.With those facts in mind, this read could be a hard listen at times. (Bourdain jokes a lot about death in KC–his own and the lives of others he knew, which was brutal to process given his death by suicide.) But KC also helped me belatedly appreciate Bourdain as both chef and person: supremely talented, sarcastic, vulgar and gruff—the “Elvis of bad boy chefs.” Bourdain’s delivery of his own words could at times be exhilarating (the way he talked about food made me want to immediately try whatever he was discussing, from oysters to sashimi to Beef Wellington) while also exhausting. (There’s one chapter where he delivers an hour by hour account of his life as a chef, barely pausing to take a breath, and I felt like I needed to sit down on his behalf when I was through with it.)It is so effing sad to think Bourdain is gone when his work—from his storytelling to his culinary skills—made so many people so happy. I’m glad I finally got around to this one … I just wish (this  coming nearly 3 years to the day that Bourdain died) that it wouldn’t have been a read tinged with such melancholy as I listened. PS — One major downside to this book: Bourdain made me reluctant to ever again order eggs Benedict the next time I dare join friends for brunch. title: Susan, Linda, Nina & Cokie: The Extraordinary Story of the Founding Mothers of NPR
author: Napoli, Lisa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I think, in another life, I was a beat reporter covering Capitol Hill in the 1970s a la Nina Totenberg. How else to explain why I’m so drawn to historI think, in another life, I was a beat reporter covering Capitol Hill in the 1970s a la Nina Totenberg. How else to explain why I’m so drawn to history of that era, particularly profiles about female trailblazers from that time period? (In journalism school, one of my favorite books was Katharine Graham’s Personal History. ‘Nuf said.)I’m not sure this book will be cat nip for everyone, but it certainly was for me. Inside its pages is a fascinating slice of American history that chronicles in equal parts (1) the rise of NPR (a preferred news outlet of mine) (2) the technological and political history of the U.S. in the latter half of the 20th century and (3) the personal lives of the Founding Mothers of public radio (whose corner of the NPR office was dubbed the “Fallopian Jungle” … by a man, OF COURSE.)I loved how this book provides such detailed backstories about these four women—Susan Stamberg, Linda Wertheimer, Cokie Roberts, and the aforementioned Nina Totenberg. Their career history spans the extraordinary leaps made by women of that generation, and it never ceases to amaze me how close in the rearview mirror are the days when women routinely had their bottoms pinched and were “chased around the table” by men (gross!) while at work. This book made me admire these women even more. (I especially loved learning more about Nina, a fearless reporter who wrote scathing profiles of people in power like J. Edgar Hoover, but who also had the chutzpah to publish a piece in 1974 about the nation’s dumbest congressmen. Ha!) A perfect read to honor Women’s History Month. ...more

title: The Office of Historical Corrections
author: Evans, Danielle*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Often when I read a book I enjoy, I seek out s to see what others had to say about it. After finishing Danielle Evans’ “The Office of HistoricalOften when I read a book I enjoy, I seek out s to see what others had to say about it. After finishing Danielle Evans’ “The Office of Historical Corrections,” I found this aptly titled one: “‘The Office of Historical Corrections’ is a Necessary Critique of the Current Moment’.”Evans’ wastes no words in this collection of stories that are tightly structured and timely in topic, touching on everything from friendship and privilege to race and representations of history. Given the line “Office” walks between satire and reality, it was surreal to read the titular novella, “The Office of Historical Corrections,” a week after I finished Clint Smith’s “How the Word Is Passed.” In Evans’ fictional telling, the character Cassie works for a government agency (the Institute for Public History) responsible for correcting the historical record, from fixing a flyer for a Juneteeth cake to amending the wording of a plaque commemorating a historical event involving a Black business owner. In Smith’s work of nonfiction, he pays visits to various cities and attractions in the U.S., detailing the history of each locale hiding in plain site (making him the living embodiment of Evans’ character).The juxtaposition of these similar narratives—one very real, the other not so much—makes for a powerful reminder of just how "of the moment" this collection truly is. And because I’m the worst at remembering short stories, I'm documenting the titles of those in “Office,” along with a few notes, so I can recall them when talking about this book moving forward: “Happily Ever After”: Lyssa (who works on a tourist attraction replica of the Titanic) grieves for her dying mother while reconciling her boyfriend becoming a racial target after trying to help them “Richard of York Gave Battle in Vain”: Rena misses her sister against the rom-com backdrop of a missing groom and an interracial wedding party hookup“Boys Go to Jupiter”: Claire and her Confederate-flag bikini“Alcatraz”: A young woman reflects on how her life has been shaped by her mother’s efforts to restore a family member’s reputation as an Alcatraz prisoner“Why Won’t Women Just Say What They Want” (this one was delightful in a very George Saunders way): a series of unnamed women (ie ‘Former Personal Assistant’) receive creative apologies from a despicable Don Juan who then makes the act of apologizing into a work of public art gone wrong“Anything Could Disappear” (this story pulled at my heartstrings!): Vera and the young boy from the bus and the life that could have been for them if she hadn’t done the presumptive right thing...more

review: As a longtime Christina Lauren fan, I know I can always count on this duo’s charming romance novels for a much-needed pick-me-up. That’s why I was gidAs a longtime Christina Lauren fan, I know I can always count on this duo’s charming romance novels for a much-needed pick-me-up. That’s why I was giddy when my bookselling bestie sent me an advance copy of their newest, The Soulmate Equation (which releases May 18). The science-y premise of this book—what happens when a single mom gets “diamond” matched with the founder of a DNA-based dating company—was unique enough to sell me on the story. But what made this title my favorite of theirs yet were the multiple references made comparing the looks of the book’s broody male lead (Dr. River Peña) to my favorite celebrity crush:   [image]With that visual in mind, swooning hard for this book came easy to me. To get even more specific (as a ridiculously devoted Keanu fan), I pictured him in the role of career-obsessed Nelson Moss from “Sweet November”:  [image]For the duration of this book, that character of his happily took up residency in my brain as a stand-in for River while I was reading. (And if you want to make fun of me for how easily I allowed this to happen, too late, I already beat you to it.)Honestly though, it’s a testament to the talent of Christina Lauren that every one of their books could play out as a romantic film in the imaginations of their readers. I don’t know about some of you, but I really do miss all of those romance flicks that were made in the early aughts. (I can’t tell you the countless weekends in college wherein I would inevitably end up curled up on the couch, sucked into another cable showing of any one of these films.) Thankfully, Christina Lauren has swooped in to fill this particular pop culture void for me. I say this, but that still won’t stop me from wishing Netflix would wise up and turn one of their novels—ANY of them, please!—into one of their newest romantic releases....more

Each time I’ve followed the program, I’ve felt the best I have in my adult life. So, when I learned that Dr. Junger had a 7-day version of the program, I was game to give it a try. I purchased the set during one of CLEAN’s semi-annual sales (these products are quality and thereby not cheap!) and then I bought this book to dive into what makes this routine unique from the full 21-day version. Turns out it’s the powerful combination of functional medicine, ayurvedic medicine, and intermittent fasting.I will report back after I finish my Clean 7 routine in June, but already I’m encouraged to experience the results and to test my body with a first-time fast. In reading this text, I especially loved learning about ayurvedic medicine and discovering my dosha (aka, my body’s constitution). (I’m pitta—predominant fire-water dosha FWIW.)My 30s have taught me conventional medicine is important, but so, too, is functional medicine. I have discovered first-hand (thanks to Clean) how to help my body heal (from inflammation especially) and that experience over the past 10 years has radically changed how I approach my diet while also empowering me to “read” my body (see the five Rs in this book) as the No. 1 way to feel my best. If it sounds like I’m trying to sell some MLM product, I’m not. I just can’t say enough wonderful things about Dr. Junger (who is a cardiologist—not a quack!). review: This was such a zany little love story—so zany, in fact, that at times I really loved that fact about it and at others, I was like, “What is even happThis was such a zany little love story—so zany, in fact, that at times I really loved that fact about it and at others, I was like, “What is even happening right now? Who ARE these people?”I think that has to do with the fact that Thorne created characters in this book who say and do things that surprise the reader (that surprise even the author, who, in a letter she penned at the end of this book, acknowledges that “what happens when my hands are on the keyboard is something that makes me feel rather uncomfortable. I’m not in control. I never know what I’m going to write until I’ve written it.”)I smiled and nodded when I read these few sentences because those take-me-out-of-the-book moments I experienced at times suddenly made sense in a sweet narrative that, at its heart, is about letting go and letting love in. As for me, what I personally loved most about this book had nothing to do with its plot but was another excerpt that I read in the same letter referenced above. In these words, Thorne acknowledges a truth I have come to know intimately as a writer of fiction myself—a truth I wanted to remember in sharing this  here:“I’ve come to a realization that becoming good at something creative or worthwhile is a process of applying layers, and being willing to be really uncomfortable when the Thing is halfway done…..You will not like it. You will be pretty sure that you’re not succeeding. This is when another layer must be applied. …A book starts off as a blank page …. Nothing starts out looking like the finished product, and if you can accept that and work through the discomfort, then you can end up with a finished product that is …something only you can produce. It doesn’t even require you to make a life-changing leap; just add one new layer of effort, attention, and time. Add a new layer to that dream, and just like the tortoises at Providence, make the journey, one inch at a time. They always get where they’re going, and so will you. A blank page is a gift. Make your mark on it.”...more

review: In this blistering collection of essays, poet and critic Cathy Park Hong explores the titular topic of “minor feelings”—the “racialized range of emotiIn this blistering collection of essays, poet and critic Cathy Park Hong explores the titular topic of “minor feelings”—the “racialized range of emotions that are negative, dysphoric, and therefore untelegenic, built from the sediments of everyday racial experience and the irritant of having one’s perception of reality constantly questioned or dismissed.”In the author’s own words, “Minor feelings arise upon hearing a slight, knowing it’s racial, and being told, Oh, that’s all in your head …. Minor feelings are not often featured in contemporary American literature because these emotions do not conform to the archetypal narrative that highlights survival and self-determination.”This book is a timely read, one that reminds us that immigrants to our country don’t owe us any kind of gratitude and that the notion of a “model minority” is a myth in need of dismantling. If you’ve read Claudia Rankin’s “Citizen,” you might be equally moved by Hong’s informative, enlightening, and—at times—infuriating essays on the destructive effects of racial prejudice....more

On this front, and in the ways in which she interweaves her keen knowledge of history and pop culture into her writing, ZDH nails it. Where I struggled with this read is in the level of trust she placed in me, her reader, to keep up with the plot. Especially when, out of nowhere, she starts switching from the point of view of the main character, Zella, to….well, honestly, I’m still not quite sure who several of the characters were, not even as I came to the closing pages of the novel. Then there is the element to the book where the “Get Out” comp becomes relevant (a comp that had me giddy at first because that movie was one of my favorites of 2017). I don’t want to ruin the element of surprise for future readers, so I'll just say I could pick this concept apart (pun intended) as being too left field for me to appreciate its application in relation to the rest of the story. The race politics of this novel, coupled with ZDH’s mad storytelling skills, are deserving reasons for why this book is one of this month's most anticipated releases. review: Earlier this month, I finished listening to “Interior Chinatown,” by Charles Yu. The narration was excellent, which is just part of the reason it was Earlier this month, I finished listening to “Interior Chinatown,” by Charles Yu. The narration was excellent, which is just part of the reason it was a quick, 5-star read for me. The story is written as a teleplay about Chinatown that explores Asian-American stereotypes through the eyes of Willis Wu, a young actor figuring out his place in Hollywood as he ascends the ladder of parts (Generic Asian Man to coveted Kung Fu Guy) historically available to most Asian-American actors. The book is part speculative, part family drama, part satire, and it’s one of the most creative things I’ve read in years (which is why it’s no surprise it took home last year’s coveted National Book Award). On Monday, when I learned that Steven Yeun had made Oscar history as the first Asian American to be nominated for best actor, I thought of Yu’s book—how maybe, *maybe* Hollywood had reached a turning point when it comes to Asian-American representation (in films, in pop culture, in media). Then yesterday. Atlanta. A hate crime (CALL IT WHAT IT IS, MEDIA) that left eight dead, six of whom were women of Asian descent. It’s despicable and the signs were all there that this was coming. My heart continues to go out to everyone in the Asian community. I shared a post on Instagram today with my  of this novel and a few more thoughts about how to show my support and solidarity with the AAPI community.And, back to this stellar read that feels more relevant and necessary than ever, I found  this profile about Charles to be an excellent companion read. What a remarkable series of careers he's had! I think he can, with great confidence, call himself a proper writer now. As for me, I look forward to seeing what's in store for him in the future. ...more

(In fact, I gasped out loud at a *very* pivotal point toward the end, in a way that made my friend who was with me ask, ‘Good book, huh?’) Indeed it is—in fact, this new release might end up being my favorite book of 2021! If you like suspenseful reads, this one might be for you, too. In so many complimentary ways, I found myself drawing comparisons with this book to the works of one of my favorite authors (Donna Tartt) as well as The Talented Mr. Ripley and even (a smidge) of Stephen King’s Misery. Can’t rave about this one enough and cannot wait to see who gets cast as Florence and Helen for the film adaptation that is in the works! review: I was so excited last week when the latest novel written by my dear friend landed in my mailbox the day of its release. I tore open the package and imI was so excited last week when the latest novel written by my dear friend landed in my mailbox the day of its release. I tore open the package and immediately dove in to this charming rom-com about Sabrina, a young woman with a gift for the supernatural (she communicates with ghosts!) who tries her hardest to convince herself she’s not falling for Ray (an ex-New Yorker making a fresh start at life by running a destination restaurant in the Dells of Wisconsin). I’m biased because I adore her, but I think this is Amy’s best book yet. I loved the characters and secondary storylines, and I especially loved—as I do with all her books—the way Amy invites her readers to appreciate all that midwestern living has to offer. She has a gift for making me want to travel to Wisconsin, to experience regional cuisine, and to learn more about the culture of a place (in this case, the state’s supper club scene). If you’re looking for a feel-good story that will tug on your heart strings, that is full of romance, and that feels primed for a series adaptation on the WB, I can’t recommend “The Kindred Spirits Supper Club” enough....more

review: A new book by Amor Towles is head and shoulders above most literature written in 2021, yet I have to admit this latest novel of his, a story that chroA new book by Amor Towles is head and shoulders above most literature written in 2021, yet I have to admit this latest novel of his, a story that chronicles the misadventures of two brothers and the delinquents who insert themselves into their cross-country road trip, is my least favorite of his work. Maybe it's the time of year (December being a hectic month for myself and most others I know), but I had a lot of stops and starts with this one. I felt it could have benefitted from a tighter edit, one with at least 2-3 fewer points of view (did we really need that random chapter from Abernathe?). Also, as much as I appreciated Ulysses, he carried with him shades of the troublesome Magical Negro trope.These misgivings are slight enough to keep this from being a five-star read for me, but I still immensely enjoyed the book. To read Towles is to appreciate his clever word play and his genius comprehension of literature. And the character I came to love the most was Emmett's little brother, Billy, which is saying something because usually books with a "precocious kid" are not my cup of tea. title: A Shot in the Moonlight: How a Freed Slave and a Confederate Soldier Fought for Justice in the Jim Crow South
author: Montgomery, Ben*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Halfway through reading this book, I direct messaged a friend of mine on Instagram who is an attorney in Louisville and lives in New Albany, Indiana, Halfway through reading this book, I direct messaged a friend of mine on Instagram who is an attorney in Louisville and lives in New Albany, Indiana, right across the Ohio River. I wrote to him:"I'm tearing through this book .. I feel like it's one I wanted to specifically recommend to you bc it's part courtroom drama, part peek at the 19th century social justice movement, part history of Kentucky—all reasons why I thought you might especially be intrigued by it."He affirmed that it did sound like a great pick for him. And to me, that is the kind of book "A Shot in the Moonlight" is—one that I might not recommend to everyone, but if you are the type of person for whom any of the above sounds interesting, you will find this to be a page-turner, too.As I read it, I couldn't help thinking how George Dinning's story (a former Kentucky slave who, in defending his home from a mob of angry white men, shot and killed one of the men "kuklux"ing) paralleled Breonna Taylor's (an innocent Black woman living in Kentucky whose door was knocked on by a mob of angry white men). Their stories—and fates—are obviously different, but parallels exist in how both captured the nation's attention in a way that made a difference to the fight for social justice for Black women and men who have been the victims of white supremacy.Along with George Dinning, other fascinating figures in this historical drama include Bennett Henderson Young, the Louisville lawyer and former Confederate soldier who chose to represent Dinning in a lawsuit the men filed on his behalf against the mob who forced Dinning and his family to flee their home (which they then burned) and Bill Bradley, Kentucky's progressive governor who gained a reputation at the turn of the 20th century for standing up against white mobs brutalizing Blacks. (He also pardoned Dinning after his trial, in which he was accused of manslaughter.) ...more

title: Between Two Kingdoms: A Memoir of a Life Interrupted
author: Jaouad, Suleika*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A great voice is the make-or-break “it” factor for any writer, but especially one writing memoir. Listening to Suleika Jaouad's “Between Two Kingdoms,A great voice is the make-or-break “it” factor for any writer, but especially one writing memoir. Listening to Suleika Jaouad's “Between Two Kingdoms,” the story of the author’s years-long journey battling an aggressive form of leukemia, I was blown away by just how compelling Suleika’s voice was on the page. Her capacity for introspection and her gift of connection with her words made me feel like I was right there with her in all those hospital beds, enduring the ups and downs in her relationships, the ravaging effects of her chemo, and (much later) the freedom and solitude of traveling the open road in a beat-up Subaru. This is the best memoir I’ve read since Tara Westover’s “Educated” (and Suleika does a fantastic job narrating it on audio). In a twist of serendipity, it was a pleasure to discover musician Jon Batiste through this book. I’ve been enjoying listening to his new album, WE ARE (“I Need You” should be the feel-good song of the summer), and I loved seeing Suleika and Jon serving up #couplegoals on my TV screen after Jon took home the Oscar for Best Score for his work on Pixar's “Soul.” To give you an idea of how soul-stirring this book is, Suleika titled it in homage to a line from Susan Sontag’s book, “Illness as Metaphor”: ‘Everyone who is born holds dual citizenship in the kingdom of the well and in the kingdom of the sick.’ On that note, "Between Two Kingdoms" is not a memoir that’s food for thought…it’s a verifiable feast.Related: This CBS Sunday Morning profile of Suleika is fantastic...and if you want to go down the Internet rabbit hole of discovering the real identity of "Will" in the book, let me save you a few clicks....more

title: Empire of Pain: The Secret History of the Sackler Dynasty
author: Keefe, Patrick Radden
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I picked up this book for two reasons: 1) because I think Patrick Radden Keefe is one of the most talented journalists alive and 2) because I wanted tI picked up this book for two reasons: 1) because I think Patrick Radden Keefe is one of the most talented journalists alive and 2) because I wanted to learn more about the Sackler family, whose idealistic pursuit of discovering a cure-all drug for pain took a dark and greedy turn that led to our current opioid epidemic.In reading “Empire of Pain,” I also learned so much about the rise of how our country markets drugs (we have the Sacklers to thank for all those annoying prescription drug ads) and how dynastic families breed a level of dysfunction that can turn family members into money-hungry monsters. (If you’re a Succession fan, you will notice a LOT of comparisons between the Sacklers and the Roys!) This book is by far the most important work of non-fiction I’ll read in 2021. It’s a best-seller that, even as it infuriated me, dialed up my appreciation for Patrick to an 11, especially after learning he: (a) wrote its 400-plus pages without a SINGLE member of the Sackler family agreeing to be interviewed (enter a *mind-boggling* amount of research) (b) wrote a lot of this book during the pandemic, from his bed no less! and (c) as he was working on this book, had shady people staked outside his NY home, trying to intimidate him out of writing it. If my personal recommendation to to read “Empire of Pain” isn't compelling enough, consider this praise from Rachel Maddow: “I read everything he writes. Every time he writes a book, I read it. Every time he writes an article, I read it … he’s a national treasure.” Indeed....more

review: Big fan of Nickolas Butler here, so I'm incapable of giving less than 5 stars to his latest book—a Western thriller that examines the lengths a rich wBig fan of Nickolas Butler here, so I'm incapable of giving less than 5 stars to his latest book—a Western thriller that examines the lengths a rich woman will go in pursuing what she wants, at the cost of the men who agree to build her a custom home in the mountains under an intense (and mysterious) deadline.When Butler released his debut, "Shotgun Lovesongs," back in 2013 (OMG has it really been that long ago?!), I loved it so much I put it on my hallowed mental shelf of "Reads I Would Want With Me on a Desert Island." title: Ida B. the Queen: The Extraordinary Life and Legacy of Ida B. Wells
author: Duster, Michelle
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I remember first learning about Ida B. Wells in journalism school. I knew she was one of the most well known female journalists of the 20th century, bI remember first learning about Ida B. Wells in journalism school. I knew she was one of the most well known female journalists of the 20th century, but I didn’t know much beyond that. As Women's History Month draws to a close, I have to share how much I enjoyed reading “Ida B. Queen: The Extraordinary Life and Legacy of Ida B. Wells.” This book is filled with gorgeous illustrations and artifacts that tell a compelling story about the Black experience alongside the biography of an awe-inspiring woman who was ahead of her time—as a journalist, as a publisher, as a suffragist, and as a civil rights activist. What makes this book all the more powerful is that these stories about Ida are compiled by her great-granddaughter, Michelle Duster.Ida’s investigative journalism brought to light the horrors of lynching in early 20th-century America. For years, she failed to garner the accolades and attention she deserved (when she died in 1931, the NYT didn’t even write an obit for her). So I’m glad that, today, her activism and her investigative work are being rediscovered and celebrated through landmarks, a posthumous Pulitzer (awarded in 2020), and creative works like this book. If you have someone in your life who’s passionate about women’s history and/or social justice issues, “Ida B. Queen” would make a great gift—it’s the kind of gorgeous book that begs for a home on someone’s coffee table. I hated returning my copy to the library when I was finished....more

title: Clap When You Land
author: Acevedo, Elizabeth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'd seen "Clap" on a number of friends' reading lists for 2020, as well as a number of "best of" lists for last year. And though it's been ages since I'd seen "Clap" on a number of friends' reading lists for 2020, as well as a number of "best of" lists for last year. And though it's been ages since I've read YA, I decided to give it a go when I saw it was available to check out on Hoopla. Within the first 30 pages I could tell this was the kind of YA novel that transcends its audience—the kind of novel that everybody should read, no matter their age."Clap" is a powerful story about the bonds of family—and the secrets that can break them apart and/or bring them back together. It's also a beautiful work written in homage to the victims of AA Flight 587, which happened not long after 9/11 (and, prior to reading this, I sheepishly knew nothing about). Everyone who died on that flight in 2001 was from the Dominican Republican. Acevedo, who was just a young teen at the time, grew up wanting to write a book in response "about personal and public grief — to show how certain communities mourn on their own from events that perhaps deserve more attention.” (source)She accomplishes that goal and then some with "Clap." And the fact she does it in verse? That just makes this book all the more impressive. This is a read I've only just finished but already recommended to four of my friends. I look forward to reading more of Acevedo's books (including her award-winning debut) and have a strong hunch my future self will fall for anything she writes. A few beautiful lines that I had to highlight along the way:Passage 1 (when Yahaira is talking about her relationship with her girlfriend, Dre): "We both know what it's like to haveour parents look at uslike we are dressed in neon questionmarks.""We also know exactly what it's like to look at the other& see all the answers of ourselves there." Passage 2 (when Yahaira is processing the secret life that her father kept from her and her mother):I've always looked at my parents &seenexactly what they've shown me. Icould notimagine them as real humanswho lived. & kept the truth. Fromeach other. From me. Passage 3 (the words that a seatmate on the plane says to Yahaira):"They don't do that as much anymore. This must be a planeof Dominicans returning home;when you touch down on this soil,you must clap when you land." ...more

review: I have long been a fan of Laura Tremaine, having discovered her shortly after she started blogging as "The Hollywood Housewife." She is one of those sI have long been a fan of Laura Tremaine, having discovered her shortly after she started blogging as "The Hollywood Housewife." She is one of those souls on the Internet whose words pull you in, make you stay, and magically make you believe that she's one of your IRL friends. This would explain why she not only has a huge online following, but landed herself a book deal—a deal for a title that feels like THE book she specifically was destined to write.It's always a bit terrifying to read a debut by someone you admire so much. What if their words don't live up to the hype or to your personal expectations for the talent they possess? I will admit I held my breath as I dove into "Share Your Stuff," fearing this scenario playing out. But within the first few pages, I let that breath out. Laura's voice was engaging, her stories compelling, and her reader prompts thought-provoking. I couldn't turn the pages fast enough, and yet I hated reaching the end.I've been thinking about who I want to gift a copy of this book to and I have the perfect friend in mind. I look forward to catching up with her after this pandemic is over, picking a chapter's question to discuss, and then doing the same with a different chapter the next year and the year after that. I'm thrilled for Laura and her publishing success. In her debut, she asks her readers to think about who the people in their life are who teach them "how to be." I can't help but think that, for many of us, Laura is one of those people. I am grateful for her candor and her commitment to helping so many of her friends and followers be their best, most authentic selves, online and in person....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It is impossible for me to give this book any less than 5 stars. Heck, I'd give it 11 if I could. Because Ashley C. Ford is not just some new writer IIt is impossible for me to give this book any less than 5 stars. Heck, I'd give it 11 if I could. Because Ashley C. Ford is not just some new writer I discovered upon the release of her much-anticipated debut memoir. No, Ashley is someone I am lucky enough to call an IRL friend—a friend I first got to know after meeting her at the Midwest Writers Conference back in 2015.After all these years, to *finally* have the opportunity to listen to her read me the life story she spent a decade writing? What a feeling ... what a wonderfully surreal, "I am-so-damn-proud-of-my-friend," "THAT really happened to her? OMG NO" ride listening to this book was for me."Somebody's Daughter" was as revealing and raw as I knew it would be. By the time I made it to the penultimate meeting between a grown Ashley and her incarcerated father, I had tears in my eyes. I can attest that few people I've met know themselves as well as Ash does. It was quite the experience to discover her journey of self-acceptance—a journey that's resulted in her becoming the confident, inspiring, immensely talented creator she is today. "Proud" doesn't begin to capture my love and admiration for her. Related: —Ashley's book ends with her dropping out of Ball State (the university from which I graduated and where I'm currently employed). For those of you who read her memoir (and make it this far in my --ha!) you might be interested to know Ashley DID in fact graduate from college –-and it was an awesome moment to celebrate with her when it happened in Fall 2018.—When Ashley's book first came out, a mutual friend of ours from Ball State sang her praises on social media, sharing how Ashley lived on her floor freshman year and was always around to give her "a hug that felt safe." I messaged her to say that I smiled when I read that, because it's true—if you're lucky enough to know Ashley, she really does give the world's best hugs, no exaggeration. When she returns to campus this fall, I can't wait to give her another one! ...more

review: MULTIPLE times throughout the course of my reading this insanely ambitious novel, I had to stop and marvel at the fact its author, Maggie Shipstead, iMULTIPLE times throughout the course of my reading this insanely ambitious novel, I had to stop and marvel at the fact its author, Maggie Shipstead, is younger than me. Because she writes with the wisdom and knowledge of someone who's at least twice her age. To dive into “Great Circle” is to take flight on two parallel journeys—one set primarily between the 1920s-1950s alongside daredevil female pilot Marian Graves and the other alongside the young actress Hadley Baxter who, in modern times, gets cast to portray Marian in a big-screen biopic. “Great Circle” ticked so many boxes for someone who’s a history buff and pop culture aficionado like me—twins! aviation! Prohibition! art! WWII drama! Hollywood! celebrity!—that I’m confident those are all reasons why, despite the book clocking in at 600+ pages, I was able to devour it in a week’s time. If any of those topics sound interesting to you, then I encourage you to add this (big!) sweeping narrative to your summer reading list. In the words of NYT er Lynne Steger Strong, “‘Great Circle’ starts high and maintains altitude. One might say it soars.” For me, this sentiment rang true right up through an ending that both satisfied and surprised me in a way that only the best novels can and do....more

review: This book is such an amazing debut. Author Dawnie Walton made me wholeheartedly believe that Opal Jewel and Nev Charles were an IRL interracial ‘70s rThis book is such an amazing debut. Author Dawnie Walton made me wholeheartedly believe that Opal Jewel and Nev Charles were an IRL interracial ‘70s rock duo—and the oral history format in which this book unfolds played a huge role in making the pair’s story feel all the more real and iconic. Whereas Taylor Jenkins Reid used this same format to great effect as a way to explore the inner workings of her fictional Daisy Jones and the Six, Walton employs it more so to explore bigger, more external themes—from race to cultural appropriation in music—that are as relevant today as they were in 1971.If you love oral histories and rock-n-roll journalism as much as I do, then you won’t be disappointed by this read (only by the fact that you can’t go out and buy a copy of Opal and Nev’s “Polychrome” for yourself)!...more

(I didn't know this, which is why, about 70 pages in, I found myself Googling past pandemics, wondering when I had missed the big one she was referring to that happened in the mid-1800s, then realizing she'd made it up. See also: her interpretation of the makeup of members belonging to the actual Hole-in-the-Wall Gang.)2) This particular band of bandits features "queer cowgirls, gender nonconforming robbers, and a band of feminists fighting against the grain for autonomy, agency, and the power to define their own worth." She's a comedian, actress, and the first Black woman to write for a late-night network talk sh2021 is the year I discovered the amazing Amber Ruffin. She's a comedian, actress, and the first Black woman to write for a late-night network talk show (Late Night with Seth Meyers). I started following her on Instagram shortly after the new year, and I've liked every one of her posts, many of which are snippets of her monologues from her own late-night show on NBC's Peacock. In a similar vein as Trevor Noah, Amber uses caustic humor to explore our country's social justice issues. Last month, she released her first book with her sister, Lacey, chronicling the many (many) incidents of racism Lacey has encountered in her personal and professional life in Omaha, Nebraska. When I say I loved this book, I mean I LOVED THIS BOOK. On audio, it's an A+ listen. That's almost entirely because of Amber's comedic timing and delivery. She and her sister had me laughing out loud multiple times, and, just as often, shaking my head in "Can you believe this shit?" agreement. To give you an idea of just how good this book is, one of the mornings I was listening to it while getting ready for work, my husband overheard a bit of it and got so sucked in that he sat on the edge of the tub and listened to the rest of the chapter with me. As we both discussed, it's truly appalling the extent of microaggressions that Black women and men put up with on a daily basis. Listening to a book like this reminds those of us who are white that we need to do a hell of a lot better calling out this kind of racist behavior (in stores, in our workplaces, and in social settings). Thank you, Amber and Lacey, for emboldening us to speak up—and for finding the humor in the crazy shit that comes with being Black. ...more
