title: Afterparties
author: So, Anthony Veasna
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: “Afterparties” first came to my attention back in the winter, when it landed on some list I read on the Internet of most anticipated book releases for“Afterparties” first came to my attention back in the winter, when it landed on some list I read on the Internet of most anticipated book releases for 2021. I knew little about the author, and I don’t typically delve into collections of short stories, but, intrigued enough by the promise of learning more about Cambodian culture, I added it to my “to reads” list.I was about three stories into this collection when, amidst my Googling of topics like the Khmer Rouge, “The Killing Fields,” and the resettlement of Cambodian refugees to California after the end of so much ‘70s era conflict in Southeast Asia, I discovered this stellar profile of Anthony Veasna So, written by the talented journalist, E. Alex Jung. I was SHOCKED to discover Anthony had died of an overdose on December 8, 2020, less than a year before he could experience the release of the book he had, at 28, dedicated his young life to creating. It’s a crying shame he’s gone, too, because, as Jung writes, Anthony would have delighted in the praise that followed for his (in the words of the NYT) “witty and soulful” stories.Many of the stories are indeed that. They are also a comprehensive glimpse into the lives of “Cambos” who struggle to process the legacy of their family’s past traumas as a result of the genocide that led to the fracturing of Cambodia and the deaths of between 1.5 and 3 million of its people between 1975 and 1979.Discovering Jung’s profile in tandem with reading “Afterparties” made for an unforgettable reading experience—a chance to dive deep into the inspirations of a particular artist who proudly lived his queer, immigrant life on the page.Because short stories are reading that’s “slippery” to me (meaning, I later blank on most, if not all, of the stories I read when I do pick up collections), I wanted to make note of my favorites from “Afterparties” so I don’t soon forget them: “Three Women of Chuck’s Donuts”—the first story in the collection (and previously published in the New Yorker) there was a cinematic quality to this story of a mother and her two daughters holding down the family’s all-night donut shop that I found particularly arresting“Superking Son Scores Again”—an interesting introduction to Cambodians’ passion for the sport of badminton that was equal parts funny and informative “Generational Differences”—Initially I sort of rolled my eyes at this one, because the fact AVS writes it in second person felt like an annoying hat tip to his MFA training, but I found this story—a sort of “looking back” manifesto written to a son from a mother who survived the Khmer Rouge and also witnessed a school shooting at a Stockton elementary school—to be a powerful one and it left me guessing how much of it may have been autobiographical for the author and his family....more

review: This year, the copyright expires on “The Great Gatsby,” which means the American classic belongs to the public domain—which means *any* writer out theThis year, the copyright expires on “The Great Gatsby,” which means the American classic belongs to the public domain—which means *any* writer out there is welcome to take a crack at re-interpreting Fitzgerald’s most famous work. One of the first authors to take a go at it is Michael Farris Smith, whose new release “Nick” serves as a prequel to “Gatsby.”The book’s dust jacket—itself a reinterpretation of “Gatsby”’s most iconic cover—was enough to lure me in. But what kept me turning the pages is my long-held appreciation for Nick Carraway. In “Nick,” we are with the character on the battlefields of World War I, then back home again to the Midwest, an ill-fated sojourn in New Orleans, and beyond. Smith’s version of Nick, a young veteran confronting the traumas of war, pandemic, and economic decline, reminded me that history has a habit of repeating itself. Leaving behind a year in which Americans have endured so many losses, I found myself wondering if, post-pandemic, we (like Nick) might get our own version of the Roaring ‘20s. And if we do, then who are the new Fitzgeralds whose work will define this time for us 100 years from now?...more

review: I love a good book that is 9/10ths of the way to being a screenplay and that’s exactly how Steven Rowley’s “The Guncle” played out for me.The story ceI love a good book that is 9/10ths of the way to being a screenplay and that’s exactly how Steven Rowley’s “The Guncle” played out for me.The story centers on Patrick, a gay man who’s grieving a past love and living like a recluse in Palm Springs before he’s coerced into spending his summer caring for his young niece and nephew, Maisie and Grant, whose mother, Sara, has just died from cancer.Sara was Patrick’s BFF before she fell in love with Patrick’s younger brother, Greg (who coincidentally checks himself into rehab in the first 10 pages of the book … hence the set-up for why the kids are spending 90 days with Gay Uncle Patrick—or GUP for short). There were scenes in this book that made me laugh out loud, and others so tender and contemplative on the topic of loss and love and family and regret that I felt compelled to read certain lines twice. As one Goodreads er so aptly described it, this book is “charmingcholy”, through and through. The ending of this book was especially rewarding, as Rowley allows Patrick to discover a fresh start for himself in a way that lets him build off his charisma as the former star of a popular network sitcom. Playing casting director in my mind, I tried out Jim Parsons as Patrick before deciding I’d love to see what Matt Bomer would do if given the opportunity to play GUP. Either way, I’m on board for a book-to-TV adaptation that features an actor who is *actually* gay landing the lead role.[EDITED as of 6/2/21 to add: I sat in on a virtual Zoom event with Steven Rowley and he suggested that he could see Dan Levy as Patrick and OMG YES PLEASE I WANT THAT FOR THIS ADAPTATION][EDITED as of 6/9/21: This LitHub essay Patrick wrote is a great companion read to the book.]...more

review: I've long been a fan of Lenny Kravitz—from his music, to his voice, to his remarkable good looks.But prior to listening to his memoir, I can't say I kI've long been a fan of Lenny Kravitz—from his music, to his voice, to his remarkable good looks.But prior to listening to his memoir, I can't say I knew much about his personal life. That's why, for me, this book was an absolute treat from cover to cover. I loved listening to Lenny share insights into his young life (this first volume covers his childhood to the making of his first record). With a white father who worked in journalism and a Black mother who was a stage actress before she landed a starring role on "The Jeffersons," Lenny had access to a fairly privileged world (both in NYC and LA) that, for someone who loves the arts as much as I do, read as a kind of heaven.His upbringing was not without problems (like so many artists, his relationship with his father was especially strained), but his life story overall (especially with all the name dropping) felt like a crash course in Black excellence.I loved how he detailed the years-long GRIND that went into finally landing commercial success as an artist, as well as the chapters that chronicled his love for Lisa Bonet and the early days of their marriage, along with the birth of their daughter, the talented actress, Zoe Kravitz.Kravitz is a fantastic storyteller with a smoky, sultry voice made for audiobook narration. my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: One of my book besties chose this book as one of his favorites of 2020. With his  in mind, I bought it on audio (because who doesn’t want Carey One of my book besties chose this book as one of his favorites of 2020. With his  in mind, I bought it on audio (because who doesn’t want Carey Mulligan reading to them in their ear?) …and then promptly forgot about it.Cue a long car ride this spring, which equaled lots of time to listen, which allowed me to fall hard for this tale about a young woman, Nora, who, on the brink of suicide (trigger warning x 10: those first chapters are TOUGH) gets the chance to relive dozens of different versions of her life. In “trying on” these lives—from an Olympian to a famous singer to a glaciologist to (my favorite) a professor/mother/wife (I <3ed Ash!)—she discovers her real life is, in fact, very much worth fighting for. I’m a sucker for plots like this (see also: George Bailey in ‘It’s a Wonderful Life’ or Domhnall Gleeson’s character in ‘About Time’). As bleak as this one nearly turned, it had that same affirming quality that reminds us that we never know whose lives we impact day to day or how small gestures on our part can have a significant impact on others around us.In my own personal “Midnight Library”, here are a handful of lives I’d be curious to “try on” for a few hours or a few days (she types while acknowledging that, just like Nora, the life I’m presently living suits me perfectly!)1) Famous actress taking the stage to accept her Oscar2) Debut author on the call with her agent and editor to learn her novel just landed on the NYT best-sellers list3) Astronaut docked on the ISS (because my brain SO does not work like this so I’d be curious to experience it!)4) A singer about to take the stage at a folk festival (I can’t sing for shit, so that would be a trip-ha!)5) Literary agent living her best life in NYC with a fabulous apartment (that, since this is make-believe, is outside of her pay grade and overlooks Central Park)6) Travel writer (a la Anthony Bourdain) on her latest assignment to some place exotic, like Borneo7) Chef at a Michelin-starred restaurant (I would be SO curious to experience the pace of life of this profession—and to have that kind of culinary talent!)8) Tennis pro who’s one set away from winning Wimbledon. (I’m not much of a competitive athlete, so it would be surreal, as it was for Nora, to experience what life would be like in the body of one!) What type of lives would *you* want to try on? ...more

title: Malibu Rising
author: Reid, Taylor Jenkins*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As someone who has read (and loved) every one of TJR's books, I think her newest release will prove to be her most divisive. I say this because, basedAs someone who has read (and loved) every one of TJR's books, I think her newest release will prove to be her most divisive. I say this because, based on a few early GR s, there appear to be readers who aren't on board with what she's trying to accomplish with "Malibu Rising." Before I break down the reasons why I disagree with them, let me acknowledge that what I've long loved about TJR is her willingness to push herself as an artist. I've read all her titles, and I've enjoyed their progression from standard women's fiction to novels with bigger thematic and structural risks (e.g., the incorporation of Old Hollywood tabloids in "Evelyn" and the oral narrative of "Daisy Jones"). With "Malibu Rising," she's broken the novel in half: the first section is told in third-person omniscient style (a style popular in classic lit), wherein we're inside the heads of all the Rivas, from parents Mick and June to their offspring, Nina, Jay, Hud, and Kit. The chapters jump perspective AND time, which was a style I settled into after a few chapters, but may not work for every reader.In the second half of the novel, we follow the plot from inside the heads of a host of characters—A-list celebrity, model, and lowly caterer alike—in attendance at Nina Riva's epic annual summer bash. Again, this style of narrative head-hopping won't work for some, but for me, it reminded me of some of my favorite '80s and '90s "party" flicks (e.g., "Sixteen Candles" and "Can't Hardly Wait"). When done well, you don't care that you're only "meeting" these characters once or twice—they still have a line or scene that makes them memorable. And for me, that rang as true with "Malibu Rising" as it did those films. (Case in point: Vaughn Donovan, aka the "Plate Thrower")At its heart, this book is about the bonds of family. But, true to the style TJR has grown into, it's also about celebrities, fame culture, and the place that is the epicenter of where the two collide.Already I'm eager (as always) for what TJR puts into the world next. It's fun to imagine a future novel of hers set at the Chateau Marmont or, true to the way she creatively pushes herself, maybe she'll give us her version of "Mulholland Drive" next. Wherever she takes her readers, I'll be ready for the ride.A FEW LINES I WANT TO REMEMBER-----(these were two scenes I really, really loved)[the moment when Ashley, Hud's girlfriend, leaves the party...Springsteen lover that I am, it's writing like this that is a primary reason why TJR is my No. 1 Author Crush]:"As she pulled out onto PCH, "Hungry Heart" started playing through her speakers and Ashley felt just the tiniest bit of hope. Your whole world could be falling apart, she thought, but then Springsteen will start playing on the radio."[The way TJR describes how Kit grieves is...exactly the way I grieve, too]: "The two of them still held pockets of grief in their bodies that bubbled up at inopportune moments. **Kit, particularly, grieved the way some people drink, which is to say: rarely but always alone and to excess.** So she could not keep Mick's gaze at that very moment because she did not want to cry."...more

review: I discovered Kate's poetry when she was first featured on Joanna Goddard's Cup of Jo blog and I've been a fan (especially of her Instagram account) evI discovered Kate's poetry when she was first featured on Joanna Goddard's Cup of Jo blog and I've been a fan (especially of her Instagram account) ever since. So, it was a full-circle moment to finally be able to support her by purchasing her first collection of poetry this fall.What I loved most about these poems is how arresting so many of them were. With just a few stripped down lines, Baer is able to capture an essential sentiment about womanhood/motherhood—a feat that, more than a few times, left me in breathless awe of her tremendous talent. Here is one such poem I never want to forget—a poem that took me *right* back to the delivery room on the afternoon my daughter was born. It was a day that made me feel closer to God in a way that might as well have been my personal version of a Terrence Malick/"Tree of Life" movie montage. Kate's words returned me to that otherworldly moment: "On the Evening of Her Birth"On the evening of her birth, the first one with its dim light and tender room, an afterbirthstill pulsing.Here is the beginning, the earth and its fragilityheaped on your chest while you lean over to drink,still clad in the robe you picked out with your motherone Saturday. Even the glass of water is poetry now.There is a shriek of hunger, your bruised body bending.Oh, you wonder, is this religion? The swirl of hair tuckedunder your chin while you breathe.I am yours, I am yours, I am yours. ...more

title: Wintering: The Power of Rest and Retreat in Difficult Times
author: May, Katherine
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I picked the perfect time (between Xmas and bleeding over into the week after New Year's) to read this book, which is one part rumination on how to emI picked the perfect time (between Xmas and bleeding over into the week after New Year's) to read this book, which is one part rumination on how to embrace the concept of "wintering" (accepting the lessons that accompany life's toughest seasons); one part ode to the stark beauty of winter; and one part travelogue of places and pastimes that are decidely "winter-ish" (ie, road tripping in Iceland, chasing the Northern Lights in Norway, swimming off the coast of England in January). It's the type of book that comes along as the best kind of surprise, one that braids together topics that until the moment you pick it up, you'd never given that much thought to how—or even why—they belong together. For these reasons and more, I'll be thinking about this read for a long time, and gifting it to a few chosen people in the years to come, too.Here were a few favorite passages (I had so many that I probably had 50+ highlighted notes when I was done!):"Once we stop wishing it were summer, winter can be a glorious season in which the world takes on a sparse beauty and even the pavements sparkle. It's a time for reflection and recuperation, for slow replenishment, for putting your house in order. Doing those deeply unfashionable things—slowing down, letting your spare time expand, getting enough sleep, resting—is a radical act now, but it is essential. This is a crossroads as we all know, a moment when you need to shed a skin. If you do, you'll expose all those painful nerve endings and feel so raw that you'll need to take care of yourself for a while. If you don't, then that skin will harden around you. It's one of the most important choices you'll ever make."“Then we enter that strange period between Christmas and New Year, when time seems to muddle, and we find ourselves asking again and again, What day is it? What date? I always mean to work on these days, or at least to write, but this year, like every other, I find myself unable to gather up the necessary intent. I used to think that these were wasted days, but I now realize that’s the point. I am doing nothing very much, not even actively being on “holiday”. I clear out my cupboards, ready for another year’s onslaught of cooking and eating. I take Bert out to play with friends. I go for cold walks that make my ears ache. I am not being lazy. I’m not slacking. I’m just letting my attention shift for a while, away from the direct ambitions of the rest of my year. It’s like revving my engines.”"Winter is the best season for walking, as long as you can withstand a little earache and are immune to mud. Best are the coldest days when even that freezes solid and the ground crunches underfoot, firm and satisfying. A good frost picks out every blade of grass, the crenellated edge of every leaf. The cold renders everything exquisite." ...more

review: One of the reasons I love my book club is because it gets me to read books I would never otherwise pick up.Enter Ivan Doig's "The Whistling Season." SOne of the reasons I love my book club is because it gets me to read books I would never otherwise pick up.Enter Ivan Doig's "The Whistling Season." Set shortly after the turn of the 20th century, this book portrayed a vanished way of Western life, one complete with a one-room school house and detailed descriptions of the hardships of a pioneering existence on the prairie. The plot is narrated by one of the three sons, Paul, of Oliver Milliron, a dirt farmer whose wife dies and who is in need of a housekeeper to help him and his boys. The woman who shows up, Rose, brings her brother-in-law, Morris, along, and the drama that unfolds makes for a heartwarming story with cinematic qualities, a lovely nod to Halley's Comet, and a surprise twist ending! I tend to stick to one of several lanes as a reader (contemporary, literary, women's fiction) and rarely explore writers who are known for their work on a geographic basis. In reading this, I learned that Doig has been described as the "reigning master of Western literature," and I enjoyed discussing his work with my sister in law, who lives in Bozemann and is quite the fan of the fellow Montanan....more

title: Leave the World Behind
author: Alam, Rumaan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book took me out of my skin in a quietly uncomfortable, yet compulsively readable way.Reading some of the s of it—"It's like the events of This book took me out of my skin in a quietly uncomfortable, yet compulsively readable way.Reading some of the s of it—"It's like the events of 2020 meets 'Get Out'"—I found myself nodding in agreement. It IS that. It's also not a book I would recommend to just anyone (especially if they're prone to anxiety or triggered by doomsday prophecy).My unease with this book was heightened by my physical surroundings on the night I finished it, which happened to be Halloween. We were driving back from a (physically distanced because #2020) visit with family, and I was reading on my phone in the car. At a certain point, a friend texted me a link to a news story about the caravans that had ran the Biden campaign bus off the interstate, and the account deeply disturbed me. That news story felt like a harbinger of bad things to come, and that word—harbinger—is basically the plot of "Leave the World Behind" in a nutshell. So yeah, on a holiday filled with its own spookiness, in a year with a nothing-but-ominous news cycle, I was sitting in our vehicle, reading this nail-biting book, and THEN we were nearly in an accident when a truck careened in front of us on the 465 loop around Indianapolis. (Cue the Hitchcock strings.)By the time we made it home, I felt more wound up—because of the election, because of the state of the world, because of our near-miss on the interstate—than I have at any other point in 2020! Maybe it was fitting then, that I would finish this foreboding book on a night that already had my heart racing—a night when I was more than ready to leave both the fictional world I was stuck in (and the real one I wanted to get out of) behind. Related: I decided to read this b/c I knew about the Netflix adaptation in the works with Julia Roberts and Denzel Washington. I really enjoyed picturing them as two of the main characters (Roberts as Amanda; Washington as G.H. Washington), and I also found myself thinking this *could* be a rare instance where I end up liking the film more than the book. We'll see...but knowing this news is why I chuckled at the wish fulfillment aspect of the author slipping a "You look like Denzel Washington" line about G.H. into the book. Now, what will make that line work overtime is if they end up having Julia say it to him in the film!)...more

title: Kind of Hindu
author: Kaling, Mindy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This fall, Mindy Kaling released a series of short essays on Amazon. And because they were released as individual titles (which is ridiculous, given eThis fall, Mindy Kaling released a series of short essays on Amazon. And because they were released as individual titles (which is ridiculous, given each is the equivalent of about 10 pages long, but I'm sure was a marketing ploy), GoodReads wants me to  them each individually, too. Instead of doing that, I'm just going to tell you in one swoop that I read—and enjoyed—all of them. And if you're a fan of Kaling's, you will enjoy them, too. It's just that simple. Because almost everything this woman does is good. (Top-rated TV series? Good. Comedic movie starring the goddess Emma Thompson? Good. Two NYT best-selling collections of essays? Good.) In the case of these stories, they're effortlessly good. The kind of good that makes obvious that Mindy is a born storyteller. The kind of good wherein she admits she cranked them out in her bed at night, after doing all the other awesome things she does in her day-to-day life (from being a hands-on single mom to helping run a production empire) and they are STILL that good. Some of the stories in this collection are fluff. ("Searching for Coach Taylor" is basically just Mindy humorously professing her undying love for Coach Taylor....which, can't all FNL fans relate to?)Some of the stories are hilarious. ("Once Upon a Time in Silverlake" is Mindy sharing about the time her and BFF BJ Novak were...well, not quite, but almost carjacked in LA by a drifter who looked like an "extremely worse-for-wear Sean William Scott" and who recognized them from "The Office.") But others are more emotional (like this one, "Kind of Hindu," about her desire to raise her daughter as Hindu and how complicated that wish proved to be, given her own falling out with the faith she was born into). Then there is the one that got to me most as a mother myself (one who is lucky enough to still have her own mom to look up to) and that's "Help is On the Way." In it, Mindy writes about how much she misses her mom and how hard it was not to have her there to help her when her daughter, Katherine, was born. I loved reading about how Mindy was able to find a live-in nurse (Rose) who became a surrogate mother figure in her life right when she needed one most. To me, that story was a powerful reminder that when we look at celebrities who we think "have it all," that's not always the case. I'm pretty sure Mindy would trade on her fame and fortune for the opportunity to relive her daughter's first few months with her beloved mother at her side. If you're looking for something light but also lovely (in a way that might make you tear up, but in the best way), I can't recommend these stories enough for your holiday reading....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Christina Clancy’s sophomore novel, “Shoulder Season,” introduced me to a character I didn’t expect to appreciate as much as I did—Sherry Taylor, a yoChristina Clancy’s sophomore novel, “Shoulder Season,” introduced me to a character I didn’t expect to appreciate as much as I did—Sherry Taylor, a young Midwesterner who, in an attempt to find herself after losing her mother, lands herself a gig at a Playboy resort that once operated in the lake country of Wisconsin.Much to my surprise, I was completely fascinated by the detailed scenes of what life as a Playboy Bunny was like for these women, many of them small town girls suddenly surrounded by the glitz and glamour of the celebrity set who frequented the resort. This book was a lesson in why we shouldn't judge a woman for her profession—a truth I was reminded of when I read a recent essay Christina wrote for Lit Hub: "Every woman’s experience is worth investigating, and if former Bunnies felt their time spent in a costume was fun and empowering, that’s valid, especially if there were so few other avenues available to them if they wanted to have a blast. Telling their story is a means of listening to them, and to think about what they did and why they did it in the context of their own lives and times. If we only look at them as sex objects, we’re no better than the men who were titillated by them. The narrative isn’t that simple, and fiction shouldn’t be either."Add to the story the backdrop of a famous Midwestern lake scene (I stole a lot of breaks to Google Lake Geneva and old pictures of the resort) and a doomed romance that offers up a big surprise in those final few pages, and you have a sun-soaked work of historic fiction that I found hard to put down during a recent vacation with my husband’s family....more

title: The Beauty in Breaking

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's been a long time since I've read a memoir written by a physician (see: Atul Gawande's "Complications" and "Better"), so diving into "Beauty" was It's been a long time since I've read a memoir written by a physician (see: Atul Gawande's "Complications" and "Better"), so diving into "Beauty" was an evocative reminder of ... how much I weirdly love this genre?Are there enough medical memoirs out there to even *call* it a genre? I'm not sure. But what I do know is that, much like Gawande sucked me in with his stories of the medical field, I became emotionally invested in the lives of each of Harper's patients whose stories melded with her own. A few grabbed me more than others (Baby Doe and Joshua, especially), but all provided powerful insights into medicine and into a bevvy of related topics that served as emotional baggage for each patient (from abuse and racism to addiction and socioeconomic decline)—topics that are as timely as ever in 2020. Harper is a phenomenal writer, and if she chooses to write more books on her profession, I would be happy to read them. For now, I'll settle for reading and watching interviews with her (like this stellar one with Trevor Noah, another creative crush of mine), and remembering a few memorable passages from her memoir, which I've shared below. On how her wealthy family kept the abuse at the hands of her stepfather a secret for so long:"Like all elites, we didn't expose our private, upper-middle-class shame to the public sphere. Why would we have? After all, we had worked too hard to get here to risk a crack in the fragile facade that fronted our legitimacy. All elites knew the code: Take your pills with your cocktail, use your cosmetics to cover the blemishes and bruises, clean up quickly, whatever it takes so you can present a smiling, perfectly coiffed and clad self to the world.""America still has so many more strides to make. I am evidence.""...these details fall under the category of 'it's not my job,' but that's what doctors are often called to do, and it's what makes it impossible for us to excel at what is actually our job. In emergency medicine, as in the case of the overworked mechanic, working outside one's prescribed duties makes the work dangerous. All this, of course, doesn't answer the most important question I was forced to answer: How many of the shortcomings of this modern health care system was I willing to put up with?" ...more

review: It's been a few weeks since I finished this harrowing but mesmerizing read. And one of the ways I know it's one of the best books I've read this year It's been a few weeks since I finished this harrowing but mesmerizing read. And one of the ways I know it's one of the best books I've read this year is because I'm still thinking and talking about it with friends and family members. It takes a supremely talented researcher and storyteller to weave the complicated history of a misunderstood mental disorder with the chilling story of a family that unraveled because of it—and I think Robert Kolker pulled off this double feat with style, grace, and a deep respect for his subjects.I was as engrossed learning about, for example, early treatments of schizophrenia (insulin injections to induce comas? AYFKM?), as I was reading about the trials and tribulations of the poor Galvin family. This book is profoundly sad, I won't deny that. But it has fundamentally shifted the way I think about mental illness beyond depression and anxiety, making it one of those hard but necessary reads I am grateful I made the time to invest in discovering. ...more

title: A Burning
author: Majumdar, Megha*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This read is a struggle for me to , because part of me acknowledges the reasons why this debut landed on the short list of National Book Award nThis read is a struggle for me to , because part of me acknowledges the reasons why this debut landed on the short list of National Book Award nominees. And part of me, after reading it, still feels "meh" about it. (The book, I mean ....)I've thought quite a bit about why this book wasn't a knock-out for me, and I think it comes down to the three main characters and their individual story lines. To use an analogy (that will make sense only to me, and maybe the 2 or 3 other GoodRead-ers who stumble upon this ), it takes three strings to make a braid, right? And each string has to be equally strong to hold that braid together. If "A Burning" was a braid, I'd tell you that the strings/stories about Jivan (the Muslim girl accused of bombing a train station) and PT Sir (Jivan's opportunistic gym teacher who hitches his star to a right-wing political party) weren't as strong as the one that pulled you along with Lovely (the hijra on the fast track to becoming the next Bollywood star).For that reason, about a third of the way through the novel, all I could think about was how I no longer cared about Jivan (sad as her story was) or PT Sir (who witnesses a mob murder SO distressing I almost put the book down—ANOTHER reason this one left me lukewarm), and that the only reason I wanted to finish was to find out what happened to Lovely.I guess this  is my long-winded way of saying, had this book been Lovely's life story, it might have been a five-star read for me. Because Majumdar is a wonderful writer, and I learned so much about Indian culture with the glimpses into the lives of these characters she created, Lovely especially. I had never heard of the term "hijra" before, and suddenly, thanks to her, I found myself reading fascinating articles like this one: "The Peculiar Position of Indian's Third Gender". That, at its heart, is the beauty of reading, am I right? ...more

title: The Answer Is…: Reflections on My Life
author: Trebek, Alex
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Up front, Trebek reveals in the introduction of "The Answer Is..." that, for years, he never thought his life warranted a memoir. It wasn’t until he sUp front, Trebek reveals in the introduction of "The Answer Is..." that, for years, he never thought his life warranted a memoir. It wasn’t until he shared his cancer diagnosis with Jeopardy! viewers, and experienced an outpouring of love, that he realized perhaps people *did* want to know more about the guy who’s been reading all those clues to them over the past 35 years. Trebek’s humble manner (a hallmark of Canadians, eh?) and his do-good-ism are evident throughout this book. One example can be found in the stories he reveals about his role as a World Vision Ambassador. He has given generously to the non-profit, and traveled extensively in his role as a humanitarian. Learning this was a nice reminder that, behind the scenes, there are plenty of people in Hollywood who are doing honorable things—the kind of things we should be talking more about IMO. My one critique of this book (which I listened to, with Ken Jennings doing a bang-up job narrating, with Trebek’s trademark voice chiming in to deliver the most personal stories) is that it was organized in a “cutesy” way. Every memory seemed to have a “What Is ….” lead-in to it. This was obviously meant as a tie-in to Jeopardy! but proved cumbersome by the end.What I loved most about "The Answer Is ..." was how Trebek spoke so lovingly about his wife and his children, about his pride in being an American (and what that stands for in light of our democracy’s current struggles), and his acceptance of his cancer and final months of life. (His thoughts on these topics were so poignant and personal they drew a tear to my eye.)Two bits of trivia he shared that I really enjoyed:—The theme song for Jeopardy! was written by show creator Merv Griffin as a lullaby for his infant son. Griffin has earned royalties off the song ever since to a tune of $80 million and counting (about $3 million a year!). Isn’t that crazy?— Trebek has a favorite animal. And it is (drumroll) the MUSKOX. How RANDOM, right? But he describes his great affection for how they are “family oriented” and talks about his years as a devoted activist to the animal. I found this anecdote to be equal parts odd and endearing....more

title: The Four Winds
author: Hannah, Kristin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was about 30 pages into this book when I texted one of my favorite bookish best friends the following: “So, I started Four Winds last night and was I was about 30 pages into this book when I texted one of my favorite bookish best friends the following: “So, I started Four Winds last night and was immediately annoyed at how much this main character is being treated like a 1920s Cinderella.”I stand by that critique of the first third of the book, which set up Elsa Wolcott’s historic world in such a way that, at times, I felt I was reading less about a real person and more so a caricature of a Disney princess. But as I kept reading (because Kristin Hannah makes that so very easy to do), I eventually found myself sucked into the plot, especially once the Dust Bowl hit. Talk about an absolutely fascinating, gut wrenching time in American history. If you have never seen Ken Burns’ Dust Bowl series, you should. It chronicles the horrors of that particular ecological disaster through the testimonies of the real women, men, and children who lived it, and as I was reading Four Winds, I kept picturing the stark visuals and voice overs from that film. Overall, what I enjoyed best about Four Winds was the empathy I felt for Elsa and the hard decisions she had to make as the mother of two young children. And, ever the softie, I fell hard for the romance that ultimately blossomed between her and Jack. At the end, I felt there were a few too many storylines that got shoehorned into the plot, but I finished this book feeling grateful that our present-day hard times are nowhere near as bad as ones like these that our ancestors lived through. I feel compelled to add that many of the issues explored in this book—labor organizing, xenophobia and economic exploitation among them—are issues that still have their hooks in America today. In Hannah’s skilled hands, you read history and find yourself contemplating the troublesome pattern it has of repeating itself. ...more

title: 28 Summers
author: Hilderbrand, Elin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you’re looking for pure escapism on the page (which is exactly what I was craving in these waning days of summer) then Elin Hilderbrand delivers wiIf you’re looking for pure escapism on the page (which is exactly what I was craving in these waning days of summer) then Elin Hilderbrand delivers with her newest novel, “28 Summers.”This is my first book of hers (a fact that surprises me because I’m open to reading anything, but especially “beach reads”). Now that I’ve experienced Hilderbrand’s talent, I can attest she’s a master of her genre in the same way Stephen King “owns” horror and Mary Higgins Clark “owns” suspense. From the opening pages, I was swept up in the story of Mallory and Jake, a couple who never get the timing right for a real relationship outside of the Labor Day weekend they spend together every summer at the Nantucket cabin Mallory inherits from her aunt.Normally I’m not one to get behind a plot that involves infidelity. But Hillenbrand makes the set-up for Mallory and Jake’s affair SO convincing that I went along with it, even if many, *many* times I wanted Jake to throw in the towel on his marriage to his wife, Ursla. This book made me fall hard for all of its characters (even the unlikeable ones). It was zeitgeist-y (which I LOVED, especially the political tie-ins and the blatant references to Kavanaugh and the #MeToo movement). And it made me SUPER nostalgic (driven in large part by its clever use of a “What were we talking about in [fill in the blank year]” plot device that kicked off every chapter). I was sad to come to its (rather abrupt) ending, as fitting as I thought it was. Related: As I was reading this, I sent a text to my book BFF Jamie to comment on how GOOD Hilderbrand is at naming her characters (ie, Jake McCloud—perfect ‘hot guy’ name; Cooper Blessing—perfect WASP name; Bayer Burkhart—perfect billionaire name; Ursula DeGournsey (UDG)—perfect political powerhouse name for a woman whose real-life role model would be RBG) and Jamie wrote back, “It’s a real skill.” Well, I had to laugh when I reached a paragraph in the Acknowledgments where Hilderbrand thanks her friends, including a woman named Debbie Briggs “who named nearly every character in this book; it’s her superpower”! I don’t expect Debbie to ever find her way to this , but if she does, hat tip to you! ...more

title: Afterlife
author: Alvarez, Julia*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: One of the reasons I will always love my book club is because it introduces me to novels I might otherwise never read. Julia Alvarez’s “Afterlife” is One of the reasons I will always love my book club is because it introduces me to novels I might otherwise never read. Julia Alvarez’s “Afterlife” is one such novel. I’m ashamed to admit I’d never heard of Alvarez before this summer (especially since her prior works are considered classics by many). Within the first 5 pages of her latest novel (her first in 15 years) I knew immediately why she is as beloved as she is. In those pages, Sam, the husband of main character Antonia, dies—but it’s the way Alvarez reveals his death (in a discombobulating but beautiful kind of poetry) that really sunk its hooks into me. I want to say I loved the rest of this novel as much as I did the first few chapters, but after awhile it lost a bit of luster for me. Antonia’s tendency to seek direction from the works of literature she loves (and taught for decades as a professor) was a narrative device that ultimately became overused. And her constant nitpicking with her sisters (while colorful and relatable) grew tiring to me, too. What I *did* love was how Alvarez took one tiny detail she introduced in an early chapter (a sticker affixed to her Subaru, a gift received for having made an annual donation to her local sheriff’s fund) and turned it into a kind of Chekhov’s gun—one that delivered a powerful punch by the novel’s end.Overall, a timely read that explores the topics of loss, family, grief, immigration reform, and what we owe society as “good” citizens of our country. I’d recommend this one to readers who love the work of Elizabeth Strout....more

title: Live from New York: An Uncensored History of Saturday Night Live
author: Shales, Tom
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As an oral history of one of the most iconic shows on television, “Live from New York” made for a delightful audio read (and a timely one, too, given As an oral history of one of the most iconic shows on television, “Live from New York” made for a delightful audio read (and a timely one, too, given that the premiere of season FORTY SIX takes place on Saturday). This book does an excellent job of giving readers a comprehensive history of the show (and a deep dive on what so many people think of its creator, Lorne Michaels). I wish it had more about and from the cast members who defined the seasons that I recall with great fondness from my junior high/high school/college years (Will Ferrell, Tina Fey, Kenan Thompson, Amy Poehler, Seth Meyers, and company). But it was a treat to hear from some of the most legendary cast members (Bill Murray among them) and to fall down a few rabbit holes rewatching some of my favorite clips from my childhood.My favorite moment was listening to Dana Carvey recall his debut and hearing him talking about his “Chopping Broccoli” sketch. Watching him at such a young age  in front of that piano (“SHE CHOP UHH”) made me giggle all over again. Gotta love a series that, over the course of nearly 50 years, has given our country so many collective laughs and nostalgic memories.As a critical aside, the commentary from the female cast members was especially insightful, as it was a harsh reminder that women in comedy have mostly had to claw their way into the spotlight. The exception here being the great Gilda Radner, who was spoken about by everyone in this book in such beloved terms you might come away thinking the woman deserves sainthood. ...more

title: Native Guard: Poems: A Pulitzer Prize Winner
author: Trethewey, Natasha
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm not much for poetry (never have been and, despite repeated attempts, have accepted that I likely never will be). But after finishing "Memorial DriI'm not much for poetry (never have been and, despite repeated attempts, have accepted that I likely never will be). But after finishing "Memorial Drive," I felt compelled to discover the collection of poems that won Natasha Trethewey her Pulitzer back in 2007.And .... wow. Why don't I read more poetry again? "Native Guard" is outstanding. The book features a series of poems that shed light on a cast of black soldiers (many newly freed slaves) who, during the Civil War, protect a fort on Ship Island, off the coast of Trethewey's hometown in Mississippi. These men, the Louisiana Native Guards, were the first black regiment to fight for the Union Army. Trethewey finds ways to weave their legacy into the other poems she features in "Native Guard"— poems that largely explore her personal history, including several that honor her late mother (whose too-short life she would examine more fully in 'Memorial Drive').After finishing "Native Guard," I felt bereft. Wanting to hold on to Natasha's talent a bit longer, I took to the Internet to read a few interviews with her, which is how I came across this profile written for Chicago Magazine by another writer I admire, Rebecca Makkai. Highly recommend reading it, because it will leave you even more in awe of Trethewey's remarkable ability to rebuild a life for herself, one no longer defined by the tragedies she's endured....more

title: Caste: The Origins of Our Discontents
author: Wilkerson, Isabel*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Without question, this book is not just one of the most informative (and transformative) books I will read in 2021, but over the course of my life. NoWithout question, this book is not just one of the most informative (and transformative) books I will read in 2021, but over the course of my life. Now that I've absorbed the truths that Wilkerson laid out in these pages, I will never be able to think about racism in America in the same way. For, as Wilkerson describes, caste is "the bones" and race "the skin" in our country's body of discontent. I am in awe of her research and, most especially, her ability to weave disparate ideas (the study of caste systems of India, the Third Reich, and slavery/Jim Crow in the US) into a thoughtful and compelling narrative that reveals the commonalities that existed between these groups all along. Also, I never want to forget that I was reading this on January 6, 2021, when a riot to uphold white supremacy played out within the hallowed halls of our U.S. Capitol. This is what I wrote  about that day—and about this book—on Instagram. What a moment to have Wilkerson's words guiding me through that dark hour in our nation's history. Finally, here are a few passages from the book (my copy has so, so many dog-earred pages) that I don't want to forget: “In our era, it is not enough to be tolerant. You tolerate mosquitoes in the summer, a rattle in an engine, the gray slush that collects at the crosswalk in winter. You tolerate what you would rather not have to deal with and wish would go away. It is no honor to be tolerated. Every spiritual tradition says love your neighbor as yourself, not tolerate them.” “So the real question would be,' he said finally, 'if people were given the choice between democracy and whiteness, how many would choose whiteness?" (Taylor Branch, quoted in Caste)“Radical empathy, on the other hand, means putting in the work to educate oneself and to listen with a humble heart to understand another's experience from their perspective, not as we imagine we would feel. Radical empathy is not about you and what you think you would do in a situation you have never been in and perhaps never will. It is the kindred connection from a place of deep knowing that opens your spirit to the pain of another as they perceive it.Empathy is no substitute for the experience itself. We don't get to tell a person with a broken leg or a bullet wound that they are not in pain. And people who have hit the caste lottery are not in a position to tell a person who has suffered under the tyranny of caste what is offensive or hurtful or demeaning to those at the bottom. The price of privilege is the moral duty to act when one sees another person treated unfairly. And the least that a person in the dominant caste can do is not make the pain any worse.”...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "Citizen" is a slim read that, in essence, is a powerful exploration of the daily micro- and macro- aggressions of racism. There were certain sections"Citizen" is a slim read that, in essence, is a powerful exploration of the daily micro- and macro- aggressions of racism. There were certain sections of this prize-winner that confused me (namely because the work itself feels less like a book and more like art—its contents a mash-up of poetry and lyrics and photos and video scripts), but there were enough essays to ground me in the thematic structure of the work to keep me both reading and learning.To the point on learning, I took to GoodReads to see what others were saying, and found that the many referenced articles in this reader's   were helpful as companion pieces that provided greater understanding about some of the subject material (Serena Williams, Jena 6, Mark Dugan, and Zinedine Zidane) that Rankine wrote about in this book. My copy of "Citizen" was an e-book from the library, which is how I was able to learn (thanks to a teaser at the end) of Rankine's newest release (which just came out last month) called "Just Us: An American Conversation." "If 'Citizen' changed the conversation," the publisher writes, "then 'Just Us' urges all of us into it."Perfect timing, then, to continue where I left off reading the insightful work of this talented writer.[Passages from "Citizen" that moved me to the extent I don't want to forget them] — "Who did what to whom on which day? Who said that? She said what? What did he just do? Did she really just say that? He said what? What did she do? Did I hear what I think I heard? Did that just come out of my mouth, his mouth, your mouth? Do you remember when you sighed?" — "I know whatever was in front of me was happening and then the police vehicle came to a screeching halt in front of me like they were setting up a blockage. Everywhere were flashes, a siren sounding and a stretched-out roar. Get on the ground. Get on the ground now. Then I just knew. And you are not the guy and still you fit the description because there is only one guy who is always the guy fitting the description."— "because white men can't/police their imagination/black people are dying"—"Yes, and this is how you are a citizen. Come on. Let it go. Move on."—"In line at the drugstore it's finally your turn, and then it's not as he walks in front of you and puts his things on the counter. The cashier says, Sir, she was next. When he turns to you he is truly surprised. Oh my God, I didn't see you. You must be in a hurry, I offer. No, no, no, I really didn't see you." ...more

review: I’m not a comic connoisseur by any means, so I only knew about Greg Rucka’s “The Old Guard” once I saw Charlize Theron begin sharing stills from the fI’m not a comic connoisseur by any means, so I only knew about Greg Rucka’s “The Old Guard” once I saw Charlize Theron begin sharing stills from the film adaptation to her Instagram. My curiosity was piqued (because CT excels at being a badass on screen—obviously) and I eagerly anticipated the arrival of this film on Netflix earlier this month. What can I say after watching it and reading the first volume of the comic? Namely that the movie (while hewing close to the source material) is better. Why? Because it takes what’s done well in the comic and ratchets it up ten-fold. Also, the casting is SO superb—the main characters are more diverse (and better looking) than their comic counterparts, as well drawn as they may be. It’s a rare feat to create a comic-verse outside the DC/Marvel realm as well done as The Old Guard. Whether you watch the film or read the comic (or in my case, both), don’t miss out on these characters and their drama because they represent the best new entry to the superhero genre in years.Related: If you’re curious enough, Slate has a great (spoiler-laden) breakdown of the changes Netflix made to the comic—and why they’re for the better. I happily agree with every one, and I’m now waiting on that sequel to drop in 3….2…1….....more

review: Bustle calls Party of Two the perfect summer read for fans of the movie "Long Shot", and I can get down with that description (seeing as how, speech wBustle calls Party of Two the perfect summer read for fans of the movie "Long Shot", and I can get down with that description (seeing as how, speech writer and Charlize Theron fan that I am, I absolutely ADORED that film).But “Party of Two” is also the perfect summer read for those of you who, like me, may want to turn your attention away from all the doom scrolling you’ve been doing and experience two people—fictional though they may be—fall head over heels in love. This is my second novel of Guillory’s and while “Party of Two” gives readers more satisfaction (in terms of fewer fade-to-black romantic scenes) than her earlier books, it also stumbles a bit in the manufactured drama department (which is true of a lot of popular rom-com reads). Despite that minor grievance, I still loved reading this love story and I still think Guillory is very smart and VERY good at creating fiction that too many people think is easy to write (and thereby consider “fluff”). Anybody who’s a writer knows it’s the very best of the crop who can make any form of writing look effortless, and Guillory proves she’s at the top of her game with this latest release of hers.Side note: There is a LOT of cake in this book—so much so that just envisioning eating as much of it as Olivia and Max do made me fear for the diabetes diagnoses in their future! review: Sometimes when I’m bored on my phone, I do what any true bibliophile does: pore over the lists of “Best of” reads for any given year. One night, as I Sometimes when I’m bored on my phone, I do what any true bibliophile does: pore over the lists of “Best of” reads for any given year. One night, as I was on Apple Books (my gateway to reading on my phone), I discovered this paranormal romance had made its way onto one such 2020 list tucked away on the app. I chuckled to myself because the title stood out (in tone and genre) from the other books (which included heavy hitters I’d read and/or seen elsewhere). But since “Reborn Yesterday” was only a few bucks and I needed a new book to read on my phone, I thought, “Why not?”Here’s where I admit that circa 2008-09, I happily devoured the glut of vampire fiction that was EVERYWHERE during those days. (I was equal fans of Edward Cullen AND Eric Northman is what I’m saying.) Now, in 2020, here’s where I admit that (much to my surprise), I was, like the Fug Girls, ready for some “hot vampire shenanigans again.” What I liked most about “Reborn Yesterday” is that there was some solid humor baked into the romance of the plot. (In fact, the way in which the MC, Ginny Lynn, meets the very hot and very undead Jonas Cantrell is a great comedic set-up that would make Taiki Waititi and the rest of the vampire gang from “What We Do in the Shadows” proud.)For a large portion of this book, I enjoyed the plot and the development of these characters, but I struggled toward the end. (Translation: I got bored in certain places, particularly the repetitive descriptions of Ginny and Jonas’ obsession with each other as "mates".) Still, it was an enjoyable enough read (especially for the $$) that if a TV series was developed, I’d be curious enough to want to see which actors were responsible for bringing Ginny and Jonas to life. ...more

author: Sullivan, J. Courtney*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In my previous job, I hired and mentored a string of remarkable young women, many of whom I grew incredibly close to and remain in touch with to this In my previous job, I hired and mentored a string of remarkable young women, many of whom I grew incredibly close to and remain in touch with to this day. It’s for this specific reason—and the fact I’m not so far removed from my own days of mothering an infant—that I am so very, very fond of this book (which happens to have been written by an author who is a favorite of mine).In “Friends and Strangers,” Sullivan mines the relationship between the new mom in her story, Elisabeth, and the college-aged caregiver, Sam (who watches her son), to explore a myriad of topics—from class and privilege to womanhood and what it means to come of age in our modern times.I think this novel would make for a tremendous book club selection—so much could be discussed about the way Sullivan compassionately uses her characters to examine complicated facets of life. I especially loved how she made Elisabeth out to be the sort of woman who is not inherently bad, but who has an obvious blind spot to her own wealth—access to money that has made her life immeasurably easier (but also, in terms of her relationship with her father and sister, harder as well). “Friends and Strangers” is not the kind of book that I would recommend to everyone, but if you read the synopsis and/or my or other people’s s and your interest is piqued, I can promise that, in Sullivan’s talented and capable hands, you will not be disappointed with your decision to pick it up. PS — If you get a minute, check out this NPR interview with Sullivan, wherein you learn both the origin for this book and how an interaction in Sullivan’s own life might have influenced what (to me, at least) was its satisfying ending. And speaking of satisfying, this Washington Post  hits the exact right note on how great this novel is, particularly with this parting line: “Once again, Sullivan has shown herself to be one of the wisest and least pretentious chroniclers of modern life.”...more

review: This book floored me on SO many levels—and pretty much convinced me that Curtis Sittenfeld may be an actual genius. Because it takes an INCREDIBLE amoThis book floored me on SO many levels—and pretty much convinced me that Curtis Sittenfeld may be an actual genius. Because it takes an INCREDIBLE amount of confidence, intellect, and credibility to rewrite the history of a person's life. With "Rodham," Sittenfeld proves she's a master at it (and who knows, maybe she'll tackle John Roberts' life next?) In the first half of this book, Sittenfeld writes in such a candid, revealing way about Hillary's young life that I found myself constantly wondering what was fact and what was fiction (case in point: fictional Hillary's mentor, Gwen, is a convincing stand-in for activist Marian Wright Edelman, a mentor to real-life Hillary). But come the second half, when Hillary and Bill's paths split, I felt my mouth continuing to drop open a little wider with each chapter I read, gobsmacked at the (entirely plausible) alternative history Sittenfeld had created for one of America's most recognizable couples. By the end of this big, brave, remarkable book, I had tears in my eyes, wishing I could stick around a little longer in Sittenfeld's world of make believe—a world in which one of our country's most qualified and capable politicians gets the HEA she deserves....more

review: I loved this book SO much, especially because of its setting (1940s NYC) and the fantastically rendered world that it immersed me in (the magic of theI loved this book SO much, especially because of its setting (1940s NYC) and the fantastically rendered world that it immersed me in (the magic of theater). I had put off reading this last summer when it came out because, well, I'd couched Gilbert as a "writer of non-fiction" in my mind and refused to budge on my limited (though favorable) view of her. Which, how SILLY of me, right? So, I'm glad that "City of Girls" was selected as our July book club pick (which forced me to pick it up) because WOW did it captivate me! As I was reading, I felt so close to all of the players in this novel, from Vivian (the main character) to the many secondary characters (Aunt Peg, Billie, Olive, Edna, Celia, and Frank), all of whom were richly drawn, with backstories as compelling as Vivian's. Perhaps what I adored most about this read is knowing that, in the midst of great uncertainty and grief in her life, Gilbert wrote AND researched the hell out of it. (For REAL, the research in this novel—it's remarkable! I'd love to sit down with Gilbert and just pick her brain for an hour about all the ways she worked to make this book feel as true to life as possible.)In a time of turmoil in our country, when my head's been full of fear, anxiety, and the hard but necessary homework of reading antiracist texts, slipping into the sparkling and salacious world of "City of Girls" felt like the ultimate form of escapism—one I didn't know I needed until this month, when I found myself ever so gratefully immersed in it. Can't wait for the miniseries, which I'm already casting in my mind!...more

title: The Fire Next Time
author: Baldwin, James
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The more Baldwin I read, the more I’m convinced he was a modern-day prophet, sounding the call for racial justice with an urgency and elegance that coThe more Baldwin I read, the more I’m convinced he was a modern-day prophet, sounding the call for racial justice with an urgency and elegance that continues to resonate years after he left this earth.In “The Fire Next Time” (which happens to be the first nonfiction work of his I’ve read), Baldwin explores the topics of race and religion in two essays first published in publications during the early 1960s. The first one, “My Dungeon Shook,” is a letter to his nephew (that was surely the inspiration for Ta-Nehisi Coates’s “Between the World and Me"). The second essay, “Down at the Cross: Letter from a Region in My Mind,” explores Baldwin’s dissolution of faith, his meeting with Elijah Muhammad, and Baldwin's take on why Blacks were historically drawn to the Nation of Islam. I read this book right around the time I watched “I Am Not Your Negro,” and if you’re new to Baldwin, I’ll admit that this documentary is where you want to start. It’s incredible, made all the more special because of how many clips it includes of Baldwin speaking—his intellect on full display, the cadence of his speech fiery, the anger and sorrow in his eyes as electrifying as it is memorable. So yeah, in case it’s not clear, I really, REALLY dig the guy—and I look forward to continuing to read everything he’s ever written. Here are a few passages from “Fire” I don’t want to soon forget:“White people in this country will have quite enough to do in learning how to accept and love themselves and each other, and when they have achieved this—which will not be tomorrow and may very well be never—the Negro problem will no longer exist, for it will no longer be needed.”“Therefore, whatever white people do not know about Negroes reveals, precisely and inexorably, what they do not know about themselves.”“If the concept of God has any validity or any use, it can only be to make us larger, freer, and more loving. If God cannot do this, then it is time we got rid of Him.”“Depressed populations don’t have the time or energy to spare [to read]. The affluent populations, which should have been their help, didn’t, as far as could be discovered, read, either—they merely bought books and devoured them, but not in order to learn: in order to learn new attitudes.”And WOW does this line drive home how current Baldwin’s words and ideals remain:“It demands great force and great cunning continually to assault the might and indifferent fortress of white supremacy, as Negroes in this country have done so long.  It demands great spiritual resilience not to hate the hater whose foot is on your neck, and an even greater miracle of perception and clarity not to teach your child to hate. The Negro boys and girls who are facing mobs today come out of a long line of improbable aristocrats—the only genuine aristocrats this country has produced.” ...more

title: The Second Home
author: Clancy, Christina*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are some books that you can tell, even within the first few pages, will imprint on your heart forever. Christina Clancy’s debut, “Second Home,” There are some books that you can tell, even within the first few pages, will imprint on your heart forever. Christina Clancy’s debut, “Second Home,” is one such book for me. Its plot centers on a Midwestern family from Milwaukee who summers in their old family home (one passed down for generations) in Wellfleet (halfway between the “tip” and the “elbow” of Cape Cod). The book’s three main characters, Ann, Poppy, and Michael, alternate points of view throughout the novel—their complicated dynamics and life-altering secrets acting as the glue that holds this beautifully rendered narrative together.So why is “Second Home” a five-star kind of read for me? Because it falls into that small but remarkable category of novels I’ve read wherein the characters feel SO real, it’s as if, should I look up from the page, I’d see them sitting across from me. For that reason, I know that these three siblings—along with their fabulous parents, Ed and Connie—will never leave my heart. At various points in my life moving forward, I’ll think of them in that way that will make me wonder, “What are they up to now?”Sigh. I’m already jealous of anybody who gets a chance to read this for the first time. ...more

review: It was surreal during a pandemic to read a novel about a young Asian American woman who...survives a pandemic. And yet, I couldn't put this novel downIt was surreal during a pandemic to read a novel about a young Asian American woman who...survives a pandemic. And yet, I couldn't put this novel down! Its plot braids the backstory of the main character's immigrant experience with the story of her life working as a millennial through the early stages of the pandemic, followed by the story of her journey with the cult-like survival group she ends up with as the pandemic progresses. It's uncanny the ways in which Ma, whose novel was released in 2018, predicted our current global crisis. And it’s perhaps because of these eerie parallels that this book's handling of topics like capitalism and self-worth and the theme of "what constitutes as a good life" resonated with me all the more....more

review: The first few chapters of "Writers & Lovers" left me cold because the book began with a lot of short, declarative scenes that offered little in the waThe first few chapters of "Writers & Lovers" left me cold because the book began with a lot of short, declarative scenes that offered little in the way of dialogue. In that way, I found it very Hemingway-esque—which is why I almost abandoned it before I hit Page 75! BUT .... the writing was too good NOT to persevere, and I'm so glad I did because the rest of this novel (which, honestly, felt like an entirely separate story from the narrative contained in the first third of the book) was truly outstanding.The more time I spent with the main character, Casey, the more I fell for her as I followed along with her efforts to finish her first novel, all while waiting tables at a fancy Boston restaurant. At the same time, she's mourning the recent loss of her mother while juggling two relationships with fellow writers: one with established author Oscar (whose young sons become smitten with her) and the other with Silas, who's closer to her age but distant in ways that make it hard for her to get close to him. Where this book REALLY sunk its teeth into me was in the final chapters, which left me (as someone who dreams of publishing a book one day) with a racing heart and sweaty palms, equal parts thrilled and anxious on Casey's behalf. In the end, W&L proved to be a brilliant novel that, IMO, opened as slowly and as beautifully as a rose in a springtime garden. It's bound to end up on my Top 10 List of Reads for 2020, for sure. ...more

review: Samantha Irby’s latest collection of essays, “Wow, No Thank You,” is my favorite work of hers yet. Her deadpan humor and confessional approach to writSamantha Irby’s latest collection of essays, “Wow, No Thank You,” is my favorite work of hers yet. Her deadpan humor and confessional approach to writing are on full display once more, polished to the point where I experienced even more laugh-out-loud moments in “Wow” than in “We Are Never Meeting in Real Life.”I think a big reason I loved “Wow” so much is that, having read “Real Life” before it, I knew enough about Irby to feel a personal connection to her life stories as she updated us about the status of her marriage, her relationship with her stepkids, her credit score, her bodily functions, and the evolution of her career from working at an animal hospital to becoming friends and writing partners with the likes of Abbi Jacobson and Lindy West. (Samantha’s essay about how Abbi befriends her, as well as her essay about the summer she spent in LA, writing for the TV adaptation of “Shrill,” were my absolute favorites in “Wow”—mostly because I am a pop culture junkie and so reading about a fellow Midwesterner’s misadventures in Hollywood was extremely my jam.)Overall, I recommend reading Irby if you’ve never given her a try. This interview is a great introduction to how much of an open book she is—not to mention off-the-cuff funny. Her sarcasm is the perfect antidote to these anxiety-inducing times we are living in, and I’ve become a dedicated fan who forevermore will read anything she writes....more

title: The Only Plane in the Sky: An Oral History of 9/11
author: Graff, Garrett M.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: On this 20th anniversary of 9/11, I finally felt emotionally prepared to listen to the audiobook of Garrett Graff’s award-winning “The Only Plane in tOn this 20th anniversary of 9/11, I finally felt emotionally prepared to listen to the audiobook of Garrett Graff’s award-winning “The Only Plane in the Sky: An Oral History of 9/11”. From the minute I pressed play, I was sucked into this book, which provides a minute-by-minute account from hundreds of people who were part of this tragic day but also reveals many telling details I never knew about—from the marine evacuation of lower Manhattan to where President Bush went to wait out the attacks to how flight controllers coordinated landing every other plane in the sky.This was an *incredibly* gut-wrenching read. And yet, I found myself making every excuse I could this past week to get back to it. In part because, as Graff writes in an afterword, for too many of us, the events of 9/11 have shifted focus to the geopolitical consequences of that day, from the creation of the TSA to the war in Afghanistan. What has gotten lost along the way are the human stories—the vivid memories of people present at the tragedy, from first responders to officer workers in the towers to government leaders to children recalling their memories of the morning. We like to use the hashtag #NeverForget when we talk about 9/11, and yet, the more time passes, the harder it is for all of us to remember the details of that day. Thanks to the work of Graff and so many other historians, there exists this incredible collection of these personal stories, culled from thousands of oral histories, to make sure that we never do. If you, like me, want to find a small but significant way to honor the victims of this day, I encourage you to pick this book up and press “Play.”...more

title: A Very Punchable Face
author: Jost, Colin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really needed a funny book to lighten the "heavy" of some other reads I’ve plowed through in recent weeks, and Colin Jost delivered ten-fold for me I really needed a funny book to lighten the "heavy" of some other reads I’ve plowed through in recent weeks, and Colin Jost delivered ten-fold for me with his memoir, “A Very Punchable Face.” I laughed out loud while listening to him read me these stories—so many times, in fact, I lost count. But I know one of the first occasions was in his introduction, when Colin riffs about why he knows he looks like someone who’s punchable. In his own words:“I look like a guy who’s always on the verge of asking, ‘Do you know who my father is?’ Even though my father was a public school teacher on Staten Island ….. I also realize that I look like the president of the Young Republicans Club …. and it doesn’t help, punch-wise, that I’m one of the whitest white people outside of 'Frozen.' Here are some names I’ve been called on social media as well as regular media: “Bland,”…."Transparent,” “Powder,” .... “If Milk Became a Person,” “Gay Casper,” ...”If Jizz Became a Person,” …and of course, “The Actual White Devil.”With that passage, Colin had me in stitches by page 3. I love a good celebrity memoir—and a good SNL tie-in—so it’s no surprise that I’m giving Jost’s take on the genre five stars here.I’ll end this  by sharing that Colin and I are only a few months apart in age. As a result, his life timeline (the college years and early 20s, anyway) aligned with mine in a way that made his stories resonate all the more with me. (One in particular that I don’t want to forget, “Why I Love My Mom,” had a 9/11 focus that had me taking a break from the laughter to tear up at the power of Colin’s memories of that harrowing day and the heroism of his mother, a doctor for the NYFD who barely survived the towers collapsing—TWICE.)Overall, I loved discovering Colin’s sharp intellect, his insane work ethic on behalf of SNL, and his remarkable ability to make any story he tells a super funny one. Speaking of, dammit if “The Time Jimmy Buffet Saved My Life” didn’t send me down the rabbit hole of looking up photos of Colin surfing, which led to my realization that, “Welp, I guess I have a huge crush on Colin Jost.” So, thanks “Punchable Face,” for that ...more

review: Alexis Coe's new biography of our country's first president had me wishing that more women could take a stab at rewriting history. In the first 50 pagAlexis Coe's new biography of our country's first president had me wishing that more women could take a stab at rewriting history. In the first 50 pages of this book, Coe dives into some solid rhetorical criticism about how Washington and his family have been portrayed by men in previous biographies written about them. I was SO there for that kind of dish and was really captivated by her writing.But within a few chapters, the book settled into a pretty standard biography (albeit a great one at that) and I struggled (ie, started to nod off in bed) a few times while reading it. This was mostly due to the fact there were a lot of 18th century personalities mentioned whose names were immediately forgotten soon after coming across them. Also, whenever Coe included sample text from an article/journal/letter of the period, I had to re-read it because the writing of yore was SO different.I think my greatest takeaways from this book were 1) the attention Coe paid to covering Washington and his treatment/attitude to his slaves and 2) learning specific details about the great rivalries that existed among our Founding Fathers—proof in historical form that this Nation has ALWAYS struggled with a political divide. ...more

title: You Say It First
author: Cotugno, Katie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are certain writers whose voice you fall hard for, and Katie Cotugno is one of those writers for me. I’ve read almost every one of her YA novelsThere are certain writers whose voice you fall hard for, and Katie Cotugno is one of those writers for me. I’ve read almost every one of her YA novels, and with each one I've found pieces of my teenage self reflected back to me through her characters.It’s impossible to travel back in time and hand a tote filled with Katie’s books over to the version of my 16-year-old self blasting Dave Matthews in her bedroom. So instead, I’ll announce plans to 1) buy them all for my daughter someday and 2) before her, my teenage niece who turns 15 this year. With her newest novel, which releases in June, Katie explores the complicated relationship that springs up between her dual narrators, Meg and Colby.Meg is a proud feminist who’s equal parts cynical and smart. She’s just ended the “perfect” relationship with her boyfriend. She’s still coming to terms with her parents’ divorce and, now, the fact her mother might be an alcoholic as her father moves on with his new family. With all that she’s got going on, Meg still finds time to excel at her job, working for a nonpartisan non-profit where she spends her nights calling people, helping them register to vote.It’s during one of these phone calls from her cubicle in Pennsylvania that Meg “meets” Colby, a surly, hot loner type living in a small town in Ohio, working long hours at the Home Depot, trying not to open his own Pandora’s box of family woes.I won’t give away what happens between these two, but I will say I 100 percent loved this book’s ending. I especially loved how real Meg and Colby felt to me. Their late-night phone calls took me back (in ways good and bad) to a particular long-distance high school relationship of my own. Maybe that’s why I’m always gonna recommend Katie’s books to people, regardless of whether they’re 16 or 36. Because every now and then, it feels good to remember the messy, complicated nature of young love. And when I’m reliving that kind of love in a world created by Katie Cotugno, I’m never disappointed. ...more
