author: Raskin, Ellen
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In reading s of a recent release I’m excited to pick up soon (Kate Racculia’s ‘Tuesday Mooney Talks to Ghosts’), I came across one that describeIn reading s of a recent release I’m excited to pick up soon (Kate Racculia’s ‘Tuesday Mooney Talks to Ghosts’), I came across one that described it as an “adult ‘Westing Game.’” Intrigued, I looked up this book and was surprised to discover that, not only had it won a Newberry, but also that I’d never heard of it!I checked it out on Hoopla (this is where I share I’m always reading something, including books on my phone) and soon found myself totally sucked into Ellen Raskin’s world. The colorful cast of characters, the bizarre plot, the mystery to be solved—I loved all of it.For someone who just saw “Clue” (for the first time!) and “Knives Out,” and thus has been in a serious mood for quirky stories that center around brain-teasing puzzles, this book scratched a particular literary itch I didn’t know I had. Now, here’s where I admit that I’m HORRIBLE at trying to solve mysteries in books, TV shows, or movies (I don’t even try), so I didn’t see the ending of “The Westing Game” coming. What I DID see was an off the wall story that, multiple times throughout, I could not BELIEVE Wes Anderson had never gotten his mitts on adapting! I went so far as to Google whether “The Westing Game” had ever jumped from page to screen. Turns out it did, but in the form of a low-stakes TV movie that debuted in 1997 to mostly lackluckster s (thanks IMDB). Last week, after watching the trailer for “The French Dispatch,” I couldn’t help but imagine the line-up of stars Wes could bring in to portray Sandy, Turtle, Berthe, Sydelle, and the rest of “The Westing Game” crew. And if it ever happens, trust I’ll be first in line to see that film!...more

title: Dear Edward
author: Napolitano, Ann*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There was a lot of buzz about this book after its January release. So much so that FOMO compelled me to check it out from the library. Shortly after IThere was a lot of buzz about this book after its January release. So much so that FOMO compelled me to check it out from the library. Shortly after I started it, I received a text alert that Kobe Bryant, his daughter, Gianna, and seven other people had just been killed in a devastating helicopter crash in Calabasas, California.I’m not sure there’s ever a … good time (?) to read a novel that centers on a plane crash that kills every passenger onboard save a little boy named Edward. But there’s certainly a bad time—and that’s when you and the rest of the world are reeling at the news of a crash that killed too many lives, including one of the most famous basketball players of all time.So yeah, maybe my heart ended up being too heavy for this book. Maybe that’s why it didn’t “land” with me where I hoped it would. But still, I persevered to the finish. Because Ann’s writing was vivid and sharp, but also because I appreciated how she set this story up: alternating chapters from the viewpoint of Edward post-crash (chapters where months might pass before she ‘checked’ in with him) with chapters told from the viewpoint of a handful of characters whose heads we were in every hour leading up to—and during—the crash itself. Toward the end, with the inevitable seismic event creeping closer with every page, I found myself reading with actual bated breath—a physiological response that, I admit, is its own kind of praise for this read....more

Well, the fact that Kate is clearly a pop culture junkie, as evident in her writing. The fast-paced banter between her characters gave me serious Amy Sherman-Palladino vibes, and I loved getting to know Tuesday, her BFF, Dex, and the rest of the novel's eccentric and well-drawn cast.The only reason I'm not giving this book five stars is because I have to admit, around the midway point, the plot sagged a bit for me. Honestly, I can't even put my finger on why that is, exactly? Just that, when I picked it up at night to read before bed, I wasn't as enthusiastic for awhile there as I had been when I first dove in. I'm grateful I had an hour stretch to tear through the last 100 pages, which were as wholly satisfying as the first. For that reason, I would highly recommend this engaging read. review: I’m a complete and total sucker for time travel narratives. Center one on a woman hopping through the events of her life out of order (in NYC through I’m a complete and total sucker for time travel narratives. Center one on a woman hopping through the events of her life out of order (in NYC through the ’80s, ’90s, and 2000s, no less), and you’ll find me staying up late, eager to finish her story.That was certainly the case for me while reading Margarita Montimore’s “Oona Out of Order.”I. LOVED. THIS. BOOK. In particular, I loved everything about Oona.I loved how much she loved Velvet Underground and Kate Bush.I felt deeply for her every time she made a leap, never knowing which people from her past or future were going to be there with her—and whether or not she’d know them when she did.I loved ALL the secondary characters, especially Dale and Madeline.Now ... can I admit that, like any time traveling narrative, there were a few times where I might have scratched my head, wondering how this piece of the creative puzzle fit into that piece over there?Sure. But when a time traveling narrative is done well (like, IMO, Time Traveler’s Wife or About Time), these kinds of time-space hiccups are just that. Hiccups. And in the case of this novel, they do not detract from what I found to be a highly imaginative ride. I finished this read legitimately sad, unwilling to let Ooona go. If there were a sequel to her story, I’d snatch it up in a heartbeat....more

review: Yaa Gyasi’s debut, “Homegoing,” is one of the best novels I’ve read in the past 10 years. I wanted to love her sophomore effort in equal measure, but Yaa Gyasi’s debut, “Homegoing,” is one of the best novels I’ve read in the past 10 years. I wanted to love her sophomore effort in equal measure, but I have to admit that I found myself less enthralled with her latest book. That is not a knock on the writing. Gyasi is one of the best writers of her generation. It’s more the case that “Transcendent Kingdom” is a book that is much quieter than her debut, both in terms of writing and plot. Also, (and this is very much a personal hang-up), the incorporation of so much scientific research (the MC, Gifty, is finishing her PhD in neuroscience) wasn't doing it for me (simultaneously reminding me of my reaction to another buzzy 2020 release I read earlier in the year). Where this book DID get me is in Gifty’s stream-of-conscious exploration of her religious upbringing in the rural South. Dang. Some really powerful, revealing moments contained in those ruminations of hers, and just a lot of heartbreaking sadness overall....more

When I first started this book, I thought, "What does the title have to do with this story?" But as the pages flew past, and I came to the point of the narrative where the connection is made, I smiled because it's perfect on multiple levels. title: Fair Play: A Game-Changing Solution for When You Have Too Much to Do
author: Rodsky, Eve*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a title that was much talked about in 2019 (especially in the wake of Reese picking it for her book club), so when I saw it on the list of audThis is a title that was much talked about in 2019 (especially in the wake of Reese picking it for her book club), so when I saw it on the list of audiobooks I could check out from the library, I thought, "Well, why not?" It took a while for my copy to be made available (and wasn't the best timing of reads), but I found it to be a fast listen, and I liked how Rodsky talked in specifics (and gave acronyms to) a lot of the elements related to domestic responsibilities that cause problems among couples. (For example, she points out that "CPE"—conceiving, planning, and executing—of a task needs to be owned by ONE person, and that it's this breakdown——wherein, say, one partner may conceive and plan a grocery list, and the other executes, leading the person who does the last step to think he/she has 'done it all'—— to be especially problematic in the division of household labor in the house. (Namely, that women are FAR more likely to do the C and the P, which takes a lot of mental work, with men occasionally helping with E and thinking, "Look at what I did for the family!," if that makes sense.) I've already talked to my husband about the book, and I'd be interested in "playing the game" within the Werner house (and he seems amenable to giving it a try), because, while he is better than a lot of men in contributing to division of labor in our home, there are still tasks that—if we could provide definition to who is holding the card in any given week, as Eve would say—we could eliminate the tendency to nag one another about when one of us forgets to do it, or to allow RATS to crop up on us (randomly assigned tasks), which can be equally frustrating and argument-inducing. The elements I took objection to in the book are covered in other s here on GoodReads, but I'll add that Eve's term "unicorn space" (to define the time partners gift one another to chase their passions) nearly drove me up the wall! (It's so woo woo!) Still, I'm glad I dipped into this one, as the author captures well the daily dilemmas that cause divisions in many of today's modern households....more

title: The Giver of Stars
author: Moyes, Jojo*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A few years back, I remember reading about the Depression-era, horse-riding librarians in Smithsonian magazine (sidenote: For years, this magazine hasA few years back, I remember reading about the Depression-era, horse-riding librarians in Smithsonian magazine (sidenote: For years, this magazine has been a favorite of mine), and then, around the same time, seeing a post about them on Facebook (one of those "Did you know" trivia pieces that gets shared by all your girlfriends) and thinking, "There should be a book about them."Fast forward to 2019, and there is (more than one, even, which I'll get to in a minute).Many GoodReads s compare "Giver of Stars" to "Where the Crawdads Sing" and I see why now. Both are compulsively readable, sucking you into their respective slices of history, relying on the murder of a town local and resulting court drama to beef up the second half of their narratives. But whereas "Crawdads" is more coming-of-age, "Giver" examines the lives of five women (two mostly) settled into adulthood and struggling with the more mature themes of marriage and motherhood. For this reason, I think I liked "Giver" more. (Of course, this also has a LOT to do with the fact this book fictionalizes the stories of real women who stepped up in a badass way to deliver books to the hill folks of eastern Kentucky. Horse-riding librarians! Truly! How incredible is that?!) If you love history (specifically, if you are such a history nerd you have a niche obsession with all stories related to the WPA), this book will be catnip for you.Lastly, I might add that, until I hopped on to this website post-read, checking out other people's s of the book, I had no idea the controversy that surrounded it. I found myself agreeing with this librarian's assessment of what likely happened, and I'll leave it at that. ...more

title: Catch and Kill: Lies, Spies, and a Conspiracy to Protect Predators
author: Farrow, Ronan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: To borrow an idiom of the times, I felt “all the feels” while reading “Catch and Kill.”AWE at the way in which Ronan Farrow detailed the extensive repTo borrow an idiom of the times, I felt “all the feels” while reading “Catch and Kill.”AWE at the way in which Ronan Farrow detailed the extensive reporting that went into the stories he wrote for the New Yorker about Harvey Weinstein’s decades of sexual abuse of women.SHOCK at how little Ronan’s work overlapped with that of Jodi Kantor and Megan Twohey from the NYT (whose book, “She Said” is an equally enthralling read on this topic). The implication, of course, being that Weinstein was such a despicable human being who harassed, abused, and raped SO many women, that MULTIPLE reporters chasing him from multiple publications still couldn’t keep up with unspooling the tangled ball of his deplorable acts. (Also, SHOCK when I looked up Ronan’s age, expecting him to be pushing 40, and discovered that he is THIRTY-TWO, with the resume of a child prodigy.) ANGER at how many times Ronan was told “No” by NBC News when he tried to push to break this story for the network (which he worked for at the time) in the first half of 2018. Couple this with Farrow’s reporting on Trump, Weinstein, and American Media, Inc., and I was borderline rage-y by the end of this book.DISGUST at what a pig Matt Lauer was and (likely) still is. Same goes for too many heads at that network who tolerated a culture that mistreated women for far too long. I told my husband after finishing this, “If you ever turn the news to NBC, I will turn it off immediately.”FASCINATION with how Farrow incorporated bits and pieces of his personal life—namely his relationships with his sister, Dylan, herself an abuse victim, and his fiancé, the podcaster and speechwriter, Jon Lovett—into this story. I especially lived for the moments when he’d write about talking through his next steps in reporting with Jon, whose wry sense of humor shone through every time Ronan included him in the book.And, lastly, RESPECT, which is my attitude regarding most journalists, but especially those whose work made for some of the most captivating stories of 2018.I’ll end this  by adding that “Catch and Kill” was the best audiobook I’ve read since Trevor Noah’s “Born a Crime” in 2017. Ronan knocked the narration out of the park, so if you can, I highly recommend you give this incredible read a listen....more

review: I was lucky this month to hear Gloria Steinem speak in person, an event that inspired me (with a bit of shame, I must confess) to finally get around tI was lucky this month to hear Gloria Steinem speak in person, an event that inspired me (with a bit of shame, I must confess) to finally get around to reading some of her work. Soon after that exciting afternoon, I was elated to discover that the library had an audio version of her 2015 memoir available—a memoir that I tore through, enthralled as I was by Gloria's recollections of her vagabond childhood and her life's experiences as a journalist, activist, and feminist icon.And oh what a remarkable life this woman continues to live! At 86 years young, Gloria is among the last living chroniclers of a generation that witnessed many of the most defining moments of the 20th century. As I listened to Debra Winger narrate Gloria's words, I found myself "bookmarking" certain passages, but then I realized I needed to stop. "My Life on the Road" is a book I need to own, not borrow. And when my physical copy arrives, not only do I intend to I re-read it, but to highlight passages from nearly every page. ...more

author: Hrabowski III, Freeman A.

review: This book is a great read for folks who work in higher education who want to better understand the ways in which culture change and shared leadership This book is a great read for folks who work in higher education who want to better understand the ways in which culture change and shared leadership are crucial to the growth of a university.Its author, Dr. Freeman Hrabowski, is one of the most respected college presidents in the country. As an acquaintance of my boss, Dr. Hrabowski delivered the Commencement address at my employer (and alma mater) back in December.His words onstage that morning were every bit as empowering as those found in the pages of this book (which he wrote with the help of several of his colleagues at UMBC, where he’s been president for decades). I read about three-fourths of this text, and took lots of notes as I did. Then I read a few s about it, and smiled when I came across one that described Hrabowski as “the kind of university president whose conference talks make you feel like you gulped some coffee, not like you need to.”That has been my personal experience with this inspiring leader, a man who wears on his shirt sleeve his passion for reshaping America’s colleges and universities to be better both culturally and academically....more

review: I'd seen so many folks buzzing about this novel, I blame FOMO for picking up my copy from the library. And I have to admit that, for the first half ofI'd seen so many folks buzzing about this novel, I blame FOMO for picking up my copy from the library. And I have to admit that, for the first half of the book, I understood the appeal. The plot of "Nothing to See Here" involves twin children who catch on fire and is narrated by a female protagonist with a sardonic sense of humor that, a handful of times, actually made me laugh out loud.But, a little past the half-way point, Wilson lost narrative steam. So much so that, by the book's climax (a scene that happens with a swearing-in in Washington, D.C.), the story felt as if it had gone off the rails, resulting in an ending that limped along to a predictably disappointing conclusion.(But then, maybe I should have known better than to expect too much from this book. After all, I wasn't the biggest fan of "Family Fang" either.)...more

review: Adding this to my latest read with my 7 year old son. It can be hard to find chapter books that hold his interest, and so I send kudos to Mr. Harris. Adding this to my latest read with my 7 year old son. It can be hard to find chapter books that hold his interest, and so I send kudos to Mr. Harris. Over the course of 224 pages, this book accomplished this goal, keeping Dean interested over the month it took us to read it. (I trade off with my husband on nights we put our son to bed, so we each have our books we're reading with him.)Two things I loved about this first in this series: 1) There are legit magic tricks folded into the narrative as their own little chapters, complete with diagrams and drawings. (I think I loved these more than my son!) 2) NPH did a wonderful job of incorporating certain vocabulary words that are a stretch for younger readers. Often times, he'd follow up and explain what a word meant, but a few times, he didn't, and so I found room for some teachable moments of my own with my boy.One thing I didn't love: The length of the book's chapters, especially at the beginning. When I read aloud, I often need a drink of water (or I do right now, as I've been battling seasonal allergies and a cold), so this book I found myself thinking (especially in the first 6-7 chapters), "Come on, Neil, end this chapter already so I can put this book down and get a drink already!")...more

review: I LOVED J. Ryan Stradal's second novel, “The Lager Queen of Minnesota,” ever bit as much as his 2015 debut, “Kitchens of the Great Midwest." PrimarilyI LOVED J. Ryan Stradal's second novel, “The Lager Queen of Minnesota,” ever bit as much as his 2015 debut, “Kitchens of the Great Midwest." Primarily because Ryan writes Midwesterners with a level of respect and authenticity lacking in a lot of lit set in the middle of the country. The characters of this book—Edith, Helen, and Diana—are an amalgamation of a lot of hardworking, no-nonsense women in my own life, my mother especially. Perhaps that’s one reason I came to the end of this read with tears streaming down my cheeks. Another is because this is such a beautiful, redemptive story, one that celebrates the complicated bonds of sisterhood, the pull of family ties, and the way a strong work ethic can empower a person’s dreams. One of my favorite reads of 2019, for sure (and I’m already looking forward to Ryan’s next book)!...more

author: Prince
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "The Beautiful Ones" opens with the last conversation the (super young, super inexperienced, but extremely lucky!) editor Dan Piepenbring had with Pri"The Beautiful Ones" opens with the last conversation the (super young, super inexperienced, but extremely lucky!) editor Dan Piepenbring had with Prince before the pop-star icon died suddenly in 2016. “I wanted to ask,” Prince says, “Do you believe in cellular memory?” The chapters that follow are as equally unexpected as they are evocative: told in four parts, this is a memoir that unfolds through handwritten memories, scrapbook photos, lyric sheets, and the original iteration of what would become the film, "Purple Rain."USA Today calls "The Beautiful Ones" “not a read, but an experience,” and that’s a description I can get behind. This is the perfect book for someone who loved Prince’s genius and/or is a music lover in need of a gift this holiday season. I’ll add that, as someone who’s been binging her way through “New Girl,” it was tragic yet comedic timing this month to come across the third season episode where Prince (brilliantly) guest stars. As legendary as the man was—mythical even—I adore the little peeks he gave us into his pop culture tastes. (Other favorites mentioned in ‘The Beautiful Ones’: ‘The Matrix’ and ‘About Time,’ a Richard Curtis movie I also adored.)...more

title: Over the Top: A Raw Journey to Self-Love
author: Van Ness, Jonathan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If ever there was a memoir that commanded to be listened to, it's JVN's "Over the Top." Truth? I was not expecting this book to get as dark as it did.If ever there was a memoir that commanded to be listened to, it's JVN's "Over the Top." Truth? I was not expecting this book to get as dark as it did. But I'm glad that Jonathan didn't shy away from sharing the good, the bad, and (most especially) the ugly parts of his life journey so far. Given his popularity, I envision his story is going to positively impact the lives of many readers. One of the reasons I love reading memoirs is because, no matter how different I may be from the author, I always find a kernel of my own story in their stories. I felt that while reading Michelle Obama's "Becoming last November, and I felt it again while listening to JVN's book. When he writes about being a kid CONSUMED by the Olympics, inventing his own gymnastics and ice skating routines in the basement of his Quincy home, I was transported back to my own childhood and the "choreographed" basement routines I created for myself as an (equally imaginative) youngest child. JVN's love of these two sports was an amusing counterweight to the heavier elements of this book, and I chuckled repeatedly at how effectively he infused this particular passion (along with his fondness for Russian spy pseudonyms!) into his story....more

review: Shea Serrano is the funniest, smartest pop culture critic you’ve (maybe?) never heard of. He’s a popular contributor to The Ringer whose latest contriShea Serrano is the funniest, smartest pop culture critic you’ve (maybe?) never heard of. He’s a popular contributor to The Ringer whose latest contribution to his “And Other Things” book series is a must-have for any movie junkie. What I loved most about this collection of “questions asked, answered, and illustrated,” is how it perfectly captures how Shea’s mind works. By that I mean, it’s all over the place in a way that exemplifies why he’s such an awesome critic, podcast host and (I’m guessing) excellent guest at a dinner party. To illustrate, here’s a sampling of the delightfully weird yet wonderful questions he poses in this great coffee table book-kind-of-read:• Is this movie better, the same, or worse with The Rock in it?  (This chapter I had to read out loud to my husband…. by the end of it, I was laughing SO hard I actually couldn’t breath.)• Did the Rockford Peaches make the right decision trading kit?  (Where my “League of Their Own” fans at?!)• Which race was white-savored the best by Kevin Costner?  (Hilariously on point.)• When did Michael B. Joran break your heart into the most pieces?  (When DOESN’T Michael BAE Jordan do this?)• When was Diane Keaton the most charming in Something’s Gotta Give?  (Not Shea’s answer, but my own: Every. damn. scene. she’s. in. )Lastly, the one that I’m STILL chuckling over: “What happened at the Michael Myers press conference?”This book (with BRILLIANT illustrations by Arturo Torres) is the ideal gift to give that extra cool someone in your life (you know, the person so cool you never know what to buy him or her). The fact it’s annotated (why are annotated books a form of literary catnip? is that just me?) makes it all the more special. HIGHLY recommend this read this holiday season! ...more

review: Raunchy and real is the best way I can describe Ali Wong's comedy. If you’ve seen her Netflix stand-up specials, you know exactly the kind of real I’mRaunchy and real is the best way I can describe Ali Wong's comedy. If you’ve seen her Netflix stand-up specials, you know exactly the kind of real I’m talking about. In a similar holds-nothing-back way, Ali brings that same brand of comedy to her new book, a collection of letters she wrote to her daughters (to be read by them when they are MUCH older!). I expected “Dear Girls” to make me laugh and cringe in equal measure, but I was surprised by how insightful Ali’s stories could be, too. For instance, her take on why she believes there aren’t more female comedians working today: “It’s the safety thing. I stayed in so many shady-ass motels by myself. You have to put yourself in those situations. Even now I’ll go to dive bars and I always ask some other comics to walk me back to my car.” Lastly, the afterword that her husband, Justin (whose “ass” Ali famously trapped) wrote was pure #couplegoals—a sweet reminder that behind her success is a partner secure enough in his masculinity to withstand her jokes about him and hold down the fort at home so Ali can flourish as the badass multi-hyphenate she is....more

review: From page one, "She Said" was one of the most riveting books I've read all year. The ex-journalist in me was in awe of the hundreds (thousands?) of hoFrom page one, "She Said" was one of the most riveting books I've read all year. The ex-journalist in me was in awe of the hundreds (thousands?) of hours Jodi Kantor and Megan Twohey invested in breaking open the Harvey Weinstein sexual harassment scandal. These women are 21st-century heroes who helped inspire a generation of women and men to no longer be afraid to speak up. Thank you, Jodi and Megan, for your remarkable reporting and for (in the second half of your book) giving us a behind-the-scenes look into the before and after of Christine Blasey Ford's brave testimony before Congress. What a reckoning these past few years has been, but as you so eloquently wrote to your daughters in your acknowledgments: "May you know respect and dignity always, in the workplace and beyond."Here's to this being our daughters' reality—a reality made possible in part by your tireless work that helped spark a worldwide movement....more

review: If you had handed me this book without a cover, and asked me if a man or woman wrote it, I would have been able to tell you within the first five pageIf you had handed me this book without a cover, and asked me if a man or woman wrote it, I would have been able to tell you within the first five pages—when our male protagonist compares the breasts of the woman he’s painting to the various sizes of citrus fruit.Groan.This book went downhill for me after that. I kept reading because it was my book club’s latest selection, but I can’t say I enjoyed it. It was SUCH a “dude” book: many, MANY (overly) descriptive passages about the southwestern setting and the minutia of fly fishing; a protagonist with a overly gruff exterior and a bevy of underdeveloped women as his lovers; and an author who clearly worships Hemingway in both prose and as character (so much so he actually includes a scene where a guy in 'The Painter' points out how much the protagonist, Jim Stegner, physically looks like him). title: Know My Name
author: Miller, Chanel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Two weeks removed from reading Chanel Miller’s “Know My Name” and the words I would use to best describe it are: thought-provoking, painful, and necesTwo weeks removed from reading Chanel Miller’s “Know My Name” and the words I would use to best describe it are: thought-provoking, painful, and necessary. As Brock Turner’s victim, Chanel Miller was sexually assaulted, left with pine needles in her hair, and with few answers as to what happened to her. Afterward, she was coerced into entering a years-long journey through a judicial process that, in her words, made her “question, then forget” who she was. Chanel chronicles this painful chapter of her life in vivid detail. And while I can’t say I’m surprised at what a remarkable writer she is (she did, after all, pen Emily Doe’s victim impact statement—a statement that resonated with millions of people around the world), I didn’t expect to be as transfixed as I was reading “Know My Name.” Chanel’s smart, stylized voice, coupled with her fiery rhetoric and stream of conscious questioning, made this book the most powerful of reads, especially when she forced me to ponder statements like the following: “When society questions a victim’s reluctance to report, I will be here to remind you that you ask us to sacrifice our sanity to fight outdated structures that were designed to keep us down. Victims do not have the time for this. Victims are also students, teachers, parents, who can’t give up work or education … It is not reasonable to casually demand that victims put aside their lives to spend more time pursuing something they never asked for in the first place. This is not about the victims’ lack of effort. This is about society’s failure to have systems in place in which victims feel there’s a probable chance of achieving safety, justice, and restoration … The real question we need to be asking is not, ‘Why didn’t she report?’ but ‘Why would you?’...more

title: Where the Light Gets In: Losing My Mother Only to Find Her Again
author: Williams-Paisley, Kimberly*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I purchased this book on a whim, as I follow Kimberly Williams-Paisley on Instagram  (once a fan of "Father of the Bride," always a fan!), and I saw hI purchased this book on a whim, as I follow Kimberly Williams-Paisley on Instagram  (once a fan of "Father of the Bride," always a fan!), and I saw her promoting the e-book on sale for a few bucks. I'm so glad I clicked "Buy," as I found this memoir to be a profoundly moving read.I lost my maternal grandmother to Alzheimer's when I was 16, and I can remember vividly the toll her decline took on her caregivers, especially my mother. Dementia is the cruelest of conditions, and KWP doesn't shy away from describing in detail how painful it was for her, her siblings, and her father (bless that man!) to watch a woman as brilliant as Linda Williams (who, at the time of her diagnosis, was raising millions for the Michael J. Fox Foundation) succumb to the disease. And yet, I greatly admired KWP's retelling of this difficult time in the life of her family. It reminded me that the people we think have it all together—the ones who look so beautiful in movies and on the pages of glossy magazines—have their own crosses to bear outside of the celebrity spotlight.As difficult as it was to read about Linda's condition, there were plenty of light moments to leaven this read. I especially loved learning about how Kim got cast in "Father of the Bride" and how she met and fell for her hubby, the country singer Brad Paisley. But what I will carry away from this well-written memoir—and why I will buy future copies for the people I love whose life is touched by Alzheimer's—is to pass along the valuable lessons KWP shares with others forced to confront this disease head-on. Those lessons include a helpful resources guide and FAQ that includes KWP's advice that anyone diagnosed with dementia create a personal note while they still are able, detailing how they want to be cared for as their disease progresses. Her mother never took the time to do so, a fact that complicated her family's decision-making about her care in the years that followed. KWP shares her own example, and the power of this note serving as the final sentences of this memoir cannot be overstated. ...more

title: It's Messy: Essays on Boys, Boobs, and Badass Women
author: Cadenet, Amanda de
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It took a little project of mine I dubbed "Summer of Keanu"  for me to discover the badass feminist journalist-turned-photographer Amanda de Cadenet.TIt took a little project of mine I dubbed "Summer of Keanu"  for me to discover the badass feminist journalist-turned-photographer Amanda de Cadenet.To summarize, I spent my summer watching all of Keanu's movies. As the linked post details, part of that cinematic adventure entailed a lot of YouTube rabbit holing. One of those YouTube binges brought me to Amanda's interview of Keanu in the early '90s for the UK program, "The Word." As it turns out, Amanda (the UK '80s-It-Girl who married John Taylor from Duran Duran) has enjoyed a years-long friendship with Keanu (that, at one time, turned romantic). She speaks lovingly about that friendship in "It's Messy," a book that was such an enjoyable experience to listen to, I was sad to finish it (especially since Amanda's voice in my ear felt like it belonged to a wise older sister that commands your respect with her wit, humor, and no-nonsense advice giving).The more I've read about Amanda, both in her book and online, the more I've come to admire her. Namely because her interests are my interests: I'm a journalist turned photographer who LOVES interviewing people, so it makes sense that Amanda's professional arc from "The Word" to fashion photographer to originator of the awesome series "Conversations" would be catnip for me.What I loved most about "It's Messy" is that it's a collection of essays that found me at the right age, at the right time. Amanda's musings about men, sex, friendships, and, most especially, motherhood, all resonated deeply with me. The fact she dished about the ups and downs of her life while keeping the narrative focused on the feminist lessons she's learned along the way has made her a woman in pop culture I intend to keep my eye on. ...more

review: I can't remember the last time I read a book this fast! After reading Tracey Garvis Graves' most recent novel this spring, I picked up "On the Island"I can't remember the last time I read a book this fast! After reading Tracey Garvis Graves' most recent novel this spring, I picked up "On the Island" on the recommendation of a friend (hi Cathy!). I bought it through the iBooks app on my phone, immediately got hooked into the first few chapters, then stole breaks throughout my day (in the Starbucks line, in the school pick-up line, while stirring the soup we had for dinner that night) to read it. THEN, sucked in as I was, I stayed up into the wee hours of the night, compelled to know how Anna and TJ's story would end. If you're a fan of romance, this is a book you don't want to miss. review: This is my second book of Ann Patchett's, and, at this rate, I'll get around to reading everything she writes because I love her prose. So much so thaThis is my second book of Ann Patchett's, and, at this rate, I'll get around to reading everything she writes because I love her prose. So much so that I struggle to come up with the right words to describe it, so I'll let this New York Times  do the job for me:"Patchett’s prose is confident, unfussy and unadorned. I can’t pluck out one sentence worth quoting, but how effective they are when woven together—these translucent lines that envelop you like a spider’s web.” There wasn't much I didn't love about her latest novel: the incredible bond between Danny (our narrator) and his sister, Maeve (whom I adored); the remarkable gem of a (Dutch) House they spent their childhoods in until the moment they didn't—a house that became a character unto itself; the smart way Ann hopped narratives between the present and the past in a way that almost, but never quite, lost me; and the way this book felt at once like a modern-day classic.It wasn't the fastest of reads for me, but that was okay ...it just meant that every time I picked it up, I savored anew the setting, the language, and being back with a cast of characters I came to love all the more.A great novel to kick off my fall reads, for sure. Also: I loved reading Debbie's   after I finished—I agree with so much of it!...more

review: This book (my book club's late summer selection) was so dramatically over the top, I don't even know where to start. Since I'm not a fan of sharing spThis book (my book club's late summer selection) was so dramatically over the top, I don't even know where to start. Since I'm not a fan of sharing spoilers in GR s, I'll just say that each plot twist Jackson introduces in "Never Have I Ever" becomes more and more unbelievable. To the point that, by the final pages, I wanted to throw my phone (on which I was reading the book) across the room.Years ago, I read a book on craft that floated the theory that readers will allow an author one "jump to conclusions" type moment in any story. More than that, and writers loses the trust (and interest) of their readers. I thought about that sentiment a lot while reading this book; it certainly applied here.Also, what was with the MC's obsession with food? Introducing an eating disorder on top of a bonkers plot was so unnecessary to this narrative. Every time Amy (our MC) started stuffing her face with food (in one scene, she jams handfuls of meatloaf and mashed potatoes into her mouth, not even bothering with a fork or spoon) I was yanked out of the narrative in such a jarring way I couldn't help but wonder if Jackson was battling her own demons through the unhealthy choices of her narrator. ...more

title: Such a Fun Age
author: Reid, Kiley
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Entertainment Weekly was spot-on when it wrote that Kiley Reid had written "the most provocative page-turner of the year." With "Such a Fun Age," ReidEntertainment Weekly was spot-on when it wrote that Kiley Reid had written "the most provocative page-turner of the year." With "Such a Fun Age," Reid immerses her readers in the transactional relationship of Alix and Emira.Alix is a Waspy 30-something who's shot to modest fame with her online brand as a feminist cheerleader (a brand that, over the course of her novel, Reid calls into question as a disingenuous, navel-gazing charade). With Alix, Reid simultaneously skewers "influencer" culture while creating the best mean girl character since Regina George. (And yet, the fact that, as Tina did with Regina, we still find ways to empathize with Alix speaks volumes about Reid's impressive talent.)Emira happens to be the young black woman babysitting Alix's precocious toddler, Briar. As a recent college graduate, Emira's struggling to define her career aspirations, trying not to begrudge her girlfriends whose professional lives are taking off in a way that's leaving her—and her IKEA furniture—behind. For now, she's content to keep watching Briar, a child she suspects she loves in a deeper way than the woman who's paying her in cash every week to help raise her.The opening chapter of the book finds Emira at a grocery store with Briar, being interrogated by a security guard and a white shopper who fears Emira's kidnapped this white child. It is the kind of aggravating racial aggression experienced on the daily by (too) many black people, and Reid makes the scene feel as real as if you were watching it play out on your television. (Speaking of, I cannot wait to see how Lena Waithe adapts this story from page to screen.) The chapters that follow track what happens after this frustrating night, chronicling the aftereffects of the incident on Alix, on Emira, and on Kelly, the white customer who becomes Emira's boyfriend soon after he sends her the video he recorded on his phone of the charged encounter.The way the lives of these characters intersect is as surprising as it is surreal. I was more than happy to accept a (fairly major) coincidence Reid worked into her plot for the resulting pay-off of discovering what she had in store for each of them by the end of the book.I'll end this  by saying that "Such a Fun Age" is the most "now" novel I've read in ... well, ages. In all her young wisdom, Reid has captured in her writing a kind of self-reflection (about race and class and privilege and popularity) that defines a lot of the fears and frustrations of our modern age. I cannot wait to press this book into the hands of a lot of friends in 2020, urging them to make it their first great read of the new year....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I do this thing where I often "cast" books as I read them. While reading Andrew Sean Greer's "Less," I could NOT unsee the talented Paul Bettany as ArI do this thing where I often "cast" books as I read them. While reading Andrew Sean Greer's "Less," I could NOT unsee the talented Paul Bettany as Arthur Less. I mean, he's even wearing Less's ubiquitous blue suit here!It was this soft spot I had for Paul-as-Arthur that kept me reading. Well, Paul-as-Arthur coupled with the occasional chuckle I'd let out every few pages as I came across a turn of phrase or line in the book I found particularly witty.That's the draw of this book in a nutshell. Because its plot was borderline insufferable in that entitled way we need less of narratively in 2019. By that I mean, Arthur is a well-off, gay white man who more or less cons his way into a year-long, round-the-world quest of self-discovery. (In a world where fact meets fiction, he and Elizabeth Gilbert meet at a bar in Morocco and hit it off swimmingly.) On one hand, it's hard for me to believe a book like this one can win the Pulitzer in 2018. On the other, maybe those judges were, like me, worn down and eventually charmed by Paul-as-Arthur's pratfalls—not to mention an ending that pulls off the sweetest of narrative surprises.A book I'd recommend to some, but certainly not all of my friends. ...more

title: How to Be an Antiracist
author: Kendi, Ibram X.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are a LOT of anti-racist texts on the market right now—a few of which I’ve read, more of which I plan to read, and all of which seem to be sittiThere are a LOT of anti-racist texts on the market right now—a few of which I’ve read, more of which I plan to read, and all of which seem to be sitting on the NYT Best Sellers list (with good reason!). But I can already tell that this is the one I’ll most want to press into other people's hands. Why? I think it’s because of how Kendi approaches the subject material, blending the personal with the intellectual in a way that commands attention and respect. As the New York Times puts it, “Instead of focusing on our racist ideas, Kendi offers up a wrenching examination of the evolution of his.”It’s very powerful to realize that ANYONE can be racist. And in striving to push people to become antiracists, Kendi leads by example. Each chapter of his book explores various topics (from Ethnicity and Color to Body and Culture) in tandem with the ways in which his life experiences shaped the stereotypes he absorbed (which informed the creation of his own prejudices). The writing of this book leans academic (which makes sense, given Kendi is a college professor), but it's worth persevering through the occasional complex passage to absorb the book's biggest takeaways (and to make it to an ending that shocks as much as it reveals about Kendi’s health and fortitude). I think I underlined passages on every page of this book. In ing them now, here are a few that I don’t want to forget any time soon in my own journey to become an antiracist:“Racist ideas make people of color think less of themselves, which makes them more vulnerable to racist ideas. Racist ideas make White people think more of themselves, which further attracts them to racist ideas.”“This is the most consistent function of racist ideas—and of any kind of bigotry more broadly: to manipulate us into seeing people as the problem, instead of the policies that ensnare them.”“One either believes problems are rooted in groups of people, as a racist, or locates the roots of problems in power and policies, as an anti-racist.” “The history of the racialized world is a three-way fight between assimilationists, segregationists, and antiracists” (This theory, found on page 31, which Kendi incorporates throughout the novel, was a MAJOR lightbulb moment for me in terms of contextualizing racism in a way I'd never considered before). As an example (from page 80): “Segregationists who consider Black neighborhoods to be war zones have called for tough policing and the mass incarceration of super-predators. Assimilationists say these super-predators need tough laws and tough love to civilize them back to nonviolence. Antiracists say Black people, like all people, need more higher-paying jobs within reach, especially Black youngsters, who have consistently had the highest rates of unemployment of any demographic group, topping 50 percent in the mid-90s.” “The problem of race has always been at its core the problem of power, not the problem of immorality or ignorance.” “The history of racist ideas is the history of powerful policymakers erecting racist policies out of self-interest, then producing racist ideas to defend and rationalize the inequitable effects of their policies, while everyday people consume those racist ideas, which in turn sparks ignorance and hate.”...more

title: The Underground Railroad
author: Whitehead, Colson*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book had me right up until it lost me—which was about midway through, when our protagonist, Cora, makes it to North Carolina. Up until that pointThis book had me right up until it lost me—which was about midway through, when our protagonist, Cora, makes it to North Carolina. Up until that point, I'd fully accepted the book's use of magical realism. An actual underground train transporting slaves out of the South and into freedom? Hella cool. And I was deeply rooting for Cora and Caesar as they made their break from Georgia and established themselves in South Carolina (where the government set-up gave them at least a semblance of freedom...not that it was really that at all).But it was after this—when all hell broke loose and Cora wound up in North Carolina—where this book took an eerie turn that sent actual chills down my spine.Any slave narrative is going to be a challenge to read. But in this alternative narrative, one in which each state adopts its own approach to handling slavery, the picture Whitehead paints of what's happening in North Carolina sat with me in a way so wrong, I couldn't shake it. Because in North Carolina, runaway slaves like Cora are violently executed and then STRUNG UP ALONG THE ROAD FOR MILES AND MILES, WHERE THEY REMAIN FOREVER FOR EVERYONE TO SEE.The knowledge that those bodies went on for miles, never to be taken down ... I just... I couldn't. After reading this, I continued to plod along, but my heart was largely stripped from the story (mostly out of shock). Still, I hung in there for a conclusion that was far more optimistic for Cora than I'd been expecting (especially after that harrowing scene!) Also, I did appreciate Whitehead's decision in the end to share with us what happened to Mabel...I'd been wondering!...more

review: I was on maternity leave when the rebooted Queer Eye hit Netflix in February 2018, and so I blame a mix of maternal hormones (and great casting!) for I was on maternity leave when the rebooted Queer Eye hit Netflix in February 2018, and so I blame a mix of maternal hormones (and great casting!) for binging that entire first season with happy tears streaming down my face for most of those feel-good episodes. Needless to say, I love the new Queer Eye crew—Tan France especially. When I saw he'd released a book, I was intrigued. Then delighted to pick it up and discover what Publishers Weekly calls a "feisty but affecting" memoir tucked away behind its eye-catching cover. (The book also features lovely illustrations created by Tan's talented—and equally fetching—husband, Rob Frances; I found this knowledge to be quite endearing.) Tan's life is, as you might expect, pretty darn interesting. From his upbringing in a small English town to the launch of his clothing label to his surprise audition for QE with Netflix—his story made for a real page-turner. Sprinkled throughout the book are chapters with fashion advice. (Tan hates belts. And Crocs. And believes bangs are a regrettable experience for women ... "I love bangs, but women, do your gay friends a favour. The decision to get bangs is yours. Don't put that shit on us." HAHAHA)His voice is breezy with an edge (especially when he's talking about the discrimination he's felt as a Pakistani man living—and traveling frequently—in a post 9/11 world), and, while it didn't necessarily come as a surprise, what I most admired about “Naturally Tan” was how much humor was injected into the book. A wonderful read that felt like having a tell-all conversation with one of my favorite new celebrities—I'm sure the audio version (which Tan narrates) would be exceptionally great, too....more

title: On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous
author: Vuong, Ocean
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: At a certain point while I was devouring "On Earth, We Are Briefly Gorgeous," I felt this sense of, “What EXACTLY am I reading?” Because it is the thiAt a certain point while I was devouring "On Earth, We Are Briefly Gorgeous," I felt this sense of, “What EXACTLY am I reading?” Because it is the thinnest of veils that separates this book from being a work of fiction and being a memoir of the young Vuong’s life.“On Earth” tells the story of a young boy (who becomes a young man) named Little Dog and his Vietnamese family, all of whom are immigrants to America. The narrative is written as a letter to Little Dog's mother, recounting traumatic snippets of their immigrant experience. These vignettes include stories about the beatings he took at the hands of his shell-shocked mother, the sadness he felt watching her endure a debilitating career as a nail technician, and his grandmother’s haunting memories of the Vietnam War—all told alongside Little Dog’s memories of his sexual awakening as a young gay man. There were SO many lines of beauty in this book, which blossomed not only because of Vuong’s talents as a wordsmith, but because of his fascination with linguistics. (“It’s not fair that the word laughter is trapped inside slaughter,” is one such line that comes to mind.)As hard as this book was to read, I am grateful I did so, as Ocean is clearly one of the most talented writers being published today. Expect great things to continue to come from him. And I’ll put a twenty down now on this book winning the National Book Award for 2019. What say you? Related:So much of Ocean’s storytelling in “On Earth” is incredibly bleak, so I found this interview of him with Seth Meyers to be a refreshing reminder of what a delight he appears to be in person. Also, this  of the book from The New Yorker captures the raw beauty of Ocean’s language and his crazy talent as a writer. Couldn’t agree more with the writer’s assessment of the book....more

review: It’s a testament to the remarkable story Richard Powers wrote (and the fantastic narrative talents of Suzanne Toren) that I managed to hang on for theIt’s a testament to the remarkable story Richard Powers wrote (and the fantastic narrative talents of Suzanne Toren) that I managed to hang on for the two months it took me to listen to “The Overstory.” Most audio books I read are in the 10-hour range. This one? TWENTY-THREE HOURS. Reaching the final chapter of this novel felt like the literary equivalent of finishing a marathon, but one I’m better for having completed. In his  of this “tree mad” novel, Nathaniel Rich writes for The Atlantic that Richard Powers has “the courage and intellectual stamina to explore our most complex social questions” … including “the destruction of the natural conditions necessary for our own survival.” I felt that sentiment over and over again during the course of listening to this epic work of environmental fiction. What made “The Overstory” so smart and so special wasn’t just Powers’ exceptional writing (certain lines felt like poetry, reminding me of my experience reading “All the Light We Cannot See,” another Pulitzer winner I listened to a few years back) but the rich payoff of discovering how the lives of this book’s nine major characters were all interconnected.Sometimes I think certain novels find us right when we need them most, and that’s the case with “The Overstory” for me. From the minute I hit play, listening to Toren’s calm voice narrate this story soothed me at a time when a global pandemic has left my nerves otherwise frayed.And what a serendipitous blessing it was to listen to this novel while swinging on warm spring and summer nights in my backyard hammock, eyes trained to the sky, watching the soaring branches of my neighbor’s oaks sway in a magical way that felt like the perfect visual accompaniment to a novel devoted to a trees’-eye view of our planet.With every walk I’ve taken in recent weeks, I’ve found myself looking up at the trees with more wonderment than ever before. Thanks to this big, beautiful book (a “gigantic fable of genuine truths,” as Barb Kingsolver so deftly described it), I hope that feeling doesn’t fade any time soon. Major character names so I don’t forget them: Olivia (Maidenhair), Nick (Watchman), Mimi Ma (Mulberry), Douglas (Doug-fir), Adam (Maple), Patricia Westerford, Ray and Dorothy Brinkman, Neelay Mehta...more

review: "The Nickel Boys" is Colson Whitehead's fictionalized take on a Jim Crow-era Florida reform school (Dozier School for Boys) where young black boys wer"The Nickel Boys" is Colson Whitehead's fictionalized take on a Jim Crow-era Florida reform school (Dozier School for Boys) where young black boys were tortured for decades, their bodies buried in unmarked graves only recently discovered by archaeology students from the University of Florida.As you might expect, it's a timely, tragic read. And yet, I couldn't stop caring about these poor Nickel boys, especially sweet Elwood, the book's protagonist. I don't want to say much more about the plot, as I think this is a story that deserves to be discovered on the page. But know this: Whitehead leads these characters to an unforgettable ending that takes your breath away. review: Angie Thomas more than delivers with her sophomore follow-up to her NYT best-selling debut, The Hate U Give. I found myself completely immersed in BriAngie Thomas more than delivers with her sophomore follow-up to her NYT best-selling debut, The Hate U Give. I found myself completely immersed in Brianna's world, and I was in awe of her talent (as translated from Angie's own skills) at rapping. I listened to this book, which was read by actress and audiobook narrator Bahni Turpin, and I was SO impressed. Bahni does a wonderful job making Angie's characters come to life, so much so that I will seek out future titles narrated by her. title: Inspired: Slaying Giants, Walking on Water, and Loving the Bible Again
author: Evans, Rachel Held
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I expected this book to inspire me (it’s in the title, after all), and in some respects, it absolutely did. And yet, I’m also hard pressed, a few weekI expected this book to inspire me (it’s in the title, after all), and in some respects, it absolutely did. And yet, I’m also hard pressed, a few weeks removed from finishing it, to give you a good reason WHY I was inspired. I think because it's chock full of good takeaways, and yet it’s a dense read, one that proves that, unlike some of her contemporaries, Rachel had a true academic's approach to writing. She was clearly brilliant, and she knew her subject material well (which makes her untimely passing all the more depressing). Instead of trying to describe what “Inspired” is about, I’m just going to reshare a handful of the notes I highlighted as I was reading it, because I think they give a good glimpse into the passages I did appreciate in the book, which was our latest pick for our church book group (so dubbed “Gin and Jesus” ....which should tell you plenty about the delightful group of ladies I keep company with!) —“It is no more beneath God to speak to us using poetry, proverb, letters, and legend than it is for a mother to read storybooks to her daughter at bedtime. This is who God is. This is what God does.”—“A book of poetry, stories, letters, and prophecies cannot be easily rendered down into bullet points, so treating Scripture as an owner’s manual, based on a few verses here and a few verses there, will leave you more lost than found.” —“Jesus is what at the living, breathing will of God looks like.”—“The Bible looks the way it does, because God lets his children tell the story.”—“There are parts of the Bible that inspire me, parts that perplex, and parts that leave you with an open wound. I’m still wrestling, and like Jacob, I will wrestle until I am blessed. God hasn’t let go of me yet.”— “What I love about the Bible is that the story isn’t over. There are still prophets in our midst.”— “I am a Christian, because the story of Jesus is the story I’m willing to risk being wrong about.” ...more

review: I don’t read many graphic novels, but I’d heard such wonderful things about Mira Jacob and her memoir, “Good Talk,” that I felt compelled to purchase I don’t read many graphic novels, but I’d heard such wonderful things about Mira Jacob and her memoir, “Good Talk,” that I felt compelled to purchase a copy from Women & Children First during my visit there while in Chicago last month. Within the first few pages, I could see what all the fuss was about: Mira weaves an intimate look into her personal experiences growing up the child of immigrants juxtaposed with scenes from her current life raising a young, biracial son in a deeply divided America. I loved the illustrations, I loved the questions her son asked of her, and I loved how Mira put her readers in her shoes, time and time again. This beautiful book makes for a fast read that’s full of the tough discussions I wish more Americans were having today. So glad I made room for it on my book shelf this year....more

title: Tornado Weather
author: Kennedy, Deborah Elaine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book was our July book club pick, and I should preface my  by admitting that, in the end, I don't think I was the right audience for it.It’This book was our July book club pick, and I should preface my  by admitting that, in the end, I don't think I was the right audience for it.It’s a portrait of a struggling fictional Indiana town, Colliersville, as relayed through a series of vignettes of characters all vested in the disappearance of 5-year-old Daisy Gonzalez, a little girl whose father teaches at the local high school.And yet, here was my issue: The author sets Colliersville amid a handful of real Indiana towns, including one 3 miles away from where I grew up.She chooses to write about these characters with a benevolent disdain, painting each with a form of inescapable despair that felt draining to keep pace with. (Not to mention multiple times I thought, “Wait a minute, I KNOW people from Spencerville…not everyone hates this little town! Not everyone is this much of a loser/fuck up/parasite on the world!”)Therein lies my problem with certain authors of Midwestern lit. It’s why I’ll favor a writer like Nickolas Butler or J. Ryan Stradal over someone like Deborah Kennedy. At least Nick and Ryan know that, amidst the struggles of any Midwestern town, there are rays of hope and good reasons why people stick around. Communities that come together to support one another in ways big and small.I wanted to see more of THAT flavor of a small town represented here—even if it was just a sliver of security and purpose from ONE character—but instead, what Kennedy's readers get is a portrayal of a backwater Hoosier town, a portrayal that too often is the ONLY version of Indiana (or most Midwestern towns) that anyone gets.Add to this disgruntlement my frustration with keeping track of all the characters in this book, and we have a read that clearly wasn’t my cup of tea.BUT, this book IS beautifully written (which is why I kept reading; see also, I always finish a book club pick), and I understand that my visceral reaction to it is weighed HEAVILY by the fact I’m from the area where the book is set, so, I can see why others would like it far more than I did....more

review: I just wrote a  about one Southern woman’s privileged take on her life and profession, which I read around the same time I listened to a libraryI just wrote a  about one Southern woman’s privileged take on her life and profession, which I read around the same time I listened to a library copy of Reese Witherspoon’s audiobook, Whiskey in a Teacup. So yeah, same issue here: another woman (who I happen to admire very much) offering a very privileged take on life in the South. Despite this fact, there were plenty of elements to this read that I enjoyed. It’s mostly a big ‘ol collection of recipes (all of which look good!), etiquette tips (which admittedly taught me a few things), and a compendium of Reese's favorite Southern traditions, like monogramming and transferware. (I had no idea that's what that china I'd see in flea markets was called!)The pretty presentation of all this down-home material woos the reader into overlooking Reese’s oversights about a very different version of the South than the one she’s presented here. After all, when such tales are spun in the sugar sweet voice and sunshine-y web of Reese Witherspoon, well….who wouldn’t want to live in the “Y’all, come on down for some sweet tea” world where she grew up? (On a related note, this essay captures my dichotomous feelings about this book perfectly.)...more

review: Recently, I attended an author event where Tracey Garvis Graves stood up in front of a few hundred people and spoke about her latest novel, “The Girl Recently, I attended an author event where Tracey Garvis Graves stood up in front of a few hundred people and spoke about her latest novel, “The Girl He Used to Know.” Intrigued by its plot (and charmed by Tracey’s eloquence), I checked the book out from the library, and then spent a few days eagerly picking it back up every evening from my nightstand.“The Girl He Used to Know” is a love story that swallows you whole as you follow the lives of its two main characters, Annika Rose and Jonathan Hoffman. The book spans the course of a decade—a timespan in which these two fall in and out and back in love with one another. This story is a well-drawn examination of what it’s like to life with and love someone on the spectrum. It's also a bit of a nostalgia-inducing trip into the past, a reminder of what it's like to live moments (good, bad, and historic) without the trappings of today’s technology. “Girl” jumps between 1991 and 2001, and I was equally swept up in both time-hopping narratives. Even with an ending that dishes out some serious soap-opera level drama, I can’t say enough good things about this book. If you’re looking for your next poolside read, make this your next pick. ...more

review: This book is one of the buzziest of the summer, and with good reason. It’s a searing work of non-fiction that offers a deep exploration of female desiThis book is one of the buzziest of the summer, and with good reason. It’s a searing work of non-fiction that offers a deep exploration of female desire, as relayed through the narratives of three women followed for a decade by the author, Lisa Taddeo. In an interview with TIME Magazine, Taddeo described her subjects—Maggie, Lina, and Sloane, all women with VERY different sexual and relationship experiences—as inspirational, noting that, “If we are truthful about our desire, then we are putting our souls on an examination table. [These women] did something I don’t know that most people can do.” I felt that on every page of this brave book. It’s not a read for everyone, but for this journalism junkie, I couldn’t put it down—and a huge part of that was thanks not only to Lisa’s remarkable storytelling ability, but also her lyrical writing style, which I happened to love....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Growing up, I wanted to be a long-form magazine writer. In high school, I used to sit in the aisles of my library, devouring profiles in Rolling StoneGrowing up, I wanted to be a long-form magazine writer. In high school, I used to sit in the aisles of my library, devouring profiles in Rolling Stone, Vanity Fair, and Esquire. I still read those profiles, and, in recent years, have discovered that my favorite such stories are always written by the uber-talented Taffy Brodesser-Akner. I follow her work the way sports junkies follow their favorite athletes, so it was no surprise that I couldn’t wait to get my hands on a copy of her debut novel, “Fleishman Is In Trouble.” And wow. What a gripping read it is. As much a takedown of elitism as it is a nuanced glimpse into misogyny’s role in marital and mid-life breakdowns. If you pick up this book (which will end up on multiple ‘Best of’ and “Must Read” lists before the end of summer), be aware Taffy plays around with the narrative structure. At first, I found this…strange? confusing? But by the end of the book (with a final line I absolutely LOVED), I got the genius of what she was doing by switching up her narrator—and, more importantly WHY she was doing it—which only affirmed why, to me, she is one of THE finest writers in the game today. Also, I can’t tell you how much I want to talk about this book with other people! So friends, read it! Let’s discuss in the comments! Please! ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book found me at the perfect time (as I'm currently suffering from a creative dry spell in between writing projects). So yeah, a lot of good stufThis book found me at the perfect time (as I'm currently suffering from a creative dry spell in between writing projects). So yeah, a lot of good stuff here. My attempts to capture some of the highlights are below:[A conversation about whether we can still like the work of artists like Woody Allen and Michael Jackson and Bill Cosby...this caught my attention only because it provided me with a term for these jerks now]: "Take a quick dip into any one of the thousands of years of art history and you'll find that plenty of great art was made by jerks, creeps, assholes, vampires, perverts, and worse, all of whom left a trail of victims in their wake.  To steal a term from Jenny Offill's Dept. of Speculation, these people are what we call "Art Monsters." [About why you still get up and do the work]: "You start each work not knowing exactly where you're going or where you'll end up. 'Art is the highest form of hope,' said painter Gerhard Richter."[Creativity vs productivity....and I agree wholeheartedly with this statement]: "It's always a mistake to equate productivity and creativity. They are not the same. In fact, they are frequently at odds with each other: You're often most creative when you're the least productive." [On persevering as an artist]: "Try your best to fill your days in ways that get you a little closer to where you want to be. Go easy on yourself and take your time. Worry less about getting things done. Worry more about things worth doing. Worry less about being a great artist. Worry more about being a good human being who makes art."And a great checklist that captures some of the ways to get yourself unstuck as an artist: (1) switch your phone to airplane mode (2) draw up some lists (3) have a child teach you how to play (4) make a gift for someone (5) tidy up (6) lie down for a nap (7) take a long walk ...more

review: I'm catching up on my GR s before the end of 2020 and just realized I never added this read from October! Gosh, Kristin Hannah knows how to writI'm catching up on my GR s before the end of 2020 and just realized I never added this read from October! Gosh, Kristin Hannah knows how to write a good story, doesn't she? From the moment I picked up this book, I was swept up in the story of young Leni Allbright and her (crazy/hippy/irresponsible) parents who hauled her up to Alaska to "get away from it all" in the 1970s. "The Great Alone" takes some seriously dark turns (and about three quarters of the way through, the melodrama *really* gets ratcheted up .... to an almost eye-rolling degree), and yet I always hated to pull myself away from the characters and the evocative imagery of the rugged Alaskan setting every time I set the book down. This is now my second book of Hannah's (after 'The Nightingale') and I eagerly anticipate the release of her newest, "The Four Winds," in February. I have an odd fixation on the Dust Bowl, and I cannot wait to see what she makes of that time period with a set of new characters and her remarkable writing talent behind the venture. Characters from "The Great Alone" whose names I don't want to forget: Leni, Cora (Leni's mom), Ernt (Leni's dad), Large Marge, the Walkers (Tom and Matthew especially)...more

review: Earlier this month, my sister and I took our mom to Graceland—a pilgrimage she’s always wanted to make, given she’s been an Elvis fan since she was 10Earlier this month, my sister and I took our mom to Graceland—a pilgrimage she’s always wanted to make, given she’s been an Elvis fan since she was 10. The trip did not disappoint, and it opened a new world of discovery for me about an artist whose music I’d always enjoyed, but now have a deeper affinity for after visiting his home. (I went so far as to start my record collection while at Graceland, picking up Elvis's first (and arguably best) album there). And curious reader that I am, there was no way I was leaving the place without snatching up SOME book about The King. I could have nabbed one of the many biographies that were everywhere in the gift shops, but instead, I was compelled to pick up this memoir written by his wife, Priscilla. In part, it caught my attention for the cheese factor alone (that cover! the back jacket photo of Priscilla with her 1985 Dynasty hair!) but after the first 50 pages, I got so engrossed in her and Elvis’s love story, I couldn’t put it down! My only regret? Wishing I could have read it poolside because it is the quintessential vacation read—a dishy, dramatic tell-all that reads like fiction (and cost only $8 so if it gets wet, who cares?)Here’s a related side hop down memory lane: After I started reading this, I had a flashback to being a kid, remembering watching a TV movie about Elvis and Priscilla on a tiny television set in my parents’ bedroom. Turns out that movie was inspired by this very book, and it premiered in 1988—which meant I would have been a 6 year old with no business watching it! Needless to say, I HAD to look the movie up and was delighted to rediscover it in its entirety on YouTube. Cheesy? Without question. But when you’re talking about Elvis, you accept the cheese and flash as part of his legend, knowing where he ended up in life wasn’t where he hoped to be when he rocketed onto the scene in the late 1950s and changed music as we knew it forever....more

review: I’ve joked with one of my closest girlfriends that the only way I’m surviving the Trump administration is by upping my intake of romance novels. Ha! BI’ve joked with one of my closest girlfriends that the only way I’m surviving the Trump administration is by upping my intake of romance novels. Ha! But the truth is, my interest in the genre has dovetailed nicely with a trend I’ve seen sweep bookstores: giving romance a new life with playful covers that are an entire flight of stairs removed from the cheesy bodice rippers my grandma used to read. The plot of Samantha Young’s “Fight or Flight”—which I treated myself to during a birthday bookstore splurge—follows Ava Breevort as she meets a handsome, arrogant Scotsman, Caleb Scott, at the airport. All you really need to know is that he steals her first-class seat on a trip back to Boston and (naturally) high jinks, missed connections, and a few steamy bedroom scenes ensue. A quick indulgence of a read—not a favorite, but a fun one that made for a few good nights of escapism before my head hit the pillow. ...more

review: I downloaded a sample of this book on my phone and 10 pages in, I hit "Purchase." I HAD to because, with just a small glimpse into Evvie Drake’s worldI downloaded a sample of this book on my phone and 10 pages in, I hit "Purchase." I HAD to because, with just a small glimpse into Evvie Drake’s world (as created by the remarkably talented Linda Holmes, host of my favorite podcast, NPR’s Pop Culture Happy Hour), I knew didn’t want to leave. “Evie Drake Starts Over” is a SUPER smart rom-com about Evvie, whose husband dies, leaving her upset NOT because she’s a grieving widow, but because, on the day of his death, she's getting ready to leave him. This rom-edy(?) (this story is WAY more dramatic than a typical rom-com) set up then involves Evvie renting out an apartment in her home to the best friend of her best friend, Andy. Andy’s best friend happens to be Dean (ho hey! You KNOW I love that name), a Yankees pitcher with a case of the yips. Together, Evvie and Dean begin the hard work of healing each other’s hurts, one broken piece of dishware and one errant pitch at a time. This is A BEAUTIFUL book that I’m sad I can’t read again for the first time—I can’t think of a novel I’m recommending more this summer than this one!...more

review: Candice Carty-Williams’ debut novel, “Queenie” is not an easy read. In fact, there were times I felt conflicted picking this book back up, because QueCandice Carty-Williams’ debut novel, “Queenie” is not an easy read. In fact, there were times I felt conflicted picking this book back up, because Queenie—a British-Jamaican 20-something trying to navigate a rocky past, mental health issues, and a series of emotionally abusive run-ins with the opposite sex—is hell-bent on a 300-page journey of self-destruction. And yet, I’m so glad I stuck with Queenie’s story. The redemptive element to her ending was sweet justice, and Candice's powerful portrayal of a modern black woman—a “nuanced exploration of Black-British womanhood,” as Bustle describes it—made for an enlightening educational read for this particular white woman who found herself falling pretty dang hard for her. (See also: My affinity for Queenie’s gang of girlfriends she texts with and lovingly refers to as her “Corgis”—a Royal reference that made me laugh!) ...more

Here were a few that struck out to me especially:• Once we belong thoroughly to ourselves and believe thoroughly in ourselves, true belonging is ours. Belonging to ourselves means being called to stand alone—to brave the wilderness of uncertainty, vulnerability, and criticism.• Belonging so fully to yourself that you’re willing to stand alone IS a wilderness—an untamed, unpredictable place of solitude and searching. • True belonging doesn’t require you to change who you are; it requires you to *be* who you are. title: Shortest Way Home: One Mayor's Challenge and a Model for America's Future
author: Buttigieg, Pete
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have a friend who lives in South Bend who, for some time now, has spoken glowingly about Pete Buttigieg—praise that goes back at least a few years iI have a friend who lives in South Bend who, for some time now, has spoken glowingly about Pete Buttigieg—praise that goes back at least a few years in our conversations. Over the past few months, this friend and I have been texting like crazy as we’ve cheered for “Mayor Pete” in his rise leading up to his run for President of the United States.It’s far too early in the campaign slog to determine how Pete will fare come 2020, but I cannot deny that I am deeply impressed by this man: a fellow Hoosier who’s brilliant, modest, and committed to restoring hope in the heartland—a heartland too many coastal elite are too quick to write off as some kind of post-industrial, conservative wasteland. Pete’s memoir is a well-written, revealing look into the life of a quiet academic, an aspiring politician, a well-respected mayor, and a 30-something grappling to accept his sexuality. (His chapters about meeting and falling for Chasten, his husband, brought tears to my eyes, particularly because, in the audio version of the book, Pete himself becomes emotional as he tells their story). Above all else, Pete Buttigieg appeals to me as a person and as a politician because his outlook on the world resonates deeply with me. He is only a few weeks older than I am—a fellow millennial whose optimistic take on change is one I wholeheartedly endorse. For these reasons and more, I have found his call for generational leadership change and his aspirations to usher in a new era in politics inspiring in the best, breath-of-fresh-air kind of way. ...more
