review: I was first introduced to Lee Miller as a 26-year-old aspiring photographer who discovered her work while at a San Francisco Museum of Modern Art exhiI was first introduced to Lee Miller as a 26-year-old aspiring photographer who discovered her work while at a San Francisco Museum of Modern Art exhibit in 2008. I bought her biography from the museum bookstore because I was amazed by her life story: a woman who had been a Vogue model in the 1920s before she took off for Paris to become a muse to the likes of legendary artists like Many Ray and Picasso … and all this before she became a WWII photographer (who became infamous for the shot taken of her in Hitler’s bathroom after the war ended). Hers was truly an EXTRAORDINARY life, and I came to view Lee Miller as an American badass. I still feel that way about her, which is why, when I heard about Whitney Scharer's “The Age of Light”, I had to pick up this new read. The book is a fictionalized dramatization of Lee’s life in Paris and her love affair with her mentor, Man Ray. It’s a powerful story about one of the most fascinating women of the 20th century—a woman who is SCREAMING to have a biopic made about her (come on Hollywood, get on it and resurrect that Kate Winslet project, please!)Reading Whitney’s debut sent me down a rabbit hole of looking up Lee’s work and falling for it (and her) all over again. Thank you, Whitney, for reminding me why Lee is such a muse to me....more

review: Catching up on book s, and I wanted to start by sharing my love for this Bruce Springsteen memoir. Something you should know about me (in case iCatching up on book s, and I wanted to start by sharing my love for this Bruce Springsteen memoir. Something you should know about me (in case it’s not already apparent): When I develop a random, impromptu crush on an artist, I fall HARD. So, being stuck at home with the flu in February, I spent a night on the couch catching Bruce’s Broadway special on Netflix, which led me to finally pick up his memoir from my unread bookshelf. I'm glad I did, because this read is such an inspiring glimpse into the mind of a musical genius. What I loved most about it is how Bruce’s blue collar roots shine through: It was powerful to read about his tenuous relationship with his alcoholic father; his meteoric rise as an artist creating Born to Run (arguably THE best Bruce album); his soulmate connection to his wife, Patti; and his love for his band members, Clarence Clemons especially. Reading about creatives always sparks my own creativity, and this emotional read did exactly that for me. Glad it found me when it did (even if it meant my husband had to endure weeks of me listening to ALL of Bruce’s albums—and ahem…admiring MANY a photo of the rocker in his younger days— like this one, for example!)...more

review: As much as there were times I wanted to set "Mrs. Everything" aside and walk away, I couldn't. I ended up caring too much about its two main characterAs much as there were times I wanted to set "Mrs. Everything" aside and walk away, I couldn't. I ended up caring too much about its two main characters (two sisters, Bethie and Jo)—enough to want to know where life took them right up until the end. This story (or should I say, Jo's story) was inspired by Weiner's own mother coming out after a long marriage, so I can see why this was a narrative Weiner felt compelled to write. I think this book would make for an excellent book club pick, especially if your club was comprised of all women. Because, as USA TODAY so aptly puts it, "If you are a woman who has lived through the past 50 years, this book will make you uneasy, even angry. But maybe that’s the point."No maybes—that IS the point.This book made me think about my own mother's life journey. I want her to read it. I want to talk to her about it. I want to discuss all the ways life has changed and life hasn't changed for women today. So yeah, there were parts of "Mrs. Everything" that were overwritten (Jennifer Weiner certainly did her research, I'll leave it at that!). And there were parts that contain plotlines far too convenient for real life, but still, I believe, overall, this book works. And that's because the best books stimulate conversation. I can envision at least a half-dozen conversations I want to have with the various women in my life I hope get around to reading this, too....more

review: Most of the books I pick up are contemporary reads, and I try to make sure my reading list is diverse year-round. But during Black History Month, it’sMost of the books I pick up are contemporary reads, and I try to make sure my reading list is diverse year-round. But during Black History Month, it’s become a tradition to read a classic by a person of color. This year, I picked up Zora Neale Hurston’s “Their Eyes Were Watching God,” a book that has been on my bookshelf for years. It took me a while to get comfortable with the dialect of the characters, but once I did I was swept up in the drama of their lives, most notably Janie and Tea Cake and their circumstances living in the 1930s-era Everglades. What a beautiful story of love and independence—not to mention a bold celebration of feminism that was ahead of its time....more

review: There are some books so special, they imprint on you: the characters, the narrative, the way the author captures specific thoughts on the page that hiThere are some books so special, they imprint on you: the characters, the narrative, the way the author captures specific thoughts on the page that hit you hard because they’re also YOUR thoughts. That is exactly what happened to me as I read the talented Claire Lombardo's debut novel, “The Most Fun We Ever Had.” This is an extraordinary saga about family, about marriage, about the bonds of siblinghood, and about the lies we tell ourselves when it comes to any of us “having it all.” This book hits bookstore shelves today (June 25) and trust me when I say it’s the kind of read where, even when your nose isn’t stuck in the book, you’ll be wondering what the Sorenson clan is up to. (Though, in full disclosure, I must share there is a scene involving a still birth in the book—for any of my friends who may be triggered by this, a heads up.) review: I have a weird soft spot for books with apocalyptic themes like this one. Karen Thompson Walker’s newest novel, “The Dreamers,” kept me on the edge ofI have a weird soft spot for books with apocalyptic themes like this one. Karen Thompson Walker’s newest novel, “The Dreamers,” kept me on the edge of my seat with its menacing story about a mysterious contagion that puts to sleep half the inhabitants of the small college town of Santa Lora, California. For much of the novel, I wondered where Walker was taking her readers, but by the end, any questions I had were replaced with a deep admiration for her use of evocative language and her ability to make me wonder about the very nature of consciousness as well as the power of our dreams. I’ll be thinking about this sci-fi fairy tale for a while to come. ...more

Without question, it's my favorite passage of the book.Because in it, Jeff Zentner does what he does best: write lovingly about characters experiencing the beauty of a moment that will live on in their memories forever. Consider this sentence and you’ll see what I mean:“There’s something about witnessing something holy with someone you love, because you take that sacred thing and weave it, like a golden thread, into the fabric of your togetherness.”Lovely, right? It’s why Jeff will always be one of my favorite authors for young adult readers, and why I’ll always be game for picking up one of his books....more

review: Here’s how I know Dani Shapiro is masterful at her craft—because in the hands of a lesser talented writer, this memoir (about how Dani discovers throuHere’s how I know Dani Shapiro is masterful at her craft—because in the hands of a lesser talented writer, this memoir (about how Dani discovers through one of those popular DNA kits that her father is not her biological father) would have been better as a long-form article in a magazine instead of the novel-length biography it became. But because Dani’s prose is so evocative, I found her words pulling me along, not even caring where her musings about this major life upheaval took me, just wanting to read more of her thoughts as she put them down on the page. I loved this read and think it would make for an incredible book club selection, especially because the questions it raises (about genetic testing, the history of fertility treatments in our country, and the bonds of family) would make for a powerful discussion. ...more

review: Now that I’ve read “After I Do,” I can say I’ve read every book written by Taylor Jenkins Reid.No lie, I’ve loved every one.“After I Do” is her secondNow that I’ve read “After I Do,” I can say I’ve read every book written by Taylor Jenkins Reid.No lie, I’ve loved every one.“After I Do” is her second novel and, like her other books before “Evelyn Hugo”, it’s the very definition of women’s fiction: books about women, embracing themes related to relationships/home/family …you know the drill. Too often, these books get poo-pooed for not being serious enough or having pink covers or script-y fonts.But here’s why Ms. Reid is a queen of women’s fiction: She writes stories about real women, leading ordinary lives, in a way that elevates the genre. In the instance of “After I Do,” the book centers on a couple who takes a year-long break from their marriage. Not divorced, but separated—and MULTIPLE times I found myself wishing I could press this book into the hands of every person in my life who’s ever complained to me about her marriage.It has such lovely gems of truth, particularly for readers who, in their own life circumstances, may want to save a sinking relationship. The characters are well-rounded and entertaining (I loved the grandmother especially), and it’s the perfect read for when you want something light enough to lift you up, but serious enough to make you appreciate the universality of its truths. ...more

title: Small Fry: A Memoir
author: Brennan-Jobs, Lisa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: First off, hats off to narrator Eileen Stevens. She did SUCH a wonderful job with this audiobook, delivering nuanced performances for each of its majoFirst off, hats off to narrator Eileen Stevens. She did SUCH a wonderful job with this audiobook, delivering nuanced performances for each of its major players. (The voice of Lisa's mother was especially distinct). Her narration was reason alone to keep me reading.Of course, so was this powerful coming-of-age story, one that centers on the fragile relationship author Lisa Brennan-Jobs had with her father, the creative genius Steve Jobs, who died in 2011. At best, Lisa remembers Jobs (who at first denied paternity of her, until he was sued by Lisa's mother for child support) as awkwardly warm, with Steve trying be an engaged father but never quite getting there with the many off-color comments he'd make in her presence. (Asking her once, in front of her stepmother, if she masturbated is one example.) At worst, Steve could be an outright dick—unapologetically mean to Lisa or to anyone else in his path of disapproval, be it a waiter, employee, or fellow family member. I've read plenty of memoirs, and I can't recall any that left me feeling as hollowed out as this one did. Maybe that's because I didn't really know how casually cruel Jobs could be in his day-to-day life. But also because, as Katy Waldman described in her 2018 New Yorker  of the book: "[Lisa's] memoir elicits little sympathy for [Jobs], and “Small Fry,” a book of no small literary skill, is confused and conflicted, angry and desperate to forgive. Its central, compelling puzzle is Brennan-Jobs’s continuing need to justify not just her father’s behavior but her longing for his love. It is a mesmerizing, discomfiting reading."Discomfiting is a PERFECT way to describe how I felt reading this book. Even with that discomfort level factored in, I'd still recommend this read. For me, it was a fascinating exploration of how all the money, prestige, and accomplishments in the world can't make a person truly happy. And how, more often than not, our perceptions of a person are never what they seem....more

review: This is one of those books that people will suggest you read if you enjoyed Kristin Hannah's "The Nightingale." And yet, for me it fell short (as it dThis is one of those books that people will suggest you read if you enjoyed Kristin Hannah's "The Nightingale." And yet, for me it fell short (as it did for several of my girlfriends who put it down!)The characters in "The Alice Network" felt enough like caricatures that I could never quite fall for them (in particular the antagonist, René, who was SO over the top all he was missing was a mustache to twirl, a la a Disney villain).Admittedly, I stuck around because I was smitten with Finn (the Scottish driver), but I found myself struggling to like Charlie St. Cloud (the protagonist in the post-WWII-era story). This was mostly due to the fact the author INSISTED on summarizing her thoughts in math equations (ie, "She had taken the hopeless mess around her, pared away the meaningless variables, the Ys and Zs that didn't matter, solved for x.") UGGGHHHH. These equations tied back to Charlie's interest in math, which we learned about early in the narrative, but considering there were about 20 of them sprinkled throughout the book, they drove me mad after awhile.Lastly, on a related note, this book could have benefited from the heavier hand of an editor who might have whittled it down at least 50-75 pages. I will, however, say that I admire Quinn's dedication to bringing to life the true stories of the heroines who contributed to the war efforts through their espionage. title: This Is How It Always Is
author: Frankel, Laurie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book was a slow burn for me. I can't say why, exactly (it was certainly good!) but I think it just was the result of timing (December is such a bThis book was a slow burn for me. I can't say why, exactly (it was certainly good!) but I think it just was the result of timing (December is such a busy/exhausting month that my bedside reading goes by more quickly b/c I'm more prone to falling asleep with my book in hand!)This was our winter book club pick and I look forward to talking about it with the ladies in a few weeks—I felt like Laurie Frankel wrote a very passionate portrayal of one family's cathartic journey in handling the ups and downs of their child's gender dysphoria. I didn't always agree with the parent's decision-making (that cross-country move was a doozie!) but I respected the care and thought that went into everything they did. I also loved how funny and warm the author made these characters—they came to life on the page, in particular Penn and Rosie's marriage. Lastly, because I always read Acknowledgements and Author's Notes, I loved what Laurie had to say about writing a novel (which refers to the idea that this book is based on her child's trans journey): "Writing a novel is like making a soup. The base is a broth we make up wholesale—for instance, I have one child, not five, and am not only not a doctor, but, in fact, am made woozy by paper cuts. Then, to that entirely made-up broth, we add a sprinkling of research, some chunks of childhood memories, a handful of sauteed morsels overheard at the playground, a few diced bits we weren't planning on but turned out to need for depth of flavor, and some finely chopped pieces of our own lives. Simmer until all the disparate parts mellow and blend but still enhance and augment one another. This is how you cook a novel. Some made up, some real life, all true....more

title: The Stranger in the Woods: The Extraordinary Story of the Last True Hermit
author: Finkel, Michael*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Last month, my book club met up to discuss Michael Finkel's "The Stranger in the Woods," a non-fiction read detailing the life of Christopher Knight, Last month, my book club met up to discuss Michael Finkel's "The Stranger in the Woods," a non-fiction read detailing the life of Christopher Knight, a man who spent TWENTY SEVEN years living alone as a hermit in the woods of Maine. I've been in my book club for ten years, and what I've learned is that the books that spark our best discussions are non-fiction reads like this one. (Others that have kept us talking for upwards of an hour: Tara Westover's "Educated", Jeanette Walls' "The Glass Castle" and Susan Jane Gilman's "Undress Me in the Temple of Heaven.") With "Stranger," we were fascinated by this one man's journey to retreat from the world, and we asked ourselves whether we could or would ever do the same. What I also loved about this book is how Finkel gives his readers a detailed history of hermits (it's more fascinating than you think!) and how it's probable that genetics plays a role in personalities seeking extreme isolation. Highly recommend this one—it would make a great gift this holiday season for readers in your family....more

title: The Library Book
author: Orlean, Susan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "The Library Book" is one of those fascinating amalgamations of a book: the kind that weave together a little fact, a little memoir, and a whole lot o"The Library Book" is one of those fascinating amalgamations of a book: the kind that weave together a little fact, a little memoir, and a whole lot of "I never thought someone could write such an interesting ode to one particular subject, but here we are."On the surface, the book is an in-depth examination of the events before, during, and after the 1986 fire that destroyed much of L.A.'s Central Library. But tucked in between chapters about the fire is an historical accounting of libraries across America—with a few tangential chapters on arson, the history of book burning (the pages about the Nazis made me shudder) and a few snapshots of what it's like to work as a librarian today. (I was especially amused by a scene during which Orlean 'shadows' the reference desk of the Central Library for a day—the questions people asked of them are absurd!) Orlean also mines the concerns of today's librarians in a way that makes you empathize with them, from how they must keep pace with technology to how they are expected to best serve the homeless, men and women who deserve to be in the library as much as the next person, but who often tax the library's resources by making the stacks and reading rooms a second kind of home. This is the perfect book for someone who is a) a history junkie b) a book junkie and/or c) grew up spending almost as much time at the library as he/she did at home. In summary, it was a book that was right up my alley, one that had me Googling aplenty afterward, looking for pictures of the library, reading profiles about the author, and looking up stories about Harry Peak, the man who was arrested but never indicted for starting the '86 fire. More often than not, these are the kinds of books that stay with me the longest after reading them, and I'm sure "The Library Book" will be no different. My only caveat: I listened to this as an audiobook, and while the author does a nice job reading it, I had a hard time keeping track of certain names (like the FASCINATING American figure of Charles Fletcher Lummis, who plays a central role in the history of the Central Library) and certain narrative elements as the weeks flew past. ...more

review: Over the Thanksgiving holiday, I DEVOURED Michelle Obama's "Becoming" (much like I devoured the pumpkin pie cheesecake I made :P). What to say of our Over the Thanksgiving holiday, I DEVOURED Michelle Obama's "Becoming" (much like I devoured the pumpkin pie cheesecake I made :P). What to say of our First Lady's much-touted memoir? It's every bit as good as you expect it to be. What surprised me most was how relatable Michelle's story felt. When she talked about her love for her parents, when she talked about the grief of losing people close to her, when she talked about the perils and trappings of being a working mom—I saw myself in all those moments she described. Michelle writes openly and authentically about her life in a heartfelt way that resonates thanks to little nods of wisdom she drops carefully throughout the book. And, as much as it is a book about her life, it's also a fascinating peek into the rise of Barack's political career and presidency. (I was especially intrigued by her description of life in the White House ... the word "stifling" comes to mind.) With Christmas on its way, "Becoming" would make for an excellent pick under the tree. Just don't be surprised if the person you gift it to slips away all day to binge read! ...more

author: Gray, Anissa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: “The Care and Feeding of Ravenously Hungry Girls” is a solid debut from a writer whose Midwestern roots shine through in its pages. This is a multi-ge“The Care and Feeding of Ravenously Hungry Girls” is a solid debut from a writer whose Midwestern roots shine through in its pages. This is a multi-generational story that features three sisters, all of whose backstories and subplots come together in a way that makes you want to keep reading. Some of the writing was lyrical enough to make me stop and savor it, which is always a plus.If I had any critique, it’s in the way this book was marketed. It’s billed as “The Mothers” meets “An American Marriage” and….well, I’ve read both of those wonderful novels and I just don’t see it. If you want to go there because this novel—like those—delves into the lives of African American characters, sure. Maybe I’ll let you pass on the “American Marriage” comparison because one of the sisters, Althea, is, like Roy, incarcerated. But her crime doesn’t read nearly as serious as his, nor is there any question she's the one at fault. I found myself frustrated by the comparisons because, in making them, I felt like they took away from the pleasure of this story’s ability to stand on its own. Thanks to Berkley Publishing Group for providing me with an ARC so I could read it before its release. If you are a fan of family sagas and/or have a heart for Midwestern literature, you may enjoy this read, too....more

title: Daisy Jones & The Six
author: Reid, Taylor Jenkins*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Re-read in March 2023: In anticipation of the much-hyped release of the "Daisy Jones & The Six" television series, I decided to re-read this incrediblRe-read in March 2023: In anticipation of the much-hyped release of the "Daisy Jones & The Six" television series, I decided to re-read this incredible novel—this time in audio format. Much like my first go at it, I devoured it in 2 days ... remembering all the while just how GREAT its premise was. I also binged the first three episodes of the miniseries after they dropped Friday night and man oh man do I love this cast. If I (as a devoted fan) have a hard time comprehending just how surreal it is to listen to (really great!) music created by fictional characters made real, well ... I can't imagine how surreal it must be for Taylor Jenkins Reid, who calls this book her "baby" and this TV adaptation her "grandchild." I cannot wait to keep watching as Amazon releases more of the 10-episode series on a weekly basis. Original  (December 2018-January 2019): I picked a hell of a good book to start off my stack of 2019 reads. I’m a super fan of Taylor Jenkins Reid and her latest, “Daisy Jones and The Six” was THE book I was most looking forward to reading this year. I was lucky enough to snag an advance copy (the book releases in March) and I tore through it in two days. It’s a mind-blowing read on multiple levels: 1) the concept—a ‘tell-all” memoir of a ‘70s-era rock band, is revealed in an oral history so original, it’s unlike anything I’ve ever read 2) as is true of most TJR books, there’s a fantastic narrative twist you don’t see coming 3) by the end of the book you're so convinced that this is a REAL band, that you will long to find their No. 1 album “Aurora” online, just so you can hear Daisy and lead singer, Billy Dunne, duet together but 4) since that’s impossible, TJR has done something that's off-the-wall incredible—she’s WRITTEN THE ENTIRE ALBUM, the lyrics of which are included at the back of the novel. The creativity it takes to pull off a feat like this is extraordinary. If you are a fan of rock ’n’ roll, love the film “Almost Famous” or have made a resolution in the new year to read more “good” books, stop what you’re doing and pre-order “Daisy Jones” right now....more

review: What to say about “Normal People,” a novel that took the UK by storm last year? One that was written by a 27-year-old, Irish-born literary phenom who’What to say about “Normal People,” a novel that took the UK by storm last year? One that was written by a 27-year-old, Irish-born literary phenom who’s been hailed as the ‘Salinger of the Snapchat generation’? Ummm …. how about an honest admission that I didn’t LOVE this book the way I expected I would. I was lucky to get my hands on an ARC (it releases stateside in April), and while I found plenty of passages where Rooney’s exceptional writing was on full display, I also felt like I was picking up a heavy weight every time I plucked this read from my nightstand. That has mostly to do with the book’s main characters, Marianne and Connell. Over the course of “Normal People,” we follow them from high school into college and beyond, observing the ways they come together as sexual partners, as friends, as occasional frenemies. One  I read of “Normal People” professed the writer’s belief that Rooney had convincingly captured what it meant to be young today: often overeducated, neurotic, and slightly too self-aware. This I can see, but the truth of it depresses the hell out of me. Namely because this book was exhausting, both in terms of its realness and the emotional complexities of its characters. If it makes any sense, I was glad I read it, and yet grateful to come to its final page. ...more

Complicating matters? Her dashing son, Alex, has fallen HARD for a member of the Royal Family: the storybook handsome Prince Henry. title: I Miss You When I Blink: Essays
author: Philpott, Mary Laura*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There was enough buzz about this collection of essays that I really looked forward to diving into them. And yet, after a few, I was left with that holThere was enough buzz about this collection of essays that I really looked forward to diving into them. And yet, after a few, I was left with that hollow feeling that the words on the page weren’t hitting me the way Mary Laura Philpott intended. In 2019, it’s hard to read essays like this and not think about the entitlement of the person writing them. Most of Mary Laura’s musings are about her frustrations of being a creatively stifled, working mother of two. She’s entitled to share those thoughts and opinions, but it’s hard to feel…empathy? connection? with someone living such a comfortable upper-middle-class life in Atlanta (someone who comfortably affords to uproot her family to Nashville to work for Ann Patchett at Parnassus Books….not that I wouldn’t jump at that chance, too!) If representation and privilege are words you're applying to your literary picks as of late, this book isn’t for you. But if you’re open to a “pep talk from your sister” (as Simon and Schuster so aptly puts it), you’ll be more inclined to enjoy reading about the various ways this writer reinvents herself as she enters the second stage of her life and career....more

review: I've never come across a YA read that transported me into a new culture quite like Adib Khorram's "Darius the Great is Not Okay." It tells the story oI've never come across a YA read that transported me into a new culture quite like Adib Khorram's "Darius the Great is Not Okay." It tells the story of Darius, a teen whose family returns to Iran (his mother's homeland) to spend time with his ailing grandparent and extended family. Within these pages I learned so much about Persian culture and traditions—topics that had me Googling aplenty. (I spent 20 minutes alone reading about the country's social system of politeness known as ta'arof!) But as much as this book helps readers explore a culture that is one of the oldest in the world, it's also a beautiful, quiet story about one young man's personal journey to become closer to his father and to battle his self doubts and loneliness—all while sharing with readers a glimpse into what it's like to live with manageable depression. Adib, congrats on your amazing debut. I'm proud to call you a friend, and I hope I've convinced a few friends to add this book to their to-read list in the new year!...more

title: Ally Hughes Has Sex Sometimes
author: Moulin, Jules
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm glad this rom-com of a read had a Q&A with the author at its end. Because it affirmed what I assumed to be true: That Jules Moulin (a writer for TI'm glad this rom-com of a read had a Q&A with the author at its end. Because it affirmed what I assumed to be true: That Jules Moulin (a writer for TV and films) wrote "Ally Hughes" as her "midlife fantasy on paper."This book certainly reads as such—a dual narrative centered on the life of serially single Ally Hughes both in the past and the present. In the past (10 years ago), she hooks up on the last day of the semester with one of her seniors at Brown (where she is a professor). That student, Jake Bean, is where the fantasy comes into play: He's handsome in a blue-collar kind of way, handy (Ally hires him to fix a bunch of stuff around her house), a fan of feminist theory, and charming as all get out. In the present narrative, Ally meets Jake again—only this time, he's the famous actor "Noah Bean" (picture a Chris Evans or Chris Pratt kind of hunky-every man-turned-Hollywood-leading-man star). As a lover of pop culture, I was down for this storyline, which basically read like a movie script. Admittedly, the plot meanders into weird territory. (Ally's daughter, who meets Noah because she is cast in a movie he's starring in, gets involved in a weird Internet sex scam, and Ally's friend, Teddy, is just plain awful). But what saved it for me was whip smart, fun dialogue and, of course, my own midlife fantasy crush on Jake Bean. A sampling of dialogue that made me LOL:Ally shrugged. "I don't know, Jake. What do I know? Look at my life."Jake smiled. "Listen, you fold your towels in thirds. That's class. We fold our towels in half at our house. Your'e doing great."Ally laughed and studied him.Also, I loved this passage (please note that Jake takes the initiative to make the bed here...he really is a fantasy on paper!!! Ha!):"It's a beautiful day." He turned and started to straighten the bed. "You don't have to—" She crossed to him."Yes, I do." She joined him and they pulled up the top sheet together, then the blanket. Jake began to tuck them in.Ally then stopped. She was struck by how easy it was to make a bed with someone else. It's a two-person job, a bed. It's a two-person job, this life. ...more

title: Yes We (Still) Can: Politics in the Age of Obama, Twitter, and Trump
author: Pfeiffer, Dan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There’s been a glut of Obama WH memoirs hitting publishing lately and I’m here for them. A few weeks back, I blazed through Dan Pfeiffer’s “Yes We StiThere’s been a glut of Obama WH memoirs hitting publishing lately and I’m here for them. A few weeks back, I blazed through Dan Pfeiffer’s “Yes We Still Can” enthralled with his recounting of his years as Obama’s communications director. If you’re a friend of Pod Save America, you already know Dan’s style—sarcastic and entertaining, scathing and super intelligent. Dan didn’t set out to write this book … until Trump won. So if you pick this up, you’ll read a LOT about his frustrations with the current state of politics. But you’ll also discover great gems about what it was like to work for a decent man and brilliant leader. Some gems are funny (when Dan tried Tweeting from the hospital on pain meds, or when he was there for Barack’s take on a Hollywood fund-raiser with Kayne), and others might leave you teary. I ended this feeling hopeful, too. Hopeful that, in the words of our former President, this current administration is “the clarifying event that will show the public the two different visions for the country.” I know which vision I still believe in. ...more

title: Every Note Played
author: Genova, Lisa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was a summer pick for my book club and our reactions were similar: We all agreed the two main characters were pretty insufferable. Both of them—RThis was a summer pick for my book club and our reactions were similar: We all agreed the two main characters were pretty insufferable. Both of them—Richard, the pianist with ALS; Karina, his ex-wife who isn’t over his cheating but grudgingly cares for him—were so stubborn and narcissistic in their own ways that it made their bullheadedness nearly unforgivable.Yet, what I loved about this book was how ALS became the most important character. Similar to what she did with Alzheimer’s in “Still Alice,” Lisa Genova masterfully chronicles the progression of a heinous disease. It makes for a brutal read, but also an enlightening one—particularly when you consider whether you could endure dying in such a way with dignity.The acknowledgements are worth a read. In them, Lisa shares that she was inspired to write this book because the director of the film adaptation of “Still Alice” (which was fantastic) suffered from ALS. As someone who took piano lessons for seven years, I also loved the way the instrument played (ha!) such an important role. And the character who plays Richard’s male nurse, Bill, was incredible. He was so patient and funny and kind—the best depiction of the talented, brave women and men who do the hard work of being home health aids. One final thought: Even if I didn’t love these lead characters, I’ll still read anything Lisa writes—she’s such a talent. This interview with her is very insightful....more

review: This will come across as hyperbolic, but I really believe Rebecca Makkai has written The Great American Novel about the ‘80s AIDS epidemic. In this swThis will come across as hyperbolic, but I really believe Rebecca Makkai has written The Great American Novel about the ‘80s AIDS epidemic. In this sweeping, brilliant book, she has masterfully captured what it must have been like to endure the terror and tragedies of this country’s worst health crisis. To be handed down what essentially was a death sentence, and then, to wonder who you loved would get the horrific news next … I cannot imagine the fear and anxiety that followed an entire generation of men, but Rebecca did a hell of a job casting those feelings onto an incredible cast of characters for me. And because I love novels that jump around in time, I might add that this one does a terrific job of taking readers between a 1980s Chicago storyline and a 2015 Paris storyline, with a character that has a prominent role in both stories. As someone who came of (early) age during the AIDS crisis, I am drawn to books that help me better understand just how far-reaching this epidemic was and how little our government did to combat it. (Growing up in Indiana, it was Ryan White who dominated the headlines. I’m ashamed to admit it was YEARS before I knew about the resistance efforts of advocacy groups like ACT-UP. ) I was deeply affected by “Great Believers,” and I wasn’t surprised at all to learn this week that it had been long-listed for a National Book Award. Talk about well-deserved recognition for a novel that will go down as one of my favorite reads of 2018....more

review: I kept seeing this book pop up on Instagram and Twitter this summer. I love a good contemporary romance (key factors to “good”: light on cheese, well I kept seeing this book pop up on Instagram and Twitter this summer. I love a good contemporary romance (key factors to “good”: light on cheese, well done on the heavy, and well-drawn characters that aren’t too damsel in distress-y). Now that I’ve read “The Kiss Quotient” I can attest that Helen Hoang DEFINITELY delivers. I liked Stella a lot (and I particularly loved the way Helen positively portrayed her spectrum-related social struggles). But the character I NEED to talk about is Michael. Don’t be surprised if you finish this one with a serious fictional crush. If I haven’t hooked you yet, Helen pitched this book as a reverse “Pretty Woman.” So, who’s in?Postscript: As a fellow writer who dreams of publication, this interview with Helen REALLY spoke to me. title: Circe
author: Miller, Madeline*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My junior year in high school, I had a male math teacher who taught algebra. Much as I tried, I never clicked with him, and I had to work extra hard tMy junior year in high school, I had a male math teacher who taught algebra. Much as I tried, I never clicked with him, and I had to work extra hard to understand his teaching style. That spring, we had a young woman as our student teacher. Under her patient tutelage, all those equations and symbols suddenly made sense to me.I thought of this yin-yang academic experience as I was reading Madeline Miller’s “Circe.” In a similar vein, I never had a high school English teacher or humanities professor (all male, in my experience) who did Greek mythology justice—not for me, at least. All that time, I guess all I needed was for Madeline Miller to come along.“Circe” started slow for me (mostly due to my lack of understanding about basic Greek mythology, which explains why I had to Google “Titans vs. Olympians’ multiple times as I wrapped my head around the vast family tree of Greek gods). But after the (badass) goddess Circe is banished to the island of Aeaea, I I couldn’t stop turning the pages. Miller’s prose is poetic and powerful, and I was transfixed by her account of Circe’s entry into witchcraft, her love affairs with men like Daedalus and Oydysseus, and her desire to become more human than nymph. I give Miller all the credit for inviting new readers to discover Greek mythology thanks to her extraordinary work. Her debut, “Song for Achilles,” is next on my must-read list!...more

This is a great read if you already love Sedaris (but not the best to delve into if you've never read him before; it's written very much in a style that assumes you're familiar with his family and his partner, Hugh, and his past works). I'm not sure what more I can say because it's very "Sedaris being Sedaris". I love the guy, so a lot of these essays made me LOL in the car. My favorite ones were about the snapping turtle he befriends (and grossly feeds a tumor that a fan removes from his body—seriously!) and also the one about his relationship with certain words. (He hates how much Americans love "awesome," for example). This Q&Awith him is pretty great and I'll always want to see the guy at another one of his live readings. The only other time I've been, I sat in the first row and laughed so hard that he legit gave me a look like, "Woman, even *I* know I'm not THAT funny." review: I wanted to really love this book. I read an essay the author wrote for TIME magazine in June (coinciding with the anniversary of D-Day) and I was intI wanted to really love this book. I read an essay the author wrote for TIME magazine in June (coinciding with the anniversary of D-Day) and I was intrigued. I’d never heard of épuration sauvage, the wild purge, that followed WWII—a time when women across France were publicly humiliated and wrongfully accused for perceived collaborationist activity with the Nazis. I love books that shed light on forgotten elements of history, so I was like, “Sign me up!”But I ended up giving up on this one. Once it was due back at the library, I returned it half-read.There were a few reasons it frustrated me: 1) Mah utilized too much French. Her characters are French (but not her protagonist, an American visiting the country), so I can understand the decision. But it was done to a gratuitous degree (there would be at least six or seven French words italicized on most pages), and so it became a distraction—especially for someone who doesn’t speak much French. And 2) there was some foreshadowing going on in certain places that felt misplaced or unintended. (In one example, I thought the wife of the cousin the protagonist was staying with was ill and they didn’t want the protagonist to know…maybe that ended up being true, but I think I was wrong). Again, little distractions that maybe only nagged me. I’m glad to see so many others loved it more than I did....more

review: I read an interview with author Curtis Sittenfeld where she described the women whose stories are the basis of her new book of short stories as “smartI read an interview with author Curtis Sittenfeld where she described the women whose stories are the basis of her new book of short stories as “smart, grouchy, Midwestern women.” And those are exactly the characters you’ll meet if you pick up “You Think It, I’ll Say It.” The beauty of that analogy, however, misses the nuances of these narrators—nuances that the talented Sittenfeld writes just about better than anybody putting out fiction today. Her writing is always a treat to read, and these stories were so well crafted I couldn’t put the book down—which is saying a lot b/c I’m not often one to love short stories. Highly recommend for those who love great character studies and especially for my fellow mom friends hovering around the middle-aged mark (as I am). You’ll find a lot of yourself in these pages, whether you want to admit it or not. (And for those who have read it, let me know your favorite stories: Mine were “Gender Studies” and “Prairie Wife,” which was so brilliant it will go down as one of the greatest things I’ve read all year.) ...more

review: SO many people I know encouraged me to read this book since its publication that I did that thing where I sort of put it on a pedestal (and then prompSO many people I know encouraged me to read this book since its publication that I did that thing where I sort of put it on a pedestal (and then promptly kept putting it off). I decided 2020 would be the year I tackle 3 stellar novels that have sat too long on my bookshelf: A Gentleman in Moscow, Heart’s Invisible Furies, and Americanah. (Two down, one to go!) What a narrative ride this book proved to be. It gave me so many insights into what life was like for so many closeted gay men who were forced to hide their sexuality in secret for much of the 20th century. I loved all the characters (even the ones I didn’t much care for) because Boyne created them with such love and attention to detail.Some readers have compared this book to “A Little Life” but I didn’t pick up on that. (If anything, I thought it paralleled a lot of the themes of Rebecca Makkai’s “The Great Believers".) Maybe it's because of this comparison that I wasn’t prepared for the dark humor that was so abundant throughout this book. As bleak as the subject material could be, there were moments I laughed out loud (Cyril had such a wonderful dry sense of humor, and there were lots of running gags, ie 'adopted son'). But then….oh, but then…I did cry, too. I don’t want to say why (that risks giving away the masterful delivery of the book’s most harrowing scene), but that moment—and much of the story—got to me in a way only the best books can.A few of the main characters, so that I don’t forget their names: Catherine, Cyril, Charles, Maude, Julian, Bastiaan, Alice, Ignaac....more

Women aren't just running for office in record numbers, they are winning in record numbers, too ... So you see, Madam President, having survived the unprecedented scene in the movie where the world exploded after all, we can now write our own happy ending. I let my 12 yo niece borrow my copy of Sarah’s book (she loved it BTW) and then, to my delight, recently gave it a read myself. It’s the story of fifth grader Ada Roundtree, whose twin sister goes missing in the annual town “sweepstakes” and whose mission it is to find out what happened to her. What I loved most about this book is how WILDLY inventive it is. Ada lives in the town of Oddity (where normal is odd and odd is normal), and with nearly every page of the book came a new, wildly imaginative character to delight in. title: Killers of the Flower Moon: The Osage Murders and the Birth of the FBI
author: Grann, David*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: An unbelievable look into a time in American history largely forgotten until Grann wrote this book. You will be shocked and saddened (but perhaps not An unbelievable look into a time in American history largely forgotten until Grann wrote this book. You will be shocked and saddened (but perhaps not surprised) to learn the details of this story. It charts the mysterious deaths of America's Osage Indians—many of whom were poisoned, shot or disappeared on the plains of Oklahoma in the 1920s, all in an attempt by white counterparts to claim the Osages' invaluable land rights on property flush with oil.The convergence of this story with the one Grann tells about the rise of the FBI (and the brave Texas Ranger/FBI agent who brought one of the worst perpetrators of the murders to trial) was riveting. My only advice? Try to read this as quickly as you can. I read it throughout my maternity leave (whenever I could hold a 300-plus page book with an infant in my arms!) and my only complaint was that, because the book was flush with names, I kept forgetting major players in the story and would have to flip through previous chapters to remember them. ...more

author: McNamara, Michelle
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I don’t delve into true crime often, but when I do, I make it count. In Cold Blood…. Helter Skelter ….those once-in-a-generation crime stories that gaI don’t delve into true crime often, but when I do, I make it count. In Cold Blood…. Helter Skelter ….those once-in-a-generation crime stories that gain a level of popularity that helps them defy their genre. I believe Michelle McNamara’s “I’ll Be Gone in the Dark” belongs on that same lauded shelf. “Gone” is the harrowing story of the serial rapist/killer Michelle dubbed the Golden State Killer, a man who terrorized California in the 70s-80s with his break-ins and boogeyman behavior. What makes the book gut-wrenchingly sad is Michelle died before she could finish it. (Thankfully her husband, actor Patton Oswalt, was able to compile her research and notes!) What makes the book SUPER creepy is the Golden State Killer was never caught. So now I’m drawing the blinds at night but the anxiety was worth it for this terrifying page-turner I can't stop thinking about....more

review: Confession: Before I read The Perfect Nanny, I read this New Yorker profile about its author, Leila Slimani—and I was entranced by her.I don't know ifConfession: Before I read The Perfect Nanny, I read this New Yorker profile about its author, Leila Slimani—and I was entranced by her.I don't know if it's the combination of her being French, my age, WAY sophisticated and smart, and, (to a far lesser degree) her beauty, but danggg, she is impressive. Which is why I was similarly entranced with this novel of hers, despite the heavy subject material. I think it's a bold move when an author attempts a "ripped from the headlines" concept for a story. In this case, Slimani pulls it off well as it's eerie to plunge into the minds of a nanny who kills the two children she cares for (don't worry, you find this out in the opening pages) and the couple for whom she works. Slimani doesn't dwell on the horribleness of what happened so much as spend the bulk of her novel developing a brilliant character study of these three along with commentary/criticism about the modern times we live in (as parents and people both).I'm also intrigued by the fact this novel captivated France upon its release, becoming one of the most read books in the country in 2016. Its setting there made for a solid lesson in cultural exploration on top of it being such an intriguing story to read. ...more

review: Tom Hanks' debut collection of short stories was interesting to me if only because it proved to me the guy CAN write. (I liked Ann Patchett's blurb, tTom Hanks' debut collection of short stories was interesting to me if only because it proved to me the guy CAN write. (I liked Ann Patchett's blurb, that finding out Tom can write fiction is like finding out Alice Munro is the world's greatest actor.")Munro he is not, but Hanks is pretty good at crafting tales that keep you reading—fueled in part by the narrative trope he uses here of incorporating a typewriter into every one of the stories (sometimes a one-off mention, other times the centerpiece of the story). Like all short story collections, there were a few that I'll remember (the piece about the WW II solider calling his war buddy on Xmas Eve; the one about the son surfing with his dad; the one about the time-traveling billionaire) and others I'll forget. Still, I enjoyed thinking about the ways Tom's life and his career infiltrated his writing here. And, as odd as it is to admit, I was a sucker for this line of his Acknowledgments: "Because of Nora"**And if you don't get that reference, far be it from me to explain to you. But if you've seen the best of Hanks' films, you should get the significance. This NYT piece should do the trick too....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A word that I kept coming back to in describing "Call Me by Your Name" to friends who were fellow readers was LUSH. Not that the book's setting, summeA word that I kept coming back to in describing "Call Me by Your Name" to friends who were fellow readers was LUSH. Not that the book's setting, summertime 1980s Italy, is LUSH in, say, a tropical sense...but if ever there was a book that invokes richness and sensual pleasure, it's this one.Admittedly I read this because I'm eager to see the film adaptation. This is one of those times where I was actually GLAD that I was aware of the casting of Timothee Chalamet as Elio and Armie Hammer as Oliver because I could NOT imagine better actors playing these two characters. They were who lived in my head as I turned the pages. And while I occasionally grew tired of Elio's inner monologue about Oliver (it was a hyper-intellectual version of "He loves me, he loves me not"), I was so taken by this book's ending that I came to love it. It haunted me, the way Aciman ended things between these two lovers on such a plane of nostalgia and reflection (invoking "Brokeback Mountain" in some ways). Now, to see the movie...which I believe may be one of the few times I might like what I see on screen even more than what I've read on the page! A few passages I loved (most from the end):"What did you write on the back of the postcard?""It was going to be a surprise.""I'm too old for surprises."[ .....]"Just two words.""Let me guess: If not later, when?""Two words, I said. Besides, that would be cruel."I thought for a while. "I give up.""Cor codium, heart of hearts ... I've never said anything truer in my life to anyone." (a conversation between Elio and his father that struck me as such a mature way to talk about a topic with your child that, to some degree, feels taboo to them)"We may never speak about this again. But I hope you'll never hold it against me that we did. I will have been a terrible father if, one day, you'd want to speak to me and felt that the door was shut or not sufficiently open.""But we've always known, and not saying anything now confirmed it all the more. We had found the stars, you and I. And this is given once only."...more

review: Reading Nic Stone’s YA debut, “Dear Martin,” I was struck by how much it was not a book for me: a story about a young black man who is profiled by theReading Nic Stone’s YA debut, “Dear Martin,” I was struck by how much it was not a book for me: a story about a young black man who is profiled by the police and who is reconciling his struggles with his race, his relationships with his high school classmates—as well as our fractured society—through a project in which he writes letters to Martin Luther King. Then I listened to Stone being interviewed for a podcast with “88 Cups of Tea” where she flat out says who she wrote the book for: youth (particularly black youth) with short attention spans who need the message it contains delivered to them in a book that’s not 300 pages long. That being said, I’m so very glad I picked it up and plowed through it, as it’s a novel that’s a conversation starter and a powerful piece of commentary on race relations in America in 2018....more

title: Manhattan Beach
author: Egan, Jennifer*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Egan is one of my favorite modern writers—when "Visit from the Goon Squad" came out in 2010, I was so impressed by her storytelling, I raved about it Egan is one of my favorite modern writers—when "Visit from the Goon Squad" came out in 2010, I was so impressed by her storytelling, I raved about it for months (even still, I'm all 'She made a chapter into a PowerPoint presentation!'). Now, with her newest work, she's jumped into a fascinating chapter of American history: an overlapping series of post-Great Depression/World War II stories set in NYC, featuring a young woman, Anna, working in Brooklyn's Naval Yard as a wartime diver, her father, Eddie, a union man down on his luck, and his mobster boss, Dexter Styles, whose influence will shape the course of both Anna and Eddie's lives. I'm impressed by anyone who peels back a layer of relatively unknown American history and Egan does so in spades. Her book is so well researched that, multiple times, I found myself down a Google rabbit hole, looking up WWII Brooklyn Naval Yard photos, as well as terms and trends of the '20s and '30s (turns out a charlotte russe was a popular dessert in NYC long before it was a chain of cheaply made women's clothing stores!). If you like visits to bygone eras and beautiful language, you might love this read, too....more

review: Tara Westover's "Educated" was my book club's May pick and we were all fascinated by this young woman's life: raised by a fundamentalist couple in rurTara Westover's "Educated" was my book club's May pick and we were all fascinated by this young woman's life: raised by a fundamentalist couple in rural Idaho, Tara didn't step foot into a classroom until she applied for—and got in—to Brigham Young University as a teen. She's since earned her PhD from Cambridge, and her ruminations on life with a family like hers (one that fears a government takeover and apparently refuses to heed the call of safety in the workplace) made for a fascinating read. I loathed her father and one of her brothers, both of whom put her family through unnecessary hell. Highly recommend if you like memoirs. It reminded me most (in style, tone and story) of Jeannette Walls' "The Glass Castle." ...more

title: The Female Persuasion
author: Wolitzer, Meg
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I loved "The Interestings" with a passion that kept me up all night reading it, so I was eager to get my hands on Meg Wolitzer's latest work, given shI loved "The Interestings" with a passion that kept me up all night reading it, so I was eager to get my hands on Meg Wolitzer's latest work, given she's one of my favorite authors. Thanks to a gracious friend, I received an ARC and was able to read "The Female Persuasion" ahead of its April release.What I love so much about Wolitzer's writing is how fully she immerses you in the world of her characters. In this case, I was fully committed to "Persuasion"'s protagonist, Greer Kadetsky, a shy, bookish freshman at a mid-rate college whose chance encounter her freshman year with one of the country's most notable feminists, Faith Frank, changes the course of her life and becomes the crux of the plot. I loved the supporting characters too, especially Greer's Portuguese boyfriend, Cory (and his family), whose own story steals Greer's a bit; and Zee, her queer best friend. Like "The Interestings" became the year of its 2013 release, "Persuasion" is sure to be one of 2018's most buzzed-about reads. How can it not when its subject matter—feminism, misogyny, the "big terribleness" (how Wolitzer chooses to refer to Trump's presidency)—are all topics that are central to so many of the conversations so many of us are having these days? It's a novel that covers a great number of ideas and opinions and topics (and years) and while it's a bit messy and there are scenes that lean too heavy on description (well-written though that description is), overall it was another Wolitzer book I could not put down. It's also one that I very much look forward to recommending—and discussing—in the new year, particularly with my friends who are of the female persuasion.Passages I loved:A scene where Cory and Greer are reading together while still in high school (early in the book) that resonated with me given my own love of readingCory was reading a bulky book for his economics class; Greer was reading Tess of the D'Urbervilles, and underlining so often that some pages were entirely marked up."What are you marking up?" he asked, curious."Things that stir me," she said without self-consciousness.[...] Love ran through everything Greer read—love of language, love of character, love of the act of reading—just as it ran through everything that had to do with Cory. Books had saved Greer as a child, and then Cory had saved her again later on. A scene where Faith is giving Greer more responsibility at the women's foundation Faith founded, Loci (blech–horrible name...it was one of the things I liked least about the book, but I think that might have been a point Wolitzer was trying to make): Greer wondered why Faith was giving her this gig. She remembered something Faith had said to the team once, early on: "Men give women the power that they themselves don't want."  And just, overall, because with the flip of every few pages, Wolitzer writes the kinds of reflective passages (like the ones below) that feel like arrows to your heart because of the way they resonate with her readers:Your twenties was a time when you still felt young, but the groundwork was being laid in a serious way, crisscrossing beneath the surface. It was being laid even while you slept. What you did, where you lived, who you loved, all of it was like pieces of track being put down in the middle of the night by stealth workers. There are some people who have such a strong effect on you, even if you've spent very little time with them, that they become embossed inside you, and any hint of them, any casual mention, creates a sudden stir in you. ...more

review: So grateful to my friend Allison for mentioning this book in her Twitter feed. It felt serendipitous that no sooner had I seen her Tweet than, during So grateful to my friend Allison for mentioning this book in her Twitter feed. It felt serendipitous that no sooner had I seen her Tweet than, during a trip to our local library, I happened to spot "Words in Deep Blue" on the the book end of our (newly expanded) YA section. Crowley's writing style is the kind that could pull in any reader, young adult or not. Her paragraphs were rich with lyrical lines and vivid imagery. It made it easy to get lost in this story, about a young girl named Rachel whose unrequited love for her best friend, Henry, comes back to haunt her in the wake of her brother Cal's untimely death.I'm a SUCKER for books that incorporate an epistolary element to them, and the letters in this novel didn't disappoint. That's because they were shared between the pages of books in the "Letter Library" of the (failing) bookstore owned by Henry's parents. Hundreds of books marked up by strangers who became friends or lovers, all while sharing with each other favorite words and lines they'd discovered within their pages.If you're a bit of a romantic (I know I am!) you'll be hard pressed not to fall for this quick read. It will put you in a literary trance like the best kind of dream....more

title: Camino Island        (Camino Island, #1)
author: Grisham, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I haven't read Grisham since I was a kid. But upon hearing an NPR interview with him around the release of "Camino Island," I was curious enough aboutI haven't read Grisham since I was a kid. But upon hearing an NPR interview with him around the release of "Camino Island," I was curious enough about the storyline (admittedly because I'm a sucker for all things Fitzgerald) to want to pick it up.What can I say? Grisham is the King of Commercial Fiction. Which means he doesn't disappoint in the fast-paced plot department, but there's little to no development to his characters here, something that bothered me as I came to the closing chapters of the novel. Nevertheless, "Camino Island" is a quick read as Grisham keeps you turning the pages, trying to guess how those original Fitzgerald manuscripts will ultimately make their way back to their rightful owner (Princeton University). One passage that stopped me in my tracks (which surprised me, only because that's not something that usually happens for me outside of literary fiction) was a small, rather insignificant description from the main character (a writer named Mercer) about her relationship with her sister. It caught my attention namely because I've seen people IRL going after the same empty dream as her sister (especially now in my 30s), and I appreciated the way Grisham captured that chase on the page:"Now the sisters emailed once a month; chatted by phone once a month; kept things civil and upbeat. Mercer dropped by occasionally when she was near Nashville, often at a different address. They moved a lot, and always to larger homes nicer neighborhoods. They were chasing something, a vague dream, and Mercer often wondered where they would be when they found it. The more money they made the more they spent, and Mercer, living in poverty, marveled at their consumption."PS - For anybody who's read this, did you catch the way Grisham made Mercer's mother mentally ill in a way that mirrored Zelda Fitzgerald's own mental illness? He even placed her in a psych hospital in Asheville, North Carolina, where Zelda died in a fire in 1948!...more

title: Conversations with Friends
author: Rooney, Sally*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My introduction to Sally Rooney was Normal People, a book that I read around the time of its release and then, feeling “meh” about, gave 3 stars. ThenMy introduction to Sally Rooney was Normal People, a book that I read around the time of its release and then, feeling “meh” about, gave 3 stars. Then, last spring, in the first quarter of the pandemic, I tuned into the television adaptation and promptly fell head over heels in love with Marianne and Connell. Off the page, they became a five-star couple for me—a pair I worshipped so much I was texting all of my girlfriends, feverishly telling them to watch the series along with me.What does that have to do with Rooney’s debut, “Conversations with Friends?” Well, I always had good intentions of getting around to reading it, but once a title hits the backlist, it becomes harder and harder for a reader like me to find the motivation to make it a priority. UNTIL, that is, news breaks about another Hulu adaption in the works. Once I knew that these four (Alison Oliver, Sasha Lane, Joe Alwyn, and Jemima Kirke) were going to be cast as Frances, Bobbi, Nick and Melissa (in that order), I was ALL IN on finally getting around to reading this book.  [image]Picturing these actors in their respective roles (and envisioning just how GOOD Hulu is at adapting Rooney’s work), this book became an easy 5-star read for me. Well, not easy in terms of subject material. Rooney writes awkward, smart people better than any living author alive, and when she plunks her emotionally distanced characters into situations that peel back their layers …. shew, you feel equal parts awed and discomfited while reading. No, what I mean by easy is that I can effortlessly imagine each of these actors portraying the four main characters in this book, which at its core is a love quadrangle between two best friends and a married couple. I know already how good this crew will be in their parts, Joe Alwyn especially. And yes, all right, I have always had a celebrity crush on him (even before Taylor Swift got her mitts on him), so I wasn’t at all bothered reading scenes like this one with him in mind:   [image]To sum things up: I’m glad I waited to read this book until I did. I loved it even when I didn’t. And I cannot wait to obsess over another television adaptation with others who belong to the cult of Sally Rooney....more

review: I spent some time at a writer's conference in July talking romance reads with some of my favorite author friends of the genre. A consensus was reachedI spent some time at a writer's conference in July talking romance reads with some of my favorite author friends of the genre. A consensus was reached how it's b.s. the way society looks down on it. I read widely so I'm not ashamed to share that includes the occasional romance, too. The most recent example is Robinne Lee's "The Idea of You." When a trusted friend gushed about it, I hit Google for a synopsis: A 39-year-old art gallery owner who takes her 12-year-old daughter to a British boy band concert and catches the eye of one of its hottest members. I was immediately like, "WHY HAS THIS PLOT NEVER BEEN WRITTEN BEFORE?" Suffice it to say, I fell HARD for Solene and Hayes and looked for any excuse to read their story. Robinne Lee has written a smart, believable (no, seriously!), steamy read that's also an insightful look into the price of fame and society's expectations on aging women. If you're looking for an hours-long distraction from the continued shitshow known as 2017, I can't recommend it enough. ...more

title: All Our Wrong Todays
author: Mastai, Elan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I REALLY wanted to like this book. When our book club picked it back in June for one of our summer selections, we all were sold pretty much immediatelI REALLY wanted to like this book. When our book club picked it back in June for one of our summer selections, we all were sold pretty much immediately after hearing its concept: "Back to the Future meets Outlander."And yet, I gave up less than 100 pages in. Despire a solid blurb from a comedic writer I love (Jonathan Tropper), I thought Mastai was trying too hard to find the humor in his writing. I also was BORED OUT OF MY MIND with all the set-up he was insisting on giving his readers about how this famous scientist invited this famous engine that allowed the world to draw an endless supply of energy from it, and on and on and ON. Throw in some complex explanations about time travel and I was done.Here's my final thought on time travel books: I have already bought into the concept, authors. You do not have to sell me on the particulars of HOW your characters are time traveling. Just....LET THEM TIME TRAVEL. Let them fall in love. Let them fall out of love. Fight, kill each other...what have you. Just, for the love of God, DO NOT EXPLAIN TO ME IN DETAIL HOW IT WORKS BECAUSE I DO NOT CARE....more

review: Damn, can Roxane Gay write or can Roxane Gay write? This is my first reading a full work of hers (versus select essays from "Bad Feminists" and her wrDamn, can Roxane Gay write or can Roxane Gay write? This is my first reading a full work of hers (versus select essays from "Bad Feminists" and her writings and interviews for various online publications and magazines) and I would for sure read anything of hers moving forward now that I've finished this. Her raw honesty in recounting her experience being sexually assaulted as a young girl and how that shaped her into the fat woman she became (and remains) was brutal at times to read and yet felt so necessary to hear her tell. I was in awe of her courage to put all those complicated feelings on the page. (Even though she would be the first to tell her readers no one should be in 'awe' of her.) Feels like it should be required reading, particularly for the powerful way it evokes empathy in readers, this one included. ...more

review: Without question one of my FAVORITE reads of 2017. I have long been a fan of Taylor Jenkins Reid and yet, with this newest release of hers, I found myWithout question one of my FAVORITE reads of 2017. I have long been a fan of Taylor Jenkins Reid and yet, with this newest release of hers, I found myself thinking multiple times at just how much she'd upped the game. This is a novel that transcends book club fiction and is borderline literary in the way Curtis Sittenfeld and J. Courtney Sullivan straddle those two worlds. I had one of those reading experiences where I simultaneously couldn't put the book down and yet kept drawing out the time I was spending reading it because I didn't want my time with the Hollywood starlet Evelyn Hugo (and co.) to end.I have always appreciated how TJR can masterfully weave twists you don't see coming into her works and this book was no exception. The final chapters were gripping and I finished the read believing it was one of the most satisfying endings to a novel I'd experienced in quite some time.Would HIGHLY recommend and am excited my book club let me convince them to read this for our summer pick. One friend who borrowed my copy told me Evelyn felt more real to her than Hollywood startlets like Liz Taylor and Rita Hayworth. I couldn't agree more. ...more

review: I had the great fortune of meeting Jessica Strawser (author of 'Almost Missed You') at the 2017 Midwest Writers Conference. I enjoyed getting to know I had the great fortune of meeting Jessica Strawser (author of 'Almost Missed You') at the 2017 Midwest Writers Conference. I enjoyed getting to know her better and learning more about her career as editor of Writer's Digest (a publication I love and draw gobs of inspiration from). Even more, I was grateful I had a chance to chat with her over several dinners and in general, get to know her better.The experience made it a no-brainer for me to purchase her debut novel (and get it autographed!) during the conference. "Almost Missed You" is a wonderfully drawn study of three characters—Violet, Finn, and Caitlin—whose lives are intertwined by the bonds of marriage, friendship, and (oh yeah) the kidnapping of a child. To say more risks giving away plotlines I think are better kept fresh to the reader. I'll just say that Strawser wrote beautifully about the complications of marriage, the push-and-pull of motherhood, and the family ties that bind all while spinning a tense thriller that kept me up late several nights reading just so I could find out how she was going to finish it! ...more

review: When you’ve lost someone in your life to dementia (in my case, my maternal grandmother), reading a book on the subject—fiction or otherwise—is a crapsWhen you’ve lost someone in your life to dementia (in my case, my maternal grandmother), reading a book on the subject—fiction or otherwise—is a crapshoot. But Rachel Khong found a beautiful balance between happy and sad tackling the topic in her slim little read “Goodbye, Vitamin.” I loved this book for how much it read like the chronological diary of a young woman trying to manage her own quarter-life crisis while helping her father, a college professor comiing to gripes with the early stages of Alzheimer’s, handle his own. It was witty and wise and gave me warm fuzzies in ways I never expected. A “darkly comic” novel, as the NYT so aptly describes it…I could definitely see this one being given the big-screen treatment. A few passages I loved:“What imperfect carries of love we are, and what imperfect givers. That the reasons we can care for one another can have nothing to do with the person cared for. That it has only to do with who we were around that person—what we felt about that person.”Today you held your open hand out and I shook the pills into it, same as every day. Fish oil. Magnesium. Vitamin D and C and A. Gingko biloba. …. “Hello, water,” you said, holding the glass against the moonlight and shaking the pills, like they were dice you were ready to roll, in your other hand. “Goodbye, vitamin.” ...more

review: Have you heard of Rep. John Lewis’ March series? A three-part collection of graphic novels retelling the 77-year-old’s involvement in the civil rightsHave you heard of Rep. John Lewis’ March series? A three-part collection of graphic novels retelling the 77-year-old’s involvement in the civil rights movement, the third and final installment won the 2016 National Book Award for Young People’s Literature—a first for any graphic novel. These books are just…incredible. So powerful that at certain points, I’ve been deeply moved by them.The format of a graphic novel feels like the perfect way to drive home the fear felt by the civil rights leaders who worked to confront legislators about ending legal segregation. Nate Powell’s illustrations are so well done that now I’m anxious for the third book to come in at the library (been waiting on it for weeks!) so I can read about Lewis’s concluding recollections of the Selma March.I was also shocked in reading the first two volumes by how much I learned about African American leaders like Rep. Lewis and A. Philip Randolph and Stokely Carmichael. Where were their stories in our U.S. history books? Here’s hoping this trilogy finds its way onto the shelves of school libraries across the country as it’s great material that should be required reading in American history classes....more

review: Ng's "Little Fires Everywhere" is my favorite read of 2017 (and I'm certainly not alone; the book has wound up on nearly ever 'Best Of' list I've seenNg's "Little Fires Everywhere" is my favorite read of 2017 (and I'm certainly not alone; the book has wound up on nearly ever 'Best Of' list I've seen this year!). It's the story of a suburban family (with a house full of teenagers), that develops a close relationship with the mysterious woman who’s living with her daughter in the family’s rental house nearby. But it's so much more: a fascinating exploration of race, making art, coming of age in the late '90s (which is exactly when I did, making me feel a deep affinity for the Richardson clan), and what it means to be a mother. I couldn't put it down, but I did—often—just to keep revisiting the pleasure that comes from reading the best books. I'm lucky to have met the author at a reading she gave at Ball State a few years back and I love the fact that I have both her debut and her follow-up signed. When you're a book nerd, you never forget meeting your literary heroes….Celeste is definitely one of them for me!...more

title: Breakfast of Champions
author: Vonnegut, Kurt, Jr.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There's just nobody who writes like Vonnegut. At least nobody I've come across and I'd like to think I'm fairly well-read.In (trying to) read a more rThere's just nobody who writes like Vonnegut. At least nobody I've come across and I'd like to think I'm fairly well-read.In (trying to) read a more recent contemporary novel (All Our Wrong Todays by Elan Mastri), I came across this quote in the book about Vonnegut that I really loved and wanted to jot down with this . Despite feeling different about Mastri's own work (I couldn't even finish it), I did absolutely agree with him about Vonnegut's writing.Of "Cat's Cradle" he said: "It's weary, cheeky, and wise, which are my three favorite qualities in people and art." I couldn't agree more and think you could apply that sentiment to most of Vonnegut's manuscripts. I feel so grateful that thanks to a professional opportunity I had as a writer for Ball State University, I got to visit the meat locker in Dresden where Vonnegut sought refuge during WWII, and meet members of his German family during the trip. Vonnegut and I aren't a lick alike in any way (and hell, who knows, maybe if I met him in real life, I would have thought him a heel). Yet, because of this experience I had, I feel a fondness for him unlike anything I've felt toward any other author. ...more

In “In the Nation, there is law; in the Colony, there is only a concern with order. In the Nation, you have rights; in the Colony, you have commands. In the Nation, you are innocent until proven guilty; in the Colony, you are born guilty.”—Chris HayesIf you saw Ava Duvernay's Oscar-nominated documentary 13th, most of what you'll read in MSNBC reporter Chris Hayes' new (slim) book will be familiar—infuriating— material. In summary? It's DISGUSTING the ways this country has turned criminalization into its newest form of slavery. My hope is that the more of us (white, black, doesn't matter) helping spread word about books and films like this—works that force us to acknowledge and study America's brutal intersection power and punishment—the better equipped we become to act as the generation that makes it stop. review: Mohsin Hamid’s much-heralded “Exit West” is a hard read, mostly because it captures the refugee crisis in a sort of dystopian way that makes you feel Mohsin Hamid’s much-heralded “Exit West” is a hard read, mostly because it captures the refugee crisis in a sort of dystopian way that makes you feel like a refugee could be anybody in the world, including yourself. But what I loved about it was this brilliant magical realist plot device Hamid used in the storyline whereby refugees could escape their current plight through doors that opened up to them in cities around the world. So basically, his characters never knew where they were going to next, and if the place they found themselves in would be a better alternative to the city they were leave. Talk about a fascinating concept. The book is a slim read that provokes a lot of questions—with some really beautiful writing. I can see why it’s on a ton of Top 10 Lists for 2017…even if it wasn’t the most jolly of reads! ...more
