title: Lincoln in the Bardo
author: Saunders, George
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: George Saunders is a critically-acclaimed writer who’s wonderfully weird. If you’ve read any collection of his short stories (Tenth of December is a gGeorge Saunders is a critically-acclaimed writer who’s wonderfully weird. If you’ve read any collection of his short stories (Tenth of December is a good place to start), you already know this and it’s likely what you love about him. It’s also the reason why, when I heard he was writing his first novel, I was down for whatever it would be.The end result is Lincoln in the Bardo, an other-worldly look at the true story of the night in 1862 when a young Willie Lincoln dies and his father, then-President Abraham Lincoln, visits his crypt. Saunders reveals the plot through quotes from historical documents (some real, some not) coupled with monologues from 100-plus ghost-like characters who, like Willie, are stuck in the “bardo”—a Tibetan state of post-life, pre-afterlife existence in-between.I listened to Lincoln as an audiobook and, in the end, that might have been both a blessing and a curse. A blessing because of the incredible star-studded line-up of celebrities—Nick Offerman, Rainn Wilson, David Sedaris, Lena Dunham, Don Cheadle and so many more—who brought the story to life.A curse because the time I devote to an audio book is reduced to snippets drawn out over the course of a few weeks (listening in the car, walking the track at work at lunch, etc.) So, this particular story (namely because of the sheer number of characters) suffers if you try to "check in" with it over time.My attention waned in multiple places and I barely finished it. And so, in the end, I give the originality of its premise five stars, but my interest in the plot overall two stars. What I loved most was the insights Saunders gave into what Lincoln must have gone through in those early days mourning his young son. What I could have done without was the dozen or more side narratives of the ghost-like characters whose subplots weren't pertinent to the overall story. ...more

title: Pachinko
author: Lee, Min Jin
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: REVIEW from 2022:I wasn't sure if I would be able to finish a re-read of this novel, but I was willing to give it the old college try, seeing as how IREVIEW from 2022:I wasn't sure if I would be able to finish a re-read of this novel, but I was willing to give it the old college try, seeing as how I wanted the characters fresh in my mind ahead of watching the Apple TV adaptation of Pachinko. But pretty much from the first chapter, I was once more sucked into the story of Sunja, the female protagonist around whose life this multi-generational novel turns. I just love the way Min Jin Lee writes. So much so that, when I was nearly finished with this, I went ahead and ordered a copy of her first novel because I love her work too much not to read everything she publishes. I look forward now to watching the TV series (even as I know, from reading up on it, that much has changed in terms of characters and timeline). And I stand by my 5-star  of this novel, which in every way is a modern classic. REVIEW from 2017:As soon as I heard about Min Jin Lee’s Pachinko, I fell hard for its gorgeous cover and was intrigued by its title. What is pachinko? Turns out it’s a game of chance that’s a cross between pinball and a slot machine (or Plinko, if you grew up a Price is Right fan ;) ). It’s also hugely popular in Japan and serves as the glue of this novel, a sweeping saga about a Korean family enduring the hardships of their nation being annexed by Japan during the 20th century.What an eye-opening read this was. I had no idea the extent to which Koreans have historically been looked down upon by the Japanese. As a total sucker for a well-told family drama, I was immediately drawn into this book’s multi-generational storyline. If you like novels that read like contemporary classics (in the vein of Dickens or Tolstoy), you can’t go wrong with discovering the memorable characters of this harrowing yet beautiful read....more

title: The Animators
author: Whitaker, Kayla Rae*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There’s a gossip blogger I follow (Elaine Lui) who writes all the time about her obsession with stories about women who work. Specifically, stories abThere’s a gossip blogger I follow (Elaine Lui) who writes all the time about her obsession with stories about women who work. Specifically, stories about women AT work. And I found myself thinking about this time and again as I devoured Kayla Rae Whitaker’s “The Animators”. Here was a fully realized story about two young women—the underconfident Sharon Kisses and her in-your-face BFF Mel Vaught—who unabashedly chose creative careers over the men (and women, in Mel’s case) in their lives. And they were so unapologetic about doing so, it felt impossible to fall into the standard societal trap of questioning their choices otherwise. At several points in this book, I found myself thinking about how fresh it all felt (the ideas, the bawdy language—from Mel especially, whose antics might have made Sid Vicious proud) and how it’s the kind of read where I know the characters will stay with me for a lonnngggg time. I mean, Vaught & Kisses….how can you forget a combo like that?For this Midwesterner, an added benefit: After the book’s first “No way!” plot twist, Whitaker, a Kentucky native, draws her characters back to Kisses’ rural Kentucky hometown. Living only five hours and some change up the interstate from where a lot of this part of the book took place, all of it (the people, the language they used, the food they ate) was familiar in a context I don't see often in contemporary literary fiction. Without a doubt, this book is my first must-read of 2017. It meanders a bit, it’s not perfect (what book is?) and for anybody who leans on the prudish side, it may not be for them … but for everyone else, "The Animators" is a creative ride you’re going to want to take....more

title: Story: Substance, Structure, Style, and the Principles of Screenwriting
author: McKee, Robert
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Writer confession: I haven’t written in months. Ongoing rejections of my second manuscript (it happens! I’m okay with it!) coupled with a series of diWriter confession: I haven’t written in months. Ongoing rejections of my second manuscript (it happens! I’m okay with it!) coupled with a series of distractions (planning for our big Iceland trip last fall; an election that left me reeling; holiday after holiday) all snowballed into shaping up the creative conundrum I’m in now: needing to scratch my writerly itch by putting some g.d. words down on the page.And I will—my hard stop on starting Manuscript 3 is this summer. Meanwhile, in the pocket of downtime I’ve been wallowing in, I’ve been boning up on craft. Robert McKee’s “Story” was a book that had sat on my to-read list (and book shelf) for a long while. I’m glad I finally tackled it this spring. It’s one of the rare times I followed it up with a date for myself at Starbucks during which I filled dozens of pages of a notebook with all the lessons I learned from it. Here are but a few: • Story is metaphor for life.• When talented people write well, it is generally for this reason: They are moved by a desire to touch the audience.• Of the total creative effort represented in a finished work, 75 percent or more of a writer's labor goes into designing story. WHO are these characters? WHAT do they want? WHY do they want it? HOW do they get it? WHAT stops them? WHAT are the consequences? Finding the answers to these grand questions and shaping them into story is our overwhelming creative task.• Talent without craft is like fuel without an engine. It burns wildly but accomplishes nothing. • The source of cliches can be traced to one thing: The writer does not know the world of his story. • An honest story is at home in one—and only one—place and time.• Can't kill your talent but starve it into a coma through ignorance. Talent must be stimulated by facts and ideas. Research wins the war on cliche, and is key to victor over fear and depression. • The sudden impression that a story is writing itself marks the moment when a writer's knowledge of a subject has reached its saturation point....more

author: Trelease, Jim
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Originally I picked up Jim Trelease’s “The Read-Aloud Handbook” because I was searching for a “greatest hits” collection of books I wanted to referencOriginally I picked up Jim Trelease’s “The Read-Aloud Handbook” because I was searching for a “greatest hits” collection of books I wanted to reference for Dean’s at-home library. And I DEFINITELY hit a home run in that regards, as the last 100 pages of this book is a giant glossary of titles by age range that’s guiding me through creating “Dean’s Library” wishlist on Amazon. But what surprised me about this book was how much I learned from the chapters Trelease wrote before the glossary. Each is chock-fill of research and extraordinary insights that backs up the importance of reading aloud to children. It’s more important than work sheets, homework, book reports, and flash cards and high SAT scores have been linked to parents who read to their kids daily, even after they can read on their own.I CANNOT recommend this book enough, especially if you have children, are a teacher or librarian, and/or want to help kids become better readers. It’s a text I’ll be returning to again and again....more

But after spying this slim collection in the feeds of multiple lit-loving girlfriends, curiosity got the best of me. Inside its covers are some truly remarkable poems with equally remarkable illustrations. Most can be read in (literally) a minute. While some feel applicable to all women, most read as if Rupi Kaur is bleeding her heart out in the words she spills onto the page. It’s from a privileged position I confess I’ve not dealt with a tenth of the heaviness outlined in “Milk and Honey”’s four chapters (domestic abuse, violence, loss). review: My weekend read: Lorraine Hansberry's "A Raisin in the Sun." Did you know Hansberry was the first black woman to write a play performed on Broadway? UMy weekend read: Lorraine Hansberry's "A Raisin in the Sun." Did you know Hansberry was the first black woman to write a play performed on Broadway? Until recently, I didn't. But then, there's a lot about black culture I don't know. The older I get, the more I'm working to change that. "Raisin" is such a powerful piece of art I'm mad at myself I haven't seen it performed on stage yet ... going to work on changing that, too.With a title taken from a Langston Hughes poem, this is the story about the Youngers, a black family struggling against segregation that's willing to take on a restrictive housing covenant to own a home in a mostly white neighborhood of Chicago post-WWII. Hansberry's own family fought a similar battle all the way to the Supreme Court. Now I'm curious ... how many of you have seen the play or film? Did you know Hansberry wrote it in her 20s and, sadly, died of cancer at 34? What a loss. ...more

title: Norwegian by Night        (Sigrid Ødegård #1)
author: Miller, Derek B.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book was a great slow burn of a read that, once my interest properly ignited, I raced to finish. I discovered it after reading an interview in ThThis book was a great slow burn of a read that, once my interest properly ignited, I raced to finish. I discovered it after reading an interview in The Millions with Richard Russo (whose work I’ve long admired), mentioning it as one of the books he enjoyed most in 2016. After finishing it myself, I can see why. “Norwegian by Night” is the story of WWII vet Sheldon Horowitz, a Jewish curmudgeon who, after the death of his wife, is forced to uproot his American life to move to Norway with his granddaughter Rhea and her husband, Lars. He hates everything about his present situation until the day he gets entangled as an accessory to a brutal murder that happens in the family’s apartment complex. Relying on his military training, he takes it upon himself to go on the lam with the murder victim’s young son, creating a cat-and-mouse plot that concludes with a gripping climax that left me wishing for more of Sheldon’s story.What I loved most about this thriller was Miller’s writing (certain sentences I savored enough to re-read and make note of) and the way this book felt like a mirror reflecting the world’s changing geopolitical landscape and people’s fears of refugees. It’s one of those novels older people would enjoy (especially in light of Sheldon’s flashbacks to his war experience and his regrets over losing his own son in Vietnam) and would make a great gift for any parent or grandparent who’s a reader....more

It took me about 75 pages to get A good friend of mine asked me several times to read this novel, knowing I have a soft spot for a well-done romance. It took me about 75 pages to get into the characters of Lucy and Josh (they hated each other SO much and I had too little context for why up front) but once I got hooked by the storyline (somewhere around the time Lucy went on her date with Danny, a decision that prompted a hot scene of jealousy from Josh), I didn't want to put the book down.As my friend pointed out, nothing about the plot of "The Hating Game" is original and yet Sally Thorne "wrote the crap out of it." Thanks to plenty of great banter between the characters (who had great chemistry in the end) and a build-up of sexual tension that held until the book's final chapters, there was plenty of reasons to keep reading. Over the course of the book’s 300-plus pages, Rena plays out the narrative via a story-telling device that offers us glimpses of Clara’s life in the past juxtaposed with those in the present. And BOY was I quickly hooked.The main reason I found myself so fascinated by The Girl Before is because of the subject matter upon which it’s based. I don’t want to give it away, as discovering the “world” I’m referring to is part of the allure of the novel. All that to say, I couldn’t believe it was my first time reading a story that revolved around such timely subject material.I love how Rena made you root for Clara, while also understanding her faults and why she was so drawn to Glenn (writing a bad guy with redemptive qualities? Maybe the best audio book I've ever listened to. Trevor Noah proves himself as not only a capable comedian, but one hell of a storyteller. I was transfixed by his narration (ooohhhh that voice of his!) of his story of growing up in South Africa. I felt like I learned so much about the effects of apartheid, and felt ashamed on more than one occasion as I was struck by the realization that Trevor and I are near the same age. And that, while I was reading Babysitter Club Books and going to piano lessons at 11, Trevor was sleeping in a car in a garage, living off caterpillars.Loved how he ended the book, tying it back to his infuriating love for his mother. review: Stand-up comic Phoebe Robinson’s “You Can’t Touch My Hair” is a pop-culture laden look into what it’s like being a black female in America today. For Stand-up comic Phoebe Robinson’s “You Can’t Touch My Hair” is a pop-culture laden look into what it’s like being a black female in America today. For every light essay she writes (i.e., her list of nine guilty pleasures), she pens a more serious narrative exploring issues ranging from the deplorable meaning behind the word “uppity” to how fed up she is dealing with microaggressions on the daily. Despite all the political and racial issues she tackles here, Robinson walks that fine line of never sounding too preachy with her take on the topics she covers. Her debut was as informative as it was entertaining…and now (fellow pop culture junkie and U2 lover that I am), I count myself a newfound fan of both her and her 2 Dope Queens podcast. ...more

review: Lately it feels like too many news headlines are standing in as plot points from some dystopian novel I’m too afraid to read. Which is why I’ve let myLately it feels like too many news headlines are standing in as plot points from some dystopian novel I’m too afraid to read. Which is why I’ve let myself get lost this month in the “reality” of a few charming YA reads. Among them is Morgan Matson’s 2016 release “The Unexpected Everything.” A sweet story about a Congressman’s daughter, Andie Walker, who finds herself unexpectedly employed over her summer vacation as a dog walker. It’s this job that leads to her meet-cute with the shy, smart Clark, whose backstory makes for such a fun twist to the book it had me burning through its pages. Throw in a few fierce female friendships, hilarious emoticon-infused conversations between characters, and dialogue that feels true to life, and this book is everything light literary escapism should be. review: When you really love an author’s first book (in this case, Nicola Yoon’s 2015 YA release, “Everything, Everything”), you find yourself nervous about tWhen you really love an author’s first book (in this case, Nicola Yoon’s 2015 YA release, “Everything, Everything”), you find yourself nervous about the follow-up. Thankfully, Nicola’s latest release, “The Sun Is Also A Star” isn’t as good as her debut, it’s BETTER. I found myself falling SO hard for this quick read. So hard, I carried it around all week and stayed up until 1 a.m. Monday because I didn’t want to leave the version of NYC Yoon had created for her characters. Natasha and Daniel’s timely 21st-century story is a multi-ethnic mash-up that’s one part “When Harry Meets Sally,” one part “An Affair to Remember.” It’s a book about love (which the world ESPECIALLY needs more of right now), family, immigration, existentialism, and the power of fate. If I had mad Oprah money, I’d buy up 1,000 copies and hand them to everyone for Christmas. THAT’S how much I LOVED this book.And because Yoon is a master of language (seriously, this gal is SO brilliant, she has me all, who’s John Green again?) there were many pages of this book I dog-eared so I could remember the lines she spun that I loved. Here are a few:• I’d give anything to really want the life my parents want for me. (Pg. 50)• There’s a Japanese phrase that I like: koi no yokan. It doesn’t mean love at first sight. It’s closer to love at second sigh. It’s the feeling when you meet someone that you’re going to fall in love with…Maybe you don’t love them right away, but it’s inevitable you will. (Pg. 74)• America’s not really a melting pot. It’s more like one of those divided metal plates with separate sections for starch, meat, and veggies. (P. 128)• It’s hard to come from someplace or someone you’re not proud of … “You’re not your dad,” I say, but he doesn’t believe me. I understand his fear. Who are we if not a product of our parents and their histories? (Pg 144)• Maybe part of falling in love with someone else is also falling in love with yourself. (pg. 150)• I squeeze her hand. “You know the way we feel right now? This connection between us that we don’t understand and we don’t want to let go of? That’s God.” (pg 272)• The highest thing you can do is the thing God put you on this earth to do. (pg 287)PS - I love, love, LOVE how Yoon is adventurous with her writing in a way no other YA author is. The histories she wove throughout “Sun” (aka “Hair” being one example) along with the points of views of the secondary characters whose lives in some way had an impact on (or were impacted by) Natasha and Daniel was so, so enchanting. ...more

title: Undress Me in the Temple of Heaven
author: Gilman, Susan Jane*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: One of the reasons I love book clubs is because they push you to read outside your comfort zone, discovering books you never knew existed. Susan Jane One of the reasons I love book clubs is because they push you to read outside your comfort zone, discovering books you never knew existed. Susan Jane Gilman’s “Undress Me in the Temple of Heaven” is such book for me. The true account of Gilman, an accomplished journalist, who set off to tour the world with one of her college classmates, this story is a WILD ride. Namely because the two start their journey in 1986 in China, landing in a country whose borders had been open for “all of ten minutes”. What happens to them leaves you on the edge of your seat (and turning the pages!) but for anyone who’s traveled—especially abroad—this book is full of plenty of reminders of the graces that come with stepping outside your comfort zone and developing camaraderie with fellow travelers you meet along the way.A few favorite lines: “No one ever tells you this,” I said despairingly, waving at the turquoise tiled walls, the bare, hissing light fixture. “All those travel magazines. People with their vacation photos. They just make it look so easy.” I suppose, travel is a bit like the Internet—there’s a protective anonymity to it. Cast into a situation with people you never have to see again and shielded from repercussions, you turn brazenly candid.Lee was thirty-six. If we’d met in the States, we’d have had absolutely no reason to sit together and probably nothing to say. But here? We had the special camaraderie of the displaced, of sad people with suitcases. ...more

review: Earlier this summer, I ranted about how I couldn't get into Emma Cline's "The Girls". Here was this super buzzy book that was being touted as definingEarlier this summer, I ranted about how I couldn't get into Emma Cline's "The Girls". Here was this super buzzy book that was being touted as defining what girlhood meant through its throwback storyline and all I could think was, "Am I reading the same book?"I bring that novel up again only because of the timing of the release of Jacqueline Woodson's latest novel (her first adult book), "Another Brooklyn." HERE is a book that, within a small number of pages, manages to define girlhood. The kicker for me as a white reader? I'm not black like its characters. Nor am I from Brooklyn. Or a child of the 1970s!And yet that's precisely the power of Woodson's writing. As much as her themes resonate with black readers, they are written so eloquently as to strike the same level of nostalgia in white readers, too. (I had numerous flashbacks to the days of my own four-some squad of girlfriends at this age while reading it.)I'm still new to Woodson's work ("Brown Girl Dreaming" was my introduction), but "Another Brooklyn" solidifies why she has become one of my all-time favorite writers. Her style is lyrical, evocative, and defined by the kind of prose you savor. (It's also highly distinctive; you could hand me a book without showing me the cover and within a few pages, I'd be able to tell you it's her work.)So yeah, I HIGHLY recommend this little gem of a novel—and while it's the pettiest of bonuses, at a slim (and quick-reading) 192 pages, this is the perfect pick if you're in the mood to boost a reading goal, or feel more accomplished, or more 'up' on fiction these days. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I can't believe I made it 34 years without reading this book. A classic for a multitude of reasons, somehow it always slipped off my radar.Probably beI can't believe I made it 34 years without reading this book. A classic for a multitude of reasons, somehow it always slipped off my radar.Probably because I never took a French class in school.Or maybe because, for a whole lot of years (too many, I'm ashamed to admit), I confused it with Machiavelli's "The Prince" which, talk about two books that could not be more unalike. (The fact I DID read Machiavelli in college, and didn't care for it, may also be why I felt some weird aversion to reading anything else with 'Prince' in the title.)That aside, I finally got around to this slender gem at the prompting of my graduate assistant (who loves it). After I finished reading it, we decided to watch the Netflix adaptation together and WOW. SO glad we did. I feel like I can't talk/think about the book itself now without thinking of what sweet justice director Mark Osborne gave the story. If you haven't seen it yet, here's the trailer. There is so much that's been said about The Little Prince over the years I feel no  of mine would do it further justice other than to say this is one of those rare books that, every time you pick it up, will teach you a new lesson. What a gift it is.And rather than list every quotable line I want to remember from it, I'll just let BuzzFeed do it for me instead....more

author: Picoult, Jodi*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It takes a lot of chutzpah to Write the Other. If you’re not familiar with the term, it’s the phrase writers use to discuss the approach of writing chIt takes a lot of chutzpah to Write the Other. If you’re not familiar with the term, it’s the phrase writers use to discuss the approach of writing characters outside their race, religion, sexual orientation, etc.Jodi Picoult wrote the other in a MAJOR way with “Small Great Things,” a multiple-point-of-view novel anchored by the story of a black neonatal nurse named Ruth. When confronted with a medical dilemma presented by the newborn patient of a racist parent at the hospital—a white supremacist who refuses Ruth’s care for his son—Ruth balks. As a result, the child dies (and the bulk of the book afterwards follows the days leading up to the climatic trial that ensues). This book—the only Picoult I’ve ever read—helped me understand why her work is so popular. The story was compulsively readable and I felt she did a pretty good job of creating fully realized characters, including Ruth’s public defender, Kennedy, a woman best described by Roxane Gay in her NYT  of SGT as “a proxy for well-meaning white folk who don’t realize the extent of their racism until they are forced to confront it.”For those who’ve read SGT, what did YOU think? Did you find the story and/or characters believable? This was our book club’s spring pick and I have a feeling it’ll stir up quite the conversation!...more

review: I love, love, love Lauren Graham (really, who doesn’t?) but also would have loved a little more out of this memoir of hers. The first third, it felt lI love, love, love Lauren Graham (really, who doesn’t?) but also would have loved a little more out of this memoir of hers. The first third, it felt like Graham struggled to ease into her own narrative voice (it was so! Lorelai! Gilmore!) and she threw in a lot of corny little jokes on top of it (which weren’t necessary IMO…she’s witty enough without the need of punchlines in need of a rim shot). I LOVED the mid-section (though many people might not have) because, as a writer, I was curious to hear how she found a daily routine that allowed her to squeeze in work on this memoir, her second novel, AND a screenplay for The Royal We (CANNOT WAIT FOR THAT). She shares the schedule gifted to her from a Hollywood friend, Don Roos, and I copied it down so I could hang it above my desk for inspiration.The last third of the book felt like the payoff everyone was looking for and that was her journal-esque chapters on how the Gilmore Girls Netflix reboot came to be. The big takeaway from this final passage: Lauren felt like that ending was a gigantic cliffhanger too AND her writing hints at an interest in playing Lorelai again, should ASP want to resurrect the town of Stars Hollow a third time.While a bit uneven in tone and subject material (some of those essays felt like a stretch to hit a word count!), overall I’d recommend this memoir to anyone who counts Lauren Graham among the celebrities they’d most like to grab a drink with (me! me! me!)Two other tidbits worth commenting on:1) That Peter Krauss is an outdoors-ish type of guy. I'm confident he and my husband would get along well. (Also, that he is very tall...SWOON.)2) I could not BELIEVE Lauren Graham and Alexis Bledel never read together before they were cast in their GG roles. They met when filming began—talk about casting chemistry luck! ...more

review: Reshma Kapoor is a lot like House of Card's Claire Underwood—if Claire Underwood was an Indian teenager willing to stop at nothing to get into StanforReshma Kapoor is a lot like House of Card's Claire Underwood—if Claire Underwood was an Indian teenager willing to stop at nothing to get into Stanford (versus get her husband elected president). I found this book equal parts brilliant and frustrating ... if a book can be such things. Brilliant because author Rahul Kanakia created such an unlikable narrator I SHOULD have wanted to throw the book across the room. Instead, I kept being tugged along by the words on the page, wondering what she'd do next. Reshma is SO cut throat, she's willing to plagiarize, blackmail, and file lawsuits against anyone who stands in the way of the collegiate future she envisions for herself.On the other hand, I grew frustrated because, throughout the narrative, the softie in me that desperately wanted Reshma to be kinder and gentler finished the book a bit disgusted with her decision-making and the way she treated even the most genuine, loyal people who cared about her (GEORGE!) That said, Rahul DOES gives Reshma a final chapter that leaves you satisfied for having taken this narrative journey with her. Because while Reshma will always be Reshma (cut throat and competitive), she does manage to find a way to channel that energy for good in the end. ...more

review: With his latest release, What Light, I’m not sure YA author Jay Asher could have swung his creative pendulum any farther from his debut, 13 Reasons WhWith his latest release, What Light, I’m not sure YA author Jay Asher could have swung his creative pendulum any farther from his debut, 13 Reasons Why.Whereas 13 was gritty and dark and profoundly sad, What Light is whimsical and charming with a storyline ready-made for ABC Family’s 25 Days of Christmas. And you guys, whimsical and light was EXACTLY what I was needing this month.As an #imwithher gal, I was pretty down in the wake of Donald Trump winning the election. As a result, Asher’s book showing up at the library when it did felt like a karmic sign. I happily devoured this sweet slip of a story about Sierra, whose family operates an Xmas tree farm in Oregon, requiring her to spend every Christmas helping her parents sell said trees on a lot in Southern California. Asher makes Sierra feel like a very relatable teen and her crush on one of her customers, Caleb, took me back to my own days of pining for cute dark-haired boys with dimples. Maybe the one surprise for me was how I kept expecting the storyline to get darker (Caleb allegedly has a dark past). When that past finally gets revealed, it left this reader at least thinking “Huh…that’s it?” Which also made me realize that, in the world of YA fiction, not every book needs something as dark in its plot line as a suicide or a murder or physical abuse. A timely read for the holiday season, What Light made me feel a bit happier than I was when I picked it up. It also left me wanting to go order a peppermint mocha. And smell all the Xmas candles. And buy a live tree for the first time in 15 years. ...more

title: Kindred
author: Butler, Octavia E.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Every year during Black History Month, I aim to read a book by a prominent Black author whose work I’ve yet to discover. In 2022, I finally got aroundEvery year during Black History Month, I aim to read a book by a prominent Black author whose work I’ve yet to discover. In 2022, I finally got around to reading my copy of Octavia Butler’s “Kindred” (which has sat on my book shelf, unopened, for too many years to count).I have to admit, this one stuck with me in a BIG way. First published in 1979, "Kindred" is about a young Black woman, Dana, who keeps being pulled between the present (1976 Los Angeles) and the days of 19th century slavery. While in the past, she has to keep saving Rufus, the white man she discovers is a distant ancestor of hers.It's the ultimate Catch-22 of a plot, and as a slavery text, it brought to life the antebellum South in a way I've never experienced from any other book set during this (awful, awful) time in our nation's history. This, of course, was Butler’s intent: “The reason for my writing this novel really was to try to make people feel the past as well as understand it (the slavery experience) in your skin, in your mind, in your emotions, to feel it.” (Source)Last year, FX ordered a TV adaptation of this seminal novel, and now I am SO curious to see who will play these characters. And because playing amateur casting director is one of my favorite related pastimes to reading, here are my picks for who should play Dana and who should play her white newlywed husband, Kevin:Kiki Layne as Dana —If you’ve never seen Kiki act before, she’s incredible in “If Beale Street Could Talk” and “The Old Guard,” both of which are also adaptations (of a Baldwin novel and a graphic novel, respectively). Chris Pine as Kevin —Chris does period pieces well (see his role in the Wonder Woman franchise) and his graying hair and scruff as of late are perfect for this role (for reasons I won’t elaborate on for fear of spoiling a plot element in “Kindred” but IYKYK).Also, I want to give a huge shout-out to Octavia Butler, who was the first Black woman to receive the Nebula and Hugo Awards, the highest honors in the science fiction and fantasy genres—and the first science fiction writer to win a MacArthur genius grant. What a brilliant mind!...more

title: You'll Grow Out of It

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Few things can cheer me up more when I'm having a shitty day (especially when I'm all caught up on Veep) than a good batch of comedic personal essays.Few things can cheer me up more when I'm having a shitty day (especially when I'm all caught up on Veep) than a good batch of comedic personal essays. Jessi Klein's collection was no exception. From the start, I loved her voice—wry but laser sharp, keenly pointing out and then skewering so many of the things women didn't know they needed to be laughing about (case in point: her essays on the insanity of the Bar Method and her loathing of bathes–which I share—were two of my favorites). Klein's writing was relatable because she's a real women who just happens to have a bad-ass job (which is why her essay on trying to buy French lingerie was hysterical because THAT WOULD SO BE ME). And if you're a mother, much of what she writes about her new experiences as one herself might also ring true (especially if, like me, you, too, are a BIG fan of epidurals).As head writer of Inside Amy Schumer, Klein is stepping out from her boss's shadow to have her own well-deserved time in the spotlight. I look forward to following what comes next.A few related tidbits:Great  from New York Magazine of "You'll Grow Out of It"—I especially loved this sentiment of Klein's: “I think for a very long time, including now, there has been this view that writing about the details of women’s lives feels somehow more trivial than writing by men,” Klein tells me, adding that she always believed her own insights and experiences could never pass as quote-unquote “real literature.” Working on Inside Amy Schumer, in a writers’ room where she was free to pitch topics that another sketch show might have rejected, helped her strengthen her voice, and to realize that she had something to say that other women might want to hear. “Even when I was starting out to write a book, I thought, those are books, that’s literature, and what am I going to write?” Klein muses. “How is my stupid essay about Anthropologie going to matter? And I think that’s a really toxic view to internalize. I think the details of women’s lives are as important as anything in all of literature.”AGREED! And because I fell down a rabbit hole that consisted of finding clips of Jessi (EVEN HER WEDDING PHOTOS....#help), I loved this skit with her and Amy: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tTtdP......more

THIS BOOK IS JUST SO DANG GOOD. Thomas tells the gripping story of Starr Carter, a young black girl coping with the fallout of witnessing her best friend get shot and killed by a cop.In the hands of a lesser writer—someone who didn't know her subject as well or couldn't tell the story with as much passion and insight—"Hate" might have turned readers off before buzz for it could build. review: It's funny how sometimes, no matter how much you read a particular type of fiction (in this case, young adult), you can go years without knowing one oIt's funny how sometimes, no matter how much you read a particular type of fiction (in this case, young adult), you can go years without knowing one of its biggest names. That's how I felt when I discovered Morgan Matson earlier this month. Then suddenly, she was everywhere. (And by everywhere, I mean I came across 1) an Amazon interview with her and 2) her interview on a podcast called 88 Cups of Tea, which, I happen to love: http://88cupsoftea.com/podcast/morgan...)Pretty sure Morgan came onto my radar as of late because she has a new book out but when I searched for it at the library, all I could find was this novel, which was her debut. I reserved it and, upon picking it up, was utterly charmed.It's one of those YA reads that's sweet but underscores all the issues and complicated feelings that come along with being a teenager. In this case, Amy is grieving the loss of her father while trying to navigate the tricky business of moving cross-country from California to join her mother in Connecticut. Enter Roger, the neighbor-turned-college kid hired by Amy's mother to accompany her on her journey east (and for whom Amy can't help but develop feelings for--wink, wink ;) )I think I got swept up in this book for two big reasons: 1) it's an epistolary novel, with a series of journal entries, play lists, "receipts" and postcards complementing the narrative and 2) Morgan Matson has great voice. So, so great. I found the world she spun for her readers so easy to jump into that I looked forward to cracking open the pages of this book every change I got. Which is probably why it read as quickly as it did. Looking forward to reading more of her stuff! ...more

title: The Nix
author: Hill, Nathan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As much as I liked this book, I also struggled with it. This is less the result of the book not being good, and more the fact I tried tackling a 600+ As much as I liked this book, I also struggled with it. This is less the result of the book not being good, and more the fact I tried tackling a 600+ page tome in the span of two months that involved a lot of travel and other commitments. I put it down and picked it back up multiple times, which is why—looking back on it now—it feels as if the various narratives (Sam’s experiences with his friend and his friend’s sister, his unrequited love; the flashbacks to his mother’s life in the ‘60s; the present-day narrative about Sam and his World of Elfquest friends) all feel like separate books to me. There is a lot of humor to this narrative (very wry humor, I might add), which is probably what carried me through to the end. Not to mention the on-the-nose social and political messages it has to offer in these tumultuous times we find ourselves living in here in the U.S. (aka, Trumplandia). I think Nathan Hill has a writing style that would appeal to fans of Donna Tartt and/or John Irving. He’s immensely talented and I’ll have my eye out for whatever he puts out next. A line to remember: "What's true? What's false? In case you haven't noticed, the world has pretty much given up on the old Enlightenment idea of piecing together the truth based on observed data. Reality is too complicated and scary for that. Instead, it's way easier to ignore all data that doesn't fit your preconceptions and believe all data that does. I believe what I believe, and you believe what you believe, and we'll agree to disagree. It's liberal tolerance meets dark ages denialism. It's very hip right now."...more

review: How many of you stumbling across this  have seen the film of “Hidden Figures” and read the book? This  may only make sense to those of youHow many of you stumbling across this  have seen the film of “Hidden Figures” and read the book? This  may only make sense to those of you who answer “Both.”First thing first: I picked this as an audio read. In hindsight, that wasn’t such a good idea. This book is chock full of history, which, at times, made it quite the slog. With so many names (and so many opportunities to get distracted while listening), I got lost more than a few times (forgetting some folks, though never the key players). Then, I saw the film when I was about half-way through the book. It led to this bizarre set-up where I was constantly contrasting what I knew was true with what I was watching on the big screen. There were multiple examples, but here are two: 1) the Kevin Costner character was an amalgamation of multiple male bosses in the book and 2) the bathroom incident in the film happened to Katherine Johnson; in the book, it’s Mary Jackson (and the run-in she had with one of the engineers while stewing about it is what led to her landing a better job and becoming an engineer herself).In the end, these differences bothered me only a little as “Hidden Figures” proved to be SUCH a visual story it’s one of the rare times I preferred the film to the book. I left the theater wondering how the screenwriter had written it—did she have Shetterly’s manuscript in her hand while crafting the screenplay? And how had she managed to pull off what Shetterly couldn’t—shining a laser-sharp spotlight on the few years that made for the most fascinating convergence of these women’s stories (for context: Shetterly doesn’t even GET to John Glenn’s space odyssey until the last few chapters). Turns out screenwriter Allison Schroeder wrote it at the same time Shetterly was writing her book, using the author's research to inform her, but not the manuscript itself (this profile about her is a must read)My final take: If you are a history nerd and/or super interested in the full account of these women, you’ll want to read the book. But if you are the type that finds finishing, say, a beach read challenging, this isn’t the book for you. Pay your tribute to these women at the cineplex instead. The movie is remarkably inspiring and their story far too good to miss. ...more

review: “For the most part, you don't hold the people you love in your heart because they rescued you from drowning or pulled you from a burning house. Mostly“For the most part, you don't hold the people you love in your heart because they rescued you from drowning or pulled you from a burning house. Mostly you hold them in your heart because they save you, in a million quiet and perfect ways, from being alone.”WHEW. Just finished Jeff Zentner's new "Goodbye Days" and now my ❤️ heart ❤️ feels like it's made of goo (in the best possible way!) What I love about reading Jeff's words is not only does he get his characters, he LOVES his characters. It shows in a million different ways, from the nuances he gives them to the colorful way he describes their world. While the storyline of "Goodbye Days" is capital "H" heavy—a Nashville teen (Carver) is grappling with the weight of knowing his text message may have caused the car accident that killed his three best friends—Jeff is the kind of talented writer who balances that abundance of sorrow with just the right touch of humor, keeping readers hooked by how relatable his books feel.I'm delighted his sophomore novel is every bit as tremendous as his debut, "The Serpent King" (aka, one of my FAVE reads of 2016!) PS - And thanks Jeff for always caring so darn much about your readers!...more

review: Author Brit Bennett writes with a wisdom far beyond her years. This was one of 2016’s most heralded debuts with good reason—the voices of the characteAuthor Brit Bennett writes with a wisdom far beyond her years. This was one of 2016’s most heralded debuts with good reason—the voices of the characters are strong, the details evocative, and the story unravels so, so beautifully. Nick gifted me it for Xmas (I had to own it for that STUNNING cover) and so it became my first read of the new year. It’s set the bar high for the rest of 2017! A few favorite lines: Grief was not a line, carrying you infinitely further from loss. You never knew when you would be sling-shot backward into its grip. — 57 A daughter grows older and draws nearer to her mother, until she gradually overlaps her like a sewing pattern. — 61 Maybe she’d never really known her mother at all. And if you couldn’t know the person whose body was your first home, then who could you ever know? — 67 It was strange, learning the contours of another’s loneliness. You could never know it all at once, like stepping use a dark cave, you felt along the walls, bumped into jagged edges. — 94 All beds told stories, and Luke’s told a different one. — 154Could you be nostalgic for a friendship that wasn’t over yet or did the fact that you were nostalgic mean that it already was? — 174In his startled eyes, she felt like a sliver of herself, like an ice cube passed around inside a mouth until it hollowed into a slender crescent. — 205 These were the moments when adulthood was formed, not a birthday but the realization that she was now the one pouring a handful of candy into children’s bags, that she was now the one expected to give, not receive. — 235 She wanted this baby and that was the difference: magic you wanted was a miracle, magic you didn’t want was a haunting. — 267 ...more

title: Homegoing
author: Gyasi, Yaa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I just .... I can't even with this book. As in, I cannot even BEGIN to describe how powerful a read this novel is. If this doesn't win every book prizI just .... I can't even with this book. As in, I cannot even BEGIN to describe how powerful a read this novel is. If this doesn't win every book prize for fiction this year, something is wrong with the game. First, can we just talk about the fact Yaa Gyasi is 26? TWENTY SIX. Yeah, I KNOW. If this is her debut, be prepared to hear her name someday receiving the Nobel Prize, because seriously, she is that good.In "Homegoing," Gyasi tackles the concurrent stories of two families derived from African half-sisters, beginning in Ghana in the 1700s: one, Effia, the wife of a English trader who moves into the palatial Cape Coast Castle and the other, Esi, imprisoned in the castle's dungeon and sold into the American slave trade.In alternating chapters Gyasi introduces us to the descendants of these women as their stories span multiple generations and hardships that carry through to the present day. I am particularly in awe of how Gyasi chose to have these families' stories intertwine at the end of the book. It left me turning the last page speechless/wanting to push "Homegoing" into the hands of everybody I knew.If ever there was a modern-day sequel to Alex Haley's "Roots," THIS IS THE BOOK. If ever there was a series of stories that tackled the question "What is it like to be black in America today?," THIS IS THE BOOK. If ever there was a novel that should be required reading of everybody, especially given recent current events, THIS IS THE BOOK.Empathy is born within the pages of novels—but especially one as powerful as this.+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++I borrowed this from the library and should have bought a copy because now I'm un-dog-earring a ton of pages I marked up b/c of the most amazing prose. Here are a few I don't want to forget:Pg 18: "Cargo ships like black specks of dust in the blue, wet eye of the Atlantic" (GAHHHHH this writing...when so many of her buzzed-about peers are falling to purple prose syndrome, Gyasi's vivid descriptions are perfectly placed...this is just one example)Pg 39: "In my village we have a saying about separated sisters. They are like a woman and her reflection, doomed to stay on opposite sides of the pond" (Such an elegant way for Gyasi to mirror her plot with one of the stories told by one of the African villagers she writes about) Pg 72: "The corners of her lips always seemed to twitch upward, unwillingly, then fall within milliseconds, as though attached to that sadness that had once anchored her own mother's heart. "Ain't we all done lost someone?" Ness asked. (Ohhhh man....It was Ness's slave narrative that might have wrecked me most in this book) Couple that with the final paragraph of her story on page 87 and I was a blubbering fool.Pg 93: "They would just trade one type of shackles for another, trade physical ones that wrapped around wrists and ankles for the invisible ones that wrapped around the mind." (Very quickly in the book, you understand that one of Gyasi's objectives was to introduce her readers to how Africans—Asante and Fante, in this case—were complicit w/the whites in the slave trade—a particular chapter of the ugly slave narrative I'd never heard)Pg 112: Kojo's story—God, I just...this one was SO HARD, too: "Every time Jo saw a slave in Baltimore, he felt like he remembered. Every time Jo saw a slave in Baltimore, he saw himself, saw what his life would have been like had Ma Aku not taken him to freedom. His free papers named him Kojo Freeman. Free man. Half the ex-slaves in Baltimore had the name. Tell a lie long enough and it will turn to truth." (One of those lines I had to stop to savor ... so powerful)Pg 145: "There should be no room in your life for regret. If in the moment of doing you felt clarity, you felt certainty, then why feel regret later?" (Words to live by) Pg 216: "In the new apartment Willie had no Bess to leave [Carson] with, and so she left him by himself on days she went to work, making sure to shut the windows and lock the doors and hide the sharp things. At night she would find that he had put himself to sleep, the mattress soaked with his ever-present tears." (This scene in Willie's chapter—Willie the daughter of Big H, whose story REALLY broke my heart—made tears fall onto my cheeks because I have a son the age of her son and I could just NEVER imagine having to be in a position where I would leave my son alone all day the way this character had to) Pg 226: In Yaw's chapter, the paragraph that is essentially the thesis of Gyasi's brilliant novel: "This is the problem of history. We cannot know that which we were not there to see and hear and experience for ourselves. We must rely upon the words of others......We believe the one who has the power. He is the one who gets to write the story. So when you study history, you must always ask yourself, Whose story am I missing? Whose voice was suppressed so that this voice could come forth? Once you have figured that out, you must find that story too. From there, you begin to get a clearer, yet still imperfect, picture." Pg 244: "For Sonny, the problem with America wasn't segregation, but the fact that you could not, in fact, segregate. Sonny had been trying to get away fro white people for as long as he could remember, but, big as this country was, there was nowhere to go." Pg 295: From Marcus's chapter, "It was one thing to research something, another thing entirely to have lived it. To have felt it. How could he explain to Marjorie that what he wanted to capture with his project was the feeling of time, of having been a part of something that stretched so far back, was so impossibly large, that it was easy to forget that she, and he, and everyone else, existed in it—not apart from it, but inside of it."This last passage particular grabbed me because of Gyasi's thoughts on time that she shared in this Slate interview: http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/bo...Also, another great interview with her, this one from TIME: http://time.com/4357214/homegoing-yaa......more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: One thing I know for certain after reading three of Taylor Jenkins Reid's four books: She is an author who—for me—is a sure thing. Her newest, One TruOne thing I know for certain after reading three of Taylor Jenkins Reid's four books: She is an author who—for me—is a sure thing. Her newest, One True Loves, explores the life of Emma Blair, who marries her high school sweetheart, only to lose him in a "Cast-away" like plane crash. She finds love again with a classmate she's always had a soft spot for, but soon after, has to confront fate knocking on her door in the form of her dead husband, suddenly very much alive. As with all her books, I couldn't put this one down! [Without spoilers, I'll add I was REALLY satisfied with the ending—and I'd been on pins and needles throughout the book wondering if I would like it!]A few lines I loved/thoughts related to the book:"I think that perhaps everyone has a moment that splits their life in two. When you look back on your own timeline, there's a sharp spike somewhere along the way, some event that changed you, changed your life, more than the others. A moment that creates a 'before' and an 'after.'" "I had predicated my life on the idea that I wanted to see everywhere extraordinary, but I'd come to realize that extraordinary is everywhere.""Flirting is probably just as much about falling in love with yourself as it is with someone else." "It's rare that you love the person who loves you, that you love only the person who loves only you. Otherwise, somebody's heartbroken. But I guess that's why true love is so alluring in the first place. It's hard to find and hold on to, like all beautiful things. Like gold, saffron, or an aurora borealis." And lastly, this scene I loved (because I had never heard of this phenomenon yet experienced this MANY times:"That's the Baader-Meinhof phenomenon," Olive said when I mentioned it at lunch. "My brother just told me about this. You don't notice something and then you learn the name for it and suddenly it's everywhere." Olive thought for a moment. "Whoa. I'm pretty sure I have the Baader-Meinhof penomenon about the Baader-Meinhof phenomenon."Two things: 1) That scene made me LOL and 2) in One True Loves, there is a reference to Emma's parents taking a "disco nap." Now, I had never heard of such a thing. At 34 years old, I had to look it up! So, I'm reading this book on my phone and meanwhile, I'm reading a hardbound copy of Cynthia Sweeney's "The Nest." Like, literally a day after learning this "disco nap" term in TJR's book, it turns up in "The Nest!" So, yeah, the BM phenomenon? TOTALLY A REAL THING. ...more

review: You guys, I am such a dork that for years I coveted the four book collection set of these Paris Review interviews. (As in, they've sat in my Amazon wiYou guys, I am such a dork that for years I coveted the four book collection set of these Paris Review interviews. (As in, they've sat in my Amazon wish list since like, 2009.) But they're stupidly expensive (like, $150 for the set) so yeah, wishful thinking is right.Imagine my surprise to discover our local library has them! Recently I dived into this one and then was glad I DIDN'T purchase them b/c in the time I had this checked out, I found myself devouring a few, skimming others, and straight up not reading some b/c well, my interests just didn't align with their work (why oh why will I forever struggle to 'get' poetry? I read the TS Eliot interview and was like, 'huh?').In regards to these collections, I must add that I LOVE reading interviews (I also love interviewing, something I do practically every day for my job and have for years as a journalist/writer—if you ever meet me, expect me to pepper you with questions. I'm curious by nature and it's what I do). I also love getting a sneak peek into a creative's working life, so these are great for that as they're especially good about painting a scene of the artist in his/her work environment at the time the interview was conducted (many in this volume in the 50s-60s). Especially loved the Capote and Hemingway interviews but my absolute favorite is the Vonnegut one included in this book. (You MUST read it.) Alas, didn't get to the Didion interview before I had to return it. Next time ..... ...more

review: Sittenfeld is a popular writer (perhaps you’ve picked up her best-sellers Prep or American Wife) but this was my first book of hers and I was smitten.Sittenfeld is a popular writer (perhaps you’ve picked up her best-sellers Prep or American Wife) but this was my first book of hers and I was smitten. A modern-day retelling of Jane Austen’s Pride and Prejudice wherein the five Bennet sisters are adrift in Cincinnati, Ohio (a city I once lived). Much like the original, their attention is stolen by a (Chip) Bingley and (Fitzwilliam) Darcy. The writing is Austen-ish (so expect a fair amount of fancy words), but Sittenfeld’s wit—combined with her modern makeover of P&P’s cast of characters (case in point: Chip Bingley was a contestant on a dating reality show called Eligible; the youngest Bennet sisters are CrossFit fanatics)—will keep you turning the pages of this humorous reinterpretation of a classic. ...more

review: This book—one that's come highly recommended over the years—was a slow burn for me.I finally got around to it as my latest Audible selection this spriThis book—one that's come highly recommended over the years—was a slow burn for me.I finally got around to it as my latest Audible selection this spring and—confession time—the fact I did was driven in large part by Lin-Manuel Miranda reading it. He does GREAT BTW. But come on, are you surprised? The guy has the creative Midas touch. At first, my struggle with the story was b/c the action in the first third of the novel is slow. As in, the biggest thing that happens to Ari (our teenage male protagonist) is meeting Dante (the geeky, curious kid who becomes his BFF). The two then commiserate about being outcasts and sharing the weight of being named after famous philosophers (and we also get some backstory on their lives—a LOT of backstory when it comes to Ari's relationship w/his dad, a Vietnam vet suffering PTSD).But somewhere along the way—driven in large part by Benjamin Alire Sáenz's beautiful writing—I got more and more interested in the story until at one point, I had my car turned off, just sitting in my in-laws' driveway, not wanting to stop listening, because I didn't want to get out until the pivotal scene in my ears was over.I both loved and hated that this book had a sort of portent of doom hanging over basically the entire narrative. It kept me guessing and then sighing with relief at its HEA ending. Overall what I loved most about the narrative is that it introduces its readers to diverse characters with real and authentic problems. While it's set in the '80s, without question it's that kind of classic coming of age story that, if not already on high school reading lists, will be someday. And it should because it has that definitive "it" factor that makes you think every teenager needs to read this story....more

title: Hamilton: The Revolution
author: Miranda, Lin-Manuel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: First off, forget everything I say below and just read my friend Jessica’s  of this book. It’s perfection. My take? For a few sentences worth ofFirst off, forget everything I say below and just read my friend Jessica’s  of this book. It’s perfection. My take? For a few sentences worth of backstory, I’d never bought a cast recording of a musical before November 2015. Ever. But something happened to me last fall. I was bitten by the Hamilton bug (wasn’t everybody?) I can’t think of the last piece of art to move me the way this musical did (and continues to). I’m going to cry when I see the real thing (which, hopefully happens in Chicago in the next year because Lord knows I can’t get my mitts on a ticket to the NYC show). When I pre-ordered Hamilton: The Revolution, I thought it’d be a neat look at Lin-Manuel Miranda’s inspiration behind this juggernaut of a show. It was that, of course. But it was surprisingly SO MUCH MORE. For starters, for every person involved with this show, there's an incredible backstory. Every single one of them captivated me (Jessica details a few in her  that are SO good—the ones about Ron Chernow and his wife and Oskar Eustis and his child especially). Then, the pictures. Oh they are GLORIOUS—particularly for those of us who will never see the original cast perform on stage at the Richard Rodgers Theatre. (They also helped me understand actor relationships in the story that are hard to glean by merely listening to the cast recording—for example, how Anthony Ramos plays both John Laurens and Philip Hamilton….matter of fact, the way in which Lin uses the same actors to play multiple roles throughout his show is an aspect of the production I most appreciate)Finally, the cherry on top of this gloriously creative sundae: Lin’s annotations to the lyrics. It’s one thing hearing all these songs with the vague understanding you are listening to somebody whose influences are so ingrained they are the very reason this show exists (who else would read an 800-page biography of a Founding Father and think 'Oh, this is a hip-hop musical'?). It’s another to have Lin point them out to you in such a way that you realize this guy is a human SPONGE. (Case in point: I’ve told multiple friends about the “Ten Duel Commandments” sampling of Notorious BIG’s “Ten Crack Commandments” … again, genius!). Another thing I LOVE about Lin (there are many things, of course, not the least of which is his enthusiasm for EVERYTHING) is that, while he is a man of superior intelligence, he never lets on as such. Throughout the book he sprinkles in pop culture references to zeitgeist-y gems like Harry Potter and Parks and Rec, proving he's "one of us." It’s these little touches that make you love him that much more, which is a feat unto itself if you—like me—thought that wasn't possible. ...more

review: You guys, this BOOKKKKKK ..... I finished Ruta Sepetys' "Salt to the Sea" in a race of a final few reading hours and then spent another hour reading eYou guys, this BOOKKKKKK ..... I finished Ruta Sepetys' "Salt to the Sea" in a race of a final few reading hours and then spent another hour reading everything I could about Ruta and her extensive historical research bringing to life the largest maritime sinking in history. More than 9,000 German and Baltic refugees—half of them children—died on board the Wilhelm Gustloff during WWII when it was sunk by a Soviet submarine in January 1945. Sepetys' retelling of the sinking, shared through the vivid narratives of four unforgettable characters, is so complete you feel like you're there with them. Cannot recommend this book enough. If and when its film adaptation gets made—and it MUST because it's straight up the next Titantic—I cannot WAIT to see who will play Joana and her "knight," Florian ...more

title: The Serpent King
author: Zentner, Jeff*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I finished Jeff Zentner’s The Serpent King and then spent three days feeling bereft. Like I was missing a couple new best friends who lived in the pagI finished Jeff Zentner’s The Serpent King and then spent three days feeling bereft. Like I was missing a couple new best friends who lived in the pages of this book. So I did something I never do: I read the darn thing over again, front to cover. And I loved it even more.Look, I’m not from the South (if I was, I might get a tattoo of this book’s cover on my bicep, that’s how much I loved it). BUT I am from the Midwest, and when it comes to book love, where I’m from is as about as forgotten as the particular patch of Tennessee Zentner sets “The Serpent King.” I recognized all its people and places. Swap out chess pie for sugar cream, and these situations and this backdrop could just as easily have happened in the rural part of Indiana where I’m from. On that note, Zentner walks a fine line the way all my favorite authors do, writing openly and honestly about a place that’s down on its luck without ever being too out-right condescending about it (see also my  of Nickolas Butler’s “Shotgun Lovesongs”). I’ve started following him on social media and recently he posted a pic of his book being sold at Wal-Mart. Not in an ironic way. In a “for a lot of people I know, this is the only place you can buy books in town and I’m damn grateful for it” kind of way. No lie—it made me want to give him a high five.So yeah, I LOVE this book. Have I said that already? Six-star loved it. Loved it so much I’m sending texts to friends, asking them to read it too, then trying to live vicariously through their first readings all over again (“Are you at that part where Lydia jokes about the Starbucks? HAHAHAHAHA”!)To say too much about this coming-of-age story would be a disservice to letting y’all (see what I did there?!) discover the twists and turns of its plot. Instead, I’ll just say again it’s the characters that did it for me. For Generation Z, Dill, Lydia, and Travis remind me a LOT of another trio of friends I famously adore. Yep. Not since Sloan Peterson have I wanted to BE a teenager the way reading this made me want to be Lydia Blankenship (hell, she even had me developing my own crush on a young William de Kooning—seriously, Google him. Where does Jeff come up with this stuff?!) The coolest girl in YA lit? Abso-freaking-lutely. A few other thoughts:• Lydia’s Dad. I just….I can’t even. Best parental figure in fiction since Becky Albertalli penned Simon’s awesome mom and dad in Simon vs the Homo Sapien Agenda (a 2015 release I loved every bit as much this) . Mr. Blankenship’s moment with Dill in the car on the way home from Nashville WRECKED me. Almost as much as that other moment in the book. Y’all know the one I’m talking about. The TEARS FOR DAYS moment. • Having several creative friends who are on some level Internet famous, I loved Zentner’s take on Lydia being a fashion blogger—it’s a keen observation about the world we live in today in terms of fame and success and what it looks like on the web versus real life (the “off brand” commentary about posting photos of Dill and Travis especially!)• Jeff’s writing is incredible—especially his descriptions (sights/smells/sounds) …so many sentences I highlighted and/or underlined because they felt like a nod to poetry (all his years of songwriting have paid off!): “When they pulled into Forrestville, the shadows were long and the light looked like it was streaming through a pitcher of sweet tea”—I mean, COME ON! So good!)• And finally, where can we get a link to those YouTube videos of Dearly singing? Never before have I so wanted a character’s art to be real. (Wait…. I take that back—2016 so far has me wanting to see JB’s retrospective of Jude and Williem…but that’s when you know your love for a book is deep—when even the art the characters are creating feels alive and real) So yeah, do yourself a favor and fall for this trio already. Then join me in admitting you want to be in high school again if only to have the “once in a generation” kind of friendship Dill, Lydia, and Travis do.BRAVO JEFF!  ...more

title: The First Time She Drowned
author: Kletter, Kerry*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: You guyyyyssssss I REALLY wanted to love this book. It came highly recommended from several YA authors I greatly admire and I can see why they all lovYou guyyyyssssss I REALLY wanted to love this book. It came highly recommended from several YA authors I greatly admire and I can see why they all loved it. Chiefly because the prose is straight up GORGEOUS. As in, lines took my breath away and left me coping with that "I'll NEVER be this good" syndrome you sometimes get when you yourself are a writer reading great work.So why did I give up on it? Because I have a REALLY hard time reading books about characters who are so wholly unloved. In Kletter's story, teenage protagonist Cassie O'Malley is an emotionally neglected and abused young woman who (unfairly) winds up in a psych ward. I know there's a bunch of backstory to explain her reason for being there (backstory I never got to but read about in a few spoiler-ish s), but by the time I "met" Cassie's evil grandmother and then her evil aunt—this on top of loathing her especially evil mother—I was done. Unable to muster up a give-a-damn for three secondary characters meaner than Cinderella's stepmother and stepsisters combined. (Also, on a more practical note, the book was overdue at the library so back it went.)Beautifully told story, just one of those cases where it wasn't the right story for ME. ...more

title: Highly Illogical Behavior
author: Whaley, John Corey

review: I love JCW. He's one of my favorite YA authors thanks to "Noggin" and so I was greatly looking forward to his newest release. I can't say I was disappI love JCW. He's one of my favorite YA authors thanks to "Noggin" and so I was greatly looking forward to his newest release. I can't say I was disappointed by Highly Illogical Behavior (far from it). Just a little "whelmed" by the story tucked inside its pages (as in, not underwhelmed but not overwhelmed either).I must say HIB's premise is a great set-up: 16-yr-old Solomon has agoraphobia. He meets the sweet but slightly overzealous (and in one case, slightly conniving) classmates Lisa and Clark who try to rescue him. Conflict ensues. I loved all the scenes of the trio hanging out because they felt so true. True enough they took me back to being a teenager, playing video games with my own friends in one another's basements. But when I got to the ending of this book (which I liked) I found myself thinking, "That's it? That's all we get?" Maybe that's a testament to JCW's writing (scratch that, I know it is) but also because, in the end, this book was a quiet kind of story. That doesn't make it one that shouldn't be told (JCW needs to tell more stories—all the stories—and I'll be first in line to read every one), just that this particular one will likely slip from my memory in the months to come. (As a final note: I know one audience for whom this book will resonate—and probably stick with always. And that's those kids and adults out there who suffer from anxiety—and it's a growing number. Solomon will be your hero, trust me. Also, as I was reading, the way JCW describes the physical manifestation of anxiety in a person's body, I could tell he'd experienced it firsthand. That's why his revelation he shared in this insightful interview with BookPage came as no surprise. ...more

review: So a good friend of mine (hi Jamie!) recommended this read to me because she knew the YA novel I'd written involved a road trip (of sorts) and since sSo a good friend of mine (hi Jamie!) recommended this read to me because she knew the YA novel I'd written involved a road trip (of sorts) and since she works in publishing and has her pulse on what's being published right now in the market I specifically write in, I took her up on her suggestion.Then weird things started happening.Weird Thing No. 1: I found out that Michelle and Mindi's agent, Jim McCarthy, would be one of our agents at this year's Midwest Writers Workshop (a conference I'm on the committee of and participating in this year as a pitching author). I signed up to pitch Jim, natch. (also, here's where I plug MWW because IT.IS.AWESOME: http://www.midwestwriters.org/Weird Thing No. 2: I start reading this book and it involves an organ donation, as does my novel. Okay, okay ..... I kpee reading, enjoying the book's solid dual point-of-view romance between the BFF (Cloudy) and boyfriend (Kyle) of Ashley, a teen who died and whose organs now belong inside the people who Cloudy and Kyle are on a road trip to find.)Weird Thing No. 3: Said road trip takes them to Santa Monica. (my book's protagonist winds up there, too......). Okay, getting weirder....Weird(est) Thing No. 4: The authors are describing the California landscape and refer to a certain species of trees as "Dr. Seussian" and you guys, I WROTE THAT EXACT DESCRIPTION IN MY BOOK.Takes deep breaths for a few minutes because AYKM?!!!!All right...so, I'm fairly certain, the longer you're a writer, and the more fiction you write, the more you're going to bump up into instances like this—plot lines, themes, even SPECIFIC DESCRIPTIONS that you read on a page somewhere that you, yourself, have written.Of course, your book is the one that's not published, so it doesn't count, right? I took a moment upon coming to this passage to feel deflated (like, am I THAT unoriginal here?) But then, glass-half-full girl that I am, I chose to look at it from a different perspective: If I'm writing plot lines, themes, even SPECIFIC DESCRIPTIONS that are being published by authors with legit book deals, well then maybe, it's not that. Maybe it's just I'm one step closer to snagging one of those myself. :) :) :) :) :) :) ...more

review: This is one of those rare, pleasurable reads that defies genre and classification—is it commercial? literary? Let's flip a coin and call it upmarket .This is one of those rare, pleasurable reads that defies genre and classification—is it commercial? literary? Let's flip a coin and call it upmarket ... but wherever you find it on bookstore shelves, I recommend picking it up. Especially if you're in the mood for a read that's nostalgic, witty, smart, cute and a little bit sad. In that sense, it reminds me a LOT of Rosie Project and Where'd You Go Bernadette, so if you like either/both of those reads, this one will definitely appeal to you!This was my book club's most recent pick and it's a great selection for a group read—we all enjoyed discussing Frank's many outfits (wishing we could see visual evidence!), picking apart Alice's relationships with both Mimi and Xander, and discussing what we felt were Johnson's influences in creating her impressive debut (Harper Lee's To Kill a Mockingbird was at the top of the list). ...more

review: This book captured my attention in that it has 1) a heck of a premise (adapting the classic Sherlock-Watson duo by re-imagining their descendants as tThis book captured my attention in that it has 1) a heck of a premise (adapting the classic Sherlock-Watson duo by re-imagining their descendants as teenagers who happen to find themselves state-side at the same CT boarding school) and 2) a stunning cover—like, seriously, the colors popped so much I didn’t want to take it off my nightstand.While I fell hard for it at first (again, the shininess of the concept really won me over), my interest in the story waned the deeper into the narrative I got. Overall I liked the voice of Jamie Watson (who writes the story), but the case itself that he and Charlotte Holmes were trying to solve (who was trying to frame Charlotte, who happens to be Sherlock’s great-great-great granddaughter) was just…well, not all that interesting to me.To be fair, I’m a bandwagon Sherlock fan. I love the BBC show (though have only caught the first two seasons) and have seen the newest Sherlock films but unlike my hubby, I've never read any of Sir Arthur Conan Doyles’ stories (I know, I know—so bad!). So maybe I’m not the best judge on how well Cavallaro did, slipping nods to Doyle’s actual Sherlock stories into this book of hers. (Scratch that, I KNOW I’m not.)On a final note, not sure if any others who read this dealt with the same issues I did as far as coming across certain passages where the writing felt a little clunky. As in, I had to re-read paragraphs to infer who was in the crosshairs of a particular action in a particular scene. (In one case, I can remember the author slipping in a few paragraphs of backstory about secondary characters and then jumping back into Charlotte speaking without addressing the return to the present and me thinking, “Wait….oh, so we’ve left the past then?”) Just little things like this that might be improved upon for the second book in the series (which, at this point, I’m not sure I’ll get around to reading!)...more

review: This one was a slow (at times tedious) read for me. I don't want to take away from Nancy Jo Sales' research—it was broad and detailed and INCREDIBLY rThis one was a slow (at times tedious) read for me. I don't want to take away from Nancy Jo Sales' research—it was broad and detailed and INCREDIBLY revealing, but after the first few chapters, the content began to echo itself. So much so that, near the end, I was skimming more than reading. (Sales sets up each chapter by a girl's age, starting with 13, going on to 18...each one has anecdotes from young women in that age range, with facts and data about social media sprinkled throughout each).The greater point I took away from the book is how freaking SAD it made me—these young women (men, too) whose lives are plagued by the anxiety of trying to live a perfect existence online. It's...beyond troubling. It's disgusting. Alarming. And nothing makes me want to turn into a version of Grandpa Simpson ('back in my day') more than this particular topic (#lostinnocence #readabookinstead #quittryingtocopyakardashian) Because it's late (and I'm tired...and trying to catch up with GR s!) I'll point readers who might be interested in the book to this NYT  ... I happen to agree with the er who notes the content Sales first explored in a 2013 Vanity Fair article grows unwieldy when turned into a book of this length: http://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/19/boo... ...more
