title: Year of Yes
author: Rhimes, Shonda*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Maybe it’s because this was an audio read for me, and Shonda was SO DARN DELIGHTFUL speaking its words in my ear, but this was a definite five-star reMaybe it’s because this was an audio read for me, and Shonda was SO DARN DELIGHTFUL speaking its words in my ear, but this was a definite five-star read for me. I’ve been a fan of this woman’s shows for quite some time (though admittedly I don’t watch Grey’s or Scandal at present) and I admire the way she OWNS.HER.LIFE. Without apology. Without the “Who me? I don’t deserve this” lack of confidence so many women can fall for as a trapping of their own success. On the surface this book may seem an unnecessary read (like, hasn’t every celebrity written some kind of memoir about how to be a better person?). But because it’s Shonda, her version trumps any and all other cliched attempts from her peers to write about life truths. And man does she present a LOT of them in “The Year of Yes” (which is dedicated to all the ways she starts saying “Yes” to life—from improving her health, to taking on more speaking engagements, to appearing on an episode of The Mindy Project).Highly recommend for anyone who is a fan of Shonda’s shows (there’s some fun backstories included–I loved Shonda’s take on Christina Yang especially); in search of stories about successful women; or in need of a boost of creative empowerment and/or wanting a dose of solid inspiration. A few scenes I bookmarked while listening—sorry for the bad transcription here, but I wanted to remember these and typed them up on the fly! “I thoroughly enjoy making stuff up; I do like to make stuff up. I love it. It’s also kind of ingrained in me. My brain naturally leans in the direction of half-truths. My brain turns toward fiction like flower to the sun…fabrication is like a bad habit that feels good….spinning tall tales is my dirty little vice….but it’s not just a bad habit. I need to do it. I HAVE to do it. It turns out making stuff up is a job. For real. Seriously.”(Shonda describes writing TV as laying a track for a train—how it's never-ending and she has to keep up—I loved the analogy): “When laying track feels like going from climbing a mountain on hands and knees to flying effortlessly through the air, like breaking the sound barrier. Everything inside me just shifts and I break the writing barrier. Feeling of laying track changes from exertion to exhalation. OWN YOUR GREATNESS: “You have to grab hold of it. You have to believe it….in order to be as good as Serena, you have to decide that no one is going to be as good as you are at tennis. Then you have to make it true.” On how she had to cut people out of her life as she started living a happier life saying "yes" to stuff: “Unhappy people don’t like when other unhappy people become happy”(YESSSSS–tuning in to my writing has made me an introvert) “There’s a certain amount of time alone I need just to have the brain space to write. To have what I call mental pantry time”(THIS--because I've never read something that better captures the struggle it is to be a writer and have to fight like hell to get to that place where the words can come)“Writing is the hum. Writing is the high. Writing is the track. Now imagine that hum, that high, that track to be laid is behind a door. That door is five miles away. Those five miles are just writing crap and doodling and trying to have an idea and surfing the Internet and hoping like hell you don’t get so attracted you don’t give up. Worse, those five miles are lined with brownies and cupcakes and episodes of Game of Thrones and Idris Elba waiting to talk to only you and really good novels to read. Every time I sit down to write, I have to mentally run those five miles past all of that, to get to that door. It’s a long, hard, five-mile run. Sometimes I’m almost dead by the time I reach the door. That’s why I have to keep doing it. The more often I run the five miles, the fitter I become. And the fitter I become, the easier the run begins to feel and the less fresh and exciting all that stuff on the side of the road seems. More important, as I get fitter I can run faster, and the faster I can run the faster I can get to that door. When you sit down to write every day, it becomes easier to tap into that creative space in your mind. The faster I can get to that door, the quicker I can get to the good stuff. Behind the door is the good stuff. So when I reach the door and open it, that’s when creativity clicks in. That special spot in my brain starts working and I go fro exertion to exhalation and I can start writing forever…and then someone opens the door and asks if I want coffee and I’m five miles away all over again.”“Writing and I are MFEO. …. I have no ability to downgrade my creativity in my soul. I have no desire to do so either.” “My happy ending is not the same as your happy ending …. Everyone has their own version of happiness. We all spend our lives kicking the crap out of ourselves for not being this way or that way, not having this thing or that thing, or being like this person or that person. For not living up to some standard we think applies across the board to all of us. We all spend our lives trying to follow the same path, live by the same rules…I think we believe happiness lies in following the same list of rules and being more like everyone else. That is wrong. There is no list of rules. There is one rule: The rule is, there are no rules. Happiness comes from living as you need to. As you want to. As your inner voice tells you to. Happiness comes from being who you actually are versus who you think you’re supposed to be.” ...more

review: There was a point early on in "Sweetbitter" where I thought: I can't do this. I can't read another one of this much-touted, too fanciful releases fromThere was a point early on in "Sweetbitter" where I thought: I can't do this. I can't read another one of this much-touted, too fanciful releases from the latest literary wunderkid. (It was right around page 10, when our protagonist informs us that the guy at the gas station MASTICATES HER WITH HIS EYEBALLS....like, WTF? Pretentious much? Because WHO CHEWS ANYTHING WITH THEIR EYEBALLS?!) But I took a deep breath and soldiered on. In most ways, I'm glad I did. I can't say I ever really liked Tess. As our narrator, she's closed off. Cold. Nearly unknowable. But she's also the lens through which Danler lets us enter the behind-the-scenes world of one of NYC's most successful restaurants. And that.world.is.FASCINATING.It's very much an I-wrote-this-while-earning-my-MFA kind of read (complete with second person passages!) but all in all, I guess I'm glad I stuck with it. Why? I can't say for sure (the book left me feeling melancholy, pretty much like all the characters in it....also, I HATED its ending.) But like the best books do, it transported me to a world I'd never known before and for that, I couldn't stop turning the pages. ...more

author: Sullivan, J. Courtney*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm always intrigued by books that tie together multiple plot lines from multiple characters. It's a hard concept to pull off, but in the hands of a tI'm always intrigued by books that tie together multiple plot lines from multiple characters. It's a hard concept to pull off, but in the hands of a talented writer like Sullivan (whose Commencement was also a MPOV novel), it's done remarkably well. Which is probably why I really engaged (pun not intended!) with this novel of hers, a story that casts a mega-watt spotlight on Frances Gerety, the copywriter responsible for elevating DeBeers and diamonds to the world, penning one of the most famous phrases in the history of advertising—"A Diamond is Forever." If you're a Mad Men fan, you'll find a bit of Peggy Olsen inspiration in Gerety's character, a woman who was way, way ahead of her time when it came to being defined by her career. The chapters about her life and the elements of history about how diamonds came to prominence as THE jewel of choice for women were some of the most interesting of the book.Interwoven with Gerety's chapters were the time-spanning stories of four other characters—James, a down-on-his luck paramedic; Evelyn, a frustrated retired school teacher whose son's divorce is unraveling her at the seams; Delphine, who leaves behind the comfort of life in France for a lover she's taken in NYC; and Kate, a New Yorker who is happy with her partner, Dan, but sees no need to put a ring on their relationship.By the end of the book, I really admired the way Sullivan had pulled all these characters' stories together (hint: a diamond ring may have something to do with it!) My only criticisms were that Sullivan occasionally has a tendency to typecast characters (Kate especially drove me nuts—the descriptions of her read too much like central casting for Brooklyn Mom with Issues) and there were times where Sullivan's research came across as clunky (like she'd found a great fact about the diamond business in 1952 and needed to fold it in verbatim)Those small quabbles aside, I am truly amazed at the AMOUNT of research Sullivan did for this book. It's quite impressive and for that reason alone (along with it being an overall pleasurable read), I'd recommend it. ...more

title: When Breath Becomes Air
author: Kalanithi, Paul
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In the short time since I’ve read this book, I’ve recommended it to no fewer than a dozen people (and counting). The challenge comes when that friend In the short time since I’ve read this book, I’ve recommended it to no fewer than a dozen people (and counting). The challenge comes when that friend or coworker says, “What’s it about?” and I have to describe that it’s a memoir of a man who died of cancer. I watch their face fall as if to say, A death book? Oh man, Gail … I don’t think so.That’s when I start backpedaling, stealing the words of a er who speaks of how Paul’s words in “When Breathe Becomes Air” “crackle with life.” Because for as much as this book chronicles one man’s last days on earth, it’s a BEAUTIFUL rumination on how he lived them with fortitude (a lesson all of us, living or dying, need to hear). For me, the melancholy of finishing the last page came with the punch-in-the-gut realization that death has robbed the world of Paul’s incredible voice (and his talents as a neurosurgeon/neuroscientist). I could not believe how beautiful his prose was, how easy to read, how, even when he was suffering the effects of chemo, these were the pages he was able to produce. To say he was brilliant would be a massive understatement. I’m going to steal Ann Patchett’s words about Paul’s memoir because they are indeed so fitting: “Thanks to ‘When Breathe Becomes Air,’ those of us who never met Paul Kalanithi will both mourn his death and benefit from his life. This is one of a handful of books I consider to be a universal donor—I would recommend it to anyone, everyone.”I agree with Ann, which is why I’ll keep telling everyone I know about it until it ends up in their hands, too.A few of my favorite passages from “When Breathe Becomes Air” excerpted below: A beautiful sentiment of Paul’s: “You can’t ever reach perfection, but you can believe in an asymptote toward which you are ceaselessly striving.” Paul’s final words of the book to his daughter Cady (cue the waterworks): “When you come to one of the many moments in life when you must give an account of yourself, provide a ledger of what you have been, and done, and meant to the world, do not, I pray, discount that you filled a dying man’s days with a stead joy, a joy unknown to me in all my prior years, a joy that does not hunger for more and more, but rests, satisfied. In this time, right now, that is an enormous thing.” And my favorite passage in the gorgeous epilogue that Lucy, his wife, wrote Paul (because it speaks to all those tender moments that make a marriage the blessing it can be): “His diagnosis was like a nutcracker, getting us back to the soft, nourishing meat of our marriage …. [on their remaining time together] …. “We were as inseparable as we had been as medical students, when we would hold hands during lectures. Now we held hands in his coat pocket during walks outside after chemotherapy … He knew he would never be alone, never suffer unnecessarily. At home in bed a few weeks before he died, I asked him, “Can you breathe okay with my head on your chest like this?” His answer was “It’s the only way I know to breathe.” That Paul and I formed part of the deep meaning of each other’s lives is one of the greatest blessings that has ever come to me.”[And finally, as some of you may know, Paul’s wife, Lucy, is the twin sister of Joanna Goddard, founder of A Cup of Jo, my favorite blog on the web. While Joanna is never referenced in the book, the fact that I’ve been a long-time reader of hers and that she has written of Paul’s death (and this book) several times on her blog, served as a powerful reminder of how the Internet can make the world feel so small]...more

title: My Name Is Lucy Barton        (Amgash, #1)
author: Strout, Elizabeth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The thing about Strout is she has this amazing ability to capture the nuances of life so darn well. For me, that's what makes reading her work worth iThe thing about Strout is she has this amazing ability to capture the nuances of life so darn well. For me, that's what makes reading her work worth it. I enjoy studying it, the details she notices and transfers through her readers, the way she structures her sentences. It's uniquely her own style (and I meant to capture a few examples here, but forgot to jot them down as I was reading!) Be that as it may, this book almost felt like I could wring the melancholy out of it. The protagonist, Lucy, was a woman so beaten down, so under-confident, that being inside her head reminded me of how Arrested Development always had those Charlie Brown moments throughout the series.I was talking with a friend of mine about "My Name is Lucy Barton" after I finished. I said it felt like almost *too* personal of a glimpse into Strout's life. Because the way she writes her characters (these here in this book and in her previous works) makes me think her home life was...well, less than pleasant (this was confirmed in hearing her completely clam up talking about when Terry Gross interviewed her some weeks ago on Fresh Air about Lucy).Overall I'm glad I read this because it's a slip of a novel that I plowed through quickly (curious all the way) but I would be selective on who I recommended it to—best for lovers of literary fiction and fans of Strout's (and anybody who wants to commiserate with a loveless family situation, perhaps)...more

title: Between the World and Me
author: Coates, Ta-Nehisi
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Recently I was talking to a colleague about this book. Someone else who had read it. Together we lamented how angry it made us, reading about the hardRecently I was talking to a colleague about this book. Someone else who had read it. Together we lamented how angry it made us, reading about the hard racial truths Coates lays bare in his writing. I was telling her there was something else about the book, something it was making me feel that I couldn't quit put a finger on. She pinpointed it for me: Uncomfortable.Yep. That was it. That was EXACTLY how I felt reading "Between the World and Me." (To the point that when she shared this brilliant essay by Sally Kohn for Elle Magazine, "Why White Women Should Read Ta-Nehisi Coates' Book," I sat poring over it thinking to myself, "SHE IS SAYING EVERYTHING I AM THINKING."My favorite passage from the essay (if you're too lazy to click over and read it): "It is impossible to read [Coates'] text without wincing. And it should be. As the writer Rebecca Carroll has suggested, white discomfort is progress.  "In my experience, white people can stand to feel badly, ashamed, annoyed, uncomfortable for about 25 seconds," Carroll has written. "But the right track is to feel all of that and then some for, say, 25 weeks. To start."Amen to that. So here's to more #BlackLivesMatter and #OscarSoWhite movements, and Beyonce videos and brave witnesses (black and white) willing to stand up, hold their cell phones out, and record the kinds of footage that make it impossible for America to turn a blind eye anymore.PS - While reading "Between," I was trolling Coates' Twitter account and came across a fellow reader who'd also finished it feeling helpless (it's a bleak future, what Coates describes to his son). I favorited his response because his suggestion feels like the least any of us who care about the issue can do.PPS - I listened to this on audio, which made it that much more powerful of a read since Coates narrated it himself. WOW. ...more

title: Saint Anything
author: Dessen, Sarah*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I had my first taste of Sarah Dessen last fall and fell pretty hard. I’m by no means her target demographic (that would be 16 year old girls, ahem) buI had my first taste of Sarah Dessen last fall and fell pretty hard. I’m by no means her target demographic (that would be 16 year old girls, ahem) but nonetheless, escaping into one of her books is pleasurable for me in the same way binge-watching a season of Gilmore Girls is pleasurable. Relationship drama + great characters=excellent storytelling no matter the age, am I right?Saint Anything happens to be Dessen’s latest book and it landed on quite a few Best of YA Books for 2015. It’s the story of a wallflower protagonist (Sydney), struggling in the shadow of her trouble-making brother (Peyton), who finds love and support from a family (the Chatams) that notices her in a way her family doesn’t. In short, it’s got all the trappings of a classic YA set up: conflicted girl, cute boy (that would be Mac Chatam), and a great supporting friend cast (Layla Chatam is all sorts of fun). As a writer who’s still relatively new to her craft, I love reading Dessen because she’s an author who *gets* story structure. I know some may find fault with this (that it's tiresome and formulaic) but guys, there’s a reason Sarah Dessen has sold like, 10 million books: IT’S BECAUSE STRUCTURE WORKS AND READERS LOVE IT. I’ve come to love deconstructing her books alongside the writing lessons I’ve picked up in 2015 from authors like Martha Alderson and KM Weiland. Maybe what I love most about Dessen is her voice. It feels relatable and real with very little ‘try’ (literary fiction types could learn a lesson or two from commercial writers like her when it comes to this), and for me, that’s what makes her work aspirational—because I want whatever books I write to be as relatable to my own future readers....more

title: The Royal We        (Royal We, #1)

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Want to get dubious looks from people? Don’t just tell them about this book, GUSH about it. That’s been me the past few weeks, as I finally got aroundWant to get dubious looks from people? Don’t just tell them about this book, GUSH about it. That’s been me the past few weeks, as I finally got around to reading Royal We. (On a serendipitous note, I started it on the 5-year anniversary of Kate and William’s wedding—a fact I wasn’t aware of until former students of mine tagged me in Kensington Palace’s IG post marking the occasion … these students having joined me at 5 a.m. on a chilly April morning in 2011 to watch the ceremony in my living room, scones and hot tea in hand.)Am I a “Royal watcher”? Yes, but not in a super fan kind of way. Nor would I be the first in line to pick up a book that is for all intensive purposes fan fiction of this famous coupling. So why did I? Because of the brains behind it.You guys, Heather and Jessica are GREAT writers. You’d know this if you’ve followed their Go Fug Yourself blog. (Which I have, on and off, for years—never without having at least ONE LOL-moment while perusing the celebrities whose fashion tastes they skewer; for a nice tie-in to Royal We, check out their recent retrospective on Kate and William—again, so many chuckles). So yeah, I fell HARD for this book. In it, the Kate character is an American, Rebecca Porter (Bex for short, which I ADORE), who leaves Cornell and America behind for a British exchange program that lands her at Oxford, rooming in the same hall as Prince Nicholas (married to a prince of a man named Nick myself, of course I ADORE his name, too). What makes this retelling work so well is just how SMART it is. I mean that in the best way possible. It takes clever writers to come up with the amount of wit on display in Royal We (case in point: Bex’s father is the inventor of the Coucherator, a couch that has a fridge in the base … remember how Kate’s parents own a party-planning enterprise? Also, the amount of fun Heather and Jessica have with nicknames and imaginary tabloid headlines for these two—“Trouble in Porterdise? Bexzilla Wants Nicky to Love Her More Than Britain”) Half the fun of reading this was turning the page wondering what kind of humor I’d rub up against as I kept going.Heather and Jessica pull something else off, too—they humanize Will and Kate. At multiple points throughout the book, I took what Bex and Nick were going through and thought about the royal couple as PEOPLE. Something that, for a lot of years, we haven’t seen them as, am I right? (figureheads, yes; gorgeous celebrities, yes; people who burp and cuss and can be crass behind closed doors same as the rest of us? Not so much). To get what felt like an “insider’s take” on what it’s like to BE them was strangely humbling (says the girl who one evening while reading tumbled down an Internet rabbit hole of Googling images of Will and Kate from their own college years).All that to say, there’s a reason why this book was lauded by the New York Times and Entertainment Weekly and Kirkus and Publishers Weekly. Because it DESERVES to be. Get over yourselves (if you happen to be one of those readers snubbing it as fan fiction, which you might think is somehow below you) and go buy it or check it out from the library because I promise you, you'll have one hell of a good time reading it.Also good to know: The book JUST came out in paperback (with a great cover) so there’s that ….. AND Lauren Graham (of Gilmore Girls) is slated to write the film adaptation with Mae Whitman (her Parenthood daughter and a wonderful actress) attached to star as Bex. ALREADY I AM ALL OVER THIS MOVIE AND I HAVE NO IDEA WHEN IT COMES OUT. And finally, one last nugget of fun: People magazine imagining Royal We’s dream cast ...more

title: Garlic and Sapphires: The Secret Life of a Critic in Disguise
author: Reichl, Ruth
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I like Ruth Reichl as a writer—I really do. She's got a great voice and her writing is smooth; she's also a wonderful storyteller. But I have to admitI like Ruth Reichl as a writer—I really do. She's got a great voice and her writing is smooth; she's also a wonderful storyteller. But I have to admit I was a little drained by this book. I picked it up after reading Joanna Goddard (of Cup of Jo) praise it in audio format but for me, I grew weary of the narrator's voice, the way she put on so many different accents and inflections for the various characters. To use a food analogy (which seems fitting), too much salt can spoil a soup, you know what I mean? With audio reads, any time you find yourself being taken out of the story because you're distracted by, say, the reader doing her best Bronx accent, that's a problem.Subject material wise, as fun as it was to read Ruth's experiences as the New York Times restaurant critic (a position she held in the mid-90s), going to NYC restaurants in disguise, I just wasn't familiar enough with the culinary landscape of the city to appreciate this the way I'm betting a lot of New Yorkers would.I will say, however, that I immensely enjoyed the short Q&A that was conducted with Ruth herself at the back of the book (talk about a REAL New Yorker's accent). Perhaps my favorite part is when she responded to the question of when she writes, given that she also balances a day job (or did; having left the NYT to take on the editor role at Gourmet, a magazine that was shuttered in 2009). Her response captivated me because it is for the precise same reason that I wake (or try to most mornings!) and write myself:"Like most writers, I hate writing; I'd rather clean toilets. But I love having written. You sit down at your desk and half the time nothing good happens. But when something good happens when you're writing, it's a kind of magic that no other time. You disappear. You're sitting there and nothing happens and you look at your watch--it's 5 am; it's 5:30 am, but then, when you're lucky, something happens and the next thing you know, it's 7:30 and you vanished and there's something on the paper you can't even explain how it got there and you can't even explain how it happened. For me it's a kind of high I don't get any other way and that's why I find the time to do it."...more

title: Along for the Ride
author: Dessen, Sarah*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was trying to think of a good analogy to describe reading a book by Sarah Dessen (while admitting this is my first of hers). I'm gonna go with an exI was trying to think of a good analogy to describe reading a book by Sarah Dessen (while admitting this is my first of hers). I'm gonna go with an exercise metaphor: There are certain novels you read when you want a literary workout (Lauren Groff's Fates & Furies comes to mind). Then there are those that you approach like you would when you want something a little more gentle for your brain. While you know it's still good for you, you're relaxed by the experience, wrapped up in the sensations (characters) that come along and before you know it, you've finished in a blissed out state of mind. So, you know, a lot like yoga.That's kind of how I felt after reading Along for the Ride, a YA book for the ladies that smacks awfully close to a plot one might find as a spin-off of Dawson's Creek—sleepy seaside town, recent college grad Auden whose parents split, coming to live with her dad and new step-mother after they have a new baby. She has insomnia and soon enough, meets Eli, who suffers the same fate for entirely different reasons. Together well....you get to discover that one for yourself. It's one of those chickish love stories that's as comforting as a Lifetime movie and guess what? I COULDN'T PUT IT DOWN. What Dessen does she does well, as much for the younger set as Jennifer Weiner for the post-30 crowd. I'll definitely read more of hers, especially when I'm looking for that next literally yoga reading experience. (I'll be reading A Little Life soon, so I might have to read her newest after that!) ...more

title: Refuel: An Uncomplicated Guide to Connecting With God
author: Fields, Doug
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Another church bookstore read, I really loved this slim little book. Easy to read in one setting, though I chunked it out in a few more because I wantAnother church bookstore read, I really loved this slim little book. Easy to read in one setting, though I chunked it out in a few more because I wanted to savor the lessons held within. A look at how to spend more time with God when your days are filled to the brim with being busy, as written by one of Saddleback Church's pastors (that's a group of pastors whose work I trust more than a lot of spiritual leaders out there).A few gems from the book I underlined (and there were many) highlighted below. This would make a great stocking stuffer gift for Christian followers in your life or anyone who might benefit from learning more about the gift of God's grace:• When I'm spiritually empty, my life sputters. Things feel different. Not good different—bad different. I'm shallow, confused, and anxious. • If guilt defines you, I'm so sorry. I pray that you'll come to see that you're not a "lousy Christian" if you don't have traditional quiet time with God. The Christian life is not about locks and chains. Jesus came to set us free. Yes, some guilt may serve as God's motivator, but too many Christians cower because of false guilt—aka condemnation—that they've headed upon their own shoulders because they've compared themselves to an unrealistic model and come up short. The guild is wrong and unfair, and it will weigh you down and wear you out. • God is at work in our lives ... There will always be some sort of mess God is working with. But every time we notice a positive change in our character, we can thank God because He's at work. • My connections with God are much more free-flowing (than they used to be). I read God's Word but sometimes I do it at home, sometimes at work, sometimes in the car. Other times I'll read verses I've written on three-by-five cards that I leave on my dash to meditate on while at stoplights. <---Love that idea! ...more

review: It’s been a while since I picked up a good historical fiction read, but this one was pretty solid (and how about that cover?!) Fantastic research of tIt’s been a while since I picked up a good historical fiction read, but this one was pretty solid (and how about that cover?!) Fantastic research of the period (1914), tight story, fascinating glimpse into trends of the era (carrier pigeons! strikes! kidnappings!), as well as the not-so-subtle subtext being a woman during this time would have sucked (hurray for 1920 bringing with it our right to vote!). At the center of the story is Constance Kopp and her younger sisters, targets of a low-life factory owner and his cronies. How Kopp defies odds to take this man down after his automobile collides with the sisters’ buggy leads to her earning a badge as the country’s first female deputy sheriff. Made for a solid book club discussion—even if all of us agreed that Stewart's characters could have been rounded out a little more. ...more

title: Big Magic: Creative Living Beyond Fear
author: Gilbert, Elizabeth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Review from Second Reading, June 2023:A dear friend of mine (hi Jill!) had shared this month that she was re-reading Liz Gilbert's Big Magic and falliReview from Second Reading, June 2023:A dear friend of mine (hi Jill!) had shared this month that she was re-reading Liz Gilbert's Big Magic and falling back in love with its inspiring chapters. Given I am elbows deep in the middle of a big creative project of mine, I felt inspired to do the same—this time on audio—and boy oh boy, I was NOT disappointed. First off, Liz's voice is SO soothing. I could listen to her read me the phone book, but even better here ... it's a compilation of her thoughts on the magic (literally!) of creativity, which I wholeheartedly believe in myself.Just a few of the lines on this re-reading that I wanted to remember:"Do you have the courage to bring forth the treasures that are hidden within you?""The universe buries strange jewels deep within us all and then stands back to see if we can ever find them. The hunt to uncover those jewels, that's creative living. The courage to go on that hunt in the first place, that's what separates a mundane existence from a more enchanted one. The often surprising result of that hunt? That's what I call BIG MAGIC.""A creative life is an amplified life. It's a bigger life, a happier life, an expanded life, and a hell of a lot more interesting life. Living in this manner, continually, and stubbornly, bringing forth the jewels that are hidden within you, is a fine art in and of itself. Because creative living is where big magic will always abide." On the assistance of genius — "When that assistance does arrive ... the sense of the moving sidewalk beneath my words ... I am delighted and I go along for the ride. In such instances, I write like I am not quite myself....while it's happening, I thank the mystery for its help. And when it departs, I let the mystery go, and keep on working diligently anyhow, hoping that someday my genius will reappear. I work either way, assisted or unassisted, because that is what you must do in order to live a fully creative life. I work steadily, and I always thank the process, whether I am touched by grace or not, I thank creativity for allowing me to engage with it at all. Because either way, it's all kind of amazing, what we get to do, what we get to attempt, what we sometimes get to commune with ... gratitude always. Always gratitude." "Wake yourself up in the middle of the night in order to be alone with your inspiration while no one is watching...you don't need that sleep right now, you can give it up. What else are you willing to give up, in order to be alone with your beloved?""Do what you love to do, and do it with both seriousness and lightness, at least then you will know you have tried, and whatever the outcome, you have traveled the noble path."Review from First Reading, October 2015:For my creative soul at least, this book feels sort of sacred. Like, I could never do its pages justice. So many dog-earred corners, but here's a passage from one such page (and there are MANY)....was not prepared for how much this book would exceed my expectations!!"So take your insecurities and your fears and hold them upside down by their ankles and shake yourself free of all your cumbersome ideas about what you require ... in order to become creatively legitimate. Because I'm telling you that you are already creatively legitimate, but nature of your mere existence here among us."...more

review: I finished Lauren Groff's Fates and Furie in a bit of a literary stupor. How any writer can craft such an indepth plot with such spectacular words is I finished Lauren Groff's Fates and Furie in a bit of a literary stupor. How any writer can craft such an indepth plot with such spectacular words is truly behind me. The story of Lotto and Mathilda (two characters I will NEVER forget) is that of a happy marriage built on a mountain of secrets that, to the outside, appear as lies. My first instinct was this plot was going to revolve around an affair--I was shocked by the twists, surprises and where the story moved instead. author: Weiner, Jennifer*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm pretty sure it's a common refrain these days (and probably noted in other Weiner s on here) that the attention her feud with Jonathan FranzeI'm pretty sure it's a common refrain these days (and probably noted in other Weiner s on here) that the attention her feud with Jonathan Franzen has brought her has gained her more than a few fans.Count me among them."Who Do You Love" was my first book of hers (which happens to be her most recent) and I really enjoyed it. I was struck over the course of its pages how, the older I get, the more I'm softening for women's fiction. Call it chick lit, but, in my case, don't because I think it's a huge discredit to give such a leading label to talented writers like Weiner and others in her camp (which may one day include myself...seems like the stories calling to me in my brain are female-driven, often with a romantic element). What I enjoy most about Weiner's writing are her characters—I felt like I knew Rachel and Andy (admittedly, I might have had a crush on the latter myself) and that is a testament to her storytelling ability.What I've discovered in the past three years is that writing a book is damn hard work. To make people believable, to make readers want to turn the pages, to craft a plot tight enough that even with a few nods of predictability we want to keep living in it, is no small feat. For that reason alone, I'll keep reading Weiner's work (but her Twitter feed is a close second). ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really REALLY wanted to like this book more than I did. The plot started off so strong, sucking you in with the children of a couple discovering letI really REALLY wanted to like this book more than I did. The plot started off so strong, sucking you in with the children of a couple discovering letters from their father's lover before their mother gets ahold of them. Then it unravels because Pierpont seems to care more about style over substance—spending more time describing the world of her characters (so many little observations that, by the end, damn near pulled me out of the story) than fleshing out her characters.By the time I reached Part II (where she flashes forward in time), I wanted to throw the book across the room. The only reason I soldiered through Parts III and IV were because this was a book club read and it read so fast I knew I'd get to the end soon (and when I did, I cared little more for its characters than I did at its beginning). To me, my flat feelings about Pierpont's flashy debut reminded me of other MFA wunderkids whose work left me empty-hearted while everyone else (critics especially) gushed (ahem...Karen Russell...ahem...Tea Obreht). While I'm curious about her future work, I can't say I'm eager to dive into whatever she writes next. PS -- A fellow book clubber and I both agreed that had Pierpont used the last half of the book to delve into the world of the children (Simon and Kay) as adults, how the affair would have perhaps haunted them moving forward, then THAT would have been a much more interesting read. ...more

review: One of my favorite kind of reads is when an author centers a book around one person but tells his/her story through a cast of characters (with each geOne of my favorite kind of reads is when an author centers a book around one person but tells his/her story through a cast of characters (with each getting a chapter’s worth of perspective, a la Elizabeth Strout’s Olive Kitteridge). That’s exactly how J. Ryan Stradal’s incredible debut "Kitchens of the Great Midwest" unfolds. I picked it up because 1) that cover art (gorgeous, no?) and 2) it had Midwest in the title (Midwest tales have my <3) but the tale I discovered inside—about the young food prodigy Eva Thorvald who grows up to become the country’s most sought-after chef—had me turning the pages as fast as I could. Spot-on storytelling that makes for a perfect read for foodies, folks who love literary fiction, and anyone who appreciates plot lines with characters so real you feel like you personally know the people (ESPECIALLY if you grew up in the heartland). [And PS, the author dedicated this book to his mother, who died of cancer 10 years ago, but whose love of literature inspired her son to write one of the sweetest acknowledgments I’ve read yet]...more

review: Here's the thing: I knew after reading the last page of Commencement that I was going to keep reading Sullivan's work. (Matter of fact, I'm excited toHere's the thing: I knew after reading the last page of Commencement that I was going to keep reading Sullivan's work. (Matter of fact, I'm excited to pick up The Engagements here soon.) I say that first and foremost because what I loved best about this book is her talent. This story? At times? Ehhhh not so much.I mean, I loved the characters—Bree, Sally, April, and Celia. I loved that they were experiencing college together, sharing in 20-something memories that in many ways felt both familiar and real. And I also loved that they were four individuals who were totally flawed (because women, especially, are multi-faceted creatures, right?).What I didn't love? All the parts that read like Sullivan wrote her senior thesis at Smith College (where the book is set) ABOUT Smith College, then cut up the pages into strips she felt she had to insert into this book.In my view, its 400-plus pages would have greatly benefited from some cutting on the editorial side of things(at least 20 pages worth), most of it coming from the points about Smith that Sullivan insisted on making multiple times. Like how Smith is the Lesbian College Capital of the world. (Which, while likely true...at least according to the Google searching I felt compelled to do post-read, it still felt like this point in particular got crammed down our throats time and time again.) Overall, Sullivan a great author. This was her first novel (and it's at least 6-7 yrs old now, with two out since), so I'll be curious to see how her skills have evolved in subsequent reads. If her characters in those books are half as well-drawn as these four best friends, I'm sure to fall hard for them....more

review: It's so cool to be a writer befriending other writers--ones with too-legit-to-quit books on store shelves right next to other titles I've read and admIt's so cool to be a writer befriending other writers--ones with too-legit-to-quit books on store shelves right next to other titles I've read and admired over the years. Amy Reichert is one such writer. At Midwest Writers Workshop last month, we bonded over cider, Cards of Humanity and our fave rom-coms. The next day, I promptly bought (and had her autograph) a copy of her debut, The Coincidence of Coconut Cake. In the past three days (to use an apt metaphor), I devoured it! The story of Lou, a struggling chef with a restaurant sunk by a bad , and Al, the British import behind it, the novel is the unraveling of a meet-cute gone wrong. In Amy's deft hands, it ends up a sweetly told love story where everything turns out right. I'm SO proud of her! Seeing a Midwestern mama's dreams of publication come true is BEYOND inspiring. I highly recommend this read to all my lady friends--think of it as a foodie version of "You've Got Mail"! ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Most recently ed in December 2023:I was in grade school when my brother had to read To Kill a Mockingbird for his high school English class. He Most recently ed in December 2023:I was in grade school when my brother had to read To Kill a Mockingbird for his high school English class. He was never a strong reader on his own, so my mom used to read aloud to him to help him with his motivation and comprehension. Because of this, my introduction to Scout and Jem and Atticus happened when I was no older than eight years old. TKAMB made SUCH an impression on me, even as a kid ... that it's the reason why I knew I wanted to introduce it to my own kids at a young age, too. Dean and I finished reading this over the course of the month in which he turned 11 — and I never want to forget the light bulb moments he had as I read this story to him aloud, from recognizing the evilness of Bob Ewell before Lee made his cruelty fully known to what he whispered after I finished the penultimate chapter when Scout says hello to the shadowy stranger in the corner of Jem's bedroom ("Mom, I wasn't expecting it to be Boo Radley.")Another core memory to add to the list of reasons why TKAMB remains my all-time favorite novel—what a masterpiece. +++++++++++++++++++++++++++One of the few books I've read multiple times, TKAMB will forever remain (cliched though it is to admit) my all-time favorite book. This time when I read it, I paid particular attention to the structure of the narrative since, as a writer, that's what I've been studying so much over the summer. In that regard, TKAMB is a damn near perfect novel. Harper Lee hits all the beats at exactly where she's supposed to (inciting incident, midpoint, climax, resolution--eerily down to the page where these things should be taking place!) and each element is carried out so beautifully. Truly a masterpiece, no question....more

review: Paper Towns is a great example of how only John Green could write a John Green novel. Of his books I've read, I loved it most for the friendships it pPaper Towns is a great example of how only John Green could write a John Green novel. Of his books I've read, I loved it most for the friendships it portrays--not to mention all the humor. (Gosh that writer brain of his--he does sarcasm and teenage voice SO DAMN WELL). And yet, with every J.G. book, there is a moment that pulls me out of the story. And that moment is usually when I stumble over some kind of plot complexity that makes me think: Nope. Not even the SMARTEST 18-year-old thinks like this. For me with Paper Towns, it was the obsessing Q did over Walt Whitman's Leaves of Grass. Those passages where he dissects the poem felt more heavy-handed than the rest of the book (as if he was trying too hard to beat his readers over the head with his point), and yet they never overshadowed all the other moments of greatness that carried the story through (most notably the gas station stops along the way to find Margo in New York!). Things I want to remember most from PT: Confederate tees and black Santas...HA! Pretty sure Radar is one of my favorite teen boys in YA literature...Q and Ben too. Margo? Well, she's your definitive Manic Pixie Dream Girl. So, not so much. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm willing to admit that, prior to discovering the trailer for the recent 2015 film adaptation of Thomas Hardy's Far from the Madding Crowd, I had neI'm willing to admit that, prior to discovering the trailer for the recent 2015 film adaptation of Thomas Hardy's Far from the Madding Crowd, I had never even HEARD of FFTMC. So yeah, there's that. But one glimpse of the tranquil English countryside and that AMAZING cast that popped up on my computer and I knew I had to dig in to this classic read.It took me a while to get my bearings with the book's style (19th century British language obviously a far cry from the 140-character-driven dribble we spout off today), but I'm SO glad I stuck with it, because around 60 pages in (about the time Bathesheba sends Farmer Boldwood that ill-fated Valentine), I fell head over heels in love with FFTMC's storyline. (Which, for the unfamiliar, involves a headstrong girl who inherits her uncle's farm, and then is courted by three VERY different suitors—a shepherd, a farmer, and a dashing soldier).And finally let's not even get me started on the MAIN reason this book stole my heart.(Okay, but let's, shall we?:))GABRIEL OAK. GABRIEL OAK. GABRIEL OAK.Talk about your Grade A literary crush! (and here women are still gushing about Mr. Darcy!)Bear in mind, my Gabriel was the Gabriel of the 2015 film (the hunky Belgian actor Matthias Schoenaerts—https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Grr7b...) but I was darn near driven mad throughout much of the book, wanting Bathesheba to COME ON ALREADY and recognize just how well suited he was for her!I would love to say more about FFTMC's plot, but feel it's best (as it was for me) to go into it knowing little about all the twists and turns it delivers (and there are many!). But ohhhh how I loved the ending, and now I cannot get to a theater fast enough as reward....more

title: Simon vs. the Homo Sapiens Agenda        (Simonverse, #1)
author: Albertalli, Becky*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I finished this book three weeks ago and I'm STILL thinking about it. I can’t think of the last book I read—especially about teens—that felt so NOW. BI finished this book three weeks ago and I'm STILL thinking about it. I can’t think of the last book I read—especially about teens—that felt so NOW. Becky Albertalli has such a knack for capturing modern-day life (and speech), she's fast on her way to become the next Great Voice in YA Lit.Also? She is funny.as.hell. There were so many times I laughed out loud reading this book. The story she captures of a young Simon Spier, who’s being blackmailed by a classmate into coming out, is sweet yet filled with hilariously sarcastic undertones. The fact Simon is such a smartass is probably why we would get along if we met in real life.And yes, I said IF we were to meet in real life because I remain unconvinced (as I've seen others mention online) that Becky didn't just lift this entire story from the diary of a 16-year-old kid**Okay, I'm joking—Becky is just that good of a writer. But DANG. Seriously. It just felt SO REAL. (Like, as if you know all the characters, even the minor ones, which as a writer makes me go BUTHOWDIDSHEDOTHAT?) So go on, just read this book already. And then bust open a bag of Oreos when you're done because you will SERIOUSLY be craving them....more

review: I have too many s to catch up on here to give this the proper glowing treatment I normally would, but safe to say this is one of my FAVORITE reaI have too many s to catch up on here to give this the proper glowing treatment I normally would, but safe to say this is one of my FAVORITE reads of 2015. Judy captures the story of a cast of characters whose lives are rocked when three back-to-back plane crashes happen in their New Jersey town. She's done impeccable research into the era (1950s—and of course, perhaps a bit easier for her since she lived it!) and I loved learning her writer husband helped her craft the news stories in the book that were penned by her protagonist (Mimi)'s Uncle Henry Ammerman (one of my FAVORITE characters). I'm pretty sure only someone of Judy's talent could pull off what she's done here, juggling all the voices and storylines she had to carry through to the book's end. title: Why Not Me?
author: Kaling, Mindy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A three-act narrative  of Mindy's new book:Act One, wherein Gail cannot stop giggling: Diving back into a book written by Mindy (after reading hA three-act narrative  of Mindy's new book:Act One, wherein Gail cannot stop giggling: Diving back into a book written by Mindy (after reading her first book of essays back in '11) felt like picking up an inner monologue with an old friend. Maybe it's because I'm obsessed with her show, but I could "hear" Mindy reading these stories to me and it was such a pleasant reading experience for that reason alone. When I got to the chapter on things her friends should bring to her dinner party, I laughed out loud so hard I had tears in my eyes. Dang she's funny.Act Two, wherein Gail marvels at how Mindy does everything she does: Reading the essay about Mindy's work day (which starts at 5 am and ends at midnight) in between lulls in my own work day made me appreciate what a hustler she is. That girl PERSONIFIES ambition. And I love that she's not afraid to OWN that. Her knack is owning it in such a way that never makes her sound like a selfish, deranged nutcase (maybe it's because she's got a creative job? If a banker worked 20 hours a day, we'd call him/her a workaholic with a completely different connotation). Also, mid-way through the book is when I texted my friend a pic with an excerpt from an essay in which Mindy reveals the "sexiest thing that ever happened to her" and typed, "PLEASE LET THIS BE ABOUT CHRIS MESSINA". The read-between-the-lines-effect of this book? SO STRONG.Act Three, wherein Gail decides Mindy is the best in the biz at writing these tell-all-y memoirs: It was around the point I had my nose buried in the essay about Mindy revealing her short-lived fling with a member of President Obama's security team that I realized she's TRULY amazing at this--and by this, I mean this whole writing books thing. Then I thought, but why am I surprised by that? This is what she DOES for a living (versus some comedians whose memoirs have been less than stellar...ahem...Amy Poehler...ahemm) Anyway, I loved Mindy's command of her material, how she gives the rub to people who have pissed her off (she BURNS a Vanity Fair reporter for an unflattering food-related portrayal of her in an article he wrote about her years ago), how she's funny and REAL, and how you can just tell these essays were easy for her to write (they had to be—she must have wrote them in the four hours a day she wasn't at work!)In short (ha! the irony, given everything I wrote above), this new book of Mindy's does NOT disappoint. I'm already clambering for the third one (until then, I'll settle for the new season of The Mindy Project and fighting for the title of president of her fan club)...more

title: Thirteen Reasons Why
author: Asher, Jay*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I know there's a lot of people who love this YA book (and I have a hunch it's destined to be a classic) but I just couldn't love it in the same way. II know there's a lot of people who love this YA book (and I have a hunch it's destined to be a classic) but I just couldn't love it in the same way. I don't know if it's because suicide feels like such a played out plot device in YA (even though I have a feeling this is the book that started the trend) or if I just had a hard time believing SO much awful stuff could happen to one girl, but my hang-ups were enough for this quick read to land only a so-so  from me. I did, however, appreciate the unique format of the novel. The obvious example being the playing of the tapes as a dual story to the narrative of one of their recipients, the innocent Clay Jensen. But what I'm actually referring to is how this entire story plays out over the course of a single evening. I couldn't think of another book I'd read in recent memory to do this (ever), let alone as well as Jay Asher did here.And while it may sound like I'm sort of shitting on this book, I don't want that to be anyone's final take-away. I think what it's done for thousands of readers (giving them hope and saving their lives) is wonderful. As proof, consider this EW article with the author: http://www.ew.com/article/2011/06/13/......more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "When we confront the things we own, they evoke many emotions within us. It is these emotions that give us the energy for living. Believe what your he"When we confront the things we own, they evoke many emotions within us. It is these emotions that give us the energy for living. Believe what your heart tells you when you ask, 'Does this spark joy?' Putting your house in order is the magic that creates a vibrant and happy life." I bought “The Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up" about a year ago but purposefully held off on reading it until I knew I was at a point with creative projects and life overall that I would be up for the challenge of a mega-purge. Two weeks and 18 bags of stuff hauled out of my home later, I can't even begin to tell you how much of a proponent I am of this woman and her methods (which, interestingly enough, her popularity grew in leaps after the '11 Japanese tsunami ... it makes sense, doesn't it? A whole nation of people needing to pare down in the wake of disaster and needing someone to help them do it. Marie is so huge in her native country now they call her the Beyonce of tidying!) Note: I get that there are some mega eye-roll moments to this read. For instance, I will never talk to my possessions, I will never fold my socks, and I will never unpack my bag every night when I get home from work. But, that aside, I am such a proponent for tidying your house and its effects on your life that I'm willing to look past these kookier elements of Kondo's philosophy to appreciate the greater results she aims for with her method). ...more

title: The Game of Love and Death
author: Brockenbrough, Martha*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Back in July, Martha Brockenbrough was one of the faculty members we brought in for our 2015 Midwest Writers Workshop here in Muncie (where I live). IBack in July, Martha Brockenbrough was one of the faculty members we brought in for our 2015 Midwest Writers Workshop here in Muncie (where I live). I sat in on her session on writing and as she spoke, I felt an actual thrill run through my body—to me, she was that inspiring of a writer.Which is why I had high hopes for this read and in NO way was I disappointed as I devoured this beautiful book of hers—one that has snagged a slew of awards and nominations in 2015 for being one of the best YA books of the year.Only, I found myself wondering, IS this book YA? It is and it isn't, in the sense these characters of Henry and Flora (he's white; she's black) are young pawns in a twisted game of fate between the immortal characters of Love and Death in a story that transcends any genre I could think of ... instead it read like a wholly original book that was its own dream-within-reality genre. Combine a great story with rich history (its setting is in the 1930s); wonderful musical knowledge (Martha is a musician and clearly knows her subject material); and vivid descriptions of Seattle (where she lives) and for me, this was a high-stakes story I couldn't put down. It's gotten a lot of comparisons to The Book Thief (that whole Death as a character bit) but while it didn't feel anything like it to me, I believe fans who love Markus Zusack would also love Martha's prose. And here, from the Kirkus Review, which pretty much sums up my thoughts about the book (the "luscious prose" part especially): Kirkus Reviews (starred)A lovingly realized Depression-era Seattle becomes the field of play for the latest round in the titular, age-old game. In February 1920, Love and Death choose their newest pawns as infants: Love's is Henry, a white boy of privilege; Death's is Flora, the soon-to-be-orphaned daughter of African-American jazz musicians. Brockenbrough's precise, luscious prose cuts back and forth among the four protagonists. Race, class, fate and choice... join Love and Death to play their parts in Brockenbrough's haunting and masterfully orchestrated narrative....more

title: The Martian
author: Weir, Andy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I finished this book on a Thursday, then stumped HARD the next night for my book club to read it. I'm excited my campaigning paid off, making this ourI finished this book on a Thursday, then stumped HARD the next night for my book club to read it. I'm excited my campaigning paid off, making this our next pick, because I'm really looking forward to talking more about "The Martian"'s edge-of-your-seat plot with these women (and will be similarly gunning for them to come with me to see the film since I'm already obsessed with its cast!)To counter my positivity about the book, I *do* understand the criticisms lobbed against it. Its geektastic exposition is cumbersome at times and yet, once the plot expanded beyond this one guy's story of being stuck on Mars (incorporating everything that was happening back on Earth to try and save him), then I couldn't put the book down. I anxiously speed-read my way to the end to see what would happen to this brilliant, goofy astronaut who'd been stranded alone on the Red Planet for more than a year. As I was talking about "The Martian" with a girlfriend, I summed up my feelings about it with the following anecdote: There once was a generation of men and women that, on a hot summer night in 1970 (and if you're a Mad Men viewer, you just saw a version of this play out on the small screen), held its breath collectively as it watched an astronaut safely take man's first steps on the moon. Not since that fateful night has there been a story so massive, on such a POSITIVE (plenty of negative to counter this) scale, to capture the world's attention. Which is why this particular odyssey of one Mark Watney gave me a bright, shining glimpse of what a moment like that to come might be like. If all of us would set aside our differences amid the trials of the day--war and famine and drugs and poverty and politics among them--and join together to express collective hope for a mission that by then would stand for so much more than the science involved. Wouldn't that be something truly amazing to witness? ...more

title: So You've Been Publicly Shamed
author: Ronson, Jon
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In college, I read Jon Ronson's "Them" and quickly became a fan of his quirky coverage of a fascinating topic (conspiracy theorists). For years, I'd bIn college, I read Jon Ronson's "Them" and quickly became a fan of his quirky coverage of a fascinating topic (conspiracy theorists). For years, I'd been meaning to read his latest, "So You've Been Publicly Shamed," but never got around to it. Then 2018 happened, a year that's made me think hard about the topic of public shaming in the Internet age. A year when I realized that, when it comes to the web, most people are no match for the cruelty of the "online herd"—particularly people who love to wield virtual pitchforks on Twitter. People prone to firing off 140-character "truths" that are retweeted in unhealthy feedback loops that—fairly or unfairly—feed the outrage cycle of the Internet. At the same time I read this book, I read an interview with the writer Sloane Crosley who put it best when she said: "We live in a world right now that's rewarding the loudest voices, no matter what they're saying." A sad reality that, in my own experiences, has proven true....more

title: It's What I Do: A Photographer's Life of Love and War
author: Addario, Lynsey
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The photographer in me loved this book. Granted, my experience with the medium is of the light and lovely variety—weddings, families, babies. None of The photographer in me loved this book. Granted, my experience with the medium is of the light and lovely variety—weddings, families, babies. None of the war, famine, and kidnappings Lynsey Addario encounters in her storied (ha!) career. This was an audio book for me, which made it a bit more of a slog (I can't get to those as easy), but in every snippet I listened to, there was always the thrill of adventure to keep me going. The mother in me, however, had some hang-ups with the book. Not that I don't appreciate Addario's commitment to her career (I'm a proud career parent herself), but shooting as far as she did into her pregnancy, in some incredibly dangerous situations, made me uncomfortable in the sense that I could have never jeopardized my son that way had I been in her shoes. Fascinating read overall (particularly loved hearing how she discovers her husband is a count!)...more

title: A Little Life
author: Yanagihara, Hanya*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The only reason I didn’t bawl like a baby reading the last 30 pages of “A Little Life” is because I finished it in the car with my husband driving andThe only reason I didn’t bawl like a baby reading the last 30 pages of “A Little Life” is because I finished it in the car with my husband driving and I hate crying in front of people (even him). But people, this book. THIS BOOK. Shew. One of the few times in my reading life I needed a day of transition to ease my way out of it and back into reality. Once you dive into the world of Jude, JB, Willem and Malcolm, you, too, might have to claw your way back out (sometimes willingly, like when the writing gets darker than dark, and other times, like when you’re living in its many, many happier pages, less so). I can’t quite describe what it is about Yanagihara’s writing that felt so inescapable, but clearly I’m not alone. Consider what The New Yorker had to say: “Yanagihara’s novel can drive you mad, consume you, and take over your life. Like the axiom of equality, “A Little Life” feels elemental, irreducible—and, dark and disturbing though it is, there is beauty in it.” It’s this beauty that critic Jon Michaud writes of that sustains you as you read “A Little Life.” There are passages so magnificently crafted you want to read them twice, memories shared by these friends you want to claim as your own, and a feeling throughout that you are in the hands of an immensely talented writer who never tries to be clever about the story she is telling (if you love character-driven stories, then you will LOVE her writing). I might also add that Yanagihara’s knowledge and research of so much—medicine, art, music, architecture, and law to name but a few—is one more reason this book is so beautiful, jaw-droppingly so at times. Yet (as some of you might know), there are also a LOT of scenes that delve into Jude’s tortured past, episodes so difficult to read (some of the hardest subject material I’ve come across in fiction) that you might (as I did) have to take a break to compose yourself enough to go on. If you do, that’s okay. Chances are great you’ll come back to the story because “A Little Life” is a marathon read that demands to be finished. When you finally get there, don’t be surprised if you turn around and give your partner a hug or get up and call your oldest friend. I did the same thing myself.A few other observations:• I would go see JB’s retrospective in a heartbeat. Williem Listening to Jude Tell A Story… I just …. I CAN’T EVEN [insert bawling faced emoticon here]• The Little Life Instagram account is fascinating to follow—insights from the author and scenes of NYC that correlate with the book…those pics of Lispenard Street fascinate and gut me at the same time: https://www.instagram.com/alittlelife...• When you read widely and often, you’re always seeking characters who will live with you long after the page—some for days and months, others for years. This NYC foursome is a “years” kind of cast. Should I ever hear of anyone cutting themselves, I will forever think of Jude. When I spy an architectural model, I’ll think of Malcolm. And if the scent of sandalwood happens to be in the air, I will (so fondly and wistfully) remember my favorite HY character, Willem.• Does anyone else want to be adopted by Harold and Julia too? And for that matter, join me in the I Hate Caleb club?• Lastly, if I had one fault with the book it was that, in Jude’s final scenes, his memories felt repetitive and never-ending. A friend of mine who read it at the same time (so many texts exchanged b/wn us over various OMG plot points!) speculated that perhaps this was intentional—Jude is an insufferable character in so many ways, it may have been a case of the writing reenforcing this right up until the end. (Also, a grammatical aside: Anyone else feel there were instances of misplaced modifiers multiple times in this book? I think it was the all-male cast that led to this but sometimes I was like, what ‘he’ are you talking about?!)To end on—if you, like me, want to talk about, read about, obsess over this book, hit me up in the comments, but also see:Vulture: How I Wrote My Novel: http://www.vulture.com/2015/04/how-ha...Wall Street Journal: How Little Life Became a Sleeper Hit: http://www.wsj.com/articles/a-little-...Slate’s Interview with HY: http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/bo...HY’s Late Night appearance: http://www.nbc.com/late-night-with-se...Bustle: 18 Quotes from ‘A Little Life’ That Are So Relatable It’s Unreal: http://www.bustle.com/articles/68505-...The Atlantic: A Little Life—the Great Gay Novel Might Be Here: http://www.theatlantic.com/entertainm.......more

title: Creativity, Inc.: Overcoming the Unseen Forces That Stand in the Way of True Inspiration
author: Catmull, Ed
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Hands down one of the best business books I've ever read (granted, that number isn't all that many). But for people who work in a creative environmentHands down one of the best business books I've ever read (granted, that number isn't all that many). But for people who work in a creative environment (as I do as a writer, sitting alongside designers, web, and marketing professionals), there were so many brilliant lessons to be had in this book, including relatable no-nos in the corporate sphere that I have experienced first-hand in my career. I loved this book so much I've been advocating for it to be purchased for everyone in our office. If it comes through, I look forward to leading discussions about all the rich lessons I learned from it and want to apply in my own workplace. Bonus that intermixed with all that biz knowledge is Catmull's rich history of Pixar—as a HUGE Pixar fan, I was totally transfixed!Also fascinating to read how much of a savior Steve Jobs was for this company. I listened to this as an audio book, which was a minor downfall because I couldn't underline things or take notes the way I wanted (hence 4 stars instead of 5). But the last chapter summarizes the book well (so I can always return to it) and there were plenty of finds on the web of wrap-ups of the book. Here are some that summarize its chapters well — the lesson on CANDOR was particularly rewarding:https://getlighthouse.com/blog/ed-cat...http://www.inc.com/bill-carmody/impor...http://www.wheretowatch.com/2014/05/l......more

review: Are you missing a good rom com/rom dram in your life? Because, until I picked up this book, I hadn't realized how much I had been. You know what I meaAre you missing a good rom com/rom dram in your life? Because, until I picked up this book, I hadn't realized how much I had been. You know what I mean, right? Like, where have all the good chick flicks gone? I've lost interest in watching them play out on screen (probably because there are so few options these days!), so I was all too happy to pick up Taylor Jenkins Reid's newest, Maybe in Another Life. The Sliding Doors-ish story of 29-year-old Hannah Martin captured my attention right from the get-go. I loved the dual ways Reid carried the story through to the end, hooking readers with plot lines involving Hannah and two VERY different men. The book had me craving cinnamon rolls, obsessing over top knots, and smiling at the way Reid deftly managed to bring both of Hannah's "lives" to satisfying ends. One of those rare reads that had me up until 2 am—I couldn't put it down because I had to find out what happened to this flawed but lovable protagonist! ...more

title: Station Eleven
author: Mandel, Emily St. John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I lost count of the number of people who recommended Station Eleven to me before I finally was able to get around to reading it. My book club selectedI lost count of the number of people who recommended Station Eleven to me before I finally was able to get around to reading it. My book club selected it for its March pick and I have to say, I think it made for maybe the best discussion we’ve ever had.In large part, that's thanks to Emily St. John’s flair for storytelling: Station Eleven is an incredible work of literary fiction that follows a cast of characters on the eve of a virus that decimates the globe. (It’s also masterfully told in nonlinear fashion which is no small feat for a writer to pull off!) What all of us in our club touched on was how the book just doesn’t let you go. How we found ourselves thinking about it even when we weren’t reading it (and long after)—how we would fare in a world in which there is no more Internet or air conditioning or a thousand other modern conveniences St. John Mandel points out (in haunting language) are no longer available to people after civilization collapses. (For me, a particularly disturbing scene involved a character who no longer had access to his glasses and thus had become a stunted version of himself because he was basically blind; as someone with horrific vision, this deeply affected me, the idea of living in a world where you remembered sight but no longer had access to the things that helped you see — or, as she touches on, what about those who lose access to life-saving medications? Well..she answers that too: They die, of course.) It’s this unsettling, overarching plot paired so beautifully (and brilliantly) with some great subplots (Station Eleven refers to a graphic novel that has enormous significance to multiple characters throughout the course of the narrative) that make you understand why this was one of the most buzzed about books of last year. ...more

A memory about a Midwestern man raised in a fundamentalist family who loses his faith along the way and, in growing up, gets his heart broken for the first time by a beautiful girl he meets at church camp named Raina. I wanted to read it all in one night (conquered it in two) because having Craig’s words paired with his incredible visuals felt cinematic somehow (and who doesn’t watch a movie in one sitting?) title: Lean In: Women, Work, and the Will to Lead
author: Sandberg, Sheryl
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There's a phrase mentioned in Sheryl Sandberg’s Lean In (about three-fourths through the book) that I just fell in love with: “career-loving parent”.TThere's a phrase mentioned in Sheryl Sandberg’s Lean In (about three-fourths through the book) that I just fell in love with: “career-loving parent”.THAT is what I am. Let’s forget this “working mom” stuff. Because it’s a word that seems to come with a LOT of baggage and quite frankly, I’m sick of it. “Working mom” has this icky connotation to it, a leaves-a-bitter-taste-in-your-mouth sentiment that can make women feel guilty for taking pride in not only bringing value to a workplace, but also their home. So I think the next time someone asks me about being a “working mom”, I’m going to rephrase things. I’ll tell them I’m a “career-loving parent” who, as journalist Mary Curtis (quoted in Lean In) describes, “is just doing the best she can with what she’s got.” That’s life as a parent with an 8-to-5 job in a nutshell.Many kernels of wisdom from this book I can see slipping into future conversations I have with friends. Here are a few I wanted to remember:• Women rarely make one big decision to leave the workforce. Instead, they make a lot of small decisions along the way, making accommodations and sacrifices they believe will be required to have a family. Of all the ways women hold themselves back, perhaps the most pervasive is that they leave before they leave.• The cost for two children (an infant and four year old) to go to a day care center is greater than the annual median rent payment in every state in the country (AKA, why Nick and I don’t have a second child yet)• (these next few are from the great chapter “Make Your Partner a Real Partner”): Whenever a married woman asks me for advice on co-parenting with a husband, I tell her to let him put the diaper on the baby any way he wants as long as he’s doing it himself. And if he gets up to deal with the diaper before being asked, she should smile even if he puts the diaper on the baby’s head. Over time, if he does things his way, he’ll find the correct end. But if he’s forced to do things her way, pretty soon she’ll be doing them herself. (SUCH TRUTH TO THIS; at so many points in this book, I found myself being SO grateful to a husband who truly splits this parenting gig 50-50 with me)• When looking for a life partner, my advice to women is date all of them: the bad boys, the cool boys … the crazy boys. But don’t marry them. The things that make the bad boys sexy do not make them good husbands. When it comes time to settle down, find someone who wants an equal partner. Someone who thinks women should be smart, opinionated, and ambitious. Someone who values fairness and expects, or even better, WANTS to do his share in the home. These men exist, and trust me, over time, nothing is sexier. (AMEN SHERYL!!!)• Research supports when husbands do more housework, wives are less depressed, marital conflicts decrease, and satisfaction rises. When women work outside the home and share breadwinning duties, couples are more like to stay together. In fact, divorce rates reduce by about half when a wife earns half the income and a husband does half the housework (FASCINATING).• Today, stay-at-home moms spend about 17 hours per week on primary child care, on average, while mothers working outside the house spend eleven. This means an employed mom today spends about the same amount of time on primary child care activities as a non-employed mom did in 1975. (YESSSSSSS!!! So glad to come across research that validates this opinion I've had. Growing up, my mom stayed at home, but I don’t remember her being crazy hands-on with me—Sheryl attests to a similar childhood…I’m actually a bit overwhelmed at the extent/way many moms parent today…this helicopter madness doesn’t feel healthy to me nor does it allow a child the kind of opportunities to grow their imagination on their own)• Sheryl quotes several studies that are reaffirming to working moms. The key finding being: “Exclusive maternal care was not related to better or worse outcomes for children. There is thus no reason for mothers to feel as though they are harming their children if they decide to work.”• The best advice anyone can offer is "for women and men to drop the guilt trip, even as the minutes tick away. The secret is there is no secret-just doing the best you can with what you’ve got.” (I feel like I need to get this printed as a poster to hang in my house) ...more
