title: Everything I Never Told You
author: Ng, Celeste*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: First things first: This book is written by Celeste Ng and it's pronounced ING (which just so happens to be her clever Twitter handle: https://twitterFirst things first: This book is written by Celeste Ng and it's pronounced ING (which just so happens to be her clever Twitter handle: https://twitter.com/pronounced_ing). So why bother starting this  off with this? Because if you're like me, when you start telling everyone and their brother about this book, you'll owe it to the author not only to remember her name, but how to say it correctly.Within the first few pages of "Everything" I knew I was going to love Ng's writing style: Her prose is effortless, uncomplicated, but IMPECCABLY written. There's also just enough detail mixed in--and it's the RIGHT kind of detail, the kind that makes you wish you were as observant as she is. At 292 pages, "Everything" almost felt TOO short --which again is a testament to Ng's writing. That while it's actually an appropriate length for a novel, it reads in that I-can't-put-this-down sort of way that happens with the best of books. (Which IMO is an even bigger accomplishment given the genre this falls under--literary fiction).Another way I knew I loved this book? I slowed down reading it as I neared its end. You ever do that? Try and live in a great book a little longer by putting off its last few pages? Which to me says even MORE about Ng's talent when the narrative is as bleak as this is. "Everything" tells the story of the Lee family, Chinese Americans living in rural Ohio: father James, who's a professor fearing he's fallen short (in life in general); wife Marilyn, who's living with the ghost of becoming her domesticated mother; and their three children, Nath, Lydia, and Hannah. Within the first few sentences, you know that Lydia is the favorite child and that she happens to be dead. But it's the way the fallout of her drowning affects the rest of the family that makes for the real surprises in this story. Like I said, remember Ng's name. I have no doubt, with a debut as great as this, you'll be hearing it again. For those of us she can call fans, hopefully soon....more

title: Go Set a Watchman
author: Lee, Harper
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: UPDATE (August 7): I came across this profile of Lee's editor, Tay Hohoff, and it is an absolute MUST read for anyone who finished Watchman and, like UPDATE (August 7): I came across this profile of Lee's editor, Tay Hohoff, and it is an absolute MUST read for anyone who finished Watchman and, like me, thought, who is the INCREDIBLE editor who helped Lee shape this first draft into Mockingbird? Fascinating: http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/13/boo...Here's a passage from Watchman that, late in the book, made the hair on the back my neck stand up:“I wonder what would happen if the South had a ‘Be Kind to Niggers Week’? If just for one week the South would show them some simple, impartial courtesy…Do you think it’d give ‘em airs or the beginnings of self-respect? Have you ever been snubbed, Atticus? Do you know how it feels? Don’t tell me they’re children and don’t feel it: I was a child and felt it too, so grown children must feel, too. A real good snub, Atticus, makes you feel like you’re too nasty to associate with people. How they’re as good as they are now is a mystery to me, after a hundred years of systematic denial that they’re human. I wonder what kind of miracle we could make work with a week’s decency."That's a grown up Jean Louise Finch giving it to Atticus for his regressive views on race. In so many ways, coming to those lines made plowing through the rest of this messy first draft worth it. This much-maligned book is unquestionably an editorial disaster (lots of POV switch ups, rambling monologues, and lengthy backstories--an undisciplined first draft at best) and yet, I’m glad I dove in to it. It’s a shame Lee’s not one for interviews—I would love to hear her take on how Watchman’s message of racial unrest is as relevant today as it was all those years ago when she wrote it. ...more

title: The Girl on the Train
author: Hawkins, Paula*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Is "The Girl on the Train" destined to be the Blockbuster Breakout of 2015? It's sure shaping up to be. I've gotta admit, now that I stayed up late laIs "The Girl on the Train" destined to be the Blockbuster Breakout of 2015? It's sure shaping up to be. I've gotta admit, now that I stayed up late last night, then rose early this morning to finish (in that delicious hour before anyone else, when reading feels like the guiltiest pleasure), HECK YEAH IT IS. All the buzz for this is that it's the "next Gone Girl" and it's an apt comparison. Only instead of one unreliable female narrator, Paula Hawkins' gives us three--all great, all wanting something different and yet, in so many ways, the same thing. There is Rachel, the drunk who starts the story with her keen observations aboard her daily train into London; Megan, the woman Rachel sees from the train whose life she fantasizes about (though for reasons she'll soon discover, shouldn't); and Anna, the one who unites them, whose philandering gives her what she wants yet will burn her in the end.The book is fast-paced and leaves you guessing until a point where, even though you suspect the outcome, you still plow through to find out how Hawkins takes you to the end. As I often do, I read some articles on the book and discovered the author sold "The Girl on the Train" on a partial manuscript (fewer than 100 pages and an outline): If you're unfamiliar with how the publishing world works, you should know this is EXTREMELY rare. Meaning her agent and her editors all knew she was on to something (and what a satisfying something it was--particularly that ending...I loved the last line and the way it brought the story full-circle).In interviews she gives, Hawkins seems surprised at the book's success, but she should hold on--the buzz is only going to build from here. As the bookseller in this article noted, “The Girl on the Train is intense, and it’s in an Internet sense ‘shareable ...by that I mean, once you read it you want your friends to read it too so you can talk about it. Once a book becomes viral like that, there’s no slowing it down.” (Source: http://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/b...)So yeah, prepare yourself to hear a LOT about this one, if you haven't already. And if you want to talk about it afterward, well, I'm all ears!...more

title: The Autobiography of Mrs. Tom Thumb
author: Benjamin, Melanie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was our most recent book club pick and while I wouldn't have gotten to it any other way were it not, I did find it an easy read that went quicklyThis was our most recent book club pick and while I wouldn't have gotten to it any other way were it not, I did find it an easy read that went quickly. Did I love it? Not particularly. I found the character of "Vinnie” Bump (aka Mrs Tom Thumb) too spiteful for my liking, which made it hard for me to sympathize with her in the many challenging situations she found herself in (which was often, given her diminutive height).What I did love about it was Benjamin's research into the era the book was set--the late 1800s. I was quite fascinated to learn of P.T. Barnum's career BEFORE his circus empire (which didn't get under way until he was in his 60s), and how General Tom Thumb was the wee catalyst who launched his entire career. (Which meant I spent a solid hour or so on Google after finishing, reading up on his American Museum and others whose showbiz careers he groomed, ie Jenny Lindh)I would recommend this to those who love a good work of historical fiction, or to anyone fascinated by circuses, freak shows, or the many changes that accompanied the turn of the 20th century.  ...more

As a Christian myself, I can appreciate this and think the Biblical filters she uses in the chapters are solid ones. (For those who prefer a little less God with their time management lessons, see this: https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/1...)Personally, I had a LOT of takeaways from "Best Yes," especially since, now that I'm motivated to pursue my passion for writing more than ever before, I need to be making the kinds of wise decisions that eliminate unnecessary distractions taking me away from it. While occasionally TerKeurst's writing smacked a bit on the cutesy side, I loved so many of her messages I was able to overlook those passages that grated on me most. title: The Oldest Living Things in the World
author: Sussman, Rachel A.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Did I read all of this? No, but enough to recognize it's an incredible coffee table book. I gifted it to my father-in-law over the holidays knowing I Did I read all of this? No, but enough to recognize it's an incredible coffee table book. I gifted it to my father-in-law over the holidays knowing I would be able to sneak in time to read chunks of it on my own. It was incredible to learn more about the organisms Sussman has discovered and compiled so beautifully here alongside essays speaking to their capacity to withstand the test of time. I'd say the essay that moved me most was her piece on The Senator, a 3,500-year-old cypress in Florida. As Sussman wrote, she was spending so much time traveling the globe, working feverishly to capture the images and words she needed for the book, that she continually put off getting a newer (better) image of The Senator. (Her family lived in Florida and so she'd adopted the "Ahhh I can always get around to it" mindset with it). Until her goal was erased by a 26-year-old meth head who lit up inside its hollow trunk, burning it to the ground (see this related article: http://gizmodo.com/5889581/meth-addic...)The tragedy was a powerful reminder that these things that are ancient, which we may think will last forever, are as vulnerable today as they have always been. All the more reason to appreciate them now before they are gone for good. ...more

title: Not That Kind of Girl: A Young Woman Tells You What She's "Learned"
author: Dunham, Lena*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "Not That Kind of Girl" was such a yin yang reading experience for me. On the one hand, here is what I greatly admire about Ms. Dunham: The woman can "Not That Kind of Girl" was such a yin yang reading experience for me. On the one hand, here is what I greatly admire about Ms. Dunham: The woman can WRITE. It wasn't as if I didn't expect this, I just didn't anticipate being so blown away by her command of the English language (as well her knowledge about soo many things, from the random to the obscure). On the other hand, there were a LOT of passages that made me squirm: her recounting of her first masturbatory experience; the youthful touching of her sister while the two shared a bed--which, though it made me uncomfortable, in NO WAY did I consider it abuse, as critics have alleged; and that time she outed her sister. (Writers who turn a family member's challenges/decisions into their own always make me twitch a bit; see David Sedaris on this as well). Maybe it's because she's still young and eager to prove herself, but Dunham's work in this collection feels unnecessarily coated in a sticky layer of shock value. To me, the infuriating thing is she's a brilliant enough writer it doesn't need to be! And while in no way do her life experiences smack anything close to mine, I still found myself captivated by the "lessons" she's learned along the way. I look forward to seeing where her literary career takes her from here.PS - I have developed such an "Awww" crush on her coupling with the cute, talented Jack Antonoff. PPS - I really need to start watching "Girls" even if, much like Lena's book, in no way will I find Hannah's life experiences applicable to those of my own. ...more

title: All the Light We Cannot See
author: Doerr, Anthony*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: From the first page of All the Light We Cannot See, you know you're reading the work of a master of language. Doerr makes what he does seem so effortlFrom the first page of All the Light We Cannot See, you know you're reading the work of a master of language. Doerr makes what he does seem so effortless, enthralling readers with his well-chosen words in this harrowing but beautifully wrought World War II saga. The book interweaves the lives of a young blind French girl (Marie Laure) and German solider/tinkerer (Werner), capturing their wartime experiences and moral struggles leading up to their suspenseful encounter on the Brittany coast.I listened to this book on audio and what a treasure it was to have Doerr's rich prose spoken in my ear. It was as close a novel to poetry that I think I've ever read, certain sentences making me pause and hit rewind so I could savor them once more. I cannot recommend this read highly enough. For anyone who thinks "Another war book? Gail...I don't know if I can do it..." TRUST ME this one is worth it. Doerr gives such a fresh historical take on the era you'll be staying up late into the night wanting to finish.And when you do, "bereft the last page has been finished" (Booklist), then you can console yourself by reading these articles I greatly enjoyed: The Millions: A World Made of Words: On Anthony Doerr's Words and Verbs— http://www.themillions.com/2015/01/a-...Tweed's Magazine Interview with Doer on the book (which was 10 years (!!) in the making): http://tweedsmag.org/interview-anthon......more

title: Fourth of July Creek
author: Henderson, Smith
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There's this Twitter account I follow, Guy in Your MFA (https://twitter.com/guyinyourmfa), and about midway through "Fourth of July Creek," I couldn'tThere's this Twitter account I follow, Guy in Your MFA (https://twitter.com/guyinyourmfa), and about midway through "Fourth of July Creek," I couldn't help but think Smith Henderson could be THAT guy! Now, don't get me wrong: "Fourth" is a spectacular book in many, many ways (and for being a debut, all the more so). But the critical reader in me was taken out of the story too many times by what I can best summarize as the extent of "try" I felt Henderson put into the book.Two examples: his decision to include second person in the occasional passages told from protagonist Pete Snow's POV (see: https://twitter.com/guyinyourmfa/stat...) and also, the way he needed to make the rugged landscape of Montana as emotionally (over)descriptive as he did, as if it were an extension of his characters' feelings (see: https://twitter.com/GuyInYourMFA/stat...)As I often do with new authors I'm interested in, I read up about Smith Henderson before I read his book. In this case, that might have been a bad thing. Because I found out he works for an ad agency, one for which he was part of the team that wrote the copy for that Clint Eastwood commercial, "It's Half-Time in America" (see: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nRRJx...). Once I knew that, I couldn't keep that macho style of writing from leaking into my head as I was reading. Knowing Henderson worked on that project (which is awesome, yeah, but I feel a tad overwrought too), I could see so much of the same footprint in style here. Not saying that's a bad thing, but for me, there was too much of a yearning of "I Want This To Be The Next Great American Novel" to make it so.PS - If you decide to read it, consider buying a bottle of whiskey to imbibe as you do...this book has the taste of a man who reads Esquire written all over it. ...more

review: As soon as I spotted the  for this book that painted Tommy Wallach's debut as "a literary Breakfast Club for a modern generation" I knew immediaAs soon as I spotted the  for this book that painted Tommy Wallach's debut as "a literary Breakfast Club for a modern generation" I knew immediately I had to read it ('80s brat that I am). So glad I did as "We All Looked Up" will be one of my most memorable reads of 2015, particularly in the YA genre. Its plot--an unlikely friendship forged among four high school seniors trying to come to terms with the world-ending likelihood of a giant asteroid crashing into Earth--is genius and Tommy's writing really beautiful. My only complaint (and it's not a criticism) is how I finished it (in bed, at 5 am, having last put it down at midnight the night before) feeling incredibly melancholy (particularly in relationship to the outcome of one of the major characters, a personal favorite of mine). Seeing as how many of my favorite books leave me feeling this same way, I'm still beyond happy to have read it. Highly recommend--particularly for a smart summer read. ...more

review: Let me preface this by saying that Jandy Nelson is one of those writers for which you can say "Even if it's not your favorite read, anything she writeLet me preface this by saying that Jandy Nelson is one of those writers for which you can say "Even if it's not your favorite read, anything she writes is better than 99 percent of what's out there". I read "I'll Give You the Sun" first and maybe that was my problem -- the bar was raised WAY too high. In fairness, writers aim to get better with each book. If that's the case, Jandy went from an A with this debut of hers to an A+++++ (like that teacher of Ralphie's in A Christmas Story) with "Sun." Again, poetry is everywhere in Sky. As is Jandy's incredible lyrical prose. But something about this storyline (about a young girl mourning her sister's death and dealing with her complicated feelings for her sister's boyfriend while at the same time, her affection for the French kid who's new in town) just didn't grab me the same. I found myself putting it down often and while it was easy to get back in to, it wasn't the reading experience that was "Sun." To come back to the first point I raised, however, it's still WONDERFUL and I highly recommend. And I'll finish the thought with, good heavens, I cannot WAIT to see what this woman puts out next! ...more

review: Oh MAN did I have high hopes for this book. See, Meg Wolitzer's The Interestings is one of my favorite reads in recent memory. I felt something with tOh MAN did I have high hopes for this book. See, Meg Wolitzer's The Interestings is one of my favorite reads in recent memory. I felt something with that book in such a major way that nothing I read after lived up to it (for months!)I can't say I felt the same about her first foray into YA. Belzhar started off so promising ... I was really into the plot, about a young girl heartbroken by a lost love who gets sent to a residential boarding school (boy East Coasters LOVE those, don't they?) to get over it. There she becomes friends with a band of other misfits of misfortune, all enrolled in a life-changing Special Topics of English class. Parts of this book were written well (she does setting and dialogue especially well), but other parts felt out of touch and trope-y (especially as it went on). Then, God, the ending—-WHAT A LETDOWN. I finished the book and actually wanted to make this sound: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5atPY... I can't say I won't read Wolitzer again, but I hope she goes back to what she knows best. title: Yes Please
author: Poehler, Amy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It pains me to feel so half-hearted about Amy Poehler's much-hyped first book. Of the list of AMAZING female comedic ass-kickers out there, she is at It pains me to feel so half-hearted about Amy Poehler's much-hyped first book. Of the list of AMAZING female comedic ass-kickers out there, she is at the top. And her Leslie Knope is one of the greatest TV characters of all time. But what hurt my opinion most about Amy's book was the frequency with which she complained about having to write it (which she did--often--and to everyone out there who would LOVE to see their words get published--or maybe it's just me?--this conjured up a 'Do you want some cheese and crackers with that?' whine feeling). Don't get me wrong: There was plenty she DID manage well -- many of the chapters were humorous, duh (one of my favorites was the one Mike Schur annotated; see also her breakdown of everyone from the cast of P&R) -- but overall, there was a melancholy feel to the material that just ... brought me down in a rather unexpected way.In talking about it with a friend afterward, I told her I suppose this is because, when you finish one of these "meant-to-make-you-laugh" memoirs, you expect to feel lighter, happier, more inclined to want to be this person's best friend. Or, at least, like you KNOW them better. With Amy's, I didn't get that. I got a sense she's a tough nut to crack. I can't say I saw that coming.PS -- Another "to-love" element of the book was Amy's take on quite a few skits from the show, including one of her favorites, which also happens to be MY favorite: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=76mex... I of COURSE had to watch it as I read about it and as I was dying laughing, made Nick watch it. Fast forward a few months and "I'm No Angel" comes on in the car and Nick and I look at each other and just lose it. Thanks, Amy for that. ...more

title: I'll Give You the Sun
author: Nelson, Jandy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I love a book, I dog-ear its pages; this is one of those traits that can drive most readers nuts, but it's an old habit of mine. By the time I fiWhen I love a book, I dog-ear its pages; this is one of those traits that can drive most readers nuts, but it's an old habit of mine. By the time I finished Nelson's I'll Give You the Sun, the book had nearly doubled in size--THAT'S how many pages I'd turned down in it!Nelson's background in poetry shines through in Sun (ha! like what I did there?) So many of her turns of phrases felt like works of stand-alone art (particularly lines from Jude and Noah's grandmother's Bible, like the one below that just made my heart go pitter-patter.) Sentences like it, when combined with the book as a whole, sometimes made it feel as though "Sun" was its own kind of sun -- like, I had to stop reading it for a while because it was just that good it was like, hurting my eyes or my brain or something-- I just loved it that much. I reached out to Jandy on Twitter afterward to thank her for writing such an incredible book, one that kept me enthralled on a plane ride home, then up all night to finish it. I did so brokenhearted, not because its ending was melancholy, but because it had (whimper) finally come to an end. She thanked me for loving it (so sweet of her) and we tweeted back and forth a bit about who might play these characters if Sun were to make it to the big screen (it's been optioned). Hearing her say her pick for Guillermo was Javier Bardem had me saying out loud, "YES, YES, YES!" To which I shared MY pick for Noah and Jude's mother: Rachel Weiz. Can you see that pairing now? Now who shall we cast for Oscar? ;) (My vote? Aaron Taylor-Johnson)PS - If you can't get enough of Jandy, this interview with her is stellar: http://www.slj.com/2014/08/authors-il...Also, this gem of a line from the NYT  of the book is spot-on: "I’ve always loved this line from Stendhal: “A novel is a mirror carried down a high road.” Done well, it shows us ourselves even as it moves us forward into new places and new understandings. “I’ll Give You the Sun” is a dazzling mirror, and many grateful teenagers are sure to find themselves reflected in and learning from its pages." (read the full  here: http://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/09/boo...) (if you could, please picture me saying 'What a line, what a line' in my best Tigger voice* about the following passage of "Sun":)“Meeting your soul mate is like walking into a house you've been in before - you will recognize the furniture, the pictures on the wall,the books on the shelves, the contents of drawers: You could find your way around in the dark if you had to.”― Jandy Nelson, I'll Give You the Sun *Boy, I really am the mother of a toddler, aren't I? ;) ...more

title: Attachments
author: Rowell, Rainbow*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Okay, this is where I add that back-to-back lovefest of s for Rainbow's books. Attachments was her first novel but, coincidentally, my last bookOkay, this is where I add that back-to-back lovefest of s for Rainbow's books. Attachments was her first novel but, coincidentally, my last book of hers to read. I go back and forth on a favorite RR read, but always Attachments finds its way back up there (when I heard her speak in September, I loved what she had to say about it -- that if her books were family members, Attachments was the one who was always the most loved, the best behaved). For me, this is why Attachments tugged at my heartstrings: Because like Beth and Jen (and Rainbow!), I was once a writer at a newspaper. And I met the love of my life in the newsroom of my alma mater. So combine a love story with newsprint and I'm a goner. Throw in hilarity (I kid you not, I was laughing out loud at a LOT of these pages...there's a particular line when Lincoln is in his friend's car, when AC/DC is playing, that had me near tears), pop culture, topics all women can relate to (does he like me? doesn't he?) and Rainbow's skills, and it's no wonder this book is the gem it is. Thank you Rainbow, for putting incredible work out there. And thank you for being a journalist from the Midwest who can be an inspiration for other writers from the heartland. ...more

title: Fangirl
author: Rowell, Rainbow*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Let's declare 2014 the Year of Rainbow Rowell, shall we? I knew I loved her after reading Eleanor & Park but this fall was when I fell HARD for her--tLet's declare 2014 the Year of Rainbow Rowell, shall we? I knew I loved her after reading Eleanor & Park but this fall was when I fell HARD for her--the year in which she made it to the top of my list of favorite authors and I read everything the woman has ever published. Fangirl I have SUCH fond memories of and have gone back to several times to learn lessons from Rowell's writing style. She's SO good with banter between her characters, like a literary Amy Sherman Palladino, and I feel as though Fangirl is where she really nails this best. (Also, hats off to her for throwing pop culture references into her work like it's her job...wait.... --- writers often get told to avoid doing this, as it will make a book dated, but man, she does it so well -- and makes it look so easily -- that she is that exception to the rule).And then, well, then there is Levi. LEVI. What a Midwestern good 'ol boy (after my heart!) He's way up there in the boy crush of literary characters (gosh, September 2014 introduced me to Levi AND Jamie Frasier--what a month for swoon-worthy lit crushes!) The scenes that worked best for me in Fangirl were always, always between Cather and Levi. While Rowell handles the secondary fanfic plot of Baz and Snow remarkably well, admittedly my eyes kind of skimmed certain sections of theirs (only because I just wanted more Levi!) Needless to say, this was a definite favorite read of 2014, capped off only by getting to see Rainbow speak that month in Indianapolis. What a gem she is, the kind of author you would love to have as a BFF (but then again, isn't she already the Internet's?) ...more

review: As a Christian, this book left a solid imprint on my heart. I'm not the best evangelist for my faith, but if I could say anything on the topic here itAs a Christian, this book left a solid imprint on my heart. I'm not the best evangelist for my faith, but if I could say anything on the topic here it is that I believe firmly in the power of prayer. I've had too many moments in my life (especially as a creative) where I've had prayers (crazy specific ones even) answered to let doubt play a role in my life now. So while this book may not be for skeptics (or even some believers), it made a big impression on me. So much so, I sent a link along to a group of girlfriends (most Christians) asking them to read it, be similarly inspired, and join me in praying for one another. Mark's stories are inspiring (some gave me goose bumps), and I want to hold on to the themes of this book for years to come. Lucky for me, I've got a lot of dog-earred pages I can go back and read to help me remember. ...more

review: Ooohhhhh Outlander. Where should I begin? How about with the fact that, prior to the summer of 2014, when I started hearing the buzz about Starz' adapOoohhhhh Outlander. Where should I begin? How about with the fact that, prior to the summer of 2014, when I started hearing the buzz about Starz' adaptation of this time-traveling yarn, I'd never even HEARD of this series? I'm not sure how that's possible, biblophile that I am. But considering it came out when I was about 10, I suppose maybe that's why? ;) Needless to say, once I got a hold of this book, I couldn't put it down. At more than 800 pages, Outlander is a brick of a book, no question. (It's also the most 'R' rated novel I've read in quite some time--hubba hubba). And yet, it read as quickly as some 200-page novels I've picked up over the years. It's fair to say that this series (both the first book and the wonderfully done TV adaptation, which resumes again in April -- yeah!) held me spellbound over the fall. I'm not sure how much I'll keep up with Claire and Jamie (hats off to Diana Gabaldon for keeping up with characters over EIGHT books, and SO MANY PAGES), but this is one of those reading experiences I'll never forget. Don't we all love getting lost in the pages of a good book?PS - One of my favorite memories of reading this book is that the experience happened while I was at a rental cabin in Tennessee with my husband's family. The night I finished the book (at like, 2 am), I woke up the next morning desperate for coffee. I reached up into the cupboard and the first mug I found was an I <3 Scotland mug. PERFECT! ...more

review: Confession: When you know the author of a book, no matter what you may think of it, you tread a bit more carefully with what thoughts you want to sharConfession: When you know the author of a book, no matter what you may think of it, you tread a bit more carefully with what thoughts you want to share about it. Lucky for me, Lori is a FANTASTIC writer and while I don't delve into the mystery genre often, her debut has me looking forward to reading more! Lori is an alum of the university where I work and, like me, also works in higher education. Which is probably why I gravitated toward this plot line as much as I did: The story of a sociology professor, Amelia Emmet, shot by one of her former students, and the mystery of why. In her journey of healing, Emmet encounters quite a few ghosts from her pasts and reaches the bottom of things with help from her new grad assistant, Nath (who admittedly, I found myself developing a half-baked crush on). Lori does the dual POV between Ameila and Nath very well here, and the pages of this one go fast. ...more

review: This is one of those books that I'm guessing some readers will give five stars and others, like me, just wound up feeling "mew" about it. There's no qThis is one of those books that I'm guessing some readers will give five stars and others, like me, just wound up feeling "mew" about it. There's no question Ozeki is an incredible writer, that I never doubted. But where I got hung up as a reader was in the many sections she meandered with her words into scientific topics that just couldn't hold my interest. This was a book I could easily put down (and often did), never feeling any sort of intimate connection with the protagonist and that feeling only grew as the book went on (and it felt long to me; anybody else?)If you're interested in Japanese culture, however, it's a true gem (and that I did love about it). Also, great plot tie-in to the Japanese tsunami/earthquake of a few years back ... Ozeki is great at what she does just, not a writer for me. ...more

title: The Fever
author: Abbott, Megan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: No exaggeration when I say I haven't read a novel that's put me on edge like this since Gillian Flynn's Gone Girl. Abbott has created a story so true No exaggeration when I say I haven't read a novel that's put me on edge like this since Gillian Flynn's Gone Girl. Abbott has created a story so true to life the reader might well feel she's living in its pages. In The Fever, she's plucked a "ripped from the headline" concept (remember those girls in New England a few years back—the ones who all were falling prey to the same strange illness?) and crafted a gripping plot around it, one that keeps you glued to the page, start to finish. (I like what this Slate er has to say about her: "There are lots of authors who write books you want to devour, but, to borrow an old construction from that esteemed literary critic Yakov Smirnoff, with Megan Abbott, her books devour you." Source: http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/bo...)The main characters of the novel are members of the Nash family: 16-year-old Deenie; her older (dreamboat) brother, Eli; and their divorced dad, Tom, a chemistry teacher at the high school where both kids attend. When Deenie's friends (first Lisa, then Gabby, then more of her female classmates) start being struck with a mysterious affliction, the entire town ends up nearly delirious with worry, everyone convinced by a different conspiracy as to what may be going on. (It's remarkable how Abbott's words, the way she paints scenes in this book, particularly the night the school's PTA and board is confronted by all the angry parents, can leave you, the reader, feeling anxious and paranoid yourself.)What I love best about Abbott's writing is how tight it is. No words are wasted and just the right amount of detail is added in (and there is a lot of great detail here——descriptions of the town, its mysterious lake, the banalities and mysteries and backstabbing of high school). When you finally do figure out what's going on, the way the lives of the Nash family have intersected with the book's other (incredibly drawn) supporting characters, you still won't want the book to end. Only because immersing yourself in a world as vividly rendered as this one makes returning to real life a bit of a bore when you do. ...more

title: The Goldfinch
author: Tartt, Donna
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Let's just get my No. 1 beef with The Goldfinch out of the way: An editor should have taken a weedwhacker to its pages, trimming it from its bloated lLet's just get my No. 1 beef with The Goldfinch out of the way: An editor should have taken a weedwhacker to its pages, trimming it from its bloated length of nearly 800 pages to 600(ish)--at least! (We read this for our book club and all felt this way, though we said that while her editor perhaps might have also felt this way, he or she wasn't going to go toe-to-toe with the 'great' Donna Tartt)I had quite a love-hate relationship with this one. There were moments (especially early on, when Tartt so touchingly and hauntingly portrays Theo's confusion and sadness over the loss of his mother in the bombing) that were on par with the brilliance I expect from Tartt based on her earlier work (The Secret History being one of my favorite novels). And then there were times I felt my eyes glazing over, especially when Tartt found the need to give every minor character two to three pages of backstory--like, Jesus, GET ON WITH IT ALREADY. This was especially true toward the book's end, when Tartt took readers on a crazy international journey that lead them to the bottom of the seedy underworld of stolen art (or, in this case, Amsterdam). It was in this final leg of the book where I felt more lost than at any earlier point, but by then, I really didn't care if I couldn't keep my gangsters and mobsters straight, so anxious was I to finish the book. (Also, a note on that ending: I could have done without the approach Tartt chose of cramming a 10-page lesson on philosophy and art into it---that felt out of sync with the rest of how she told this brilliant story, didn't it?)And still, even with the faults found by this particular reader, STILL I would tell people to pick up The Goldfinch (assuming they were die-hard readers up for the challenge of tackling a heavy-ass tome of a book). I don't regret having finally picked it up (and, Pulitzer Prize winner that it is, I now see what all the buzz--good and bad--was about). I guess my only regret is ultimately the way I felt about it, wishing I could say I loved it more than I did (though, to be sure, I doubt I'll ever forget Theo or, perhaps the best gift The Goldfinch gave us, even better than a goose chase over a tiny little painting, the character of BORIS!) Would love to hear what other GR readers thought of this one. Also, for a little extra credit reading, I found some fun articles related to the book:How to Tweet Like Boris (HA!) http://www.themillions.com/2014/02/ho...Casting The Goldfinch (Elijah Wood -- yes, yes, yes!!) http://www.interviewmagazine.com/film...Fact Checking The Goldfinch (the comments in this were particularly amusing to me) http://the-toast.net/2014/03/18/fact-... ...more

review: 2019 REVIEW: Just as Harvey Karp gave me tips and tricks to survive the toddler years with my son, his "Happiest Toddler" book has saved me again as w2019 REVIEW: Just as Harvey Karp gave me tips and tricks to survive the toddler years with my son, his "Happiest Toddler" book has saved me again as we enter this same age range with our daughter. Harvey's methods are (no exaggeration) life-changing (at least, they have been in the Werner house!) and this is a book that I will implore all my parent friends of little kids to read. Here is a great  of why I, too, swear by "Happiest Toddler on the Block"!2014 REVIEW: I haven't even touched a parenting book since Dean was an infant, but once he hit that 17-month mark, the Toddler Tornado took us by surprise and I found myself grappling for how to handle the sudden meltdowns my son started having on me (much to my chagrin). No surprise that I would turn to Harvey Karp for answers, since his Happiest Baby on the Block book (he of the great "swaddling" fame) saved me as a new mother in those very early days of parenthood! His Toddler answer to his parenting series has been no different, providing me some GREAT solutions (and insight into the toddler mind) that have really helped sooth my frayed nerves during this difficult transition into a new era of parenting. title: Forever, Interrupted
author: Reid, Taylor Jenkins*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It's so nice to read a book ever now and then that just lets you get lost in the story-—it's not overly complicated, it's escapism at its finest, it hIt's so nice to read a book ever now and then that just lets you get lost in the story-—it's not overly complicated, it's escapism at its finest, it has a plot that, though straightforward and fairly simple, certainly holds your interest. Taylor Jenkins Reid's "Forever Interrupted" is just that—-and a perfect book for the beach no less. I suppose I would have liked it that much more had the main character's husband not died in the first three pages, but 1) you know this going into the book and 2) TJR does such a nice job weaving him back into the backstory in following chapters (Ben just seems so sweet so you want more of him!) that I could overlook death slapping me in the face in that first chapter! It's interesting—I've never been one to read much women's fiction before now: Then I decided to write a book, one that very much, for all intensive purposes, would likely be shelved under women's fiction. Writing my own book has made me so much more receptive to works of this genre and, just, overall, to ANYONE who gets a book published, regardless the genre. Because seriously, it's HARD WORK. And Mrs. Reid makes it look all too easy! Hers is a voice that, in some ways, reminds me of my own style of writing and that, too, has a nice feel to it, making me like this debut novel of hers all the more.Great read for any of my girlfriends who want something quick and easy to dive in to each night before you count those sheep in bed!...more

review: One of the things that's fascinated me most after reading this book, especially now that I'm learning more about the marketing of books and writers, iOne of the things that's fascinated me most after reading this book, especially now that I'm learning more about the marketing of books and writers, is discovering how E. Lockhart (and the publicity machine behind the title) are flooding the Internet with pinnable imagery featuring quotes from it, a map of the island featured in the story, a family tree of the Sinclairs … the list goes on (catering to the teen market that will be picking up WWL now that they've finished their tenth re-read of John Green's TFiOS). Then there is this clever-as-hell tagline they've come up with: "And if anyone asks how it ends, just LIE." It's such a great parting thought to share because what can I say about this book when I sure as hell don't want to give away the truth: Not when doing so would take away from what has to be one of the most satisfying (albeit jarring) endings in fiction since Gillian Finch's Gone Girl? It's masterfully written (Lockhart is among the best of the YA authors out there now) and filled with the kinds of vivid metaphors and imagery that, along with a compelling plot, make it impossible to put down.A few lines I want to remember (most relating to Gat, one of those literary crushes who's well worth having—and props to Lockhart for making him such a multi-dimensional character, both in his diversity (I loved that he was Indian) and his thoughts and actions):“He was contemplation and enthusiasm. Ambition and strong coffee. I could have looked at him forever.”“If you want to live where people are not afraid of mice, you must give up living in palaces.”So when will they start filming the movie? A few early casting picks: Vanessa Redgrave as Tipper Sinclair (the grandmother) (http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000603/?r...)Joely Richardson as Penny, Cadence's mother (http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000613/?r...)Suraj Sharma as Gat (http://www.imdb.com/name/nm4139037/?r...)Chloe Grace Moretz as Cadence (http://www.imdb.com/name/nm1631269/?r...)**A final parting thought: I LOVED Johnny. For being a secondary character, Lockhart put so much life into him my guess is he HAD to be one of her favorite characters to write! ...more

review: I've thought a lot about what it is about Maggie Shipstead's writing that elevates it to what I believe is some of the best of her generation (a femalI've thought a lot about what it is about Maggie Shipstead's writing that elevates it to what I believe is some of the best of her generation (a female Cheever or Roth or Updike, she is indeed). Like, WHAT IS IT that makes her writing SO damn good? And I think it's this: The entire time I read Astonish Me, I never once thought there was "too much try" to her work—-not even a hint of it. There are some writers out there who, in their effort to keep up with all the accolades and buzz (and there has been plenty of both heaped on Shipstead in recent years, especially with the kind of talent she has at just 30 (!!!)), feel such a need to please that it comes across for readers of their work. But Shipstead's prose reads effortlessly, carrying with it the kind of inspiring lines that showcase her keen eye at observing life (especially those moments I think we all feel but have never read in print before)I read recently how literary fiction is best described as work that's written in such a way it leaves its readers enthralled with the writing, mulling over lines long after they've read them. And if this is true, than there may be no finer example currently at work producing it than Shipstead herself. I look forward to having at her debut novel, "Seating Arrangements" soon too. One line that I loved in "Astonish Me", among MANY because it was so damn good (along with a plot that was SO thrilling—I think about ballet now constantly): "Sometimes I wonder," Joan said, her mouth red from the punch, "how you're supposed to know if you're really feeling what you think you're feeling. Like, how do we know everybody sees colors the same way, you know? Do we all feel 'happy' the same way?" ...more

title: Sleep Donation
author: Russell, Karen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Man, I really, REALLY want to like Karen Russell's work. I mean, I found the plot of this e-novella (wherein what lies ahead for us is a world in whicMan, I really, REALLY want to like Karen Russell's work. I mean, I found the plot of this e-novella (wherein what lies ahead for us is a world in which a strange, disturbing insomnia has gripped the nation, forcing people with healthy sleep patterns to donate their sleep to the less fortunate in a kind of futuristic blood bank of zzzs) to be fascinating.But about mid-way through, I hit a snag of sorts with Russell's writing that reminded me of why, despite the hoopla that surrounded it, her "Swamplandia!" failed to stack up for me in EXACTLY the same way. And I think it's this: Russell's writing overreaches and, at times, can easily pass as being condescending to the reader. I mean, I'd like to think I'm a well-read person, someone with a more than average/decent vocabulary. But when I'm highlighting words on my phone, ones she's chosen to use as her adjectives of choice, searching for their meaning ('chitinous' shell of sarcasm? the actual 'ungulate'? 'nacreous' skin?), then enough already. I mean, WE GET IT. You're REALLY REALLY smart and you have the vocabulary to prove it (and I don't know..maybe hold degrees in biology and astrology and Greek mythology? Seriously, the girl knows her stuff in those departments or else no way would she be drawing from the banks of words she does to describe the everyday and mundane.) It's just ... weird for me...I've yet to experience this phenomenon with any other writers I read, this disconnect of sorts in wanting to like the writer more than I do and feeling that the promise is there if she would just, I don't know, maybe get out of her own way a little bit (or have an editor to address this issue with her). And who knows, perhaps I'm the only one to feel this way about Russell's work (and it's likely I am, publishing darling that she is), but I just think if she would lose hold on her tendencies to overreach with all those descriptions of hers, then her books would be that much better——out-of-the-ballpark awesome even. Unfortunately, after two strikes, I'm not so sure I'm willing to find out. ...more

title: The Museum of Extraordinary Things
author: Hoffman, Alice*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was my first Alice Hoffman novel and I really enjoyed it. She has a way of writing description that pulls you right into the scenes she's creatinThis was my first Alice Hoffman novel and I really enjoyed it. She has a way of writing description that pulls you right into the scenes she's creating—just enough and not too much. In this case, it's the world of New York City shortly after the turn of the 20th century, when the city was just beginning to define itself with all the changes being hurled at it (electricity and automobiles among the most significant) and the disparity between rich and poor was at its most extreme.Along with describing how the landscape of the city was changing at this time, Hoffman captured both the 1911 Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire (more than 140 people died in it; the grossest case of worker mistreatment in that city's ugly era of injustice for the urban, working poor) and the fire that happened at Dreamland along the Coney Island boardwalk a few months later so, so well. Her main characters in this are Coralie, a young girl who's living under the thumb of her maniacal father, Professor Sardie, whose museum of misfits and extraordinary things is losing out to the growing popularity of attractions farther down the boardwalk, and Eddie Cohen, a young Jew who becomes estranged from his father, taking up with a photographer and later capturing the city's seedy underside from behind his camera. How these two meet make for a gripping love story (though Hoffman makes you wait for hundreds of pages before she gives you the pay off) but it's a good one, so it's well worth it. (The scene where Eddie sees Coralie in the yard of the museum for the first time still is burned into my brain, two months later.) My biggest fault with the book overall was its construct: This might be the first time where how a book was told actually stood out to me, and not for the right reasons. Hoffman alternates points of view between Coralie and Eddie—and that's fine, but she then alternates those between first and third person (using italics to switch off). AND THAT WAS MADDENING. This book was read for a book club I'm in and we all were in agreement this technique did nothing to add to the story and would have made an otherwise great read that much better had it just been told in one point of view or the other (not both; especially not when having TWO narrators to do so only added to the confusion, especially since she time hops between those POV narratives)A few lines that stood out: Eddie: "No wonder I had closed myself off. Love like this was all consuming. I found that I was jealous of the strangest things—sunlight, streets, curtains, even her clothing, anything that was close to her."Eddie: "He felt overtaken by his love for her. Love like this wasn't what he'd planned or wanted or expected, surely it was indeed a trap, for even when you tried to run way, it followed you through the grass and lay down beside you, it overtook common sense and willpower."Coralie: "It was an ordinary life I wished for, and that is what I have."...more

title: Shotgun Lovesongs
author: Butler, Nickolas*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As a reader, I'm drawn to books written in Butler's style: plain-spoken language, characters who aren't overly complicated (yet still complex enough tAs a reader, I'm drawn to books written in Butler's style: plain-spoken language, characters who aren't overly complicated (yet still complex enough to be believable), and a setting so true it becomes an integral element to the plot. In the hands of a writer like Butler, an author who's clearly put the time and effort into making the story one with great flow, these elements have aligned in such a way to elevate "Shotgun Lovesongs" to the five-stars, favorites shelf—-at least, for me anyway.On my end, I suppose Butler gets extra bonus points because he is a Midwesterner too (someone who also takes PRIDE in that fact, I might add), and because, a few years into my 30s myself, I felt a kinship with these characters in a way I probably wouldn't have at 23 or even 25. And I'll admit, it probably *also* stoked my love a bit (at the very least, it first piqued my interest) this whole Justin Vernon-Bon Iver angle of the book (that now everyone can't stop talking about). But for ALL these reasons and more, I'm confident "Shotgun" will wind up my favorite read of 2014. A book that, as a writer, I expect to keep thinking about for much of the rest of the year too. (For the sake of record keeping, in 2013 that title for me went to Meg Wolitzer's "The Interestings"; 2012 I didn't exactly have one ... "Fault in Our Stars" perhaps? and 2011 was Chad Harbach's "Art of Fielding"). There's plenty that's been written already about the plot of this book—five 30-somethings in a small town in Wisconsin, all trying to find their way in life while figuring out the challenges that accompany it: loyalties, friendships, relationships, finances, a sense of belonging. The most notable of the group is Lee, who's struck it big as an indie musician (here's where that Justin Vernon comparison comes in, Butler being from the same town as the Bon Iver frontman), but the characters who ground the entire book (and the ones whose chapters I eagerly awaited most) were Henry and Beth, the married couple of the book, good 'ol salt-of-the-earth people tied to their family farm, struggling to stay afloat, but content in so many ways (I saw in them traits of many of the people I grew up with in my small hometown in Indiana). You know a book is good when you don't want to quit its characters, when they stay with you even off the page, and it seems like, once or twice a year, I experience that with a title. I certainly did with "Shotgun." And while occasionally I found Butler to want to overwrite a scene, the instances were seldom enough (and stopped just short of trying too hard) for it to really bother me. Especially when there were so many other wonderful lines to treasure. Here are a few still on my mind a few weeks after reading:• "Maybe it's a good thing, from time to time, to spy on other people's lives. For me, anyway, it has the effect of making my own life feel like a well-loved thing."• [I loved this scene of Henry and Beth in a taxi, as throw-away as it may seem...chiefly because I'm always a little in awe of an author who captures a moment in words something I've experienced before that no one else has ever attempted to put down on the page] "He looked down at me, his chin compressing itself, the type of angle you only see on the face of a person you love—his nose hairs, the crow's feet about his eyes, his hairline, gently receding. I pulled his face down to me, and we kissed.• "It's a funny thing, being married to someone for so long, being someone's best friend for so long. Because on those few occasions when they surprise you, it feels like the biggest thing in the world, like a crack in the sky, like the moon, suddenly rising over the horizon twenty times bigger than the last time you looked." (such a BEAUTIFUL line and so poignantly true)• America, I think ,is about poor people playing music and poor people sharing food and poor people dancing, even when everything else in their lives is desperate, and so dismal that it doesn't seem that there should be any room for any music, any extra food, or any extra energy for dancing." Related: With the book being so new, after finishing, I hopped online to read a few s and was lucky enough to catch Butler in a live Q&A. When I asked about the status of the book being turned into a film (Fox Searchlight is working on the script), I brought up actors for characters and suggested that Ryan Gosling would make one hell of an awesome Lee. He agreed, but mentioned that the Hollywood types thought Justin Timberlake. I knew I already liked the guy, but when he wrote, "This made me cringe a little ... in my soul", I laughed out loud. YES. God, PLEASE don't let JT ("The Serious Actor") get his hands on that role. Where do I start the campaign for The Gos? ;) (as for the others, I'm still playing casting director in my mind!)...more

title: One More Thing: Stories and Other Stories
author: Novak, B.J.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Let's put it this way...it's been about 3 weeks now since I finished BJ Novak's debut release of short stories and I'm STILL chuckling over some of thLet's put it this way...it's been about 3 weeks now since I finished BJ Novak's debut release of short stories and I'm STILL chuckling over some of them. Man...there are just...too many to pick favorites, but here's a few I don't want to forget:• Dark Matter: The way this character goes on a diatribe about his social standing with his friends is brilliant• Julie and the Warlord: I heard a reading of this by the brilliant Allison Brie on TAL, and I knew then I HAD to read this book of BJ's• 'Rithmetic: Because as someone who loathed math, this principal's take on the subject was spot on• Missed Connections: Because the way BJ folded in the story of the guy in the red t-shirt over several stories in this collection was just SO FLIPPING BRILLIANT TO ME (same as the Girl Who Gave Great Advice)• The Something by John Grisham: Because damn, that was just LOL funny• Wikipedia Brown and the Case of the Missing Bicycle: I read this one aloud to my friend Ellen (we may have had a few glasses of wine in us at this point) and there were tears in our eyes when I was finished• Never Fall in Love: That last line, so great: "I just knew you'd never find love if you were looking for it"• Constructive Criticism: Because the plot of this one is just hysterical.OK, if you've never read any of these, the context on my thoughts above is lost, but if you HAVE then you know why I've picked them, right? I have to give kudos to BJ Novak (otherwise know as Ryan from The Office). He has a knack for writing material that's very on point for the times (case in point: he folds in a lot of famous people of today, along with skewering some of this country's latest bad habits—need another food of your photo posted to Instagram anyone?)I'm a huge fan now of his written work— I think my only critique might be that reading this all in a sitting or two (as I more or less did) is a disservice of sorts to the material, since there are SO many stories (all of them VERY short..like, a few pages at that) that, by the end, you'll probably forget having read at least half of them (oh well, just a great excuse to go back and have another chuckle at them again!)Here's perhaps the shortest example:"If you love something, let it go.""If you don't love something, definitely let it go.""Basically, just drop everything, who cares."If you smiled at that, then trust me, you'll want to pick this one up. ...more

title: All Joy and No Fun: The Paradox of Modern Parenthood
author: Senior, Jennifer
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I can't praise the merits of this new book enough: It's so refreshing to read a parenting book that's less about the kid (because believe me, there arI can't praise the merits of this new book enough: It's so refreshing to read a parenting book that's less about the kid (because believe me, there are PLENTY of those out there and I've read more than a few of them) and more about the actual pressures of being the PARENT——aka, what kind of mega changes are in store for you when you accept that title of being someone's mom or dad (one of, if not THE most, sudden and dramatic changes of adult life.)Senior folds in narratives of parents she meets along the way, some whose stories sound familiar to my own or that of other family members, as she dives into universal topics affecting most adults when they enter the parenting ring: a loss of autonomy (it's SO HARD to go from being an adult who's had their 20s full of ME time, to becoming a parent who has to be on his/her game for someone else 24/7); the way having a child affects one's marriage (this chapter alone was worth its weight in gold); to what IS AWESOME about having kids ("they create wormholes in time, transporting their mothers and fathers back to feelings and sensations they haven't had since they themselves were young; also, see "how cool it is when your 3-year-old starts asking you philosophical questions"); and, for this mother of a toddler at least, what is in store when it comes to some day having a teenager in the house.I think what I came to appreciate most about this book was the INCREDIBLE amount of research and detail Senior poured into it. She's done her homework, it shows, and on the shelf of parenting books that are out there, I hope it allows hers to rise quickest to the top. ...more

title: Tenth of December
author: Saunders, George
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This one had been on my list for a while, having read the incredible s and buzz for it as one of 2013's best reads.It was my first Saunders (picThis one had been on my list for a while, having read the incredible s and buzz for it as one of 2013's best reads.It was my first Saunders (picked up at the airport on my way home from Germany last month) but I'd certainly be willing not to make it my last. I have a feeling this is one I'll be touch-and-go on recommending to people. For starters, it's short stories, and I know that's not everyone's cup of tea (it's not my usual favorite, but I'm learning to love them more, especially since I want to be able to write more of them myself). Second, Saunders writes with a creepy vibe. It's a vibe I appreciated the more and more that I read, but I'm not sure it would sit well with everyone. But here's why it worked for me—Saunders' flair for black comedy. Even when I was reading some of the most disturbing stories presented here (the brilliant "Escape from Spiderhead" where the character of Jeff is sent to a experimental prison where he and several other characters are guinea pigs on display, and "The Semplica Girls Diaries", where a father keeps a diary of gifting his daughter Semplica Girls, young girls saved from human trafficking that become lawn ornaments), there was still just enough "something" that was comedic enough about them for you to want to keep reading, to even smile wryly at Saunders' ability to get away with it—it being writing about some of the absurd concepts he does (WHERE does he come up with this stuff?!)I appreciated the unique voice given to the characters of every story. Hands-down my favorite though was "My Chivalric Fiasco". I just...OMG I laughed so hard at that one ...to the point where the guy at the place I was having my oil changed looked at me funny. I think it may go down as one of the best short stories I've ever read. ...more

title: The Four Loves
author: Lewis, C.S.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What can I say about C.S. Lewis that others haven't said before me on here? The guy is just ... so brilliant. SO SO brilliant. I think, more than any What can I say about C.S. Lewis that others haven't said before me on here? The guy is just ... so brilliant. SO SO brilliant. I think, more than any other person whose put pen to page, Lewis captures what it means to be a Christian better than any other author I've ever read. Maybe it's the fact he, himself, was an atheist for so many years, but his approach in describing my faith is so powerful, I wish everyone would give him the brain space (and you'll need a little... dimestore novel readin' this isn't!) for an introduction.Selfishly, I particularly wanted to have at this book of his because I'm folding it into my own book I'm writing. It's fun to make a character of yours a fan of an author you admire — at least, for me it is! So many great quotes from this title...here are but a few:“Friendship is born at that moment when one man says to another: "What! You too? I thought that no one but myself . . ."”“To love at all is to be vulnerable. Love anything and your heart will be wrung and possibly broken. If you want to make sure of keeping it intact you must give it to no one, not even an animal. Wrap it carefully round with hobbies and little luxuries; avoid all entanglements. Lock it up safe in the casket or coffin of your selfishness. But in that casket, safe, dark, motionless, airless, it will change. It will not be broken; it will become unbreakable, impenetrable, irredeemable. To love is to be vulnerable.”“Friendship is unnecessary, like philosophy, like art.... It has no survival value; rather it is one of those things which give value to survival.”“People who bore one another should meet seldom; people who interest one another, often.” ...more

title: Landline
author: Rowell, Rainbow*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I started off loving Landline. Like, WHOA. Primarily because, like so many GoodReads readers, I'm a huge fan of Rainbow Rowell's writing. It's quick, I started off loving Landline. Like, WHOA. Primarily because, like so many GoodReads readers, I'm a huge fan of Rainbow Rowell's writing. It's quick, clever, and engaging—in short, one hell of a great way to spend an afternoon. I especially loved the early banter in this book between protagonist Georgie McCool (what a GREAT name! I read that it came from Rowell's love of the song Georgy Girl along with the town McCool Junction in Nebraska ... source: http://www.usatoday.com/story/life/bo...) and her TV writing partner, Seth (and their lackey, Scotty). There was a line Seth had about Georgie coming into the office, wearing her mom's bejeweled clothes ("You look like Britney Spears, back when she was dating backup dancers and walking around gas stations barefoot...") that made me laugh out loud. It's moments like this—especially with her dialogue— where Rowell shines most as a writer.My only criticism with the book is that, while the concept was a fun one (of Georgie finding this magical landline phone that let her connect with her husband from when they were dating in 1998, leaving their troubled marriage behind for a few nights), it started to wear on me a bit as I reached the end (especially as Georgie kept driving herself crazy in trying to find the meaning of discovering this "magic" phone). Also, I think maybe it was because it felt like Georgie and Neal kept having the same conversation—both on the phone and in her head. But those small quibbles aside, there's still plenty to love about Landline: Rowell's wonderful use of pop culture references, her smart dialogue, her great insights on life and marriage and getting what you want, and, let's not forget, a FABULOUS shout-out to "Leather and Lace" (God I love that song...and now I'll have it stuck in my head all day).Already I'm ready for whatever it is she'll put out next. ...more

review: I love books that illuminate pieces of history I’ve never heard about and A Star for Mrs. Blake falls right into that category. This new novel tells tI love books that illuminate pieces of history I’ve never heard about and A Star for Mrs. Blake falls right into that category. This new novel tells the story of the American mothers who lost their sons fighting in World War I in France and, on the U.S. government’s dime, traveled back to France to get to pay their last respects at their graves. I loved all the characters in this book, but the American reporter Griffin Reed the most. (Griff was wounded in the trenches and must wear a metal mask, his ‘tin nose’ a symbol of the war—the pages the talented Smith devotes to him will steal your heart). It’s Griff’s connection with the main character, Cora Blake, that creates the thread of conflict that holds this entire book together, one I finished in a rush feeling sad over (but in a good way, if that makes sense). Great research and storytelling here. Would make an excellent book club pick!...more

review: Guys, I tried...I really did try to finish this book. But I'm finally reaching that stage in life where my compulsion to keep reading a book, no matteGuys, I tried...I really did try to finish this book. But I'm finally reaching that stage in life where my compulsion to keep reading a book, no matter what I think of it, is waning. And for me, I just could not get past Marisha Pessl's tendency to OVERWRITE her scenes. It's a great storyline, I was completely fascinated with the hunt to find out who killed the daughter of this creepy horror director, but I would get so distracted by Pessl's distracting manner to overdescribe scenery around these characters (case in point, I remember a particular scene where they're at a gas station, just waiting on one of the characters to get some junk food inside, and about 4 sentences is devoted to describing the way birds are perched on a nearby wire like grace notes...) that it ruined it for me.In a way, maybe it's for the best. I had several friends who DID finish it say that this one fell flat for them in the end.That said, I will give Pessl credit for what has to be the COOLEST way to introduce a backstory. review: I wasn't on board with much of this book because it picked up IMMEDIATELY where the second left off and, as someone who had a few months there pass inI wasn't on board with much of this book because it picked up IMMEDIATELY where the second left off and, as someone who had a few months there pass in between (months where she definitely, you know, slept and such) I was beyond confused for much of the first ...hmmmm....HALF of the book? But things picked up two-thirds of the way through and that's all thanks to Four. I'll admit it. I'm biased to this series because I love his character quite a bit (far more than Peeta or Gale in that other uber popular YA series we're all talking about). Or wait... is it that I love the actor playing the character? (This often times is what happens with books I read wherein, mid-way through, I discover the Hollywood ideal for the character in question; thankfully, in this case, I'm 100 percent sold).At any rate, I liked that, in the end, Veronica took this series where it NEEDED to go. It was a bold ending that some hated but I appreciated. And I liked the dual perspective of Tris and Four (because honestly, Tris bored me a little bit overall). So those last 50 pages or so? They saved this one for me, big time.** I also have to note I'm a fan of Veronica's for multiple reasons (including the way she was able to write such an elaborate series at the young age she is) but I'm especially grateful to her for answering questions I posed to her for a magazine article I'm writing related to the writing workshop where she met her agent. review: Can I just take a minute to say I’m damn near infatuated with this book? I mean, I’ve read my fair share of King over the years, but I wouldn’t say heCan I just take a minute to say I’m damn near infatuated with this book? I mean, I’ve read my fair share of King over the years, but I wouldn’t say he’s a favorite author of mine (truth be told, that’s only because most of his work scares the shit out of me). BUT, On Writing? OMG I feel like it deserves its own spotlight on my bookshelf. Or a placard next to it that reads “All I Ever Needed to Learn About Writing I Learned From This Book.”As part of this novel writing course I'm taking, I was trying SO HARD to almost…overthink plot, I think. Then I read King’s sage words on the topic and just …. let it go. It all felt very free. He writes extensively on the topic (around page 163). Here were a few lines worth remembering:“You may wonder where plot is in all this. The answer—my answer, anyway—is nowhere. I won’t try to convince you that I’ve never plotted any more than I’d try to convince you that I’ve never told a lie, but I do both as infrequently as possible. I distrust plot for two reasons: first, because our lives are largely plotless, even when you add in all our reasonable precautions and careful planning; and second, because I believe plotting and the spontaneity of real creation aren’t compatible. It’s best that I be as clear about this as I can—I want you to understand that my basic belief about the making of stories is that they pretty much make themselves. The job of the writer is to give them a place to grow (and to transcribe them, of course).”SOOO many other gems in this one .... a work I will definitely be coming back to, for sure....more

title: The One and Only Ivan        (The One and Only Ivan #1)
author: Applegate, Katherine
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: An online friend of mine spoke highly of this book as a read for her book club (hi Jules!) so I thought I'd give it a read myself. Knowing it was YA aAn online friend of mine spoke highly of this book as a read for her book club (hi Jules!) so I thought I'd give it a read myself. Knowing it was YA and knowing it had just won the Newberry Medal, I ordered it. What I discovered is that The One and Only Ivan is this author's soul-stirring fictionalization of a true story. There really WAS a gorilla named Ivan who was forced to live in a pen at a SHOPPING MALL (if you want to know more, as I did, here's a good place to start: http://www.zooatlanta.org/ivan). I recently read that the author had learned of Ivan years ago in a NYT article, clipped the article out and held on to it in her "idea file". I'm so glad she did!Where Katherine Applegate excels with this book is in walking that fine line of childhood whimsy-meets-adult-wisdom with Ivan's thoughts as he processes life in his cage (with his friends, Bob the dog; Stella the elephant; and, eventually, little Ruby, the elephant who inspires him to change his life).This is one of those stories that, whether you have a child to read it to/with or not, it'll tug at your heart strings. Well worth the time and investment. Passages I Want to Remember: My life is flashing lights and pointing fingers and uninvited visitors. Inches away, humans flatten their little hands against the wall of glass that separates us. The glass says you are this and we are that and that is how it will always be. // Many days I forget what I am supposed to be. Am I a human? Am I a gorilla? Humans have so many words, more than they truly need. Still, they have no name for what I am.Would I Recommend? If you are someone who loves a good story — no matter what shelf that story may be on in the bookstore — then yes. If you struggle with themes of animal cruelty, you may be overly saddened by this one, but, overall, it's such a wonderful message that, in the end, I'm hopeful that won't turn you away! ...more

title: Grace: More Than We Deserve, Greater Than We Imagine
author: Lucado, Max*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When it comes to books about the Christian faith, I find that I look for titles from authors like Donald Miller or Anne Lamott over Max Lucado or Lee When it comes to books about the Christian faith, I find that I look for titles from authors like Donald Miller or Anne Lamott over Max Lucado or Lee Strobel. BUT, I’ve been mulling the concept of “grace” over in my mind a lot this past year and my mother-in-law let me borrow this title as a great way to help me explore the concept. Max’s writing may be a bit fluffy or simplistic for some folks, but I found this to be a quick read and one that reenforced a lot of what I love best about my relationship with God and His Son.Passages I Want to Remember: “To accept grace is to accept the vow to give it.” // “Saving grace saves us from our sins. Sustaining grace meets us at our point of need and equips us with courage, wisdom, and strength. It surprises us in the middle of our personal transatlantic flights with ample resources of faith. Sustaining grace promises not the absence of struggle but the presence of God.” // “Grace is the gift of feeling sure that our future, even our dying, is going to turn out more splendidly than we dare imagine.” —Lewis Smedes // “If you ever catch yourself thinking, ‘I can do whatever I want because God will forgive me,’ then grace is not happening to you … Grace creates a resolve to do good, not permission to do bad.”Would I Recommend? Depends on the audience. For those who, like me, are interested in learning more about the concept of grace and are open-minded to Christianity, I would. For those new to this religion or more skeptical about religion in general, this could be one of those books you start but never finish....more

review: UPDATED REVIEW (from August 2017): I don't often re-read books. But I absolutely adore Corey's writing style and I've recently started drafting a new UPDATED REVIEW (from August 2017): I don't often re-read books. But I absolutely adore Corey's writing style and I've recently started drafting a new YA manuscript that is futuristic in its concepts but set just far enough into the future so that the plotline can still focus on themes popular in contemporary YA lit. Because Corey tackles the melding of these two aspects SO DARN WELL in "Noggin," it felt like a great read to dip back into again for inspiration. Of course, it didn't disappoint. If anything, I found the characters to be even richer and funnier the second time around. 2014 Review: I can't be the only reader who, immediately after picking up a book, flips to the photo of the author at back, right? I mean, aren't you curious about whose work it is you're getting ready to dive into? So when I did this with Noggin (though believe me, it was hard to tear my eyes off its AWESOME cover—SO clever), I knew immediately upon seeing John Corey Whaley's photo I was going to like this book. That—and it was just a hunch, but a good one—it was going to be the literary equivalent of that dimpled smirk JCW was wearing on the inside jacket. Three hundred odd pages later and I can say ABSOLUTELY IT WAS. Only better because I found myself being SO impressed with this guy's talent (at what? THIRTY?) that I couldn't help but think ahead (HA! look at that …a head pun…I'm CONFIDENT JCW would appreciate that one!), knowing he's got so much more great work in store for those of us he's winning over as fans.Here's what I had to say about Noggin over on my blog, which I think sums it up best: You have to trust me when I say that while the plot is a bit out there (a kid whose head is cryogenically frozen comes back to life, five years later), the author does a brilliant job of making the focus as much a charming, witty, coming-of-age story as a sci-fi mind bender. Also, talk about a GREAT first line: Listen—Travis Coates was alive once and then he wasn’t. Now he’s alive again. Simple as that. Can’t wait to read more from this guy!...more
