review: I wanted to come back and write a few thoughts on this one: Gone Girl is most definitely one of my favorite reads of 2012. It's been a LONG time sinceI wanted to come back and write a few thoughts on this one: Gone Girl is most definitely one of my favorite reads of 2012. It's been a LONG time since I delved into the thriller genre, so I wasn't sure what to expect but from the start, Flynn sweeps her readers up in a whodunnit that leaves you on the edge of your seat.The story follows Nick and Amy, two 20-something writers who meet cute in New York City, foster a relationship that turns into a marriage, only to see that marriage hit a rough patch when the economy bottoms out, Nick loses his job at a magazine and then makes the makes the decision for both he and Amy to return to his native Missouri to care for his ailing mother. It's the course their lives take once they reach Missouri—and a mystery that arises when Amy goes missing with Nick being the first person police question-that is the plot at the heart of "Gone Girl."I'm reluctant to say much about where things go from here given that Flynn takes her readers places they'd never expect. In particular, about two-thirds of the way through comes a major twist (one that made me gasp out loud). Of course, that twist is nothing compared to what comes in the book's final pages. Overall a novel I couldn't put down and one deserving of all its "best of" fuss this year. Get your hands on it ... ...more

title: In One Person
author: Irving, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I must admit, on more than one occasion, this gender-bending book made me squirm. Its subject material walks that fine line between the delicate and—fI must admit, on more than one occasion, this gender-bending book made me squirm. Its subject material walks that fine line between the delicate and—for many of us—the entirely unknown:You have Billy, our bi-sexual narrator, who starts off as a young teen growing up in a 1960s conservative Vermont town (a familiar Irving plot construct). It's while attending boarding school that Billy begins to understand his penchant for both girls and boys (an understanding shepherded along in a variety of bi-curious ways thanks to his (ahem) "mentorship" with the local librarian, MISS Frost). As Billy becomes a man, we follow him to NYC, where Irving chooses to immerses the reader in the city's gay culture (perhaps, for this reader, too much so) and we see how the signs of the times carry a heavy weight for both narrator and a supporting cast of equally sexually confused characters.For me, the weaknesses of the book came in two key areas: 1) Irving spends entirely too much of the first third of the book dissecting the works of Ibsen and Shakespeare as his characters (Billy included) perform in productions of both at the local community theater and boarding school. It made for such a slow start to the book, a less devoted reader would have given up. 2) I found it entirely difficult to believe that within such a small circle of known characters there could be THAT much sexual confusion among its members. A grandfather who likes to cross dress? That's just the start...to say too much more about what we discover about a few other key players' sexuality would give away too much for those still curious enough to read this.But (and for me, there seems to always be a "but" with Irving), this book was a worthy read in more than a few ways:1) I learned more about the AIDS epidemic in 1980s New York than I could have imagined. Irving did his homework on the subject (thanks in large part to his friend and physician, fellow talented author Abraham Verghese) (Also, did you know more people died in NYC in the '80s of AIDS than all Americans in Vietnam? Wow.)2) It stirred up powerful feelings of empathy, trying to put myself into the shoes of this young man and those of others (real and make-believe) who struggle and/or encounter adversity on the road to accepting their sexual differences—be they bisexual, transgender or homosexual.3) Because Irving has a knack for creating characters that, before all is said and done, just get under your skin—and I mean that in both the best and worst ways possible.And finally, though I was skeptical how the rest of our book club would react to this book (it was our May pick), discussing it with the open-minded women who are its members made for one of our best gatherings yet (the conversation went on for nearly an hour). Not one for everyone but for anyone who can relate to its plot or whose worldview loves all of humanity—regardless of how it dresses or identifies itself—then this one might be an interesting read for you. BEST LINE OF THE BOOK: “My dear boy, please don’t put a label on me--don’t make me a category before you get to know me!” — Miss Frost And for any of you who HAVE read this and stumbled across this , I really really wanted a better resolution with Kittredge. I'll leave it at that. ...more

title: Fifty Shades Freed        (Fifty Shades, #3)
author: James, E.L.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: OK, here's the part where I admit I *kind* of had a hard time letting these characters go. The same characters I spent 6 days speed-reading, getting tOK, here's the part where I admit I *kind* of had a hard time letting these characters go. The same characters I spent 6 days speed-reading, getting to know. And there I was, foolishly stalling in the final 30 pages of this book, just so I could let myself live in their (now perfect) world a bit longer.Here's also the part where I admit I've clearly got a problem: "Hi, my name is Gail Werner and, against my better judgment, I actually liked the 50 Shades of Grey series. There. Oh, and I'm not ashamed to admit it."Sigh.... there's a few great (and by great, I mean soapish) plot twists in this one, making it a solid way to round out the trilogy. But I admit to feeling hopeful at its end, the way the author leaves a bit of a cryptic note of "That's all...for now. Thanks for reading!" WAIT. THERE MIGHT BE MORE?? DON'T TEASE LIKE THAT, MRS. JAMES. I've moved on to the next read in my book pile (one assuredly smarter than this), but that doesn't mean I still don't find myself wanting to talk about these books with others. Which is why I've coerced a coworker into plowing through them at this very moment. (And for the record, she's equally hooked). This whole experience reminds me of being one of those early readers to the Twilight series. It's the same kind of compulsive reading (at least, it was for me), wherein you stay up late to keep at it, want to talk to everyone you know about it, and find yourself being the only nerd brave enough (for the next 8 months, at least—until the first movie trailer hits) to pick it up. And if you liked THAT (Twilight) series, and can get past a potential virgin experience (pun intended) in reading a bit of erotica, well, I can't imagine you not liking this one. All in all, I'm glad this bit of summer fluff made its way into my stack of reads for 2012. Love it or hate it, it's a book (series) the country can't stop whispering about. Now the fun comes in anticipating when that whisper becomes a roar ... ...more

title: Fifty Shades Darker        (Fifty Shades, #2)
author: James, E.L.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: (continuing where I left off with my  of Fifty Shades of Grey)...I finished the first book in this series as my plane landed at O'Hare during a (continuing where I left off with my  of Fifty Shades of Grey)...I finished the first book in this series as my plane landed at O'Hare during a rain storm...I had a feeling I was going to get stranded solo at the airport for the night (which I did) and recall thinking, "Well, if this is night is going to suck as much as I expect it to, might as well have Anastasia and Christian Grey to keep me company". I snatched it up from a bookstore minutes away from shutting down for the night (at midnight no less), then spent the three hours in a US Airways customer service line letting myself get lost in its plot. So, you see, I feel a bit of a unique bond with these books. If for the sole reason that they were a HUGE welcome distraction to what was the most miserable travel scenario of my life.I'll say of the three books in the series, this was my favorite. With a title as such and all its talk of sex, I thought, "Oh great, what am I getting myself into with this...how is this going even DARKER in the bedroom" but it's more a reference to the main character's past and what you learn about it in Book 2 than anything. And that past for Christian Grey includes a childhood that could have him swapping stories with Dexter (another series that's more macabre but equally likable for that very reason that you can't help but root for the guy) That plot twist right there is where the intrigue in this book came for me (screw all the sex scenes--pun intended). I suddenly found myself wondering if this girl could get this guy to give up his shady sexual preferences for her more innocuous ways. If he could ever understand that, just because he was born to the person he was and grew up the way he did, that didn't make him the monster he imagined himself to be.It may be a classic bait-and-hook chick lit storyline but sure enough, it snagged me enough to keep reading. Onto Book 3.... Other thoughts:• There's a scene in this book I really love, wherein the characters attend a masked charity ball, and I think it's just because, I mean, who WOULDN'T love an evening out like that? Can't wait to see how that plays out in the movie. • By about this time, I became fixated on "casting" the roles for Anastasia and Christian based on learning that the series would head for the big screen. And good heavens, if Henry Cavill isn't the perfect Christian Grey, well, let's just say I'm going to be really disappointed in the Hollywood types who fail to cast him for the role: http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0147147/ (it's all about the hair and that rugged face...mmmmm) ...more

title: Fifty Shades of Grey        (Fifty Shades, #1)
author: James, E.L.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ohhh you guys...file this one under curiosity killed the cat. There I stood at a book/magazine kiosk at the Phoenix airport, having finished my last rOhhh you guys...file this one under curiosity killed the cat. There I stood at a book/magazine kiosk at the Phoenix airport, having finished my last read with three hours of travel time still in front of me. It was this series, a handful of Dean Koontz and/or Sophie Kinsella paperbacks, and the Hunger Games on the stand. Those were my only options to choose from. So, you see, it's like I didn't have a choice in picking this one from the stack! In truth, I'd been wondering for a few weeks what all the buzz was about over the 50 Shades trilogy so I bit the bullet and bought the first book, thinking it would be awful and I wouldn't get through it but at least I'd know what everyone was whispering about (and as I did so, I found myself wondering if I should have shielded my eyes from the clerk as I handed over my debit card). And yes, not gonna lie...by far THE most smutty reading I've personally embarked upon, but hey, I don't jump into erotica all that often (nor do I imagine three-fourths of the readers who've blushed their way through this series) so it was, let's say, a bit out of my comfort zone in certain passages. But here's what surprised me about 50 Shades—about mid-way through the book, I started actually caring a bit about the characters. Sure I still had to plow through all its sex scenes (and learn a lot about a lifestyle that neither myself or the protagonist, Anastasia Steele, was all that keen on exploring), but damn it all if, by the end, I wasn't hooked enough to want to know what happens to these two next.I am greatly amused at the way this book and its successors have become the pop culture touchpoint of the summer. I'm annoyed (is that the right word?) at those who laugh and say it's just "mommy porn" because, now that I've read it, I can't say I necessarily agree with them (maybe a smidge but that's not what hooked me enough to keep reading books 2 and 3). And because there are those who want to criticize how the series started as Twilight fan fiction, all I have to say is, had you not TOLD me that was the case, I wouldn't have picked up on the comparisons. Thankful enough, there are no vampires or werewolves to be found here. The likeness (for me) stopped at a gorgeous guy falling for a gangly girl (and the unlikeliness of it all, but come on, that's a storyline that's been played out for decades. Sixteen Candles, anyone?). Oh, and no, the writing isn't great, but, again, if you're the open-minded type that enjoys a good yarn and can put literary judgment aside for a hot minute, it's no worse than Twilight's prose. (Though, good grief, if I had a dollar for every time EL James referenced Ana's "inner goddess" I'd have my car loan paid off in full). I headed online and read a handful of s and commentary about the series and found that I liked/agreed with this article best (not to mention the "Ellen reads the audio book" bit is hilarious): http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/05...Hold your judgment until you read it, I say..and if you find you have the willpower to stop at the first book, well, you're a stronger woman than moi. ...more

review: If you're ever looking for an author who is smart with her words and creates characters with verve, Anne Tyler is a wonderful go-to recommendation.UnfIf you're ever looking for an author who is smart with her words and creates characters with verve, Anne Tyler is a wonderful go-to recommendation.Unfortunately, I just wouldn't recommend starting with this latest of hers. I found myself disappointed with "The Beginner's Goodbye," a quick read that follows its narrator, Aaron**, as he mourns the freak passing of his wife, Dorothy (she was killed by a tree falling on their house—while he was in it). Aaron finds himself haunted by her (figuratively and, for him at least, literally, in ghost form) and the central plot of the book revolves around his desire to make peace with their relationship (its quirks and unusual dynamics) and to finally let her go. Not sad I read this, just, not really moved enough to recommend it to anyone either.*** If you're looking for a great Anne Tyler read, try "Back When We Were Grown Ups". Love those characters...much more, in fact, than I loved these. **Confession, this wisp of a novel is already so hazy in my memory, I had to look up the main characters' names as I'd forgotten them just a few weeks post-read! ***To be clear, for the record, I still love Anne Tyler. We just can't consider every at-plate to be a hit out of the ballpark, right? ...more

review: I'm debating whether this was ultimately a three- or four-star read for me. So much of the first half felt like a small struggle to get through. And wI'm debating whether this was ultimately a three- or four-star read for me. So much of the first half felt like a small struggle to get through. And while the second half moved more quickly (particularly the last 40 pages), I still failed to say I loved it (neither the storyline nor how it was written). Of course, given the subject material, I should have expected this. War reads are always hard for me, particularly when they involve the haze of ongoing war we've been through over the past 15 years. Plop morally confused characters into a battlefront in an unspecified Muslim country (Iraq? Afghanistan?) and suddenly I'm melding whatever storyline is in front of me with whatever other pop culture touchpoint (be it movie, novel or magazine article) I've read on the subject since college.That sounds terribly politically incorrect (and I'm sorry for that) but I doubt I'm the only one who's war-weary (both of the actual subject and of its treatment in the media.)So, right, why then did I pick up this book? (One that centers on a 15-year-old Muslim boy whose family is killed in an errant military attack and who shares a bond with the American soldier who saved his life?)I suppose because I'd heard such great things about it. And I've read s of many who enjoyed it, despite (or perhaps because of) its heavy subject material. I just felt a pit in my stomach for so much of it — one that most definitely did not go away with the book's break-neck conclusion. Still trying to decide if I saw its ending coming .... ...more

review: A totally unique reading experience, one that does not disappoint. In Eowyn Ivey’s debut novel, a couple in the 1920s move to the Alaskan frontiner toA totally unique reading experience, one that does not disappoint. In Eowyn Ivey’s debut novel, a couple in the 1920s move to the Alaskan frontiner to escape their inability to have a family. On a snowy evening, Jack and Mabel build themselves a snow child and the young girl who enters their lives shortly after keeps you wondering what is real and what is fairy tale. What I loved most about this book is the wonderful scene-setting Ivey creates for the reader. It was as though you could truly FEEL the isolation of the Alaskan wilderness and yet, at the same time, its remarkable beauty (I particularly loved the scenes when it would snow). Would love to visit that state some day. As for the plot of the book, well, Ivey leaves it up to you to decide the fate of Faina (the snow child). It's a maddening finale, but brilliant at the same time because you can't stop thinking about it. I finished this and immediately gave my copy to a friend to borrow, just so I could have someone to talk to about it. Likely to be one of my fave reads of 2012. ...more

title: Bringing Up Bébé: One American Mother Discovers the Wisdom of French Parenting
author: Druckerman, Pamela*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've purposefully shied away from so many parenting books on the bookstore shelves these days. It seems like most of those geared toward pregnancy putI've purposefully shied away from so many parenting books on the bookstore shelves these days. It seems like most of those geared toward pregnancy put you in a mild panic about all the things that could go wrong. And the rest? They induce a sense of fear, guilt and inferiority that, book lover though I am, I don't want to gravitate toward as I enjoy this stress-free pregnancy of mine. BUT...I'd heard a lot of discussion about this particular book and I have to say, if it ends up being the ONLY book on parenting I read in the lead-up to my child's birth this fall, I'm better off for having made the choice. For some quick background, the author is an American who finds herself living with her British husband in Paris at the time of their daughter's birth. Experiencing motherhood herself, Druckerman witnesses firsthand the differences in how the French families around her are raising their children and the ways in which she's drawn to the modern-day, American style of parenting she's most familiar with.But that's the thing—this modern version of American parenting? ATTACHMENT parenting, as they call it? It's the antithesis of the way the French do it and, I believe, the way Americans USED to parent, 30 to 40 years ago. (In short, I think it's all a bit nutty). I borrowed a library copy of this book but intend to purchase my own, as I dog-earred so many pages (a guilty habit of mine!) that I want to  it again in full at my own leisure. Some wonderful parenting concepts explored inside the book, a favorite being this idea known as The Pause, or letting your infant child lay in his/her crib for 5-10 minutes and fuss before stepping in to see if there is a wet diaper or empty belly as the root cause of the problem. As the French have learned (and Druckerman provides research to support), infants need to teach themselves to fall back asleep—it's a learning process. But because Americans are so quick to jump in and intervene, it's a key reason why they set their children up to be unable to sleep through the night at 8, 9 or 10 months old.Other major takeaways touch on the emphasis the French put on establishing a "cadre" or framework of discipline and responsibility for their children; the importance of manners (it's not just please and thank you but hello and goodbye for the French); instilling a child's independence (ie, not hovering over them on the playground) and teaching them how to behave at the dinner table, all the while eating food that vastly trumps our "chicken tenders friendly" U.S. kids' menus. Some may balk at Druckerman's writing or the book's subject material, but I couldn't help but fall madly in love with these concepts. I've grown SO accustomed to seeing American children be the center of their parents' universe (constantly interrupting them in conversations, engaging their parents in their meltdowns at the dinner table) that it was a refreshing change of course to read about a culture where THAT kind of behavior is abnormal. A culture unafraid to teach its children patience ("You must teach your children frustration" is a French parenting maxim that I whole-heartedly endorse). How little of that is happening in America these days. And, as a result, not only do we have a nation of ill-behaved kids, but one for which overstressed parents are paying the price.I am so determined not to join that rat race style of parenting — and so this is a book I intend to come back and consult in the years to come. ...more

review: "The Alchemist" is one of those books you either really love or really hate. Count me in the love category.....of course, this may have something to d"The Alchemist" is one of those books you either really love or really hate. Count me in the love category.....of course, this may have something to do with listening to the audio version as read by the brilliant Jeremy Irons. The unique voices he gave each character made this inspirational fable all the more powerful (and really helped pass the time I spent painting my son’s big boy bedroom!).If you DON’T love “The Alchemist” it might have something to do with the fact you’ve given up on whatever dream(s) you once had. Or maybe, you’ve suppressed them so long all the allegories Paulo Coelho makes are lost on you as a bunch of New Age nonsense.Not me. Chasing an artistic passion in the form of writing fiction feels very much like my personal treasure, as if all the jobs and creative pursuits I've had over the years (much like Santiago with his shepherding and crystal keeping) have led me here today. And so it was, with every kernel of wisdom shared by Coelho's characters, I found a way to apply them to my own personal journey ..which is no doubt why this book resonated with me so much and will stick with me long into the future.While much has been written about this book and I hesitate sharing what can easily be Googled, for my own personal bookkeeping ;) here are a few quotes to remember (and a link to inspire):”When you want something, all the universe conspires in helping you to achieve it.” (if you’ve been around long enough and really believe in this, you know it to be true)“It’s the possibility of having a dream come true that makes life interesting.” (Isn’t it though? Not keeping up with the Jones, I’ll tell you that much)“Love never keeps a man from pursuing his destiny.” (this one made me tear up a bit, thinking about how supportive my husband has ALWAYS been of my creative aspirations, be it running my own photo business or working toward writing and publishing a novel)“The secret of life, though, is to fall seven times and to get up eight.” (as I field rejections to the novel I’ve written so far, keeping this in mind is CRUCIAL…)“Remember that wherever your heart is, there you will find your treasure.” “At a certain point in our lives, we lose control of what’s happening to us, and our lives become controlled by fate. That’s the world’s greatest lie.” 10 Powerful Life Lessons from The Alchemist ...more

review: Here I thought I was getting myself into a memoir that might read as funny as the Diane Keaton I love onscreen! Instead, "Then Again" is Keaton's mashHere I thought I was getting myself into a memoir that might read as funny as the Diane Keaton I love onscreen! Instead, "Then Again" is Keaton's mash-up of her life story (with entries as diverse as battling an eating disorder to dating Al Pacino) intermixed with chapters devoted to her mother, Dorothy Hall. I was conflicted while reading because Diane uses Dorothy's journals——unread by Diane until her death-—to share so much of her mother's stories. Some of the entries felt so private and raw and while, on the one hand, I appreciated what Diane was trying to do with preserving (or, better yet, justifying) her mother's life story, another part of me wondered what Dorothy would think to know so many strangers were reading about private pains in areas of her life such as her marriage and sense of worth. Add to all that Diane's detailed recounting of Dorothy's last days with Alzhemier's disease (an illness I'm uncomfortably familiar with, having watched my own maternal grandmother wither away from it) and I don't know...I just had a hard time with this one. Probably explains why I had to force myself to pick it up on more than one occasion.(Note: The best part of the book for me was Diane's love for Woody and Annie Hall. What a great film that was...) ...more

review: I don't  *every* book I read with my (now 8 yo) son on GR, but this one I wanted to make an exception for because it is truly EXCELLENT. Dean anI don't  *every* book I read with my (now 8 yo) son on GR, but this one I wanted to make an exception for because it is truly EXCELLENT. Dean and I loved Hugo's story and the illustrations added a magical twist. We spent a lot of time in between chapters talking about Paris, and transportation of the past (the novel being set in a French train station) and the era of early movies (which feature so prominently in the narrative). It was the perfect meld of great storytelling with interesting elements of history. Selfishly, as the parent reading this book aloud, I loved the pacing and the length of the chapters. Each was *just* long enough to hold our attention (translation: he didn't get bored and I didn't need a glass of water to keep reading!). I'm so glad his grandmother gifted him this book for Xmas in 2020! [Related: We watched the film after we finished and it's good—the cast is stellar—but it was too long and took too many liberties with the plot for us to love it to the same degree as the book.]...more

title: The Fault in Our Stars
author: Green, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I hold in high regard any book that can make me cry. Maybe because such occasions are so rare, the novels that bring tears to my eyes stick out in memI hold in high regard any book that can make me cry. Maybe because such occasions are so rare, the novels that bring tears to my eyes stick out in memory more than most.I have a feeling "The Fault in Our Stars" will be one of those titles. This is an honest, real, and raw look at cancer. Made all the more punch-in-the-gut because it's a book about teens with cancer. Yet it's the talent of an author like John Green who can find humor and an uplifting message through cancer's stages of grief. As my author idol Markus Zusak says on its back cover: "You laugh, you cry, and then you come back for more." In short, I didn't want to put it down."The Fault in Our Stars" is the story of 16-year-old Hazel, a young teen handed the fate of terminal cancer. She's been outliving her odds thanks to a new test drug, but her sharp wit is shaped by the reality she carries around that death is imminent. While attending a local cancer support group, she meets Augustus Waters (oh Gus...I adored your character so much, even if your philosophical look at life may have been a bit advanced for your 17 years) and it's his entry into her life that changes everything.To say much more would give away what readers should discover for themselves about what makes this latest novel of Green's so great. All I can say is I loved it from start to finish and am having a hard time giving these characters up. Without question, no matter the genre (as he's identified as a young adult author), John Green is one of the best writers being published today. A few other thoughts:• It was surreal to read about characters in a setting (Indianapolis) so close to home. At one point, Hazel makes a sarcastic remark about a street in the city (Grandview) that one of my dear friends lives on! It bothered me a bit to see Indianapolis painted in the harsh light of Hazel's eyes, but I reminded myself she's a teenager (and what teen likes the town they grew up in?) I feel better (having followed John for some time on Twitter at @realjohngreen) knowing the author's opinions of the city where he also lives (and I love) are much closer aligned to my own! • The lines that gave the book its name (pg. 111): "Were she better or you sicker, then the stars would not be so terribly crossed, but it is the nature of stars to cross, and never was Shakespeare more wrong than when he had Cassius note, "The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars/But in ourselves."Bits of dialog I loved and want to remember: "I'm in love with you, and I'm not in the business of denying myself the simple pleasure of saying true things.""Oh, I wouldn't mind, Hazel Grace. It would be a privilege to have my heart broken by you.""What am I at war with? My cancer. And what is my cancer? My cancer is me. The tumors are made of me. They're made of me as surely as my brain and my heart are made of me. It is a civil war, with a predetermined winner." "I missed the future ... I would probably never again see the ocean from thirty thousand feet above, so far up that you can't make out the waves or any boats, so that the ocean is a great and endless monolith. I could imagine it. I could remember it. But I couldn't see it again, and it occurred to me that the voracious ambition of humans is never sated by dreams coming true, because there is always the thought that everything might be done better and again." ...more

review: A few things hampered my attention span for this book:1) I read it over too great a length of time. Sometimes, you just need to go for it with a book, and this felt like one of them. Picking it up and starting it and restarting it gave me such a disjointed experience that it really impeded with my take-aways from the book.2) I was really hoping this would be a book I could read through and think, "This would be a great read to give a friend/family member not yet sold on the idea of Christianity". But I felt like the way Strobel wrote the book, one had to already have a solid understanding of the Gospels to grasp all the points he and the experts he interviews make throughout the text. I'm never a fan of an author assuming that one has done all his homework before picking up a book like this so I found that to be an area where there was room for improvement.3) This pregnancy of mine means trying to read a book that has a lot of "meat-and-potatoes" commentary (some of this was pretty heavy stuff...good, but heavy) came at an inopportune time. I guess, too, when you already believe that Jesus Christ is your Savior, you find yourself reading these case studies and thinking, "But I already knew that in my heart to be true..." ...more

title: Destiny of the Republic: A Tale of Madness, Medicine and the Murder of a President
author: Millard, Candice
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are only a handful of non-fiction reads that stick out in my mind from the past few years (Henrietta Lacks and Unbroken rise to the top). I'm adThere are only a handful of non-fiction reads that stick out in my mind from the past few years (Henrietta Lacks and Unbroken rise to the top). I'm adding "Destiny of the Republic" to that list as well. Trying to explain this book to friends, it seems like such an obscure premise to get worked up about: the assassination of a long-ago president whose time in office was so short, it was but a blip on most Americans' radars. And yet, to read this, you discover what a *fascinating* and supremely intelligent man Garfield was. Not only that, you can't help but be fascinated by the era in which this happened — 20 years before the turn of the century, a time of great change and yet a few years away from some of the life-changing inventions and scientific developments that would have saved this president's life.For those unfamiliar, Garfield was only months into his presidency when a crazed gunman by the name of Charles Guiteau felt called by God to shoot him. The incident happened in a train station, in a day and age when the president walked around with no security (at the time, the president had open calling hours for the public at the White House—three hours, every day. Could you imagine!?) While the gun shot was not life-threatening, what did put Garfield in mortal danger was the number of doctors who began poking and prodding for the bullet from the train station floor. It was these men who would introduce an infection into his system that would go on to (ever so painfully and slowly) claim his life. The way Millard weaves in the stories of other famous men of this era whose inventions and discoveries could have saved Garfield (in particular, Alexander Graham Bell, who worked feverishly to create a machine that would be the precursor to the x-ray to find the bullet and Joseph Lister, whose theories on sterile surgery were a few years' shy of adoption in the U.S.) is captivating. I hugely admire Millard's attention to detail and her thorough research in writing this and how well she made a work of non-fiction read like a suspenseful fictional thriller (even the passages about the politics of the era were fascinating — for instance, Garfield never campaigned for the presidency — he simply gave such a rousing speech on the convention floor that he became the overwhelming favorite politician for the post!). It's a wonderful book and so I hope its arcane subject material won't keep readers away. Elsewise, they'll miss this fascinating look at a slim but important chapter in American history. ...more

title: The End of the Affair
author: Greene, Graham
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Can I just say nobody writes novels this way anymore? In a way, I kept distracting myself from the plot of this Graham Greene novel (my first of his) Can I just say nobody writes novels this way anymore? In a way, I kept distracting myself from the plot of this Graham Greene novel (my first of his) because I kept rhapsodizing (particularly to my husband, a Greene fan) about the man's eloquent and finely tuned writing style. My copy was an old edition from the library (1950s) and a previous reader had done me the favor of underlining some of its finest lines. Consider this: "Sometimes I get tired of trying to convince him that I love him and shall love him forever. He pounces on my words like a barrister and twists them. I know he is afraid of that desert which would be around him if our love were to end, but he can’t realize that I feel exactly the same. What he says aloud, I say to myself silently and write it here."Or this: “Eternity is said not to be an extension of time but an absence of time and sometimes it seemed to me that her abandonment touched that strange mathematical point of endlessness, a point with no width, occupying no space.”Like I said, no one today writes a gut-wrenching love story (or, depending how you view this book, anti-love story) with passages like these, right? In short summary, The End of the Affair follows the tumultuous love affair between Bendix (the narrator) and Sarah (whose husband, Henry, is both a friend, confidant and enemy of Bendix's). The time period is World War II — the London Blitz — and shortly thereafter. When Sarah mysteriously breaks off the relationship, Bendix hires a (quirky) private eye to follow her. Its within the pages of her journal (stolen for him) that Bendix discovers the promise Sarah made to God that brought an end to their affair.Sadly, I feel I knew a bit too much about this book's Big Reveal. It's why I purposely shied away from giving too much of it away here in my own  (though, if you read much more about the book, the plot point I'm referring to (a good one at that)is probably given away by many other ers). I loved this book for the way it was written, for the questions its characters posed (even though I often didn't agree with them), and for the refreshing break it represented as a classic showing up in my more contemporary, go-to line-up of Good Reads....more

title: The Orphan Master's Son
author: Johnson, Adam
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **Received an advanced copy of this book as a winner in Good Reads' First Read contest**Oh this book. It's SO hard to read. So so hard. Because you ca**Received an advanced copy of this book as a winner in Good Reads' First Read contest**Oh this book. It's SO hard to read. So so hard. Because you cannot believe what you are reading has any basis in reality. And yet, when you realize the extensive research Adam Johnson has put into it (including his own trip to North Korea), you realize there is so much that *could* be true it frightens you to think where that line of fiction and authenticity blurs. "The Orphan Master's Son" follows the life of Pak Jun Do, a boy who grew up in a North Korean orphanage ran by his father (his mother, a singer, was "stolen" by the government to Pyongyang when he was a kid). From the orphanage to the tunnels he worked along the DMZ (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demilita...), on to working as a kidnapper of Japanese citizens (yep, that happened: http://tinyurl.com/78ec3pj) and later, a radio receiver on a fishing boat interpreting signals of enemy ships, the young Do becomes the Korean citizen whose live provides a glimpse into the shock and awe of growing up in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPKR). The book is divided into two parts: the first focusing on Do's life before getting sent to a prison camp. The second, on his life after his time in prison, impersonating the evil Commander Ga. Do has fallen in love with Ga's wife, the national actress Sun Moon, and will risk his life to save her and her children from the hands of Kim Jong Il. While the plot of the book seems far-fetched (the second half especially), the more you learn about North Korea, the more you ponder, "Well, actually that COULD happen." (In the book, an American rower is kidnapped by the DPKR...a plotline that reminded me of the kidnappings of Euna Lee and Laura Ling in 2009). It's hard to describe the way I felt reading this book because it was so violent——the lives of its characters so harrowing——that, at many points, I set it down thinking, "I don't know if I can keep reading this." And yet, I kept coming back because I felt I owed it to Jun Do and Commander Buc and Sun Moon. But also, maybe, to the millions of North Koreans whose own stories cannot be told under a government allowing only one kind of narrative to be shared with its citizens——a form of propaganda leaving so many in the dark. A fascinating read and timely given the December death of Kim Jong Il and questions of how the transition of power to his son will affect the country. I have read several interviews with Johnson now and admire his years-long commitment to sharing this story. It's humbling to realize, in this modern era, a life like this exists for an entire country not even aware of everything (from music to art to religion to pets, for cryin' out loud) it's missing....more

title: The 7 Habits of Highly Effective People: Powerful Lessons in Personal Change
author: Covey, Stephen R.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are certain books for which you take notes as you read along. 7 Habits is one of them. In my case, a COPIOUS amount of notes (12 pages worth, I There are certain books for which you take notes as you read along. 7 Habits is one of them. In my case, a COPIOUS amount of notes (12 pages worth, I think?) There were just that many nuggets of knowledge I wanted not just to gloss over but hold on to for the months and years—lifetime, really—to come.In a nutshell, Stephen Covey boils down the 7 basic principles he views as the principle-centered, character-based building blocks of a productive life. Here's a run-down of the habits and some of the gems I put down in my beloved Moleskin—a peek at why you need to pick up this book with your best New Year's intentions for 2012.Habit 1: Be Proactive• Proactive people focus their efforts on their Circle of Influence. Reactive people tend to focus their energies on their Circle of Concern.• The Circle of Concern is filled with "haves" (If I had more obedient kids...If I had a degree...If I could just have more time to myself) and the Circle of Influence is filled with "be"s (I can be more patient...I can be wise..I can be loving). It's the CHARACTER FOCUS.• Any time we think the problem is "out there," that thought is the problem. WE EMPOWER WHAT'S OUT THERE TO CONTROL US.Habit 2: Begin with the End in Mind• Think about what you want the end of your life to look like—what you want people to say about you—and use that as the criteria upon which you examine all else in your life.• We are either the 2nd creation of our own proactive design or the 2nd creation of other people's agendas, or circumstances, or past habits.Habit 3: Put 1st Things 1st• Effective people aren't problem-minded; they are opportunity-minded...work on feeding opportunities and starving problems.• You have to decide what your highest priorities are and have the courage to say "no" to other things. And the way you do it is by having a bigger "yes" burning inside. You are always saying "no" to something.• Work on building the emotional bank account with people (understand the individual, attend to the little things, keep commitments, clarify expectations)Habit 4: Think Win/Win• Aim to see life as a cooperative, not competitive arena, one in which your frame of mind is constantly seeking the mutual benefit in all human interactions.Habit 5: Seek to Understand, Then Be Understood• Don't project your own "home movies" onto someone else's behavior. Seek to listen to others empathetically.• Next to physical survival, the greatest need is psychological—to be understood, affirmed, validated, appreciated.Habit 6: Synergize• When working with others (spouse, employee, friend) synergize and reach solutions that both can feel good about. Honor one another's differences and what each of you can bring to the table.***I LOVE THIS THOUGHT***• The more authentic you become, the more genuine in your expression, particularly regarding personal experiences—even self-doubts—the more people can relate to your expression and the safer it makes them feel to express themselves. That expression in turn feeds back on the other's spirit, and genuine creative empathy takes place, producing new insights and learnings and a sense of excitement and adventure that keeps the process going.Habit 7: Sharpen the Saw• Routinely  your four dimensions: physical (exercise, nutrition, stress mgt.), mental (reading, writing, planning), social/emotional (service, empathy, synergy, friendships) and spiritual (study, meditation)• Covey's Daily Private Victory: Spend 1 hour a day in some combination of physical/spiritual/mental dimensions in a way to keep yourself centered• What do we reflect to others about themselves? How much does that reflection influence their lives?• The things you do in 1 dimension have a positive impact on other dimensions because they are inter-related. Physical health affects mental health; spiritual health affects social/emotional health. Improving in 1 dimension increases your ability in other dimensions.And finally, a quote from George Bernard Shaw that Covey shares and that I love more than just about anything else I've read this year:"This is the true joy in life—that being used for a purpose recognized by yourself as a mighty one. That being a force of nature, instead of a feverish, selfish little clod of ailments and grievances complaining that the world will not devote itself to making you happy. I am of the opinion that my life belongs to the whole community and as long as I live it is my privilege to do for it whatever I can. I want to be thoroughly used up when I die. For the harder I work the more I live. I rejoice in life for its own sake. Life is no brief candle to me. It's a sort of splendid torch which I've got to hold up for the moment and I want to make it burn as brightly as possibly before handing it on to future generations." ...more

author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 4/20/12: I've really slacked over here on Good Reads (fueled in part these past few months by this announcement: http://tinyurl.com/dxnko55) but I'm p4/20/12: I've really slacked over here on Good Reads (fueled in part these past few months by this announcement: http://tinyurl.com/dxnko55) but I'm playing catch-up now.... I enjoyed 11/22/63 more than I thought I would. I mean, it's about a guy who TIME TRAVELS into the past. Talk about surreal....But King has a fantastic way with this novel of not only making you ponder the perceived consequences of such a mode of transportation but also, to make you wonder if you could be the one brave enough to take a path back in time like our protagonist, Jake Epping, a newly divorced high school English teacher whose main mission is to stop Lee Harvey Oswald from killing JFK. This is a beast of a book——800-plus pages——and yet, given or take 75 pages or so, it read like a dime store paperback, so engrossed do you get in the subject material. I personally felt the storyline of Epping tracking Oswald and the president (because the "time portal" dumps him into the year 1958, Jake has to adopt an alias and live in the past until that fateful day in 1963 comes along) was boosted greatly by how Jake passes his time in the past—most notably his serendipitous chance to fall in love. Overall, a pleasurable read and one that was a surprising addition to King's otherwise grisly collection of titles. I'd recommend this to many people but especially for those leery of King because they fear nothing he writes cannot be gory or gruesome.Two tidbits to note:• King actually got the idea for this back back in 1971, but felt he didn't have the time to do the proper research (or the right skills as an author) to pull it off.• King himself hopes this a book that reaches readers outside of his typical fan base: "This might be a book where we really have a chance to get an audience who's not my ordinary audience. Instead of people who read horror stories, people who read The Help or People of the Book might like this book".Would make a great vacation/travel read if you're willing to haul it around (this is one case where an e-reader WOULD come in handy!) ...more

title: The Lover's Dictionary
author: Levithan, David*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Such a simple concept, really....write a book about love from the perspective of the alphabet. Each letter standing in for some piece of the puzzle ofSuch a simple concept, really....write a book about love from the perspective of the alphabet. Each letter standing in for some piece of the puzzle of one's relationship, all 26 coming together like a string charting its beginning, middle and end. It sounds simple until you read Levithan's take on the idea. Then you realize it's so brilliant it's probably a wise thing no one attempted it before him because no way could it be as good. There's not much to say here other than the reason I loved this book as much as I did was for how much I felt I knew these "characters" (supposedly Levithan himself and a long-time girlfriend) through this clever act of non-linear storytelling...I'll let you all be your own judge on this fast read and instead end with some of my favorite entries:blemish, n.The slight acne scars. The penny-sized, penny-shaped birthmark right above your knee. The dot below your shoulder that must have been from when you had chicken pox in the third grade. The scratch on your neck—did I do that? This brief transcript of moments, written on the body, is so deeply satisfying to read. commonplace, adj.It swings both ways, really. I'll see your hat on the table and I'll feel such longing for you, even if you're only in the other room. If I know you aren't looking, I'll hold the green wool up to my face, inhale that echo of your shampoo and the cold air from outside. But then I'll walk into the bathroom and find you've forgotten to put the cap back on the toothpaste again, and it will be this splinter that I just keep stepping on.indelible, adj.That first night, you took your finger and pointed to the top of my head, then traced a line between my eyes, down my nose, over my lips, my chin, my neck, to the center of my chest. It was so surprising, I knew I would never mimic it. That one gesture would be yours forever. posterity, n.I try not to think about us growing old together, mostly because I try not to think about growing old at all. Both things—the years passing, the years together—are too enormous to contemplate. But one morning, I gave in. You were asleep, and I imagined you older and older. Your hair graying, your skin folded and creased, your breath catching. And I found myself thinking: If this continues, if this goes on, then when I die, your memories of me will be my greatest accomplishment. Your memories will be my most lasting impression. ...more

title: The Sense of an Ending
author: Barnes, Julian
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: After finishing "The Sense of an Ending," I was struck how much I wanted to immediately sit down and re-read it all over again. It's one of *those* boAfter finishing "The Sense of an Ending," I was struck how much I wanted to immediately sit down and re-read it all over again. It's one of *those* books...the kind that drops hints and foreshadows moments that only make sense in its final pages. This is the first book of Barnes' I've picked up, namely because I'd heard such good things upon it being named winner of the 2011 Man Booker Prize. At 150 pages, it's short enough to be a novella and a title that can be read in a single sitting (as I did on one long plane flight earlier this week).The plot centers on an aging Brit, Tony Webster, who finds himself ruminating on his youth only to have certain people from it——an old classmate (Adrian) and one of his first loves (Veronica)——come rushing back into the present. When they do, he realizes his memories of the time they had together may not be the reality shared by all.I hopped online and delved into bits of commentary on this one because it's a book that begs to be talked about with others, particularly its you-never-see-it-coming-and-is-still-hard-to-make-sense-of-ending. (I love how Barnes mines this double entendre with title and plot..and oh my, how I had to  that equation of Adrian's a dozen times before it even vaguely made sense to me!)Here's what Barnes had to say to NPR about the book: "It's a book about 'memory and time.' What time does to memory and what memory does to time, how they interact. And it's also about what happens to someone in later years when they discover that some of the certainties they've always relied on, certainties in their mind and memory .... are beginning to be undermined." A fascinating concept, then....how our history is not always what we make of it and how we do (and don't) rely on others to help shape it. A few passages I loved from Tony and found worthy of marking down:"I still read a lot of history and of course I've followed all the official history that's happened in my own lifetime—the fall of Communism, Mrs. Thatcher, 9/11, global warming–with the normal mixture of fear, anxiety and cautious optimism. But I've never felt the same about it—I've never quite trusted it—as I do the events in Greece or Rome, or the British Empire, or the Russian Revolution. Perhaps I just feel safer with the history that's been more or less agreed upon. Or perhaps it's that same paradox again: the history that happens underneath our noses ought to be the clearest, and yet it's the most deliquescent.""It strikes me that this may be one of the differences between youth and age: when we are young, we invent different futures for ourselves; when we are old, we invent different pasts for others.""But time...how time first grounds us and then confounds us. We thought we were being mature when we were only being safe. We imagined we were being responsible but were only being cowardly. What we called realism turned out to be a way of avoiding things rather than facing them. Time...give us enough time and our best-supported decisions will seem wobbly, our certainties whimsical.""When you're young—when I was young—you want your emotions to be like the ones you read about in books. You want them to overturn your life, create and define a new reality. Later, I think, you want them to do something milder, something more practical: you want them to support your life as it is and has become. You want them to tell you that things are OK. And is there anything wrong with that?"...more

title: Your Baby in Pictures: The New Parents' Guide to Photographing Your Baby's First Year
author: Koh, Me Ra
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I’d be lying if I said reading this book didn’t inspire me on creative ways to capture my own future children. BUT, there’s no news on that front as oI’d be lying if I said reading this book didn’t inspire me on creative ways to capture my own future children. BUT, there’s no news on that front as of now (but thanks to those who’ve been asking ;) haha). Really, picking this up was a quick read for me and a good time to do so as I’m hopeful that I’ll be photographing more babies in 2012 for past clients and dear friends. While I am not a studio specializing in newborn photography, I like the idea of offering intimiate, at home sessions for friends and past clients who are transitioning from their wedding with me to starting a family.So, on that note, there was a lot for me to love about Me Ra Koh’s “Your Baby in Pictures”. I’ve been a fan of Me Ra’s for years now, as her blog was one of the first I discovered who actually taught me something about aperture and shutter speed and ISO. That easy-to-understand knowledge resurfaces 10-fold in this book, which, admittedly, a lot of it was old news to me (each “recipe” she posts for poses comes with an explainer on achieving the look with a point-and-shoot and a DSLR) but it’d be wonderful reading for new parents who are not professional photographers.Where I felt like I benefited most in reading was learning more about moments parents may want to have captured by their photographer, from tiny hands and yawns, to the power of a simple image like dad touching nose to nose with his new baby. While I’m tempted to give my copy away to a mom who could use the tutorials, I’m holding on to it because of the posing inspiration alone!Me Ra also shares a lot of little tips on getting your baby to best cooperate with you for a shoot, cranking the heat up so they’re not fussy, shooting early in the day as that’s when babies tend to be more active (I never knew that!), to considering shooting in a parking lot instead of a park (“I resist shooting at the paper because sunlight reflecting off green grass can give babies a weird tint”).If you’ve photographed your fair share of babies, you likely already know most of this, but I still feel like I learned a lot and this book would make for a great Christmas or shower gift for an expecting parent or a mama or papa whose baby is under a year old. Too many moments they shouldn’t have to miss!...more

title: Is Everyone Hanging Out Without Me?
author: Kaling, Mindy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Apparently the unspoken rules of celebrity writing in 2011 are as follows: Establish a framework of poking fun at your short-comings. Talk about what Apparently the unspoken rules of celebrity writing in 2011 are as follows: Establish a framework of poking fun at your short-comings. Talk about what a geek you were growing up. Mention your weight struggles. Elaborate on the trajectory of your comedy writing career. Be a woman.Yes, yes...Mindy's book and Tina's book ARE similar in those ways. And yet, different enough to leave it at that (and sorry, nothing is going to trump Bossypants ... not even Mindy). What I did enjoy about Kaling's collection of essays is how laid-back they were in tone, as if they were stories shared over drinks with friends. Or, better yet, pints of ice cream divvied up between roommies, the kind which Kaling writes so loving of during her early writing days in NYC. For me, there were never any true laugh out LOUD moments in IEHOWM, but just an overall appreciation for Kaling's wit. (And speaking of appreciation, I did learn Kaling was the writer behind the hilarious Office episode in which Michael Scott "grills" his foot on the Foreman. I mean, come on, that might be the greatest episode of that series of all time, so, really...thank you Mindy for that!) A few fave passages:From "I Am Not an Athlete": If my parents have any soft spot, it is for books, and I knew that the best way to get out of chores, or sports, or talking to elderly relatives on the phone was by holding up a book and saying, "But I'm just enjoying Little House on the Prairie so much!" (Confession: Honest to God, as a kid I did this EXACT SAME THING and (no joke) WITH THAT EXACT SAME SERIES!) From "Is Everyone Hanging Out Without Me?": Mindy writes about her freshmen "posse" -- a group of girls she clung to who were so inseparable they literally had an acronym for themselves (JLMP). It's a funny yet touching essay on how we grow up and grow out of friendships. "One friend with whom you have a lot in common is better than three with whom you struggle to find things to talk about." (If that's not one of the biggest lessons of your late teens/20s, I don't know what is).The entire chapter of "Best Friends Rights & Responsibilities", which was full of oh-so-true girlfriend rules like, "I should never be overly harsh when something doesn't look good on you, because I know you are fragile about this and so am I. I will employ the gentle, vague expression "I'm not crazy about that on you," which should mean to you "Holy shit, take that off, that looks terrible!"Other nuggets worth remembering: Mindy has major comedy crushes on Will Ferrell and Amy Poehler. Steve Carrell doesn't talk shit about anyone. Ever. (which annoys the hell out of Mindy). And she's a fan of men with chest hair ("When I see a perfectly hairless, tanned guy onscreen, I am forced to recall the Chihuahua.") HA! A fun one that's worth picking up for a casual holiday read (be it on the beach or your grandma's sofa with a turkey hangover). ...more

title: Just Kids
author: Smith, Patti*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Even though I had several friends praise Patti Smith's much-heralded memoir at the time of its release, it slipped past me for years. Until I read herEven though I had several friends praise Patti Smith's much-heralded memoir at the time of its release, it slipped past me for years. Until I read her recent New Yorker tribute  to the great playwright Sam Shepard. It was phenomenally written and reminded me again why I owed it to myself to pick up "Just Kids."Over the Labor Day holiday, I had a few long stretches of car rides to indulge myself in reading this, coupled with an hour or two where I slipped away purposefully from the pool just so I could live a little longer in the pages of '70s era NYC with Patti and her creative soulmate, Robert Mapplethorpe. I finished it early the next morning, forgoing my usual 5 a.m. writing routine because I wanted to see these two through the end, then tearing up at the final scenes of Robert's death from AIDS, captured so powerfully by Patti.To say this book is outstanding is an understatement. Even if you know nothing about Patti Smith or Robert Mapplethorpe as artists (and I knew very little myself), you will find a compelling story that will keep you reading—ESPECIALLY if yours is a creative soul. It was fascinating to read about the era Patti and Robert came of age in NYC, hobknobbing with some of the most legendary artists of that time (Joplin, Hendrix, Warhol's Factory crew, to name a few). As Tom Carson wrote in his 2010 NYT , "'Just Kids' is the most spellbinding and diverting portrait of funky-but-chic New York in the late ’60s and early ’70s that any alumnus has committed to print."I couldn't agree more. It's a book that'll stick with me for a long time, if not forever. A few lines I want to remember:(a childhood memory of Patti's, her first visit to an art museum, a scene that resonated with my own childhood experiences of coming face to face with art created by the greats, Picasso in particular): "In the following year my father took us on a rare excursion to the Museum of Art in Philadelphia. My parents worked very hard, and taking four children on a bus to Philadelphia was exhausting and expensive. It was the only such outing we made as a family, marking the first time I came face-to-face with art. I felt a sense of physical identification with the long, languorous Modiglianis; was moved by the elegantly still subjects of Argent and Thomas Eskins; dazzled by the light that emanated from the Impressionists. But it was the work in the hall devoted to Picasso, from his harlequins to Cubism, that pierced me the most. His brutal confidence took my breath away." "In my low periods, I wondered what was the point of creating art. For whom? Are we animating God? Are we talking to ourselves? And what was the ultimate goal? To have one's wor caged in art's great zoos—the Modern, the Met, the Louvre?"This line, because I had to stop and read it twice, written as beautifully as it was: "You could feel a vibration in the air, a sense of hastening. It had started with the moon, inaccessible poem that it was. Now men had walked upon it, rubber treads on a pearl of the gods. Perhaps it was an awareness of time passing, the last summer of the decade. Sometimes I just wanted to raise my hands and stop. But stop what? Maybe just growing up." Of living in the Hotel Chelsea (the chapters she detailed of this experience were among my favorite): "So many had written, conversed, and convulsed in these Victorian dollhouse rooms. So many skirts had swished these worn marble stairs. So many transient souls had espoused, made a mark, and succumbed here. I sniffed out their spirits as I silently scurried from floor to floor, longing for discourse with a gone procession of smoking caterpillars." In the final chapter, Patti writes of one of her last encounters with Robert (ohhh this scene got me!): "There was no one present save his nurse and she left us to ourselves. I stood by his bed and took his hand. We stayed like that for a long time, not saying anything. Suddenly he looked up and said, 'Patti, did art get us?' I looked away, not really wanting to think about it. 'I don't know, Robert ...I don't know.' Perhaps it did, but no one could regret that. Only a fool would regret being had by art; or a saint."...more

title: The Art of Fielding
author: Harbach, Chad*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Is there a way to give a book six stars on here? Because I'd keep adding them if I could, I loved "The Art of Fielding" that much. Truly, I didn't wanIs there a way to give a book six stars on here? Because I'd keep adding them if I could, I loved "The Art of Fielding" that much. Truly, I didn't want this novel to come to an end. Last night, I put the book down with 30 pages left. I honestly thought, "I want one more day to delve into this world." But then, 20 minutes later, there I was, picking it back up to reach its final page (and discovering a wholy satisfying resolution, which rarely happens for me with most books).This is one of those novels where the characters don't just live on the page. They live WITH you. Here I was, book nowhere in sight, and yet I still found myself at points of my day, wondering what Henry and Schwartz and Pella were doing at that very moment. The hype for this one? TOTALLY WORTH IT. And to say "The Art of Fielding" is a book about baseball is to say "Friday Night Lights" is a TV show about football. Yes, yes, the book's protagonist is short stop (and baseball phenom) Henry Skrimshander. Yes, there are plenty of scenes that involve the diamond and batting cages (and a central plot point that involves Henry's first-ever errant throw). But it's SO much more than that so don't let all the sports talk dissuade you from reading it. Because wrapped up in all those baseball analogies are the universal themes of suffering and failure and that age-old question of "What am I doing with my life?" It may be a stretch for some, but for me, this is as good as it gets in earning that rare title of Great American Novel.Finally, my love for "Art" may very well be jaded but that's only because I've learned so much about how it came to be. Chad Harbach spent NINE years laboring over this, his first-ever novel. NINE YEARS. Only to go from a poor guy with debt collectors after him to landing a book contract worth more than $600,000. If you've made it this far in this  (god bless you), and if you love "Art", you owe it to yourself to find a way to read the Vanity Fair story that details how this book came to be. Find it either in the October 2011 issue of Vanity Fair or online in this eBook (which, it may be $2 but it's worth the investment if you have an e-reader. It's a fascinating piece: http://www.vanityfair.com/magazine/eb...)...more

author: Diffenbaugh, Vanessa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've come across a few articles/books as of late about the role reading can play in making a person more empathic. I had those studies in mind as I reI've come across a few articles/books as of late about the role reading can play in making a person more empathic. I had those studies in mind as I read Vanessa Diffenbaugh's "The Language of Flowers." Chiefly because, without empathy, I would have failed to fully appreciate its narrator, Victoria Jones.A foster kid, Jones is a tough girl who blew her chance at being adopted and so, for 18 years, has bounced from group home to group home with the worst of attitudes. The book follows her life upon being emancipated (all the while weaving in her back story and her days living with Elizabeth, the closest foster parent she's ever had to a real mother). She finds a job with a local florist and, soon enough, her gift of deciphering the Victorian message of flowers becomes her ticket to a new life."Language" was a novel that captivated me for a couple reasons. I'd never heard about the Victorian language of flowers (that, for instance, asters mean patience and yellow roses infidelity) and so, as a plot construct, this alone kept me reading. But what also grabbed me was how personal this novel was to its author. Diffenbaugh herself is a foster mother. She is passionate about the importance of foster children landing on their feet upon gaining their independence. (So much so she's created a non-profit, the Camellia Network (camellia meaning "my destiny is in your hands"), to raise money for its cause.)What was most difficult about Diffenbaugh's book was exercising that empathy muscle while reading it. Victoria makes so many decisions—many of them so rash and so hurtful—that those of us who have grown up sheltered and loved could never understand her reasoning behind them. And so it takes the reminder of "You don't know what it's like to be in her shoes" to forgive her those actions (and the hurt she inflicts) over the course of "Language"'s 300-plus pages.Overall, an engrossing read (especially for a debut novel); likely to remain one of my favorites of the year.Knowing Hollywood (reportedly) has come calling for this film, I couldn't help envisioning a cast I'd love to see take this one on:Victoria: Evan Rachel Wood (the actress has to be younger and have that ability to play tough and vulnerable at the same time--I think she'd nail it)Elizabeth: Naomi Watts and Catherine: Anne Heche (I kept picturing these sisters as blonde--I think both these actresses would be amazing in either of these roles)Grant: Andrew Garfield (because I'd LOVE to see what he'd do with the subtleties of the character...plus, I just love him as an actor and want to see him in everything-haha)And finally, a passage I loved--so much so I stopped to read it twice (pg. 279):"When you work with flowers, everything about you changes. The set of your jaw loosens. Your eyes glaze with focus. Your fingers manipulate the flowers with a gentle respect that makes it impossible to believe you are capable of violence...."I knew the girl of whom she was speaking. It was the same one I'd glimpsed in the dressing room mirror with Elizabeth, after nearly a year in her home. Perhaps that girl had survived somewhere within me after all, preserved like a dried flower, fragile and sweet....more

author: Morgenstern, Erin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What was missing that kept this book from becoming a four or five-star  for me? A book that, earlier this month, had all of the publishing worldWhat was missing that kept this book from becoming a four or five-star  for me? A book that, earlier this month, had all of the publishing world and plenty of folks I know through social media in a tizzy over its release? I've mulled it over now that I'm finished and here are what I view as the strengths and weaknesses of Erin Morgenstern's "The Night Circus"...(I think if I just could have given more weight to the strengths I'd have fallen harder for it):STRENGTHS• The lavish settings—Without question, readers will want to join visitors buying a ticket for this circus, one complete with a dizzying array of features—from a Labyrinth and tents made of ice to a wishing tree and rides where the sky reveals your dreams. It's a gorgeous backdrop to Morgenstern's plot and the author walks that fine line between wonderment and the tedium of too much detail. Should they turn this novel into a film (and surely they will), I can't help thinking it'll be the most challenging to adapt (from a special effects perspective) since Harry Potter. But, on that note, also the most beautiful (I can't wait to see how they construct Celia's color-changing dresses!)• Wonderful primary characters—It's hard not to be drawn in by Celia and Marco's story, one that begins with their being trained to challenge one another as powerful illusionists (but not knowing that their opponent is each other). What they create together is the basis of the book but, better than that, are the handful of scenes in which their love takes hold. Specifically, one scene I loved so much I wish I had wrote it, involving Marco sweeping Celia away in an illusion where they're floating upon a sea of ink in a boat made of books. Beautiful imagery, for sure....and an ideal romantic gesture for this bibliophile. WEAKNESSES• For all the build-up of the challenge, its reveal felt like an anti-climatic let-down. • The back-and-forth of the storytelling—The book switches every few chapters from the present to the past. Normally, this is a fine construct for me, but the problem here is the dates being so close together (for instance, the "future" being, say, 1902, and the past, only a year or two prior). That made the narrative read disjointedly at certain spots. It also weakened the story for me, making me lose interest for portions of the first half (and thus being a big reason why this book didn't pull me in hook, line and sinker)• A bad habit of introducing characters only to reintroduce them (sometimes with 50-75 pgs. inbetween) using a nickname, or first name only..making it confusing to remember which character you're reading about (in particular, it took me a good 200 pgs to remember who was the engineer and who was the clock maker!) ...more

title: The Marriage Plot
author: Eugenides, Jeffrey
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Two of the last books I've read have plopped characters into the world of academia. In "The Art of Fielding," those characters were stripped down, livTwo of the last books I've read have plopped characters into the world of academia. In "The Art of Fielding," those characters were stripped down, living in a small Midwestern town at a small liberal arts college and the writing? It felt...less complicated but in a way that still felt true. With "The Marriage Plot" (particularly the first 100 pages), that world was Brown University and those characters pretentious in that fashion of "I'm earning an Ivy League degree so I'm going to speak in a way belittling of anyone below my IQ". Or was that just me who felt that way? Suffice it to say, "Art" was my favorite book of the year. "The Marriage Plot", still a worthy read, not so much. Here were three central characters and a plot built around how their lives intertwine: Madeleine, the WASP-y English major and Audrey Hepburn type pined for by Mitchell, the Midwesterner with a sharp analytical mind and penchant for philosophy. Problem being Madeleine's heart belongs to Leonard, a brilliant, tobacco-chewing loner whose struggles with manic depression dominate most of this book's 400-plus pages.Maybe part of my problem was I spent too much of "The Marriage Plot" trying to analyze who was who from Eugenides' own life (fueled by this article I read a few weeks' back on how Eugenides may have wrote himself as Mitchell and Leonard a loose version of one of his literary contemporaries, David Foster Wallace (http://nymag.com/arts/books/features/...)). Whatever it was, I just never connected to "The Marriage Plot" the way I wanted to and while one part of me loved the ending, another, greater part of me felt it trite after the heaviness that preceded it.Overall, I still give this novel high marks and praise as one of the year's best. The way Eugenides can craft a sentence can, on occasion, force you to pause and re-read a line not once, not twice, but, in some cases, three times. And, for me, it wasn't even the big "sweeping" passages that invoked this, but the small sentences Eugenides' used to construct his characters. One of my favorites? This description of Madeleine's mother: "Phylida's hair was where her power resided. It was expensively set into a smooth dome, like a band shell for the presentation of that long-running act, her face." Yeah, I know...I wish I could write like that too. ...more

review: I wasn't a huge fan of Perrotta's last book (which I ed on here a few years back), but thought, "OK, this is the guy who gave us Election and LiI wasn't a huge fan of Perrotta's last book (which I ed on here a few years back), but thought, "OK, this is the guy who gave us Election and Little Children...I owe it to him to give this newest of his a go").Somehow, I found myself disappointed yet again. It's not as though the story is a difficult or unpleasant read (well, the plot—which shares what happens to a community that has suddenly lost dozens of its residents to a Rapture-like mass disappearance—IS fairly depressing), but Perrotta's writing is strong throughout...so no, that wasn't the problem. I think it was just...this book didn't command my attention. A quick enough read, I finished it during a day of traveling. And only a week or two removed from its final pages, I couldn't even tell you the NAMES of the characters (I'm horrible with names though). Even the details of the plot and what happens to the main people in it are starting to get fuzzy to me.And maybe that's why I didn't love this book more. It just didn't stick with me. It didn't really TRY to stick with me. It just...well, for me, it just kind of was....more
