title: Rules of Civility
author: Towles, Amor*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Do yourself a favor and pour a dirty martini or a nice gin and tonic for sipping while you read "Rules of Civility"...otherwise, you're going to spendDo yourself a favor and pour a dirty martini or a nice gin and tonic for sipping while you read "Rules of Civility"...otherwise, you're going to spend the entierty of its 300-plus pages wishing you had said drink in hand.This book had reasons aplenty to pull me in: I'm a nut for all things featuring my favorite time period (1920s-1930s.) Make it a version of that history set in glittering Manhattan, toss in a few fine blue bloods, Art Deco accents and one hell of a finely crafted heroine and this book becomes a top read for me in 2011."Rules" starts a bit slow. The true character of the narrator, Katy Kontent, is buried under the first half of the novel's slower storyline, one that follows Katy and her boardinghouse roomie Eve (shout out to the wholesome independent Hoosier!) through a blustery courtship of sorts with the elusive Tinker Grey. It's a freak turn of events that leaves Katy as the odd girl out, pondering what she needs to do with her life to move on and out of the funk she finds herself in.Enter Wallace Wolcott. Once Katy begins to succumb to the charms of her sweet friend (platonic though those charms may be), Amor Towles finds a real rhythm to his novel, a cadence to Katy's witty prose, and I...well, I couldn't put the book down for the final 150 pages!From Katy's rise from a Wall Street secretarial pool to the publishing offices of Conde Naste, to her later dealings with Tinker and his "(fairy) godmother", Anne Grandyn, I was hooked. I wanted to BE Katy Kontent, so full of spunk and independence and a bright future ahead ——virtues uncommon to many women of her era.Quite a few lines to love in this one too. Here were a few that made me admire the talent of author Amor Towles (not that I didn't already admire a guy who, at 46, with a successful Wall Street job, publishes his first novel—doing a bang-up job of telling a woman's perspective no less):(pg. 128): "Uncompromising purpose and the search for eternal truth have an unquestionable sex appeal for the young and high-minded; but when a person loses the ability to take pleasure in the mundane—in the cigarette on the stoop or the gingersnap in the bath—she has probably put herself in unnecessary danger. What my father was trying to tell me, as he neared the conclusion of his own course, was that this risk should not be treated lightly: One must be prepared to fight for one's simple pleasures and to defend them against elegance and erudition and all manner of glamourous enticements."(pg. 215): "Watch out for boys who think they owe you something. They'll drive you the craziest."(pg. 239): (I just loved this scene)—Quit worrying about the coat. It'll find me. That's why I leave my wallet in the pocket in the first place. Now what's the fuss?—It's a long story.—Leviticus long? Or Deuteronomy long?—Old Testament long.—Don't say another word.(pg. 259): "Most people have more needs than wants. That's why they live the lives they do. But the world is run by those whose wants outstrip their needs."(pg. 297): (from Dicky, a character I loved): "If only we fell in love with people who were perfect for us, he said, then there wouldn't be so much fuss about love in the first place."...more

title: Bright's Passage
author: Ritter, Josh*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "Bright's Passage" is a beautifully told narrative (one that reads quickly as more a short story than a novel) about a World War I veteran from West V"Bright's Passage" is a beautifully told narrative (one that reads quickly as more a short story than a novel) about a World War I veteran from West Virginia named Henry Bright whose wife has died in childbirth, leaving him in charge of caring for his infant son. When his cabin goes up in flames, Bright must make his way through Appalachian wilderness in search of salvation, escaping a father-in-law with a vendetta and entrusting his fate to a guardian angel who's followed him home from the trenches of France. It's not a perfect novel——the resolution Henry reaches with the angel in its final pages felt rushed and incomplete—but at the same time, it's a hell of a debut and I found it hard to believe this is Josh's first foray into fiction writing.I have the utmost respect for an artist who can merge this seamlessly from being an incredibly talented musician to being such a promising novelist whose talent shines most in his lyrical prose. Artist crush officially cemented :) ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++True story: Josh Ritter is my favorite musical artist. From a musicphile like myself, that's a BIG statement. But Josh's storytelling in his lyrics has always made me love him so much.Consider a few of his songs if you've never heard of him:The Curse (about a mummy and the woman who keeps him -- it's odd, yes, but SO beautiful): http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KXBI2_...Girl in the War (THIS SONG. Seriously, every time I hear it, cells inside me just melt): http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bdobff...(And seriously, GO BUY HIS MUSIC ALREADY). So, yeah, I have a creative crush on Mr. Ritter. I've been dying to see him again live (the one time I have I was smitten). I was hesitant to read his novel because I'm always dubious about multi-talented people. But everywhere I've looked, Bright's Passage has gotten fabulous s.Am I surprised? Maybe a little. But not to hear the good things. Just at myself. I mean, this is Josh. Why should I suspect anything less than magic from him, regardless of the outlet? Can't wait to jump in. ...more

title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower
author: Chbosky, Stephen
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There's enough young adult material out there focused on the overtread topics of teen angst and how to fit in that to pick up another feels like jumpiThere's enough young adult material out there focused on the overtread topics of teen angst and how to fit in that to pick up another feels like jumping in to one big cliché. And yet, these stereotypes fade away at the hand of a talented author like Chbosky.For starters, he opts for a unique way of sharing this particular story: The novel's main character, Charlie, recounts his freshmen year in high school through a series of letters to a friend. For an added twist, we never do discover who said "friend" is. We just know, among the reasons Charlie likes this individual, is because he/she "didn't try to sleep with that person at that party even though you could have." Along with this friend, we learn more about Charlie's life——how he's a wallflower, a listener encouraged by teachers to "participate" more——in friendships, in school, in life. He's befriended by Patrick and Samantha, step siblings of the too-cool-for-high-school variety (and I mean that in the best way possible). He struggles to be friends with his siblings, a brother who's a collegiate football star and a sister who's tolerating an abusive boyfriend. And all this time, he's struggling with his own demons, alluding over and over again to an inner struggle to hold depression at bay.What I loved most about this book is Charlie's voice——it's vulnerable and frank and so naively smart. One of my favorite scenes is when his teacher and mentor, Bill, tells him as much ("Charlie, do you know how smart you are?"...So finally I just said, "You're the best teacher I've ever had.") Without giving too much away, "Wallflower" plods along in a seemingly predictable way as Charlie copes with his only friends prepping to graduate as he must stay behind for his sophomore year. And yet, there in the last few chapters of the book, Chbosky ends things with a shocking reveal that explains so so much about why Charlie is as damaged as he is. And makes this book a hard one to forget.This is one of those young adult reads that doesn't read like a young adult novel. That might be the highest compliment I can give it. Favorite scene in the book (and my guess is many others who've read it will agree with me):Sam tapped her hand on the steering wheel. Patrick held his hand outside the car and made air waves. And I just sat between them. After the song finished, I said something. "I feel infinite."And Sam and Patrick looked at me like I said the greatest thing they ever heard. Because the song was that great and because we all really paid attention to it. Five minutes of a lifetime were truly spent, and we felt young in a good way. And of course this is gonna be a movie. If you're curious about casting (which, I'd read it first THEN peek), here ya go: http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1659337/...more

title: Cutting for Stone
author: Verghese, Abraham*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm confident the only reason this book hasn't been read by more people is because of its impressive (translation: intimidating) size (it weighs in atI'm confident the only reason this book hasn't been read by more people is because of its impressive (translation: intimidating) size (it weighs in at 658 pages). Because for anyone who dares to dive in, "Cutting for Stone" makes for compulsive reading.Admittedly, there are a few weak spots to this book, namely one too many coincidental meet-ups among its characters. One of these fate encounters ( between the protagonist and the woman who's haunted him his entire life) nearly turned me sour on "Cutting for Stone". But it is on this scene —— which takes place with less than 100 pages remaining —— that the entire plot of the book will pivot, allowing you to come to the end with a level of respect reserved for only a truly great book (and author). Yes this is a novel about brothers, Marion and Shiva, twins born of an unholy union between a British surgeon and his beautiful brave surgical assistant (who just so happens to be an Indian nun). But it's so much more than that —— about a love for one's native land (Ethiopia in this case), a love for one's calling (and a calling for surgery runs deep in the Stone family) and the ways we all love and live and let go in our lives.So often while reading this I was in awe of Verghese's ability to easily incorporate his own medical prowess and personal history into the book, providing an overload of rich surgical details that never once bogged down the storyline. The talent and drive to become not only a doctor but to then study writing at the Iowa Writer's Workshop? Then pen several award-winning books, including this one? Literally, it blows me away. For that reason alone, I want to meet Verghese, shake his hand and tell him how much I admire him and this book. How it will most definitely stick at the top of my favorites for a long time to come. Stick this one out, all you die-hard book lovers. I promise it's worth it —— for the story, the language, the medical details and so much more.A favorite key line (one of many, but others would give away too many plot details):"The key to your happiness is to own your slippers, own who you are, own how you look, own your family, own the talents you have and the ones you don't. If you keep saying your slippers aren't yours, then you'll die searching, you'll die bitter, always feeling you were promised more. Not only our actions, but also our omissions, become our destiny." (Ghosh, pg. 351--I love how this line comes back to Marion on pg. 657)And one final note for those who may not look it up: The title of the book? Comes from the Hippocratic Oath--I loved the way Verghese reveals that fact to us on the final page of his acknowledgments: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hippocra......more
